reviews.review: Patricia Keenan . My husband and I had a lovely day walking to Alfama.The walk was lovely the views amazing the atmosphere was nice .Lovely restaurants and cafes.

Fado. If you would like to experience real Fado as I was kept being told, head for Alfama where you will find little eateries you will here them and follow the beautiful sounds to where you would like to sit and eat while taking in Fado.
Nice quarter. Old quarter in Lisbon with beautiful small places were we can have outstanding experiences. Love it.

The Original Lisboa. This neighborhood survived the 1755 earthquake. It was constructed to confuse invaders trying to get to Castelo São Jorge, and the confusion continues. But don't worry just head up or down the hill and enjoy the architecture and ambiance.
Lots of good restaurants and several excellent Fado venues.

the best area for Fado. Very old and nice area, the only survived after earthquake 1755. Old and narrow streets. Authentic. But no need to go to this "fake castle", because there is nothing left from original castle, and for the nice view you don't need to pay!

The heart of Lisbon and a must to visit.. This small welcoming district is the most authentic and atmospheric of all Lisbon. We rented an apartment in Alfama and spent a lot of times exploring the neighborhood, walking the alleys (called beco), up and downs stairs, taking pictures, just savoring the experience and the scenery, so unique and authentic. Make sure you stop by the Miradouro de Santa Luzia at the end of the afternoon for a fabulous view and a drink, it quickly became our ''tradition'' while in beautiful Lisbon. A great area to stay while visiting Lisbon, or to spend the day if staying elsewhere. It is truly unique area and a must-see, we absolutely LOVED it!
The old section. Wandering down from Castello Jorge there are many small Businesses. The miradoura looks out over the lower sections.

Don''t miss this fascinating district. Full of character, the narrow cobbled streets are best navigated on foot. Some prohibit vehicles. Get the local bus to the castle gates, visit this site and enjoy the fabulous views over Lisbon. From here it's downhill all the way so take time to explore Alfama's many bars, restaurants and quaint shops. This is Lisbon's heart and soul.
Worth the effort!. Took a walking tour of Alfama. Learned a lot that we would not have discovered on our own. Recommended!

Best place to stay in Lisboa. Authentic neighbourhood, with a lot of local people and local shops, restaurants and miraduros (viewpoints). You need to be in good shape and physically quite fit to be able to go up and down every and each time when you move from Alfama, or just take the famous tram 28 or 12. But this area is quite silent at nights, secure and can be also animated. You’ll find a lot of tourists over there, but come on, sometimes we are all tourists!!! No problem with this. I liked also the composition of the streets, the colours before the sung went down, or early in the morning. Try to find hidden cafes, courtyards, bistros, just to feel the fantastic atmosphere of this area.

Old, Old , Old area but nice. This is certainly one of the most historic areas and has great charm but then all the tourists in the world know this and flock there. It is fine for a visit...via taxi up...very steep and narrow streets, but a walking tour would be challenging. Do not take the tram unless you are prepared to deal with the pickpocket thieves. St George's Castle is worth a visit there... the restaurant is not bad...and the views are some of best

Lots to experience in Alfama. A great neighbourhood in Lisbon. Very authentic and close to everything. Although we stayed in an apartment through VRBO, it seems to be a great place for backpackers - many hostels. A great little spot across from Museo del Fado had inexpensive sandwiches and drinks. Near the river you get a lovely breeze in the evening which made it more comfortable than other parts of the city. Also good for souvenir shopping -- good selection and less expensive than other areas.
Great views of Lisbon from the Alfama. Use the trolley or taxi to get up to the Alfama - the streets are hilly. It's a small area, so very easy to see everything and do a little shopping
Great walking tour. Great area to take a walking tour. Many different shops and narrow walkways past many local residents homes. Recommend taking a few hours to tour the area by foot.

Awesome. Spend the day walking around the Alfama district when visiting Lisbon. This part of town is very old and you can easily spend the day walking around all of the cool alleyways. There are some cool shops that have some local artists if you want to try and stay away from more of the touristy type shopping spots. Try to catch some fado music when visiting if you can. This part of town is a must see for any visitor to Lisbon.
Walking through Alfama. This place is very picturesque and cool. I enjoyed it very much. The only part of Lisbon that survived the earthquake
Narrow streets up and down. Old part of Lisbon, steep narrow streets, old buildings that look like they are falling apart and small cafes. Inexpensive beer.

Love Alfama!. We did not see or do all that we could have while here but we loved the narrow streets and felt the charm, had a great lunch and enjoyed some of the historical sites. We need to go back to see what we missed! (St. Anthony's church, the Miradouro de Santa Luzia (Santa Luzia Viewpoint, the Lisbon Castle and so much more!!

Don't take a walking tour- stay for a few days. Instead of just walking through here in a large group tour we rented a room for a few nights. It is a great way to really apprpreciate the Alfama. We visited local cafe and bars.

Twisting Streets and Friendly People. We recently spent four nights in the Alfama Barrio and loved every minute of it. There are a scattering of shops, restaurants, taverns and Fado venues. It is hilly and easy to get lost so try to keep your bearings.

Older neighboorhood in town. This is the oldest neighborhood and you will find many must-see sights there as for example the castle of Saint George or the Cathedral of Lisbon which is the city's oldest church. It has wonderful, narrow streets where you can get lost easily and where it is absolutely beautiful to stroll around.

Historic District!. This is one of the historic districts of the city where you can enjoy by foot. There are many restaurants and bars in the area, so it is perfect for enjoying dinner and an after dinner as well. I also recommend it for daytime to take advantage of the panoramic pictures. Definitely worth visiting!

You haven't see Lisbon until you saw Alfama!. Along with Bairo Alto, Alfama is the very heart of Lisbon! Narrow ,colorful, vibrant streets, little dining places with traditional food (code fish is everywhere!), great wine and fado (Portuguese music), all good things in one place!

A really authentic neighborhood. We loved the tiny streets and little, hole-in-the wall restaurants. So much atmosphere! It gives a totally different impression than some of the main tourist areas of Lisbon. And it's only a 15-min walk or short metro ride from the tourist "center". I'd definitely choose this neighborhood as our "home base" again. We used an Air B&B flat. There are not a lot of actual hotels here.
Sandeman's Alfama walking tour. A really interesting 2 1/2 hour tour with our knowledgable guide Ricardo gave an insight into this unique part of a great city

more about the journey than the end. So some people say there is nothing to do when you get up into Alfama, but it is all about the journey there and back.You can walk up the hill through all the narrow streets or get the 28 tram from the city centre, yes it is a bit of a tourist thing to do, but worth it. The 28 tram will drop you off at Miradouro de Santa Luzia on the top of the Alfama district. You can use one of the little blue pre paid cards to get on the tram, very useful if your in the City for a day or three.Miradouro de Santa Luzia is like a large open sq where the trams stop and has a small coffee shop, but is like the gateway left and right to the rest of the area.You can go down next to the old wall and into the very old part of the town where houses still have no bathroom or toilet or go up and out to the castle area and the Pantheon or the Se Cathedral.Either way is full of great sights and picture ops.Walk in and out around all the passages and icons it is well worth it, you will find gems everywhere.

Great Historic Neighborhood. Loved this neighborhood. Lots of history and chance to see a historic neighborhood that is still very vibrant. My husband had to have a haircut at a cutting-edge barbershop! And the best thing is that we took the famous trolley which was a lot of fun!

Beautiful. It is amazing and enchanting to get lost in the old pebbled streets of Alfama.But beware, it is not suitcase friendly, those pebbles on the floor will make the wheels of your suitcase cry soooo hard.The architecture is lively and enchanting, planning to come back/live there, definitely.
nothing to see. we had heard so much about it but found nothing. just a walk. there is nothing to see actually. just take tram no 28. it goes along all the interesting sights on hill.
Wednesday night is Fado night in Alfama. Stroll the streets of Alfama and choose one of the many fado bars/restaurants for a truly enjoyable evening.

Get Lost!. It's great to wander aimlessly along the narrow alleyways and stairways of the Alfama district, never knowing what will face you just around the next corner. You'll probably enjoy it more without a guide book! The whole neighbourhood is worth exploring.
Easy to get lost. Its very easy to get lost in the maze of streets in the Alfama district of Lisbon...but that's the fun ogf this district. Just keep heading down!!!

neighborhood to visit. This neighborhood offers curiosities on every street corner, alleys must accept to get lost but keep a plan on you for the directions, enough to spot you. You will find many small shops and stalls as well as some really fun places to restore and relax
a must visit. its one of the best areas to visit....we enjoyed the narrow streets and the decor.... and the many cafes
must see. no guide needed, lots of steps but worth the effort. beautiful views and very interesting tile art at every corner. must see. meutermedia

Nice typical neighborhood. Take a ride up with tram 28, or by foot to take the time to taste the nice ambiance of this pittoresque portuguese neighborhood, with it's tiny Streets and the tram tracks all over the place.. Great place to take " that" tramway pictures like the one on postcards.

A classic Lisbon neighbourhood . Having lived there for a few years in my opinion it changed a lot and for the better. It was one of the few areas in Lisbon not to have been destroyed by the huge earth quake of 1755 and ensuing tsunami. It still has intact its medieval street structure with narrow and winding streets, archways and alleyways. You still can find genuine fado spots alongside trendy cafes.

The hills, the steps, the views are incomparable. We booked an apartment in the Alfama neighborhood of Lisbon and could not be more pleased with our selection. But be prepared to walk up and down stairs and hills. This is an authentic neighborhood, one of the oldest in Lisbon and overlooks the Tagus River. Small, quaint and authentic restaurants are everywhere, many featuring live fado music, the Portuguese version of Spanish flemenco. Our apartment is only a ten-minute walk down the hill to the huge Commercial Plaza that rivals some of Europe's great spaces like San Marco in Venice or the Piazza della SIgnoria in Florence. But remember--this neighborhood requires lots of walking up and down steep grades, because vehicles simply cannot reach many of the houses. Bring comfortable shoes.

Lovely stroll lots to see. Spent almost a whole day strolling around this area. Markets, buildings, views and much more. You can find some cheaper cafes and restaurants in this area, also tourist stores.

Fado is fabulous!. What an amazing area of Lisbon. Tiny little winding streets taking you to tiny little 5-8 table restaurants playing amazing Fado music all night long. Start right in front of the Fado Museum...you will see a tiny entrance way which will lead you winding streets where you can enjoy Ginja liquor and a fabulous authentic Portugal experience!
Part of the Withlocals tour. See my review of the Tour. Silvia included a walk around this old part of the city and was very charming. Highly recommended.
Very cozy area. Alafama is a very cozy area to walk around in on the evening. A lot of Fado restaurants if you are looking for this. This area is fefinitaly worth a visit.

Take a free tour in Alfama. I think it's worth seeing. Take a tour or get a guide to know about what you see. I joined a free walk tour and the guide explained many things about historic and cultural sides. The street art is amazing.

A fantastic place. It is a must to visit Alfarma If you visit Lissabon.
The atmosphere is amazing, s lot of nice restaurants to visit.
A most beautiful view on the top

What a place!!!. Well Alfama is like no other place I've seen before. If your mobility is reduced, or rely on a car to travel, this is certainly not the place for you. Indeed, as our guide told us, the streets were born around the houses. So not only is it on a very steep hill, but it's also full of steps, cobbles, and it is very narrow in places. But you should really, definitely go round and round as the atmosphere in this part of the city is incredible. You close your eyes and you can fell the vibe. The houses are as narrow as the streets so naturally, people extend their habitat in the street. It means that anywhere you go, you share a little time of their lives with them: you know what they eat, you know what clothes they washed, you know what tv programme they watch. It is also a great place to see fados, the real ones, not the commercial ones. Don't miss it!
Real Portuguese Character. I walked around here the day after the Lisbon Marathon, some very pleasant walks around and you can really absorb the culture well.

Narrow old cobbled streets. The history of the city was explained by the Tuk tuk driver who showed us round. The city had to be rebuilt after the 1755 earthquake. Big buildings were built square, but here everyone build their own, totally randomly.

AN ICONIC SUBURB OF LISBON!!. Follow the tram 28, 'travel' with the traditional music in the past, drink eat and walk, visit Castelo Sao Jorge for magnificent pictures, feel with the most of your senses!! i could write too many words for this amazing area of (old) Lisbon but i don't think that it's necessary. just be there and you will have a unique experience!!
Nice view. Nice spot to oversee the Lisbon city. You can also enjoy the view in the old area and alleys on you way up.

Hilly and crowded. I was really keen to visit based on others' reviews so jumped on the 28 tram. Looked out for the charming little streets shown on the postcards but didin't see them- ended up in Graca and walked back through Alfama. Nice market but nothing much else of note. Crowded cobbled streets up a hill. A bit disappointed really

Excellent views over the old town. Every visitor should go to Alfama once. You can walk up, take cheap but crowded tram 28 ( 2,85 euro) or touristic and more expensive the red tourist tram ( about 13 euro) . The last one gives you a full tour. Please mind your purse, if you want to stop at the best point, get out straight after the castle stop. There is a small bar with some tables offering you sun and the best views, You can choose to walk downto the central square by the road, but you can also take the stairs on your left hand after leaving the little square. You will walk directly though Alfama with lots of fado restaurants, bars and some nice little shops.
Wonderful!. The Old part of Lisbon full of winding,narrow streets some very steep. Wander around here at will and enjoy the sometimes run down air of the place.

Get lost!. The best place to get lost in! We took one of the tour buses, then took a tuk tuk as far as they're allowed. Then we walked into the area up tiny steep alleys, opening into small squares, where there are no souvenir shops, no,transport, just portugal at it's most beautiful and colourful.The graffiti has become beautiful wall art. It's sometimes in the most unexpected places. The Alfama has an exquisite shabbyness that's a joy to behold. It's tatty and run down and the walls are dirty - damp? I don't know. Ant the view from the top is spectacular - a multitude of rooftops on all levels, incvluding the long bridge in the background. Just go there!
Beautiful. I liked walking around in this quarter. It's beautiful, ther're a lot of little streets where you can discover some typical shop and restaurant. It's one of my favorite quarter in Lisbon.

Lisbon, the old city tourist style. The Alfama district is known for it's old twisty streets filled with restaurants, souvenirshops or pubs. It is right now a district in which older buildings are vigorously repaired/renovated so expect some hinder.All in all worth visiting now and surely even more in the near future.
Wedding and touring. Quaint and hilly. Fado music around every corner. Taxi drivers do not know streets well and some refuse to drive on narrow streets even when allowed.

Lisbons oldest area. The famous little tram 28 rattles its way through the very narrow streets past some of the best historic sites and viewing areas of this the oldest part of the city. From the area along the waterfront traverse some of the squares and wander up through laneways with washing drying above your heads and wafts of kitchen smells and Fado tunes being sung. It's a steep climb but a reminder of the medieval nature of its beginnings. It's still working class but cafes and restaurants abound to make breathing stops.

Wow!. What a wonderful walk through amazing history. We got ourselves lost but that was all the better because we found interesting nooks and crannies the whole way. Very atmospheric and lots of beautiful tiled houses to see. We found our way back out easily in the end. A wonderful time.

Under renovation. Not the most charming neighborhood of Lisbon, when we visited it was under heavy y reconstruction on its riverside walk so it was nasty to walk around, specially with the stroller.The inside part of the neighborhood it's fine but rather unattractive compared with the rest of the city.
Fascinating Alfama.. Do not miss the Lisbon Walk which includes Alfama district. The walk is arranged by Inside Lisbon who have excellent guides.

Interesting place to wander around. Wear good walking shoes if you are not taking a taxi or electric buggy. Some great street art in the area and plenty of cafes for "a top up". Make sure you trek into the side-streets if you like character.
favourite neighborhood in Lisbon. It is in Alfama where you can feel the old soul of the city, hidden somewhere in between narrow streets filled with music from Fado restaurants.

Interesting area.. We stayed in this area for 4 nights! We did get lost travelling along the cobblestone laneways but that is part of the experience of staying in this area. We enjoyed the atmosphere!

Stay here if you can!. We rented and AirBnB apartment right in Alfama for 4 nights. It was PERFECT! We kept the windows wide open all night long to the sounds of many different Fado singers. We were right along the track for Tram 28 and within 5 minutes of at least 30 different restaurants! The cobblestone streets and maze-like paths are exciting. Just TRY and find something on your map! So much fun and we were able to walk almost everywhere in Lisbon (took the Tram to Belem and the Metro to Sintra)- didn't need a car and the public transportation was cheap! Definitely visit here, but I would highly recommend staying here if possible.

Getting lost for fun. I enjoyed wandering through the streets and alleys climbing up the stairs, poking into nooks and crannies, and small local shops.If you get lost, head downhill and you will come to a major avenue, eventually.

Unique area of Lisbon worth the visit and climb. Many of the buildings in this area of Lisbon were pre-earthquake, and retains the "old-city" feel. Its easy to get lost in this area but as long as you keep going downhill, you will find your way back to the main streets. Many small shops and restaurants dispersed in this hilly area, and near the bottom, many restaurants with fado performances.
Fado. Strolling through the attractive narrow streets is a must in Lisbon. And a dinner (or two) in a Fado restaurant becomes a longterm memory.

A Must See in Lisbon. Alfama is a must see when in Lisbon. Take a few hours and walk the neighborhood but make sure you have a great pair of walking shoes. The streets are cobblestone and often uneven. Enjoy some grilled sardines at one of the many local restaurants but be advised, you will be charged for everything that is put on your table if you eat it. It is customary to put olives, bread, tuna pate, sardine pate, ham, cheese, etc on your table. If you do not eat it, you will not be charged. If you do, the prices can add up. We were charged 2.4€ for a tiny tin of pre-packaged sardine pate plus 4.5€ for the two rolls we put it on. We found this to be the case in every restaurant we ate at in Lisbon. Munch on the olives and add on another 3€ and enjoy the ham, and tack on another 12€.
Great area to walk around. Old and quaint area to explore, with lots of ice cream shops, some antique stores, look out spots and old churches.

Wonderful historic precinct of Lisbon. Wander through a maze of cobbled streets and narrow laneways, discover the old houses and shops, take a view point across the roof tops, church spires and domes, and stop to revive at the many small cafes and restaurants. Absolutely fantastic.
Intriguing different world. An indescribable "city" from the ancient world alive today in a modern city. It must be experienced on foot.

Stunning views, great atmosphere and reasonable restaurants. We visited on the tram and found the place amazing. Would recommend to anyone but do get transport as the walking is difficult the the pavements slippery.

Lovely place to eat and dance. Thi place is best approached on foot or by tram. The tiled streets and footpaths add to the festive atmosphere of cafes, bars and souvenir shops. The lookouts are grand and the food in the area is traditional. We saw a street dance lesson on a platform near the lookout. The traffic is heavy at night but overall is a place worth visiting.
Quaint part of Lisbon. Part of our Gate1 tour leaving the cathedral and going through the narrow winding streets was fantastic. It downhill and not really difficult to walk.
Wow! Gorgeous!. Alfama is a must visit. Beautiful sites, cute and quaint shops, artists paradise. Be prepared for a lot of tourists!

Alfama the oldest district in Lisbon. Eat and ear our fado at O Senhor Fado. From São Jorge Castle to the Fountain del king, passing the ruins of the Roman theater, where you will have the opportunity to visit the Museum of the ruins. You will pass even the imposing Cathedral the oldest in Lisbon, admire the views of the Tagus river in the Portas do Sol and walk through the streets less "touristy" of Alfama.

Quaint part of Lisbon. I loved the suburb of Alfama, its quaint streets, medieval character, the view from the castle, the walk up to the castle.. Just everything.. Ladies.. wear comfortable shoes! Cobble stones everywhere and nothing else...

A month in the Alfama!. Wonderful apartment overlooking the river and the docks where the cruise ships arrive almost daily. Plenty of really good eateries from the posh to the canteen like! Also many little grocers who stay open until midnight run by the ubiquitous Pakistanis and Bangladeshis (so language is not a problem for English speakers). Judging from the noise at night some people live on 4 or 5 hours of sleep a night because it's the centre for Fado. That means most little restaurants have live music most nights and some seem only to come alive after midnight.A reasonably short stroll takes you into the grid of the rebuilt city centre although we find the trek up the hill to the castle area and the Graca much more exciting and revealing. Some bits look as if they have been undisturbed for centuries but in reality the the general feeling is that before long tourism will take over the whole area and it'll become a huge ghetto for cash rich foreigners. But to bring you back down to level visit the flea market on Saturdays and Tuesdays. Lotsa tourists there but also lotsa Portuguese bargaining away like their life depended on getting that fine half pair of used false teeth for under 3 Euros! Graca is just up the hill and has a small town feeling which means the prices are lower and it's best if you have some Portuguese language skills.

Sunset👍😀. See different character plus the view of th water- a Lisbon experience! Many ways to experienced via tram, train, bus, hop on hop off-my least favorite but can be helpful if you time constraints? Walking is one of the best way providing you like walking and it can be strenuous uphill, stairs and it can be lots of steps- that's why it's called city of 7 hills? But take your time try to do it slow savor the environment, history, buildings,tiles , nata here and there
Narrow alley of the past. Go there to spend some time strolling and travelling in old district of Lisbon.A must visit place in Lisbon.
Excellent way to meet the city. . This is a great way to get your bearings in Lisbon on arrival. Pleasant, informative and a great way to gather info on this awesome city.
Portugal on his BEST. Fado, Food, Bacalhau, tipical houses, you have here the amazing confortable and tipical way of the portuguese way of living

Love it but make sure to take good shoes. You could spend hours walking arround stopping in little bars and restaurants. Try white Sangria for a change. You have to be in good physical condition, and comfortable non-slip shoes are the must. Loved the place.

Mitchell. We went on walking guided tour of this area. Guide was very informative about the history of Lisbon and sites we saw during our walk. Enjoyed the tour and the walk. This is a hilly area and you should expect to encounter a number steep climbs up alleyways and steps. Once you get to the top, the view is great.

Excellent view. It's a place where you can go just before the sunset so you can see and enjoy the view when it is not that hot and the sun has not gone down yet. You can enjoy some local food like tapas and have drinks like beer and sangria. After that you can visit Bairro Alto which is just a few steps away for a dinner or a drink.
So much fun to get lost here.. Bring your walking shoes and sense of curiosity. You definitely want to wander beyond the river to really get a sense of Alfama.

Nice place to get lost in!. Very picturesque, with a lot of beautiful buildings, azuleju and cozy interwining streets that will make you loose your trackand then unexpectedly find your way again. The restaurants add to the atmosphere. I give 4, rather than 5, because there are areas than need significant restoration.
Nice, but CROWDED. Went 15 years ago and enjoyed it more. With at least 2 HUGE cruise ships in port it is always super crowded with cruise escapees who seem to be always lost and under foot.

Quaint Historic Neighborhood. Very quaint little neighborhood with interesting history. Our guide told us that it once was an exclusive area that was inhabited by the wealthy Jews (merchants and such). Then they were exiled from the country by King Manuel in 1496. The area was left to the lower class. Currently the residents are comprised of the very old and vacationers renting out high priced refurbished units.We had a lovely moring walk through the quaint narrow streets on the lower portion of the neighborhood. It felt like a step back in time. We thoroughly enjoyed our time here.
A great view of the Lisbon City. Reached Alfama by tram. Take tram number 28 from the city and get down at the alfama centre. Gives a great view of the entire city
Great views.. A lot of walking to do but we'll worth the effort. You will be rewarded with fantastic views over Lisbon. Great sunset from the vantage points

Very Hilly and very historic area of Lisbon. Hills upon hills combined with narrow pathways that hide restaurants and bars in the day but open up for the hustle bustle of the evening. I chose to tour the Alfama area via a tuk tuk so therefore I didn't walk at all...and would highly recommend the tuk tuk route. Lots of vista's and overlooks and beautiful churches to see in this area....again, take the ride through if you don't want to continuously walk up hills....but well worth it...it is indeed a magical place to behold.

Nice neighborhood to hang around. good cozy restaurants, cute little bars. Very homey neighborhood. Did not bother visiting the castle. I've been told it's not worth the admission fee. But waking around and popping into a little cute cafe or sit outside in a cozy neighborhood to eat is good.

Beware of thieves & pickpockets. This area has been rebuilt after an earthquake & hence it's not as historic and atmospheric as other old historic areas in cities like Opporto. There are lots of thieves & pickpockets here. My backpack was hit twice within the hour. So visitors must be very alert & take precautions. Fortunately there's nothing of value in it.
Stay in Alfama if you can. We spent three days here and loved walking around, going to the Fado Museum and eating in the little alley ways. The best place to eat was Atasca Do Poeta
THE OLD WORD CHARM. The oldest place in lisbon with Moorish architecture. A walk throught there is just amazing. Takes about 2 hours and a guided tour is best.

interesting neighborhood. We explored the nooks and crannies of the Alfama after seeing the Castelo de Sao Jorge (we took a taxi to the castle at the top of the Alfama, then walked downhill through the area). The downhill walk along cobblestone streets took us past many interesting old buildings, houses, shops and restaurants along the way. We casually stopped in 2 or 3 places for a beer and a wine before getting lunch at one of the many places near the bottom. Definitely worth a visit!.

Felt like being in a story book :). This is a magical place. You walk around those VERY narrow cobbled stone paths, with old buildings all around, with every turn you take, you will hear Fado being played. I felt like I was walking around inside of a story book :)
Nice place. Alfama is a nice place, the oldest suburb in Lisbon and worth a look! Be sure to wear shoes as it is very hilly!
This is Lisbon. For me, this is Lisbon. Enjoy the ambiance and pop into the restaurants at night for the fado (but not the food).

Quaint, traditional and brilliant architecture. We stayed in Alfama and would really recommend it. There is lots of walking but plenty of places to explore. Would say that viewing the sunrise is a must and for brilliant photos! Lots of small shops and cafes and great to spend a day wandering.
QUIRKY. We went visit the Belmonde Hotel and walked around Alfama. Quirky and fun. A bit out of the way for me if I was staying there.
Poseta lisabonu. All recomendations for Botega de fa~perfect atmosphere,best singers,as guitar players. It is the sence oc Lisboa.

Nice old town . Visited Alfama is the oldest district of Lisbon.. amazing and love the walk through delightful maze of narrow streets, which lead from the Tejo estuary uphill to the castle. There are many little shops and cafe Contained within this ancient district. Be prepared to walk up hills. But many tuk tuk service and trams to go up the hills Many Lisbon’s most historically important buildings including the Se Cathedral, Lisbon Castle, National Pantheon and Saint Anthony’s Church.A must visit when in Lisbon.
The heart of Lisbon. It is a really nice neighborhood to visit, with a lot a small streets and shops/restaurants. It worth do it by walk.
Top of the city. When we got to the Alfama - we were surprised on how many visitors were there to enjoy views and a good seafood in open air.
Excellent tour of Alfama with Ronnie . Ronnie was absolutely brilliant! Extremely knowledgeable and funny. I would definitely recommend this tour to anyone visiting Lisbon!

A must! . This is definitely a must do in Lisbon if you are prepared for a little physical effort. The Alfama is one of the oldest areas of Lisbon and - with its collection of narrow and cute alleys - it is a must see for every tourist. Whilst some of the alleys definitely have a 'tourist trap' feel, it's also easy to discover hidden gems where locals are simply getting on with their lives... which makes it for an authentic and really interesting area to explore. The Alfama is spread on a very steep hill, so be prepared for some sore legs at the end of the day and, if it's a hot day, make sure you have some water with you (or buy it from one of the many cafes). If physical effort is not your thing, you can also catch the famous tram 28; just be mindful of pickpockets.

The true soul of Lisbon. In warrens and narrow alleys, every turn brings surprises. For me being Jewish, I looked for proof we were there and I found it. These buildings are among those that survived intact after the 1755 earthquake.
Quaint . Interesting neighborhood of narrow streets, many restaurants and souvenir shops, great views from above of the city.

Old Norman Cathedral. There is a wonderful old cathedral in the Alfama that features a partly open cloister that is undergoing archaeological excavation.
Absolutely worth the visit
Did not like!. Was supposed to be amazing...? Walked all around castle Jorge to explore Alfama was very disappointed other than a block or 2 the rest was a rundown dirty ghetto very disappointed.

Nice afternoon walk. Wandered around hear all afternoon, easy to get lost, plenty to see and many places to eat and drink.
Lots of hills but worth the effprt

Plenty to do there. Alfama is a very interesting area of Lisbon, possibly a bit less busy than the Barrio (if you expect the Castle area). Going up and down to discover old streets, some fantastic building and restaurants, the area has plenty to offer (the Cathedral, the Panteon, the Roman amphitheater and Museum - gorgeous contemporary building around the Roman ruins-). A must when visiting Lisbon.

When I dream of a nice place, its Alfama. Alfama is an amazing cozy place, even when writing I have this feeling of security and intimacy. Its very genuine with great view of Lisbon and lots of heritage. Restaurants are greta and almost everywhere is amazing, the best way to get there is by Tram 28, make sure to dine in at any of the local shops and visit St. George Castle during the evening as they stay open till 9 I guess.

Beautiful area, great place to start discovering Lisboa. We stayed in Alfama for 4 days and walked into a different direction every morning to enjoy beautiful Lisboa. Alfama has a lot of colour, history and numerous narrow streets to discover. On the square opposite of the Museu de Fado you can have a great breakfast at Alfama's. The little restaurants in the narrow streets are great also.

Can't miss!. Without a doubt you can't go to Lisbon without seeing the Alfama. Take tram 28 for a wild ride through the steep hills full of beautiful and often crumbling old structures. Driving would be insane here and even walking can be dangerous. Single file and stay off the road-tram rails gets you through the area. Lots of hills so be prepared with water.The good news is there is an abundance of history to see here including the Fado restaurants, the churches, monastery, the castle and endless restaurants and tourist shops.Tourist trap? Maybe but it was so much fun we went back.

Lovely colorful part of Lisbon. We visited Alfama with tram nr 28, it was quite a journey with the tram going upwards on narrow streets. Definitely one of the must do's in Lisbon. Alfama is very colorful, just keep wandering through the narrow criss cross streets and get a flavor of the old Lisbon. The different houses, stairways, shops, people (not tourists) leave behind a grand experience unlike anywhere else in Lisbon. it worth spending at least couple of hours over here.

Fantastic location. A place to get lost in. Full of little cobbled streets, great restaurants and Fado everywhere - you can join in or just listen at the door. 5-10 minute walk to Santa Apolonia Station.
My favorite part of the city. The colors of the buildings, the tiny streets, the smell of food. All of that make it worth to visit this neighborhood.

Quirky, cultural neighbourhood. I stayed in this district and so managed to see lots of the area. It is cobbled and steep - you must wear ridged shoes. The miradouro (viewing points) are the must sees. You get architecture at every turn and local food.

Lovely, pictoresque part of the city. Loved walking down the streets in Alfama. Stopped in small restaurants and enjoyed dinner in the late hours. Not busy and crowded at nights at all. Only minus is that my wallet got stolen by a really skillful pick-pocketer, did not feel a thing. So hang on to your belongings everywhere.

Soak up the past . We stayed five days in the Alfama district and we chose this location for the nearby historical monuments. The district takes you back in time with its array of cobbled streets that on each turn take you somewhere wonderful. The views of the city are fabulous as are the many independent trinket shops and restaurants.The tram 28 also passes through this district and takes you through the narrow streets and steep hills. For anyone visiting Lisbon - this would be an ideal location for those who want to see the Lisbon from the days of the Moors and when Portugal once had its vast empire

Fascinating district of Lisbon. The old quarter and steeped in history and character. Full of hidden bars and Fado clubs among the narrow lanes. It was my daughters highlight of the holiday. My advice, go to one of the many walking guides online and book. You will not miss a thing and if you had such a lovely guide as we did the experience will be worth it. We started at the base of the quarter, walked up to Castelo and looped back to our start. A 3 hour tour for 3 people costing 40 euros.

Gorgeous views. What a beautiful part of the city. White buildings Ceramic roofs. Beautiful vistas. In September we had perfect weather. In the evening, on Friday night we went into a small restaurant and were entertained all evening.

Atmospheric!. Wander and get lost in the hilly alleyways and step back in time. Listen to fado and eat grilled fish. While there are tourists this is still a neighborhood so be respectful. Rather empty late at night but felt pretty safe.

Went exploring with my wife. The Alfama is worth the walk and if you are where we stayed its straight up the hill. We enjoyed walking around and seeing the old city - we did not go to the Sao Jorge castle we just wandered. On the way down we stopped at the Restaurante Zambeze to take some photos since the views are spectacular. Also on the way up the Roman Amphitheater was a wonderful surprise!

I didn't get this. Maybe we didn't see it all properly but according to the map we went all around it...was ok in parts and found a decent place to eat on the outskirts tho...but not as interesting or as much fun as Bairro Alto and much less going on. Seemed like a locals residential area?!Maybe we missed something so perhaps go with a guide otherwise I wouldn't bother with it really with lots of other things to see and do in Lisbon

Most interesting neighborhood in Lisbon. Bring your camera, good walking shoes and spirit of exploration. This a fascinating and beautiful area to stroll and explore. Rick Steves' self guided walking tour is a great start. Try the grilled sardines!!
Nice area but tiring. Make sure you go to the top and walk down. It is very steep and consume lots of energy especially on a hot day. But lovely atmosphere.

Cute area. Really cute and unique area. Be prepared to walk up hill! When you look at the map, it doesn't look like you've walked very far, but you will feel like you've walked more. If you think you're going to get lost, just look for the river and you'll find your way down. :)
ANOTHER MUST SEE IN LIZBON. Alfama is one of the oldest part ofthe city whete muslims lived once. With it's nartow roads and tiled houses ypu canhave a good panorama of the city.

Super touristy area of Lisbon. We stayed here for a week and would not recommend it for a stay as its noisy, full of tourists and kids play at all hours right outside our bedroom. It's lots of stairs and hills and very difficult to park of you have a car.
Not bad for a walk for one day but that's about it.

Nice area. Alfama is an old neighberhood where the hop on hop off tour will not take you because the bus doesn't fit in its narrow streets. So spare some time for this beautiful authentic area, enjoy the views of the city, and the graffitis here and there but prepare yourself for some serious hills walking :)
The Overlook. We stopped at this overlook and the view was amazing! I wish we had more time to explore the streets.
Great area day and night. We wanted the streets several nights, there was a lot going on, music and singing. Stopped for food and then a jug of sangria- fun night.

Great for sightseeing!. The neighborhood of Alfama in Lisbon offers countless options from sightseeing to eating in traditional charming restaurants - Alfama has it all. The location is stunning and offers great views over the old city. If you are in Lisbon during 12-13 of June don't miss the parties celebrating the Popular Saints (Festas dos Santos Populares). There are parties, street food with barbecued sardines and all sorts of music stands scattered around the Alfama area. A mandatory place to visit when in Lisbon!
Excellent. One of the more exciting places in Lisbon. Walking on the narrow streets and visiting the tiny cafes is really enjoyable. You can find there places to listent to fado music.

Favourite part of the city. I really liked this part of the city the most. It has the soul of Lisbon. Cars can't go to all places, some streets are very narrow. People are yelling, talking, they know each other very well so you can feel it. So many hidden gems, so go everywhere and feel everything. Get lost in this part of the city without any concerns.

A beautiful place to visit in Lisbon. The cobbled street is gorgeous. Food is cheap. Take a good stroll along the river to relax and have some snacks, local food, drinks, enjoy some dances or watching a beautiful sunset . I love the Portugese, the country seems a quiet, peaceful , economically priced. The people are nice and kind more down to earth compared to other European industrial countries.I do love Portugal & their people.
Lisbon in a nutshell . Great quarter. Lot of tiny pastelarias and restaurants. Be prepared for stairs and labyrinth of narrow streets. If you want to hear fado live, drop in in the evenings.

Beautiful area,not kid Friendly. Stayed in an airbnb from Sept 4-9 with another couple, 1yr old and 9month old. Beautiful area, but definitely took a toll on our strollers. I'd suggest taking one you don't mind getting beat up. Every part of the city has something to see or eat! We stayed on Rue de Barrao and it was a very narrow and steep street. It's a work out! The further you move into the core of the area it flattens out so it does get better. In the evenings it's a hustle and bustle and you can find some awesome restaurants. Lots of souvenir shops as well, be weary of the price difference from shop to shop. Make sure you check a few places before you buy. The heat was intense, no tall buildings so your under the sun majority of the time. Overall really clean, pleasant area. Would probably pick a flatter less hilly area to stay if you have children.

Definitely stay in this area in Portugal!. We loved staying in the Alfama area when we visited Lisbon. It makes you feel like you really live there. I love the small windy streets, the energy, the vibe, the live music everywhere and good restaurants.
Wanderings round Alfama. Beautiful traditional Lisbon neighbourhood of narrow, windy streets and stairs, a multitude of cafes, restaurants, and homes. Good place either to stay in or explore one day.
Great Area. Great area for eating. Food is cheap generally in this area. You can eat and drink for about 30 to 40 Euros. Seafood is the go.

A Great Neighbourhood To Get "Lost" In. Alfama is Lisbon's oldest neighbourhood. Many locals view it as their favourite. It is made up of narrow alley ways, steep hills and narrow streets. It stretches from the Tagus River up the hill to the castle.Wandering the narrow alleys is a very pleasant way to spend a day or two. Although you do not need a game plan there are many points of interest to visit:* The obvious ones are the cathedral and castle* Coffee and pastries at Pois Cafe* Beers at Trodadores* Dinner at Pateo 13, Chapito a Mesa or Taberna Moderna* The Museum of Decorative Arts or the Museum of Resistance* Fado at Tasca do Chico* The no. 28 tram

Area with lots of character. We stayed in Alfama for 6 nights, and were very happy with our choice. It's definitely the most charming and genuine area, with narrow streets, cosy fado restaurants and small shops.

Worth the climb!!. A must see area to get a true picture of Lisbon and it's inhabitants. Very steep cobbled roads to access the area but worth the effort! Beautiful, traditional buildings and quirky cafes and shops. Something totally different from the main tourist areas of Lisbon.

Every turn you see something intriguing. We chose to walk back to out apartment from the Castello Sao Jorge ( which is well worth a visit). This excursion took us through the winding streets and steep stairways if the Alfama. At every turn we saw charming buildings and unique situations. nAt one point we came across a large wooden frame stretched over the street that was covered with ripening grape vines. Around the next corner we came across 3 workmen trying to get some eight-foot window frames up to the third floor of a narrow little building. Further along we watched a worker carring sheets of 4 x 8 plywood up 2 floors for a renovation. Around another corner were buildings covered in beautiful tile. although it was mid day, there was evidence of several "fado" clubs along our way. So we will be back at night..
Picturesque. Hilly narrow streets, trams, stunning views, churches, small shops, flowers, trees, mini parks, colours everywhere. We stayed in this area for several nights and would stay here again.

Alfama - I love it!. The Alfama district of Lisbon offers one a mixture of beauty, simlicity and a unique atmosphere. The history - christian, moslem and jewish - influenced strongly Alfama's flavour and is to be noticable by the narrow streets,

The historical soul of Lisbon. Alfama is the oldest of all districts in Lisbon. It’s the core starting from which the rest of the city later developed.
It has breathtaking views and a medieval maze, like a village within a city.
A really cosy area to walk around in the small streets with small stairs and alleys. must seen in Lisbon.
Special athmosphere. Treat yourself with a walk in this amazing, old part of the city - but be sure to bring a map, as it is very easy to get lost in the small, crooked streets.

Heart of Lisbon. While in Lisbon you must wander the characteristic, winding lanes of the Alfama. The neighborhood is full of slightly rustic, not overly prettified buildings. By far the best parts of this very hilly area are beautiful viewpoints called miradouros overlooking the whole city. My favorite was the Miradouro das Portas do Sol. Definitely come here to the to see those gorgeous Lisbon views and to hear the classically Portuguese style of music called fado. There are several fado bars & restaurants here (and you can probably book a tour with a local guide at your hotel or hostel).
Explore real Lisbon. Lovely area , lots to discover , make sure you cover all area ! There are many alternatives routes to the castle through there

Excellent district. A picturesque, historic district, mostly pedestrian only with winding streets. Plenty of restaurants and smaller sights. Nice vibe and atmosphere. Excellent choice to stay in Lisbon!
Pretty and interesting. A lovely little area to explore. Some cute little shops and restaurants and some decent opportunities for some nice pics!

Beautiful Lisbon District. This is a beautiful historic area in Lisbon. We enjoyed walking up and down the narrow streets of the Alfama neighborhoods, that have a very unique character. Make sure you have a fully charged phone or camera as this is a place with lots and lots to photo. Just charming.

Beautiful Old Portugal!. This is the area high above the central city of Lisbon, which originally was the home of the fishermen and ship makers. It is a maze of narrow streets with 2-3 story buildings, where every turn around a corner presents a new adventure. The area abounds with many small eateries and is a photographers delight. Just take the No.2 Tram from downtown Lisbon and enjoy the sights as you ascend to this walking delight.

Nice. It's worth visiting even if we must admit that the whole area is a bit degraded and slummy. Tourists should avoid summer time as the temperatures are really high and it's impossible to walk up and down under the sun.

Gorgeous neighborhood. Alfama is a wonderful and historic neighborhood offering amazing views, great cafes and excellent street art. Well worth taking the time to visit and see all of the beautiful sights.

Too touristy. Alfama comes alive at night, like much of Lisbon, and the narrow, twisting alleys and steep stairways make for great exploring. Sadly, many of the restaurants just want to serve indifferent food to the hordes of tourists, while their in house Fado singer performs. There are gems, but be prepared to look hard.

Really interesting lots history buildings and hidden shops. We took tuk tuk round then I went back on for next day to look at more detail. Need to do some sort of tour eg tuk tuk or jeep or mini bus to understand area first or have good guide. Very steep windy and uneven if have walking problem can use two lifts to go up parts of it but then miss sections , lots of alley ways and hidden parts to explore, take your time and stop to look at views of water and castle or churches or picture tiles on side of shops or even modern art graffiti lots of little restarants that look very good. So glad we chose hotel near this in baxia not up top end by parks .
Al Fama has character. This the official name of Old Town. It is on a hill and has a lot of restaurants and shops. Very historic. A great place for dinner as a couple.

Beautiful. The Alfama was gorgeous and fascinating. Walking around this district felt like stepping back in time. It is as if there's a postcard view around every street corner. This was my favorite area of Lisbon.

Charming old alleyways. Charming for a walk up and down the alleyways and grab a lunch, but not that much else to do. Notice that the entire area below Alfama towards the water front is currently one big construction site.

Special place must visit . Lots of history to see at Alfama we went to alfama by a tuctuc tour . AlFama is an okd city i think it was build by Muslim 800 years a go , you should have a walk to discover the historical side of a lovely Lisbon

Go arround with your love. Super romantic place, perfect to go arround with you love, discovering the litlle streets and the "miradouros" with view to the Tejo river. Full of litlle restaurants where you can eat good meals.
Simply amazing. I love Lisbon and I love Alfama district. There are a lot of places to visit, small narrow streets, trams, unique cafes. Yes it is one of the best places i have ever been to.

Charming corner of Lisbon . The streets have soul. You can discover all the narrow streets and have a nice lunch in any of the typical restaurants. Prices are ok and the people are very friendly and welcoming. Worth to discover.
Nice view. Good place for cityview. You can find other attractions in the area so it is worth to visit. You have several choices from flea market to national pantheon or other attractions.

Don't wear heals 👠. It's a wonderful thing to be lost in time without a care in the world or awareness of time. Just walk up and down the cobblestone streets until you wear out your feet and strain your legs. Picturesque views of the Lisboa water and skyline.

Brilliant atmosphere . Lots of things to do and places to see in Alfama. Also plenty of restaurants to eat the local cuisine. This district is very beautiful, you can find yourself in the bustling area where the trams scream round the corners just missing people's heads or in the very quiet alleys where you can find yourself relaxing from the commotion of the city and wander slowly finding new streets with every corner. This district is very good for people who like taking photos and getting a vibe from the city. Deffienetly go here when visiting Lisbon even try to get yourselves lost in Alfama.
Worth the visit. Very interesting part of Lisbons history and a must visit for all first timers to the city. Great selection of Portuguese eateries and should please all
Lovely place to get lost in. Spent the afternoon walking around aimlessly in the alfama area looking at the cute shops and finding lovely azulejo covered buildings.

Worth visiting. A nice place to visit with its narrow streets and beautiful buildings. We were here to listen Fado -music and found a nice place for that. Wouldn´t recommend to go there alone in the evening though.

A Survival of 18th Earthquake.... A very, very old part of Lisbon, still surviving to modern ages...a place to be and enjoy its monuments and buildings, old streets and taverns...choose an intinerary and go, you'll find gentle people there!

Average. I expected a bit more from this well-known district. It is quite hilly with narrow streets,we took a walk and also a ride in 28 tram but honestly I've seen much lovelier districts even in Portugal. This place left me with shady memories of shabby buildings, dirt on the streets and weirdoes standing here and there.

Super interesting.... Bring good rubber-soled shoes because the tiled/cobblestone marbly streets are hilly and slippery, especially in the rain. And carry water because you will do lots of walking because there is a lot to see. The tiled houses are unique and amazing. Views of the Rio Tajo are breathtaking. Castelo St. George is a highlight and worth the climb.

Old town of Lisbon - Worth visiting!!!. Alfama is the small old town of Lisbon. If you want to experience old lisbon - Alfama is the place to be. Preferably take a walking tour to this place, it helps you see the narrow old streets. Taking a vehicle to this place would not be advisable. This place is a steep walk up the hill, so keep your sports shoes on while taking a tour of this place. You get to see full city view from a couple of coffee shops and bar located at Alfama. This view cannot be missed when you go to Lisbon. Also this place gives a lot of insight into Fado music which is Portugal's famous music.
Cute old city and many little streets to discover. I love old cities with very narrow streets to discover. Also many bars and restaurants were you can listen to Faro music. Worth a visit!

Edgy and pretty!. There is much to see in this area with impressive vistas, too! Hilly with cobblestones streets/sidewalks so walking shoes are a must. Taking the tram is another good option to see the area if walking is not preferred. There are many gorgeous sites: castle, cathedral, pantheon, plaza of the sun, plus, a 'thousand' little restaurants to eat al fresco!

Amazing place. Spent a couple of days wandering this area during a recent holiday, it's an amazing place with a maze of small alleys all over the place and littered with little cafes. This is a must if visiting Lisbon, but, as with a lot of lisbon it's quite hilly so sensible footwear required.

Great colonial type lodge. We stayed at Alfama Akisol senses and it was ideal to get a taste of this wonderful old city. The famous tram line 28 is just round the corner and you have plenty of good places for a evening meal with a local touch. We enjoyed the stay a lot and hats off to the management of the lodge that made our stay really enjoyable.

A nice cliché. When people think about Lisbon , many have in memory the typical cliché of very small and tortuous streets, clothes and sheets hanging from the windows, eating resh sardines in the streets, etc. Alfama represents all that but kept its soul despite thousands of tourists cruising around its streets

Quaint winding streets and fado. Worth a half days wander through the winding cobbled streets. Small local bars are best for food. Beware of over prices tourist style menus. Communal squares where locals gather to sing and talk are full of ambiance come dusk

Get Lost in Real Lisboa. This is a must - you've not been to Lisboa if you missed Alfama. It is the soul and heart of this City, spend at least one evening here, drinking wine & listening to the Fado, or just walk arround breathe the local regular life
Nicest quarter in Lissboa. In my opinion it's the nicest part on Lissboa. No new buildings and the old character survived. Millions of tourists, better go in another travelling time.
a must when in Lisbon. Just walk around in the small streets without a map and just enjoy the atmosphere and the beautiful houses.

a must. This is a great area of Lisbon to stay in and wander through. It contains so much history from Roman times onwards. Great museums, a castle, wonderful views across the City and water, great bars and restaurants and so much music outdoors and in. Make sure you are fit to walk up and down slopes, but there are plenty of taco tacs, trams, taxis and buses to use if tiredness sets in.

The soul of lisbon. Just to get lost and walk around is the way to get to know Lisbon. the houses, the small restaurants and the people. the birth place for fado and for sure a place not t miss in Lisbon. Specially on the summer festivities, June is the best month for sure. The 12th of June is the craziest day but all weekend of the month is for sure a place to been, good sardines, drink and lots of fun music...
every building - gorgeous. This part of the city like Monmart - very colorful, so bohemian, full of brilliant shops/cafes/bars.

A place you have to visit when in Lisbon. Lovely area to walk around. Lots of nice places to see and visit. you should plan for at least half a day with a stop to eat. The hills can be steep but if you are reasonably fit it's fine.

Fado Fado. Very touristy, beautiful views, gorgeous bars and of course the fado. Enjoyed taking an air conditioned break in the fado museum before finding a cul de sac fado bar for some vinho Verde on the terrace. Beautiful. Walkable from town centre but a tad warm
beautiful. a must see in Lisboa. Spend the day at lea sure, between the Se Cathedral and St George's castle. Do nothing but take in the colors and shapes.

The oldest part of Lisbon. It is the oldest part of Lisbon.Even in Romans time the first fortification was here. After demolition earthquake and tsunami in 1755 z. , when all other parts of Lisbon down was destroyed, only this part Alfama was not destroyed.So it is origial from times before 1755 y. It is looking old, old-fashioned,with narrow streets, winding alleyways, and steep flights of steps.but there are a lot attraction:-on the hill is Castelo de São Jorge, -Museum of Decorative Arts-Igreja de Santa Engrácia-Panteão Nacional-Igreja de São Vicente de Fora-Cathedral-flea market in Tuesday and Saturdays-Fado Museum-Casa dos Bicos-National Tile Museum-great view to the neighbor, Graçaand lot gift shop,the most authentic restaurant abd caffe bars in the city, pictures seller...and plenty of bonhomie.,,Because Alfala is on the hill, I suggest to go with old yellow tram to the top, near Castelo de São Jorge as an main point of Alfama, than comeback with foot down step by step to see other atraction and come to the down part in Baisa ( I was wrote before about that how to see all Lisbon )

You have to visit Alfama! . Alfama is the oldest part of Lisbon. It gives you a clear picture how the people used to live. It was and still is a poor area. People live in small houses here. And that is also the reason why I love this area. These cute little houses, the streets.. It is so cute and romantic at the same time. Besides walking around you also have some good restaurants and authentic and souvenirs shops. Make sure you visit this heart of Lisbon!

Prepare to wander. You can get lost in these tiny streets. A slice of working class neighborhood. Most interesting at the top of the hill at St. Jorge's castle. Also a Fado museum at the bottom of the hill.

Full of energy.. Our second stay in the Alfama, and it was super busy this time (in August) so forget a trip on the trams unless you want to queue for at least 40 mins. Lisbon out of season is a super place, great for couples to meander the narrow streets and pop into one of the numerous bars and cafes. For us with two young children it was hard work. If you love street music, haphazard BBQ's, Fado and great restaurants this is the place for you. Just don't expect a quiet nights sleep in Alfama!

would be best seen out of season. crowded streets of tourists in August, trams impossible to get on, so be prepared to walk up the hilly streets rather than take the tram as the brochures lead you to believe is an option

Beautiful old part of city.. We were taken here during our tuk tuk tour of lisbon. The driver/guide thought it warranted a stop off and walk around the tiny cobbled streets and I'm so glad he did. Steeped in history this is a lovely step back in time and a romantic, car free area full of intimate restaurants and bars. We were here during the day, however our guide said that it really comes alive at night when the bars are full of the sounds of fado.Can't wait to come back here for the evening entertainment!

It's an Experience You Won't Forget. We rented a furnished apt. ffrom May-July 2016 so we got to know the neighborhood quite well. As others wrote, it's steep, and hilly with rough cobble-stone streets. You hear Fado music playing everywhere at night, tour groups passed under our window, construction was going on constantly. But, the bakery around the corner had the most delicous, crusty bread. There were shops to get a tasty Latte with a sweet and restaurants galore. You're close to the river and transportation. If you're seniors, like us, avoid the month of June when they have their big Festival. Stands are erected haphazardly and each competes for customers by blaring out loud music from speakers. This could go on into the wee hours of the morning. If you're young, have at it. Lots of history is this neighborhood - read up on it before you go.
Fantastic. Just amazing the whole city and the people . Not to mention the color the architecture the trams the cleanness of the city just mesmerizing

Morning walk. Lovely for walking. Go in the morning when it's cooler. Take a tram to the castle or to Sao Vincente then walk down. The streets are old and the houses gritty with history. Go to Uncle Georges (on Paraiso) for coffee and for pastries made by his wife. If you are expecting to have dinner there, make a reservation at the better, more recommended restaurants. They get filled fast. There are many restaurants there but of varied quality. Check for the most recommended before you go.
Steep and difficult to walk. Suggest you to join a segway tour to go around Alfama. A difficult walking area with a lot of up ramp.
Great Place. There are so many things to see at the Alfama, just walking around those narrow and winding street full of history, reminds you of the arabian population that many years ago lived there.

Winding streets and alleys. We stayed in the heart of Alfama during our visit to Lisbon. It is a very picturesque hilly neighbourhood that has plenty to see and do. There are streets that appear a little sketchy, but they are totally safe. A fun, if noisy, place to visit.

Nice neighbourhood, not so great food. I spent a few days in Alfama, and maybe I have spent to much time in Italy, but I expected more. I tried out a few restaurants and the food was acceptable but not more. It is extremely touristic, as in the locals would never it there, only tourists.

Over rated, good for walk about. Every tourist goes here, the trams are crowded and not a good way to see anything. The small charming alleyways and restaurants are worth visiting, but the old life style and original inhabitants are hiding or gone.

Great views and historic area. The common view of this city is you see more by walking the streets and this district is a must for the old houses, alleys, steps and churches.There is so much to see in this historic area.

A must to go. If you are in Lisbona I strongly recommend to visit Alfama, no map, just walking around, feel the atmosphere, drink I nice beer in a panoramic area and have dinner in one of the typical restaurants where Fado is played.
A piece of advise...especially in summertime book the restaurant in advance, average are pretty small, with few tables ;-)

Beautiful Views of the City. Make sure you make it up here to see the city. It is a great introduction on your first day and a great place to end your stay as you look over places you have begun to recognize from your visit.

Inspiring!. Be sure to go here! It's worth the taxi ride. We sought this Museum out. We fell in love with the Azulejos in Porto and our love grew as we travelled south. We loved the "louca" (Portugese pottery) for sale on the square in Alcobaça at Lisboa Pottery--a family business since 1928. Loved Portugal! Go!!!!

Classic pictures you see of Lisbon. This is the old part of Lisbon where old buildings/homes can be seen on very hilly streets. We did not take the Tram 28 through this part of the city (we walked) but we saw many people taking the Tram through this part. In any case, a must see to get a feel for the city.

Tourist Fado night out. This was our last night out in Lisbon so felt like we had to do a Fado night. It's very busy and a bit of a tourist trap but we found a table in one of the local restaurants. The food was ok but the singing was amazing, those guys have a good set of lungs on them. I did notice that one table was being shushed by the owner as they were talking through the singing. The food was ok but it was a good night to our holiday.

Beautiful old Alfama.. Alfama is one of the loveliest neighborhoods of Lisbon. Everything here is old and authentic. Small narrow streets and alleys up and down the hills, beautiful miradouros with gorgeous views. Many of these buildings are more or less run down, but they are very old and many of them survided the earthquake of 1755. It's very easy to get lost here but that only adds to the charm.During the summer months there are sometimes simply too many tourists around, and some authentic old fashioned restaurants have become tourist traps with elevated prices, but one can still find a lovely place for a good meal at reasonable price.For some reason Alfama is not as much a victim of graffiti as Bairro Alto where some fantastic historical buildings have been spoiled with ugly spray paintings.Alfama has managed to keep it's charm.

Got up there by tram 28. Satisfying tourists expectations: travelling by the tram and taking nice photos on the hill. I travelled uphill by tram and there was long queue but worth the wait; I walked downhill and can have a drink on the way.
Night Life. Great for strolling at night - many people walking around - even at midnight. Lots of fado restaurants. Felt very safe.

Get lost in the back streets of Alfama - a must for a trip to Lisbon!. I visited Alfama today, walking from Praca do Comercio in Baixa, and it is by far my favourite part of Lisbon so far. Have fun walking around the back streets and up the many steps, taking in "real Lisbon" and then make your way up to the Miradouro do Santa Luiza for a breathtaking view of the old town and the river. Bring water as there aren't many shops to buy from along the way and you will get hot!

Perfect district to see old Lisbon. You should reserve a full day to discover this old neighbourhood fully. If you're a tile lover like me, then don't miss the chance to see the nice streets as well as the Castle of Sao Jorge, Portas do Sol and other attractions.

Relaxing cup of tea. Narrow streets, old houses, friendly locals and not overly crowded. Found a small quite cafe, only two other people in it and ordered some mint tea and fruit, sat and just took in the relaxing atmosphere. Must do when in Lisbon.

Finding the way can be challenging but well worth it. Alfama is a neighborhood to get to know Lisboa and Lisboans. The narrow, winding streets and walkways have the feel of a real neighborhood. The people are friendly and welcoming as is typical in Portugal. One night, while following the light from Google maps which was failing miserably in showing us the way, a woman came out of a restaurant and told us she was not let us be lost in her city. She walked us part of the way and then passed us off to someone who was more familiar with where we were going. Alfama was a very comfortable place to spend the six nights we spent in Lisboa. I can't wait to go back.

The real feel of Old Lisbon. We would have liked to have spent more time in the Alfama but unfortunately the hilly topography of the area was far from friendly for our kids' double stroller. We therefore opted to get transport to the Castelo and walk down once we'd visited that. If walking up isn't the best option for you either (I would have in the early morning had I not had the kids), you can get there with the tram or elevador. We however, chose a taxi. Taxis are very reasonably priced by European capital city standards, I'd even say they're cheap and a ride will probably cost you the same as public transport unless you have an all-inclusive pass like the Lisboa Card. The area has the charm of an old medieval town bang in the centre of the capital city. Unlike the old part of town back home, it is very much an active part of the city with mostly local residents, bars and cafes. A must if you want to experience the real feel of Old Lisbon.

Observing the Life of locals. This city quarter is the oldest one with very narrow streets and houses close to each other. People here live also very close to each other, everybody knows everyone in this district. This is the right place to see how some local people live and in the evening you can have a dinner and listen to Fado (traditional Portuguese music) in one of the cafes.

A Little Disappointing. If you are traveling to Lisbon, you will visit the Alfama neighborhood, and you should. We found ourselves in the neighborhood two or three times. Views, atmosphere, and the attractions are definitely great, but as a photographer, I was looking for back streets and secret passageways. This is not Fez. We did not get lost in a wonderful way. I also suspect some of the old charm is disappearing. Looks like there is some gentrification going on.

Best of old Lisbon. If you want the narrow streets, old houses, small little cafes, and attractions that surprise you around a corner, this is the place to go. Not only that, but it has wonderful view points where you see the bay over the roofs, it is truly beautiful. We rented a small apartment in Alfama for the 4 nights we are here and I am writing right now with that beautiful view.
Most authentic. Amazing place to get lost in. Most authentic and beautiful area of the city. Super quiet, music, locals, narrow streets, gives you an idea what life in Lisbon used to be like.

Beautiful part of Lisbon. If you like t explore cities by walking and getting lost, this is the place to start in Lisbon. With cute, narrow streets, little cafés and restaurants this is a very charming part of the city and yet it is not touristy. Take the Elevador do Gloria to get up the hill!

Ride tram 28. I recommend to take tram 28E from Martim Moniz Square early in the morning, not later than 8 am - later the tram is overcrowded and the line for it is too long (under the sun). Alight at Largo da Graca. View the city from Miradouro da Graca and then descend along the narrow streets - all of them are worth to be seen.
Holiday. Lovely area of Lisbon very authentic and grey restaurants and culture. Really enjoyable but not to touristy. We stayed at Memmo Alfama and can thoroughly recommend this hotel.

The Most Beautiful Area in Lisbon. Alfama is the place you imagine when you think of Old Lisbon. It survived the great fire and is a collection of old fishermans' cottages, complete with winding pathways and steps with trees and coloured tiled roofs located on the side of a steeply sloping hill. As one of the premier homes of fado, also thought of as "Portuguese Blues" music, one can hear Fado at night eminating from the myriad of restaurants, bars and fado clubs. This is the true soul of Lisbon and a "must see" but does require a fair amount of climbing. One can of course enjoy Alfama through the windows of the No.28 tram, another Lisbon institution.
Worth the trip. Be prepared to climb steep streets! The restaurants, great views, and colorful twisty streets were worth the climb!k

wonderful but very touristy. This neighborhood of Lisbon has a ton of history and culture - and tourists. But, there were lots of small streets to get lost in, lots of little restaurants, and you can still get the feel of it -- worth visiting. Lots of up and down, lots of stairs, so wear good shoes and it's probably very slippery when it rains!

Beautiful!. While in Lisboa, we stayed for a couple of days in the Alfama district. It was extremely busy with many things going on like sightseeing and shopping. Locals and tourists were busy in the streets and the shops. There was lots to do and see with all of the old churches, the castle, the river with the tall ships. Took a tour in a Tuk Tuk, well worth the value. Our driver zipped us around Lisboa while providing us with all of the details of the history of the city. He even took the time to stop at Pastel Belem for a treat. If you are in Lisbon, you must spend some time in the Alfama district.
Typical old Lisbon. This suburb of Lisbon is the oldest one, made of very narrow streets and small houses, cafés and shops.
Great to explore!. Excellent location to walk around. I spent 2.5 hours exploring this area. Nice buildings and little streets. Best to take the tram if you have mobility issues.

Tiny residences, but full of history. Fortunately I was able to stay in an Alfama apartment during my week+ stay in Lisbon. The tiny streets make for friendly neighbors. It's not far from there to get to public transportation, so everywhere in the city is accessible - but be ready for lots of uphill walking!

Beautiful point of view. Did the morning free tour with Yuri and he was such a great guide that we decided to do the Alfama tour in the afternoon, the weather was very hot but he made sure that we stayed in the shade as much as possible, loved the tour and learnt a lot about this region.
Awesome neighborhood. Most typical part of Lisbon. Little alleys, cable cars etc. Check that you have good legs to handle the climb of these streets !
Scenic and old neighbourhood of Lisbon. This is the old neighbourhood in Lisbon that survived the 1755 earthquake and tsunami. It is quite scenic and has a lot of old buildings to view.

Accomodation@Alfama. We had the pleasure to stay at the most beautiful side of Lisboa,Alfama,and especially at the amazing Palacio Vila Flor. Alfama is easy to reach via the metro,bus,train or electric 28. It has the best places (alongside with Bairro Alto) to listen to quality fado (we went to Club de Fados and the whole fados experience was spectacular and the food was so tasty). Great view points and adorable narrow streets. Overall, Alfama is were the heart of the old soul of the city lives... A must see and explore. The only difficulty is that the streets are difficult to walk, impossible with strollers and always wear trainers when you visit Alfama!! :-)

Alfama. This is one of the place to visit and to experience the popular atmosphere of Lisbon.Located on the top of the hill of Alfama you can walk through a maze of alleys, vaulted passageways, small patios full colors . There is also a lot of restaurants where you can taste some specialties for cheap...Bairro do Castelo Sao Jorge surrounds the castle, ... Used tram ( 2,85 € one way ) to the top and walked downhill ..Worth a visit

walk the streets and feel the people. up and down the alley street ways to see how people live, where they eat and hear the fado!! street art, bohemian flea market and interesting nooks and crannies!!
Best place in Portugal. Awesome people, street restaurants,live grill, live musik,dancing. One big Portuguese party going on here on the weekends. Definitely don't miss it.
interesting walk. nice stroll around to come across small shops and restaurants.. very pleasant narrow cobblestone lanes

Lovely. Great area to walk around, get lost and discover the essence of Lisbon.Be ready to walk a lot, so take enough water and sun protection... It can become very hot in sunny summer days. Alternatively you can sit in many of the small bars will find in every corner; the upper you get, more chances to find bars with terrace and wonderful views over Lisbon (i.e. In tua do Castelo).

Beautiful streets of Lisbon. Beautiful cobble streets, cute restaurants, cool & relaxing parks/fountains/lookout points around every corner. The streets of Alfama makes you want to explore. I would recommend taking a tuk tuk to explore but it was also very interesting to explore on foot, see locals way of living and discover new places.

Lovely narrow streets. We loved the are so much we visited twice as plenty to do and many restuarants. The are mainly escaped the earthquake so the old building and street are intact and great for just wandering around,
Great for exploring. A nice old part of Lisbon, with lots of winding roads to explore and a nice selection of really local restaurants, most reasonably priced.
a charming area to wonder around. get lost there and enjoy the atmosphere- however please be warned that it is very hilly -so please have plenty of water to help along the way

Just go!. You don't need a plan or an itinerary. Just go and wander around. It's surely one of the most rewarding city quarters in Europe in which just to wander aimlessly. You won't be bored, I promise!
Lovely place . The quaint twisting streets reveal little gems around every corner . Worth walking even when hot so that you can gaze linger and savour . Try it !

A walk in the heart of Lisbon. Alfama preserves the true heart of Lisbon before the earthquake. It is lovely to walk through the small allies and discover hidden squares where you can feel the "fado soul". Don't miss the cathedral Se. If you get tired stop in one of the small cafes and enjoy a Sagres beer.
