Original charm of the city. This area we found was the part with most of the original; charm in this city reflecting its heritage. From the level main city streets we walked up the steep tram lined cobbled road past the cathedral and up. There were vendors and open barbeques cafes cooking sardines among the busy streets. The trams add to the ambience of it all. We waled back down using the many steep street stairways. Great place to be when in Lisbon.

Great neighborhood. We stayed in this neighborhood for 6 days. The location is great. The neighborhood is delightful old town flavor. There are many restaurants and facilities in the neighborhood. The train station is in Alfama. To fully enjoy it you will have to go up and down many small streets and stairs. Street parties were frequent when we went in July 2016, some of them due to Portugal playing in the European Cup which they eventually won.
Alfama. Beautiful viewpoint, highly recommended. You can see a great panoramic view of Lisbon. Use the tuck tuck to get up or walk (not that much of an incline) if you are a regular walker.
Great walk and things to see. Nice walk around discovering what Lisbon has to offer. Nice little cafe at top of hill after getting the team. Would recommend a few hours discovering here.

Quiet and Pretty. Lovely hotel in the Alfama district. There is a private roof deck overlooking Alfama which had beautiful views ad the area and the harbor. We hung out at the pool deck with drinks and snacks both nights. Free walking tour was wonderful.
Wonderful area to see. Wonderful area to see while traveling in Lisbon. Many small alleyways and sights to see. Working class neighborhood and communal living.
Authentic Lisbon . Old Lisbon. Very nice to see. We had a TukTuk Tour and ended up in Alfama. Had a nice small walking tour in Alfama, very nice! We can recommend Alfama!
Lovely atmosphere. We went with the Lisbon chill out free walking tour. They were so passionate about the area that they really put you in the atmosphere of it all.
Alfama. Lovely little alley ways to wander around. Little shops, bars and restaurants around every corner. In the heat of the day a great way to dodge the sun.
Beautiful little area! . Absolutely beautiful winding streets! Excellent food and drinks, lovely atmosphere. Expect to get lost as it is confusing, but enjoy that and go where it takes you!
A bit disapointing. The area looks lovely but we missed a good atmosfere. Lots of tourists and that was mostly it. The flea market is worth a visit though.

Old town. If you want to see the real Lisbon this is worth a visit. Walked around at night and found a good restaurant filled only with locals.
If you want a night out away from the tourists put on your walking shoes.

Worth at least one full day - two days if you can. Very close to quayside and the centre, wonderful paved streets and old buildings, many cafes and bars to sit and people-watch. People and buildings full of character and charm.Hills to climb, trams and tuk tuks to try - best of all just sit with a beer and watch the world go by, immersing oneself in history and times gone by.

Good central location. We stayed in this location , , very central , walk to most of the historic sites . Beautiful historic residential area with narrow cobblestone streets and sidewalks , go through all the alley ways and many stairs climbing up the many hills, you will fall in love with this part of the city . Lots of cafes , bars , restaurants and little shops.
Flea market on tues. and sat.. Not worth the effort; with exception of a couple stalls, it's essentially a large garage sale with second hand clothes, shoes, tools, "antiques" of no value.

Breathtaking. Alfama is an absolute must to wander around. You have gone back in time and are wandering round tiny roads in a maze on a hill. You have to look out for pickpockets as they are very skilled at undoing any exposed zips and grabbing whatever is on top. So many fantastic restaurants to chose from that you are spoiled for choice.

Should visit!. Very nice neighbourhood! Take the tuktuk, you will see the best places! Absolutely with visiting if you like small streets, typical houses and shops, beautifull buildings, and taking great pictures!
lovely trip. We took a small tuk tuk taxi and had an hour tour in the small streeds with prived explanation, it was very nice
Great views.. From the Alfama you can get the best view over Lisbon. This old area is so photogenic, you can spend hours walking the streets and taking photographs in this area.

The best of Alfama with Yuri. I did the Alfama tour for 14€ and it was great! Our guide Yuri was so much fun and took us to some really unique places. He had us interacting with the locals and experiencing the best of Alfama. I definitely recommend this tour to anyone who visits Lisbon!

Hidden gems in Alfama. We took a cab into Alfama to look for a certain restaurant - Lisboa Tu e Eu. No one heard of it, so it took us two tries and our GPS, but we found it and loved it. We popped in on other places as well. Walking around and discovering was the best part of this part of Lisbon.
Misterious and Fado. Up and down through the narrow streets or steps. Behind every corner a surprise. Lots of little terraces on charming inside corridors. Fado dinners or bars for nightlife gang.

Charming Alfama. Of all Lisbon’s neighborhoods, Alfama is the most charming--it is the oldest in the city & one of the only areas that survived the 1755 earthquake. The narrow, historical streets are a true joy to explore!

All about walking up and down. What a place to go up and see the whole of Lisbon from the top. The views is amazing but you can use transport to reach the top within the area. The use of tram 28 and a special tourist tram plus the Lisboa special tuk-tuk cars.
Nice beighbourhood. It took us a while to find this area but it was nice to walk down the streets and enjoy the atmosphere.

Old Lisbon. Very winding streets with local flavor. We took a walking tour to the top & trolly back.
Sweet shops & original tile on building. The church is on the top & palace is mostly trinkets

one of the last reamaining quarters with mediavel muslim design in europe!. Yes! those are rather narrow, often very narrow lanes, still lively inhabited in the 21st century; many of those are only walking (moto) lanes, any car is too wide... walk enjoying the local livelyhood always awre of possible pickpockets, it is the only danger, but if you enjoy unique characteristics it is worthwhile...fado as well?
Charming. The old town. very charming, with a great view of the city. Get yourself lost on the streets and enjoy. take some beautiful pictures.

Definitely a must see. It's a beautiful little district with winding streets and historic rail cars. There are many cafes and restaurants and beautiful views. It's one of the first stops we took when we arrived in Lisbon.
Walk and get lost in Alfama. Fantastic walks in Lisbon, you get easily lost in the charming streets of Alfama, and this is a delight. It's really worth a day !

Lovely area. Beautiful neighborhood, full of colors and local streets - a must go to if you're in Lisbon! There are several viewpoints and the view is just stunning. Get there with a tram and you could find this magical place with narrow streets and many stairways around. Be aware of pickpocketing though! Someone was trying to open my shoulder bag before I found out!!

Very authentic Portuguese experience. A must see in Lisbon! Narrow streets, beautiful buildings and old yellow trams - very nice atmosphere indeed. Both riding tram in Alfama and strolling are good options to explore it.
Stunning neighborhood . One of only two original neighborhoods left in Lisbon after the earthquake in 1755 this is a must see. Get lost walking the thin cobblestone streets and enjoy the history.
Glad we went at night. So glad we went later in the day as it was veryvery busy earlier. Great views over the city. enjoyed with a glass of wine, from the little tuk tuk.

Alfama is beautiful and very different to other Lisbon regions. Took a Tuk tuk and saw Alfama highlights in the early afternoon and went back and had dinner there and listened to passionate Fado singers that night. This old section that survived the 1755 earthquake is quaint and picturesque and I think a must see place in Lisbon.

The Corridors of Portuguese Spirit and Traditions. Alfama is an amazing place, when you start your walks through the little corridors you can feel what this walks is about. Simple things like see the locals having a chat from window to window in their own houses or families and small restaurants cooking their sardines on the streets. Wherever you go in each corner you will find a surprise. Also near by is the National Pantheon and more stunning buildings around you can appreciate. The strong feel and sensations being surrounded by an Medieval Maze is constant. Feel this amazing place with their deep and strong traditions and rich culture is an amazing experience I will recommend ALFAMA WALKS.

Nice walks but nice walks are everywhere in Portugal. Do not bother to go walking the back streets here unless you don't mind walking up and down steps!! Some of the views are amazing, but the historic area down by the Praça Dom Pedro IV and other similar places are beautiful enough for those whose knees or other joints are not up to the task of the Alfama

Difficult to walk around with limited mobility. Alfama is the old district of Lisbon. You get absolutely stunning views of the city from the top of the hills.
If you have limited mobility (which was our case) you can't really visit it on foot since its a hill, you have to plan a short visit by tuk tok or some other transport.

Historic Alfama . Having survived the earthquake of 1775, one is able to enjoy tangle of cobbled streets. Formally this area was the sailors quarters dating back to the 6th - 8th centuries. Both the Visigoths and Moors were here where their presence can still be felt. Settle in for a short while and let your imagination take you back.

Visit during daylight. This area's main attraction is the view from the castle. I didn't stick around to catch the sunset view, since being in this neighbourhood after dark is said to be unsafe. Some parts during the day felt sketchy too, and the tram is known to have pickpockets waiting for distracted tourists.

Walk up the streets and listen to fado. Alfama is one of Lisbon's old quarters. Narrow steep streets lined with excellent restaurants. We went to Faz Figura. It is a high end restaurant, where I had sea bass poached in sparkling wine :) But most of the Alfama restaurants are typical Portuguese places and it is the best place to find traditional fado singers. It is just about impossible to park and you have to be a local to drive on those extra narrow streets.

Very Cool. Very interesting neighborhood with narrow, winding, hilly streets, many restaurants and, here and there, small shops, and, occasionally, at the top of hills, interesting views of the city. A must-see when visiting Lisbon.

Lisbon is a beautiful city (as cities go). Welcoming and friendly with great food, vistas and easy to get around (try the trolly car), it feels like home (SF) and looks fresh and clean. You will not be disappointed.

Average site with great views . Went up the castle as recommended by our airbnb host and uber driver. The entrance fee is 8.50euro/pax. A little steep considering there isn't much more to do or see besides the stunning view from the top. There was the camera obscura viewpoint but didn't bother as the queue was long and the weather was too hot. Would recommend going during the evening or when the weather is cooler.
Wonderful During St Anthony's Festival. Plenty of music, great food and wonderful wine. Even the street food was delicious. Be ready to workout by walking the steep streets.

Great neighbourhood . Great neighbourhood !Really local !Nice small streets. Nice restaurants ! Only watch out for the starters which they put on the table everywhere. If you eat them you pay for it, and sometimes that's ok for a reasonable price, but not always.....
Lovely old fashioned Area...must Visit!. Excellent views and little shops. Very Portuguese area and gives you an excellent insight into how the locals live.
Beautiful maze of narrow cobbled streets. Alfama is a lovely old neighborhood for the true essence of Lisbon. The cobbled streets, wonderful people, festivity define this lovely legacy place.

Beautiful, Old & Steeped in History. Just walk without a plan. You'll discover the beauty of the area. You will meet the people who live there, and share the wonderful Portuguese cuisine, only to finish by hearing the beautifully melodic Fado.
Tram rides. The tram were full most of the times but worth the wait. The tuk tuks might be better option. Castello was very very hard to get in.
area around castle. the area looks old...and the view from the castle of the city is good. I liked it, but didn't found it awesome.

Alfama a historic district. Alfama. The Alfama district in Lisbon does not live the Popular Saints, the marches of fado and Lisbon Downtown. Facing south overlooking the Tagus River, Alfama extends from the Castelo de São Jorge to Jardim do Tabaco dock and is the biggest tourist destinations in Lisbon.

Feeling home and relaxed. The atmosphere of this place made me feel absolutely relaxed and just enjoy the sunshine. The view points offer great images of sun, water and red roofs. The houses and streets are so great and authentic-looking that you definitely shouldn't miss walking in this district.
Great walking experience. Really enjoy my walk through this city, the "azulejos" decorating the city and small shops were a fun walking experience.
fell in love with alfama. go back in time, explore,look, be looked at. eat mdine wine, arts cozy you name it. \no walmarts no americans awesome
Fado district. Go for a walk or take the tram 28, you will see the heart of Lisbon, historic sites and life as it is.
Beautiful. an exceptionnal place not to miss when you visit Lissabon. Peaceful, calm, nice views, good food and not far from the center of Lissabon, but you have to wear good walking shoes.
Loved it. This is a place where the time has stopped. So inspiring. Loved my trip in Lisbon. Will be back for sure.
Sweet old part of Lisboa - Do not miss it. The old part of Lisboa - Alfama - is one of the places everyone should visit while in the capital of Portugal.

Love at first sight! . Small streets, surprise views, unexpected street art, cosy restaurants and truly a silent and nice country feeling of the area within the great city of Lisabon. It feels like you've been dropped in the middle of the country side. Take your time, walk around without a map, get lost and just enjoy the unique area.
Alfama is so unique that you can't miss it. We rented an apartment in Alfama right next to the trolley line. What an awesome experience! Felt like we were in the original Lisbon.

Amazing old Lisbon. Beautiful old part of Lisbon city, narrow streets and Fado music everywhere. The atmosphere is like something out of an old film set, especially at dusk/early evening time when the cafes are starting up and the fado musicians launch into their own style of blues
Loved it here!. We stayed in the Alfama area for three nights and loved every minute! The streets just absorb you and the atmosphere wonderful!

Fabulous to walk around in Alfama with the street art!. Great place for walk around, dinner and keep looking up to see people still living and enjoying this district of Lisbon. The sense of history is palpable. The new street art I loved. Just watch for pick pockets!

Old City. No visit to Lisbon is complete without a visit to Alfama. There are so many interesting areas, you should not miss it. Have a meal there, the restaurants are quite authentic and well priced.
very nice places. we and my family was there by using a tuk tuk with a driver that show to us all the best places in Alfama. very nice

OLD SCHOOL, Beautiful Portuguese Town !. There is SAO Jorge castle right above it ! It is a very quaint place, I feel in love with the walls, and stone work, and it's distinct flair ! the bread, food and pastelaria vendors were soooooo awesome while I was there ! Treated us so kindly !! We would find the best Pastel de nata, assorted pastries and meat pies, palmier, lovely coffee and oj!!!

Very insightful. A lovely walk between the old buildings and in the old narrow streets, several cafes and restaurants scattered at each corner, many restaurants with the local Fado music in the evenings,
Great place for an evening walk

Charming and steep neighborhood. Alfama reminds me of San Francisco in several ways: it's near the water, it's steep as a mountain, and there are cable cars. The surroundings are different, and the architecture is, of course, much older. We sort of got lost here; we were following the GPS, but it took us a different way than it had earlier. We accepted this as an exciting way to see the neighborhood, which is unusual and alluring. Take time to walk around Alfama for a look at Lisbon. This would probably apply to anywhere you would walk around off the beaten (and touristy) path.

Wandering the streets. Quaint little streets and alleys filled with shops and cafes. There is a lot of climbing as the streets are steep but it is fascinating to see. Wear sneakers or closed shoes as the sidewalks are all cobblestone and uneven tile.
Lovely old part of the city, the best bit. I loved this part of the city as you found new cafes and bars at each turn, and it was different at night when everything was open.

Great architecture. Alfama is the highlight of any visit to Lisbon - it's the old, historic neighbourhood of Lisbon with winding, uphill, cobbled streets and old alleys and houses. You can catch a tram if you don't want to walk up and down the old streets.
Visit at night. It is a very nice place but I believe it will be much alive during evenings . Lovely souvenirs and crafts shops.

Great place but take a tuk tuk to get around. Lots of small streets with a surprise around every other corner. We had small kids with us so walking around is challenging. Best & fun way to travel around is with a tuk tuk. See all the sites without the long walks and steep climbs.If you don't have small kids - walk and enjoy. For couples its prob. A very romantic place to wonder around with small restaurants all over the place.
Old district Alfama. This is the old Fisherman's quarter. The streets are narrow and winding at the base of st. George's castle. It has many restaurants with live music.

A part of Lisbon full of charming and hidden corners to relax. We took the tramp and jump out before getting to the Castle. Only walking around, taking pictures with the gorgeous sea at the back and then relaxing it was enough for me to say this is a must during your visit in Lisbon. We had to decide between going there and Belem and definetely we don't regret for our choice, cheap food, lovely people and picturesque views. Tips for choosing the right place to eat: only the ones with hand written menus, kinda dirty and not too fancy, that way you make sure you're having 100% fresh food made that day.
Castle visit. Excellent day to spend in Lisbon. Walked all the way up. Splendid view. Admired the beautiful gardens and flowers.

Walk around. Had a good time walking around in alfama, great architecture and some street art that's great. But some of the famous street art have been demolished which are still not updated. Walked around for quite some time to realize the building had been torn down.

Amazing energy and killer views. I really enjoyed the neighborhood of Alfama. Overlooking the water, the energy in the area is electrifying with tourists and locals buzzling about. Highly recommended.

Lovely place to walk around. Nice cobbled streets to walk around. Lots of hills and narrow streets. You can get some lovely views of the city. Food is a bit more expensive, as it is a big tourist area.
fun neighborhood. Cool neighborhood to walk around. The architecture of the buildings and local scene are worthwhile. Lots of small bars and restaurants to explore.
A step back in time. It was very pleasant to take a walk around the old, beautiful, and narrow streets of Alfama. Many local cafes and shops. A free but valuable experience!

What a threat!. I really like this neighbourhood. The historic buildings, the churches, the narrow Streets. It's not a very touristy area apart from certain look out points. Steep Streets though so be reminded about this if you are not fit.

Search for Fado. Unfortunately we didn't find any Fado to watch and listen to but luckily the bars were all playing this. The number 12 tram and also the 28 run directly to Alfama from the centre so it is easy to find yourself there without much effort. Wander too far off the beaten path and it can get a little risky - beggers and homeless people can be a little unnerving at times but mostly harmless.

Lovely area of Lisbon to spend time. The Alfama district of Lisbon is a great area to spend time during visits to Lisbon. There are nice attractions, viewpoints and hours worth of lovely streets to wander, which make for a rewarding day of sightseeing. Notable attractions include church visits to Sé de Lisboa (The Cathedral of Lisbon), Santo Antonio de Lisboa and Igreja da Sao Vicente de Fora for starters and you'll definitely want to spend a bit of time at Castelo de Sao Jorge if you are a first time visitor.You can also take in fine viewpoints at locations such as Miradouro de Santa Luzia, Miradouro das Portas do Sol, the hillside of Castelo de Sao Jorge and the rooftop access at Igreja da Sao Vicente de Fora. I also very much enjoyed wandering the narrow streets of Alfama, which are lined with traditional buildings, small shops, bars and restaurants. Dining experiences during our recent visit where quite good in Alfama, particularly for traditional Portuguese cuisine. Just find a place that seems to have locals dining instead of throngs of tourists, and you'll likely be in for a treat. You can walk to Alfama from central locations in Lisbon in 20-30 minutes, taking in the attractions as you make your way through this district. Alternatively, Tram No. 28, transverses the district as well. This is a nice activity for those who have not tried street trams before. Overall, I very much enjoyed time spent in Alfama during a recent stay in Lisbon. It is well worth at least a half day of sightseeing and more if time allows.
Charming old section of town.. Very quaint with nice views of the city. Lots of old architecture and design to see, with lots of cafe's and shops offering traditional goods.

Artworks and alleyways. We took a wander through the Alfama district one evening. Whilst some parts are a bit run down everything is charming. The tiled buildings, some amazing wall murals/graffiti, fantastic architecture and colours, as well as some yummy looking restaurants and tempting bars.

Be very wary of Fado restaurants. We loved this area and decided to stay for dinner. At the end of the night everyone that was a tourist was charged 10 Euro each for listening to the music in the restaurant. One by one we saw patrons leaving disgruntled and then when we received our bill we understood why. Shame on these restaurants for targeting tourists.
Lively!. Stunning views by the day and a party place at night. Quaint little walking street uphill with loads of kiosks serving wine and beer and loads of food places

Pleasant stroll. St Anthony dominates the square. It is pleasant to stroll the narrow streets with a non threatening atmosphere although we were warned of pickpockets but did not experience this. Close to the waterfront and plenty of pavement cafes and shade. Nice tiles.

Lovely town! . Great place to visit, well worth getting lost in the streets of Alfama, beautiful little town. The streets are narrow and the town is full of all sorts of great restaurants and eclectic shops, loved it here!

Alfama living!. Rented flat behind Pantheon. Terrific location to public transport/train, Sat flea market, restaurants, square. Took intro tour with Bruno (withlocals https://www.facebook.com/bruno.m.guerra.1)
fabulous weather, fab location

Get Lost in the Labyrinth. Most travellers will head to this old part of the lively city. Set on a hillside it is best explored on foot as alleys are narrow and some traffic free. Get lost but keep heading downhill from the lookout and you will end up near the port area. Take your time and stop off at the tiny cafes and shops.

Great views!. Take the bus 737 to avoid steep climbs. It drops you close to the entrance where no other tram/bus goes. Views are fabulous! You can still go inside and enjoy the castle if you don't want to climb deep inside.
Walk down to the Cathedral from there. The streets are pretty!
Beautiful and historic neighborhood. The history and viewpoints in this area are amazing. A lot to learn here and beautiful buildings. I recommend a walking tour.

Great. Pretty area of lisbon with a few awesome view points..
Lots of nice restaurants .. but have been warned about pocket pickers..so keep an open eye. Not something i have experienced though.

A Little Maze. A lovely area to get lost in! narrow streets, most of them are up hill and the cobbles quite slippery in places, nice atmosphere and true taste of how Lisbon use to be. Worth a walk round if your legs can take it.

Beautiful neighborhood . Beautiful neighborhood, full of colors and local streets.
It is full of tourists, though- still a must go to if you're in Lisbon!

Great tour of Alfama!. I took the Alfama tour with Cuco! He was very knowledgable and told us many interesting facts about Alfama. There are some great views on the walk and prepare for a lot of walking! I´m very happy I took the tour and was not wandering alone around Alfama, because I feel like I got a great overview of the neighborhood by taking the tour!

Not To Be Missed!. Another great walking area in Lisbon. There is a plethora of sights to see and smells to appreciate in Alfama. The area just reeks of excitement and should not be missed by those who have come to soak up the history of Portugal.
Loved it!. I highly recommend you to visit this area of Lisbon! Amazing people and atmosphere will make you see Portugese life !!!

Beautiful neighborhood!. Well worth a few hours to explore around. The houses are beautiful, many of the them have the typical Portuguese azulejos. A great place to get to know Lisbon better and escape the tourist crowds at the same time.

Atmospheric and hilly. Alfama really mirrors Bairro Alto on the other side of the Baixa. It's a network of narrow streets built on a steep hillside on the way up to Graca. The Miradouro das Portas do Sol offers a great view of the riverfront and the surrounding area, though it can get very busy at times. The celebrated 28 tram runs up the hill past the Sé de Lisboa and through Alfama but can get busy in both directions (generally standing room only - and watch out for pickpockets). There's a top-notch Saturday morning Flea Market or Feira da Ladra round the side /rear of the colossal São Vicente de Fora church - some great stuff for sale if you care to lug it home.
Visit at day and night. Visit the castle at day time (be aware of sun direction) to view Lisbon and come at night to see the street restaurants.

The scent of old Lisbon. I liked just to walk through the streets, to bump into a restaurant and take a seat and eat.Even if you come unprepared, if you just stroll down the streest, every house speaks for itself.

best place in lisbon. alfama is my fav place in lisbon. i liked it a lot. its fascinating. you can get lost in the little streets and dream about the people who lived there once. colorful in any means . the buildings the culture etc. if you visit lisbon you cant miss it
Amazing area:). One of the best area to visit in the city,, specially the big castle ,, the entrance fee is very reasonable..the view is fascinating..
Great. Great old part of Lisbon. Mamy different side streets to wonder down and churches to pop into. Very good area.
Beautiful. Great neighbourhood to sleep and eat in -- the old city is stunning. Lots of little cafes and bars with Fado music, esp on the weekends.

lovery district. if you visit Lisbon, the alfama district it is a "must". because it wasn't destroy by the 1755 earthquake, it is a mirror of a typical Portuguese-Moorish middle age style. the have love the street and the stairs. great walking- but you must have comfortable and adequate shoes.
Older at part of town . Off waterfront & has great winding streets, restaurants, shops, etc. It's great to see this by the electric bike tour. It's a very large area & has a lot of historic sites.
Wonderful time in Lissabon. . Great time in AlfamaKey apartment. Fantastic hosteses Pedro and Madalena. And we loved all the help to find thins to explore.

Nice to wander around. We got there on Tram 28 which is worth a trip on its own.
Nice cobbled streets(most of Lisbon is cobbled though), interesting little side streets/passages, lots of small cafes.
Didn't seem to be too busy unlike the main touristy bits of the city.
Interesting old buildings and great views/

Landmark area not to be missed.. This part of Lisbon is a landmark area with narrow roads and interesting historical architecture of narrow face buildings. Walking up starting from Baixa to Se Cathedral, Castelo and Miraduro de Santa Luzia could be tiresome, however gives a lot of opportunity to catch nice views of the city and Tejo River.
This neighbourhood has real character . This was my favourite neighbourhood visit on our day tour around Lisbon. When visiting this neighbourhood you get a real sense of the culture.
Colourful district. We visited at the time of the annual Lisbon Sardine Festival, where there was music, crowds, food galore. The streets are hilly so be prepared for steps

The city of Light!. Lisbon is an illuminated city. The almost constant presence of sunshine and the River Tagus and the sea transform this city into a kaleidoscope highlighting the city’s architecture and beauty. There are many things to see and do in Lisbon that visitors have access to a wide array of different experiences.Explore the city in the old tram (15 and 28) and visit Alfama, Bairro Alto and wander in the narrow streets, the streets are filled with heritage monuments and characteristic neighbourhoods where the city first developed and can still be experienced at its most genuine level.Visit Lisbon of the River Tagus, whose riverfront is dedicated to leisure activities and links the monumental zone of Belém with the modern area of the Parque das Nações.Have fun in Lisbon, where nightlife continues till dawn.Want some calm head to the city’s parks, gardens, belvederes, cafés and esplanades. You can also enjoy Lisbon, through its gastronomy, luxury hotels, spas and shopping centres.
Fascinating. A magical place with narrow streets and many stairways around. Definitely ride a tram and go to see the castle.

Old town with a view. nice view across the river Tagus but very difficult to park your vehicle so best way use a Tuk Tuk or tram, if you are lucky you may listen to some one playing a accordion or saxophone!

Just let yourself get lost. This is the neighborhood to let yourself get lost in. Wandering the narrow streets and stairways you come to one surprise after another, a church, a view, a cafe, street art, interesting shops. There are beautiful buildings with tiles of all colors. Laundry flaps in the breeze. People are lying their lives and seem undisturbed by your wandering by. Lots of great places to eat and many sites to see. Go enjoy!

Interesting. I find other places and cultures fascinating. The he hills in lisboa and the narrow walk ways along with uneven cobblestone was quaint. I love to walk so I very much enjoyed everything. There are no malls but tiny shops where the proprietors live next door or above.

Great time. Lots to do, ride the tram, see the castles, take the train from Rossarip Station to Sintra, go to the many waterfront sqaures and definitely hit the 2nd hand market on friday and Saturdays.

Lovely old town a must visit . We stayed here for nearly three weeks, it is central to everything and has the most charming old streets and with the famous tram 28 rumbling through adds to the character of this old Alfarma district. Some of the best restaurants and little charming bars are found here too, this is a must experience in Lisbon!

We took a Tuk Tuk with a funny guide. Our guide was quite knowledgeable about the history, stores, with good prices and flea markets in the Alfama. He more importantly knew how to negotiate the labryinth of streets. I felt like I was on the set of the movie "Blade Runner"
Just have a wander and don't forget your camera.. We took a crowded tram up into this area, enjoyed the views and then wandered down alleyways and staircases. Very interesting and uncrowded.
Get lost . I love getting lost in this area. Gorgeous and never gets not going looking at the view, buildings, and local Tascas

The view is fabulous!. Don't miss to come up here! We were supposed to take the tram, but it was so crowded that we decided to take a Tuk Tuk instead. That was ingenious I can tell you! We could see a lot and the drivers (we had three different drivers on different tours) told us a lot that was worth to know!

"Great lookout point overlooking the Tagus Estuary". As the upper terminus of the quaint historical tramcars servicing the Castilho Heights, this impressive lookout dominates the view in every direction, is adjacent to the ancient castle and many typical local eateries cramming the fascinating narrow alleyways.

Liveliest Neighborhood in Lisbon. Don't visit Lisbon without visiting this neighborhood, particularly in the evening. There are narrow, winding, steep streets. But around every corner is a festival of music, dancing, grilling, eating, drinking, and people of all ages outside enjoying themselves.
Lisbon walker tour. Go for the Lisbon walker tour. We have taken similar tours in Denmark and Sydney, being impressed by the quality of the guide and information given to us.
Well worth the walk!. Breathtaking views!! An absolute must see for all tourists. Quite a trek up a lot of hills, but worth every step!!!!!!!!

Great place to live!. We stayed in Alfama for 4 nights and just across a famous fado place- lovely place to live, if you don't mind the music in the late evenings. Much better than spending on posh hotels (if you are the exploring type).
Location Location Location. Eclectic and different. A wide variety of restaurants, cafes and a wonderful diverse area of Lisbon. Safe and worth the walk. Some great views of the city

Don't miss Alfama, must visit!. Alfama, the old quarter of Lisbon, built around the castle on top of the hill.Survived, in part, to the big earthquake of 1755, and today is one of the most popular sights of Lisbon. Don't miss the beautiful viewpoints (Portas do Sol, Senhora do Monte), the Lisbon Cathedral, St Antonio of Padua birthplace, and also the old Jewish Quarter (Judiaria). Don't miss also the Roman Theatre, amazing museum just next close to the Cathedral, showing how Lisbon was 2000 years ago with the Romans.You can easily spend a day just exploring Alfama.
Family holiday. Fantastic area to stay, traditional streets with lots of great little places to eat. Very safe, plenty of photo opportunities. Close to Metro stations.

A place to get lost. . Cool place to get lost. Just go around and see all the nice shops and small restaurants. It is one of the best places to appreciate "Fado", the typical Portuguese music. At night you can listen in some restaurants or for free in some special places.

Charming walk. Get lost in the streets of Alfama. We wanted to see a lot and took time to walk in this very nice neighbourhood. Good sneakers, flat shoes are recommended to get lost in this charming part of the city.

warm but charming!. Wonderful and charming part of the old part of Lisbon! It was such a hot day that though, we like walking up the hills to the castle, we took a taxi /5 euros/ which brought us to the very doors of the castle St . George. The view from the walls of the fortress all over the old city and the center of Lisbon, is breathtaking.But even more charming is the road back to the center! Beautiful cafe and restaurants, musicians and small tramways to and fro...In good mod we spent more then two hours in the old city ...

Charm Worth the Effort. Beautiful views and heart pumping strolls. Feel free to take the tram or other transportation up the hill; that way you won't pass out before getting to enjoy the view. Also, stop by Santiago de Alfama for lunch or dinner on your way up to or down from the castle. It's well worth it. The pastries are divine.
Beautiful Baixa. Beautiful Baixa of Lisbon. Lovely town, must see! Plenty of terraces to enjoy a coffee. Enjoy your stay.

Very cool, very fun; if you can see past the grotty litter ridden streets. I'm a little precious, I know this, but this is because I come from a pretty clean, well organised, smog free country/environment. So when I find I have to walk over rubbish in my travels, the lustre is quickly removed.The above said, it truly is an interesting area and well worth exploring.

Amazing food and Fado music. . Getting lost in Alfama streets is one of life's treasures. Throw away your map and wonder. Keep your mind open and stomach empty when you start. You'll soon find your own hidden gems including amazing charcoal roasted sardines in season. Beware the beer prices are high by lisbon standards but that is the only down side. Fado music live is so passionate. Narrow streets, occasional Vistas open to family run restaurants. June is the best time for their festivals. And don't forget about a siesta afterwards

Lovely walk around Old Lisbon . Perfect way to get to understand and explore Lisbon. Small streets, that don't accommodate cars make for a wonderful half day stroll. This is why people come to European cities, to wander and explore.

A Must See In Lisbon. The neighborhood is a must see when visiting Lisbon. It is a throw back to time gone by and has so much charm and character that you will barely notice how many hills you have climbed! That being said this is no place for uncomfortable shoes. The slick stone streets have some serious inclines and declines and it is virtually the only way to see the sites. During the day you can explore the weaving narrow streets and paths seeing historic sites…at night the smells of sardines and traditional cooking take over.

Wonderful Alfama Tuk Tuk Tour. My husband and I hired a tuk tuk driver (Joao) for an hour tour of Alfama. We loved him and his passion for the city he loves so much. One hour turned into two as he saw how much we also loved this city!

Bohemian Lisbon. Colorful neighborhood in Lisbon close to the waterfront. Full of cafes, restaurants and (Fado) bars. This is the oldest neighborhood in the city and is full of 18th-19th century buildings. The winding, narrow maze of cobbled lanes are a joy to explore. Forget taking a map, just get 'hopelessly' lost for you will most certainly end up discovering something worthwhile. The neighborhood is build into a hillside, so be prepared for many ups and downs - your calf muscles will get a workout, but the numerous gelato shops and bakeries in the area will make it worth it! The entire district is currently undergoing a major gentrification, so there is quite a bit of construction going on. I just hope this doesn't ruin the 'rough-around-the-edges bohemian character of the neighborhood. Only time will tell.

Scroll around once it gets dark. Spirit of Free and specific Lisbon. Quarters if Portugal, Brazil, Europe, Africa all mixed. Food is good, people are nice, not very expensive and somewhat a good mixture if types of places from restaurants to stand up bars.
Great neighborhood. Stayed here in a VRBO. Lovely place but be prepared to walk steep hills. There are hundreds of small shops and great places to grab a drink or bite to eat.
Pretty neighborhood!. Nice area in close proximity to Jorge Castle. Keep in mind that there are nice souvenir shops all around, but the best restaurants are not here.
Must see. ...indeed, you must see the view from this point - especially if you don't have time to take a tour. Wonderful panorama and lots of re-fuelling stops scattered around.

The stink of beer and grilled fish. We caught a tram 28E and after travelling through part of Alfama, we were dropped off in an unpromising looking square with the castle looming somewhere above us. Having walked to and around the (far too expensive at 8 euros) castle and.then wandered down to lower Alfama. It's not that well signposted and you need a map, because you can't always see either the Tagus of the castle to get your bearings. At last we started to see the narrow streets and alleys foe which it is famous for. Everywhere were the signs of hard partying the previous night. The aroma of beer led us into the alleys where empty beer bottles, plastic glasses and discarded food plates were everywhere. They were being swept up or hosed down by small armies of council workers. The closed bars and grills were each side of the streets and very few buildings didn't have one outside it. The tinsel garland festooned streets went on for ages before leading us down to the river and open spaces. I loved it but unfortunately, I could only imagine what it would have been like to be there the night before!

Great party atmosphere . It's a few weeks after St Anthony celebrating but the party continues. The streamers are still hanging and the locals are out every night. Restaurants have setup makeshift tables and chairs, kegs at the ready, and lots of music. We wondered the streets of Adams earlier in the day to scope out some places to eat but from the afternoon til the time we arrived, not a lot looked familiar. It had transformed into this huge party for the whole neighborhood. Food was cooked on outdoor BBQs. The specialty was sardines and pork, beer and found music. A great way to spend a few hours immersed in local traditions.

Over touristed. This community is interesting however not very accommodating to tourist. The restaurants are all overpriced and not very good. it's a nice stroll there however through some tight alleys and walkways. Not a must-see of Lisbon.

not to miss. what a great part of the city of Lisbon. unbelievable views, nice small streets and pleasant atmosphere. Wonderful Castelo de Sao Jorge. But BEWARE!!! I was pickpocket either on the 28 tram or at the castelo. security on the ground were not very helpful and seemed used to hearing complaints about theft

Cute little neighborhood. Was a little tricky to find this place but glad we were able to get a glimpse of it. We were able to visit a couple of shops, bought some coffee bean from a sweet lady that owed the store and found some nice hand made souvenirs from this arts and crafts place, Reedio santos. Wish I had more time to experience this lovely place but had to rush to dinner at CR (which was terrible). Would definitely recommend to make some time for this place. I think shops and restaurants starts to open later in the evening.
Average. Not worth coming to Lisbon on its own. There was nothing special but it was interesting. A lot of tourists.
Alfama. Quirky, lovely streets and people... Great, cheap places to eat and many more to drink ;) Do go during the Festas de Santo Antonio. Just brilliant
Great area to visit. The Alfama neighborhood is a great historic place to see. Beautiful architecture and great cafes and restaurants.

Beware of pickpockets. Police station could be the most visited location in Lisbon. I spent almost 2 hours there to report the loss of my wallet. It was so crowded and the traffic was high too. One left and another arrived at no time. Seemed like a lot of tourist lost their belongings. I met one Beijing Dama. She was crying on the phone when some one came in and gave back her waist bag. She had her passport back and lost only some money. I was not that lucky to have some one return my wallet (I did not lost my passport). The photo is the Tourist Police (PSP) Station in Palácio Foz, Plaça Restauradores #bewareofpickpockets #lennonineurope2016

Wear comfortable shoes. blessed with lovely sunshine we walked the cobbled streets of Alfama which had more than enough to keep us interested. A great spot for views from the castle, churches, museums, restaurants, night time bars and daytime cafe's.

If you like medieval buildings and cobblestone streets with a qu. If you like medieval buildings and cobblestone streets with a quaint quiet feel yet in a fascinating capital city you can't beat the alfama.

Flowers and laundries on the balconies.... An old residential district with nice & interesting architecture. Lots of narrow streets with flowers and laundries on the balconies... If you visit Alfama during the June, you will be lucky to be a part of the Sardine Festival (entire June)... Also don't forget to listen Fado in Alfama!

An ordinary neighborhood without the wow factor.. Lisbon looks very dilapidated and the streets are very narrow. More so in the alfama area . Though there are 3-4 areas of attractions in Lisbon, after some time, the areas are no different in the way that they are dilapidated , narrow and feel generally unsafe. Nice to visit for an hour but you will feel bored after that.

Gladly get lost in this place. Strolling down the meandering streets of Alfama in the late afternoon is a good way to wind down your day tour of Lisbon. Then stop for some tapas or grilled Portuguese sardines with wine as you enjoy watching people pass by.
Wonderful. Gorgeous views lovely people what more do you need - just walk round and enjoy lovely - needs good shoes cobblestones every where

Lovely.. Nice area to walk around, the look out is just amazing. Lisbon is very hilly and there are many nice picture perfect spots and this one is defently my top choice. The corlful roof tops, so cute. Good restaurants like most places in Lisbon.

Beautiful Historic neighborhood. Luckily, we had a tourguide to help us navigate the "streets" of the Alfama neighborhood. The history of the buildings was fascinating, and the culture of the small community was so warm and inviting. Lots of walking and exploring. Wear walking shoes to ensure good footing throughout the neighborhood.
Unique!. One of the most beautiful places in Europe . the most charismatic neighborhood of Lisbon and Portugal and one of the oldest in the world. Unmissable!

LOVED WALKING THIS OLD HISTORICAL PART OF Lisbon. There are lots of tour options in Lisbon but the Alfama one is a must, We did 2 walking tours on the same day, and yes we were tired when the Alfama tour finished but it was well worth it. I think its important to mention that there a lot of steps to climb, this tour may be difficult for an unfit person,

Discover Portugal!. This beautiful zone of Lisbon allows you to discover just how lovely Portugal is. The kindness of their people and the charm of a city that seems to be lost in time. Be sure to stay away from the really touristic sites and take the chance to walk in the small hidden rows that lead to the real Alfama.We had the incredible chance to reach a neighbourhood party that lasted up to 2 am, where we had amazing food and met a lot of nice people!

Perfect location. We stayed in Alfama for a weekend break. If you like old mixed with new,this is it. You have the back streets of the old town, full of quaint little bars,authentic Portuguese restaurants and fantastic views over the city. Add the tram system and friendly locals giving total enjoyment. Brilliant.
Best part of town. Most typical neighborhood of Lisbon with many things to see and to do. Fado, food and fun, all in one.

Old, windy streets. Interesting to see the only area that was not rebuilt after the earthquake in 1755. Also we went to a small restaurant, I guess you could call it (had a few tables) Cantinho da Rute, where we had Ginjinha + tapas (the chorizo is grilled at your table!)

Energetic, confusing neighborhood with spectacular views. Fun area to visit. Many restaurants and bars. Multiple places offer fado. Adjoins the central squares - busy, fun. Alfama is very hilly, so be prepared for that, especially if you walk to the castle. But there are plenty of taxis and tuktuks. Also, a tram provides a useful route, but the cars are full of sightseers, so less effective as a mode of point -to - point transportation. Easy to get lost as there are many small, twisty roads, few of which showed up on my tourist map. My tip...try to find routes that follow the tram tracks as much as possible. Then, you need only remember the few turns off the tramway.

A Must Visit. Alfama is the old original city when Lisbon was founded. Full of quaint small streets, patios and old trolleys that still run. The area is hilly and you need to be in good shape and have good walking shoes.

Historic quarters. This is the oldest part of Lisbon so lots of small pedestrian streets. Bring comfortable shoes !!! Do not miss the Mirador de Santa Luzia. You can get a ride in the old yellow trams

Fun and quaint. We wondered around the neighbourhood for an afternoon. It was very interesting walking along narrow streets, in and out of small local stores and watching locals relaxing and chatting inside and outside cafes and restaurants. A real Lisbon experience!

Worth wandering!. Beautiful neighborhood! Take the #12E tram to the top of the hill (near the castle) and spend the next hour or two wandering random streets as you head down the hill toward the waterfront. The streets and alleys are all filled with character and plenty of gorgeous views over the water. Bring your camera. Let yourself get lost (you'll end up at the water as long as you don't start heading back up the hill). Have fun!

Old Lisbon. We docked on a cruise liner just at the foot of this district. luckily we have a friend who lives in Lisbon and she met us to show us around. Tiny and narrow cobble streets led us up to the castle St George for some wonderful views of this city. also the famous No.28 tram trundles through the centre, which is a sight in itself! Brilliant day..

Staying in Alfama. We had previously stayed in the Chiado district and weren't sure about moving this time to Alfama, but we are so glad we did. Our hotel is quiet but a few minutes up to the castle, and a few minutes down into the wonderful labyrinth that is the old Alfama, filled with life, smells and music. We have loved this area and will probably choose this side again next time.
A great neighborhood to experience in the evening. Fun neighborhood that comes alive at night. Wander the narrow streets, find and outdoor restaurant, listen to fado and make a few friends.

The real Lisbon. he beauty of Alfama is to walk through its streets and be part of the "barrio". Being from Chile its inevitable to think about Valparaiso, but of course Lisbon is very well preserved and taken care of.

must visit. Alfama is the old district of Lisbon famous for Fado. The buildings are traditional and a bit worse for wear but that is what creates such a great atmosphere.We went along taking in the sights while passing lovely little cafes with people enjoying their drinks. Everywhere we went there was music - we were there during the festival.of St-Antoine Lovely street parties,bustling & friendly. .Alfama is a must visit by tram or toktok and the view of Lisbon is incredible from the square.Everyone we encountered was friendly and we can't wait to visit again.
Great Experience. It is trully a magic place! So many culture mix and happiness on the streets, specially on June nights!
Fun district with lovely city views. Start at the top with the castle and work your way down the curvy brick lined streets full of tiny shops and cafes. Definitely worth a walkabout.

Wander around and be surprised. The only way to see the Alfama is to wander in, get lost (you can't, really) and be surprised at every turn of the narrow winding cobblestoned alleyways. Lovely, safe, highly recommended.

Loose your self on the streets. Very tipical and nice neighberhood , its nice to walk around, take pictures , enjoy the view from the balconies to the river.Important Thing: Dont eat there , 99% of the restaurants are crap . Very expensive and bad. The sardines are not fake but frozen and during the Saint Antony festivaties they charge more than 2.5 Euros per last year frozen sardines.

Alfama by night. I was there during and after the festival.of St-Antoine
Best street party, very crowded and good fried cod with drinks.
Return for lunch by the tramway, it was my best day in Lisbon.Alfama is a must visit by tram or toktok and the view of Lisbon is incredible from many terrace
charming. lovely narrow streets, block partys, very lively and good restaurants. Went there to eat and had a walk afterwards which was a perfect ending of the evening

Old town - must see and walk thru. Definitely one of the must see parts of Lisbon. Walking thru the picturesque narrow streets in Alfama you feel set back in time and know how it must have been many years ago. Cute little streets to walk up and down, stop over for a cerveja and a quick bite and continue on. On your way to Castelo de Sao Jorge a must.

Like stepping into another world. Alfama is the old district of Lisbon famous for Fado. The buildings are traditional and a little worse for wear but that is what creates such an amazing atmosphere.We strolled along taking in the sights while passing lovely streetside cafes with people enjoying a glass of wine. Everywhere we went there was the sound of Fado music and there are plenty of choices if you would like to sit and listen.Everyone we encountered was friendly and I can't wait to visit again
Pretty streets. Not quite the quaint streets we had in mind, quite run down un parts and not entirely what we had in mind but it was still interesting. Great views from the top.
Beautiful place. Alfama is a beautiful place. You can stay here and relax and watch Lisbon on the top.If you want to go in Alfama you have to take the metro to Santa Apolonia station.
Such a lovely view. Really nice during the Summer as the view is amazing. Remember to take plenty of water as walking around is a good idea.

A very picturesque part of old Lisbon. This is a delightful and very pretty area to stay, with small shops and cafes within easy walk of the centre of town and the ferry port, and situated on the infamous 26 tram route
Beautiful neighborhood. I loved strolling through the Alfama neighborhood. It was very colorful with the little art shops. Tried some little cafes and restaurants and loved the time I was there.

A walk for imagination. Out of all my visited places in Lisbon, this was the best. Though it was not any particular place and also I could not visit the cathedrals and pantheons and cafes and all streets, but I injected whole Lisbon inside me by just being there. It has endless spots to stop and feel. It has story of generations in it. It has mood and life and sorrow and romance.The best way to visit Alfama district is, just get lost in it .....

Your 5 senses.. ALIVE!. This area is a residential area with tall houses, and windy streets which were built around the houses. The neighbours can touch eachothers hands when they stick their hand out the window, ladies sell their potted plants on their window sills, the smell of home cooking warms the air, the sound of birds and the radio fill your ears rather than the honling cars two streets below. There is a lot of walking because Lisbon is a city of 7 hills so there are lots of stiars and not reccomended for anyone with a wheelchair/ pushchair / baby / cannot walk well. But it is just amazing how such a cute little village exists in the heart of the city! Our tour guide also told us it is one of the safest places in the city and all the neihbours are so so friendly! Highly rccomended!!

Beautiful place, great atmosphere. Wonderful place. You can wonder for hours, get lost in the small traversas and ruas, get beautiful sights and corners. All the while, you feel perfectly safe all the time (as always in Lisbon), and get a chance to stop for a glass of refreshing vinho verte in one of the many tascas. Great place indeed.

Oldest part of Lisbon; madness during the parties in June. This year, we visited Lisbon for the second time. Alfama is my favourite part of the city: small streets, steep stairs and beautiful views due to the difference in heights. We were lucky to visit during the huge party in June, which turns Lisbon (and especially Alfama) into one big crowd of dancing, drinking en partying people. The atmosphere is great, with (live) music everywhere, improvised bars and the famous BBQs with fresh sardines grilled while you wait.

Beautiful place for a wander. Alfama is full of cool things to see, and locals to meet. While walking around keep an eye out for places selling shots of Ginjinha liquer, which tastes like cherries. You can get it plain or in a chocolate shotglass; I recommend trying both!
Saints Day madness. Lovely place, hilly but scenic. A real buzz about the place when we visited on the Saint's day - lots of friendly locals and fresh BBQ'd sardines. Yum.
Fados and Delicacies. Good neighborhood to listen to not so sad fados, small eateries that serve up local delicacies. Bacalhau and Assad but watch the wine lists. Cover charges are common
What a lovely neighbourhood. We've been here for whole two days and nights. its very quiet and nice and safe by night. the view is beautiful and there are a lot of good cafés and restaurants
11th June. Big party with a lot of people. You have to go on the day of the poets, it is awesome and Lisbon has numerous parties in the streets.

Happy days in Lisbon. loved this amazing city. Recommend hop on hop off bus to get around. Lots of choice for eating . We took the train to Sintra which cost 9.60 Euros each return on the train for 40 mins well worth taking the bus from outside the train station in Sintra up to see the palace.

Just an elevator ride away. Each visitor to Lisbon has their own favourite part of what is an intriguing and diverse city. If paris and San Francisco had a child, it would be Lisbon. Our preferred location was Alfama, easily accessible by (free) public elevators. We like the cobbled, medieval and Moorish flavour of the place. It was beautiful in the daylight, walking on the sunny side of the city, intriguing in the rain and safe in the evening, with strains of fado on the night air. We liked the walkable cobbled streets, although this is not a place for choosing fashion over sturdiness in footwear. There are many welcoming cafés where you can slip inside for a cold beer or enjoy a cappuccino on the terrace either in sun or shade. This is also the part of the city that seems to have the most interesting stores filled with artifacts, antiques, arts and crafts - most at very reasonable prices.

Typical Lisbon with alleys and Fado music.. The small alleys of the Alfama area are one of the highlights of Lisbon. It seems best to represent the old local spirit of Lisbon. Loads of places to go to hear Fado as well. From on top, the view over Lisbon is spectacular. The trip up wit tramway 28 or 12 is alone wort the excursion.
Wonderful Place. Spend a little time walking around this neighbor, enjoy the sounds and smalls of Lisbon. The view is wonderful well worth the trip

So Interesting. This is the old Moorish part of the city - very steep cobbled streets and very old buildings, So many things to see in the area. Well served by the Trams and buses and easy to walk to down town Lisbon. (not so easy climbing back up though!) Wonderful view points from the castle and from a restaurant ( forgotten name) nearby! Fabulous restaurants, coffee places and bars. Some restaurants/bars have locals or staff singing and playing guitars in Fado style. Would recommend a visit or even a stay in some of the lovely hotels and apartments in this area.
Loose yourself. The winding roads and cute bistros are just a part of this Portuguese gem Steeped in history with great views of the river and skyline

Cozy, easy-going area. The atmosphere in the narrow, steep streets of Alfama is very enjoyable. Choose a bar or restaurant with local customers and eat a fresh custard pie, pasteis de nata with an expresso or coffee with hot milk.
Very Lisbon, very beautiful. The view is iconic and a must visit. Take the tram here if you don't like the climb. A photo op is a must. Get here early to avoid the crowds.

Charming & A Street Party!. We visited Lisbon during the annual celebrations to St. Anthony and the streets of the Alfama were decked out with decorations and food and drink stations all over. If you have a chance to visit during this time its one massive street party and so much fun. Everyone is very friendly and open. Loved the Alfama!
Feel the culture. The winding streets and feel of "real life" make this historic neighbourhood a worthwhile venture. Stop in a local tavern or two to soak up the atmosphere.

An Enjoyable Stroll Through Old Lisbon. After seeing the Castelo de São Jorge, we spent the afternoon wondered down the hill through the narrow, historic streets and alleyways of Alfama. Be sure to stop at the Sé (Lisbon Cathedral) and Igreja Santo Antonio (Saint Anthony Church). Do not hesitate to explore the various shops in the area; and, take a mid-afternoon lunch break at any of the many restaurants. A very pleasant and recommended way to spend the afternoon in Lisbon!

Put on your walking shoe Size!. There are more curves and twists to h neighborhood than you can imagine.many darling lanes, ladies barbecuing sardines in restaurants with 4 seats. Laundry blows in the wind over tile covered walls and gusty alleyways. The barrio is so vertical that it sometimes feels like you are in a Lego structure about to to topple over
Old town. This is the old district of Lisbon, it is worth the visit . The steep streets are very picturesque .
Alfama. Great for evening entertainment. Best to get there about 10 pm onwards. Meal and then street dancing. Wine and beer 1 euro each!

Old Lisbon. This is an area of great interest architecturally, and has some wonderful old streets full of little shops where you can browse through local artists' crafts and other items. Unfortunately, much of the entire city of Lisboa was under construction during my visit this June, but hopefully that's a good sign for the economy and tourism. There are plenty of excellent bars and restaurants in the Alfama, where you can enjoy a glass of vinho verde and some olives, and it was noticeable that the choice of music in even the most unassuming little bars was really excellent. If it wasn't the saudade of Fado, it was the soulful sound of jazz....
Cobbled area in old district of Lisbon. Twisty cobbled streets, easy to get lost in. Sometimes felt a little unsafe and unsavory in certain alleys. Great Thieves market on Saturday!
old town. If you want to have a feel of the old lisbon, just wander around Alfama!. Always surprising and everytime different!

Take a trip back to the past. For me this is a place you most visit if you are in Portugal and near Lisbon. The small narrow streets, squares, colors and architecture of this area is truly amazing and difficult the find anywhere else. I could spend days exploring this area. This for me is what Portugal is all about.

Traditional . A neighborhood you can live the Portuguese traditions the most. With plenty of viewing points you can see the river and lots of the old buildings.There's ups and downs - good for your legs ;) - small streets and villas and not many cars. You can enjoy the Portuguese cousin at every corner and talk to local people. Very friendly

Part of Lisbon bringing you back in time. Explore the part of Lisbon that surely transports you back in centuries of old streets and shop. With Castelo Sao Jorge sitting at the top, certainly worth the 8e ticket for a visit. Great street restaurants and surprises. Best to take the tram up, and walk down
Alfama. Fun place to visit, with good views and load of interesting restaurants.We really enjoyed spending time in the St. Anthony Museum. It is small, but very informative.
A must to visit in Lisbon. If you whant to meet the old Lisbon, you must go there, specially during June, were in every road you can find little parties cslled "Arraial".Very good home made sardines!

The core of medieval Lisbon. No doubt about it ... Alfama is hilly enough to make San Francisco look like Saskatchewan but it's compact and, with a little work, accessible by foot throughout. If you're tired just jump on a tram or one of the ubiquitous electric tuk-tuk tour carts. Lots of churches, museums, art, tourist sights, cafés, fado bars! No need to speak Portuguese. There's plenty of English, French and German to take care of language challenged tourists.

Vista Linda. This is a great spot to have a coffee have a meal and sit and do nothing or go to the museums nearby. A fado in one of the bars nearby makes me have a feeling of saudades . Wished I was there now!
The heart of old Lisbon. This is a must see when you visit Lisbon. Fado, Restaurants and history. Close to the cruise terminal. Many tours available.

fun place to walk around. Great area to walk around and get lost. This is the oldest area of Lisbon and the streets are very narrow. It is very lively at night, a place you must visit when in Lisbon. Lots of Sardines and other fish options, take in all 5 senses
Small road and cute. an area with has rich history, small but cute, many steep hill. Keep on going up until get the castle.!

Funky and fun. Wandering the alley's was simply wonderful. We took a taxi in the morning from our hotel to Castelo de Sao Jorge and then walked down the hills through the Alfama. Made for a comfortable walk.

Quaint and lovely atmosphere and characteristically traditional Portugal. Love it!. Really fun to go on the tram and explore the local area, great pastelleria treats and quaint atmosphere of Almama the old city.

Nice to stroll around . Visited Alfama during the June Saints festival and the place was a buzz with people frying sardines and drinking and dancing. Was a great atmosphere. Lots of hills and twisting little alley ways. This was the red light district during the time of the great earthquake and was undamaged by it so a lot of the old worldness still remains. Take care with the hills and bring water. There are nice little bakeries and wine bars dotted about the place here too. It's easy to get lost there.

walk slowly, look around, observe and experience. You have to do all those above in order to understand and enjoy this old city. Be prepared to walk inclines and steps. Excellent exprience of Lisbon, and be rewarded with nice views of the city and theh sea at the top

it is still an authentic neighbourhood. in Alfama you'll find regular people live, bbq in the narrow streets, kids playing.... still very authentic and getting more and more crowded with tourists every year...

Alfama has its vibes. Alfama during the Saint Antonio fest is blossoming: music, songs, colours, flags everywhere! People are friendly and tried to help and give directions just for the sake of making us feel at home. Sardinas and vinho verde offered like if we were family.

Alfama old and interesting. This is the old original Jewish Quarter of Lisbon. It is extremely popular with tourists who walk the narrow winding streets with old red roofed houses and restaurants providing plenty of colours and views. The cobbled streets are okay in the dry but may prove slippery when wet.In the evening it is a magnet for locals and visitors because of the many restaurants and the atmosphere.Highly recommend a walk through here.

Worth checking out . My husband and I stayed here for two nights, one of which was the Santo Antonio Festival where the whole city shuts down the streets to eat, drink and dance. It is amazing. This area is a great mix of tourists and local living the he steep hills and sharing life. Worth checking out but pace yourself on the steep hills.
Go for the views!. Nice little cafes and parks with a wonderful views of Lisbon and all the red roof tops, the river etc. It's a good hike up or you can take a tram or cab or bus.

Medieval Lisbon and good exercise. The old Alfama district contrasts markedly with the grid-layout of the 18th-century Baixa. It is a colorful area that also offers the opportunity to walk up the steep and twisting lanes.
Alfama district. Small streets, small houses, a few restaurants. Nice to walk through and splendid views over the city.

Pintoresque inner city site for Lisbon. Alfama is set at the inner city of Lisbon. Full of visitors and lots of walking!! To get on board the cable card you will need to obtain the metro card on any station first. The line is busy but is worth the wait!! The cable car will take you places the "Tuk-Tuk" will not. Reach the top of Alfama and come down walking. Many squares on Alfama, lots of small places to have local beers or else! Alfama takes over an hour to visit. Gilberto- PR

Walk back in time in this moorish district. This is the oldest and most interesting district in the city - originally inhabited by the Moors, obviously its name is Arabic. Delightful maize of narrow sometimes very steep streets which leads from the city upto St George's Castle. Although once had a great status in the city it is now a trendy area of Lisbon.One way through Alfama is to ride on Tram 28 which is the most notable tourist attraction which great views of the city and the River Tagus. Please note this district has very limited public transport either walk, take a taxi or the tram.On you way up you will have the Cathedral, a good pit stop, great shops to look in,washing hanging out of windows - a real cultural district. Well worth a visit

Too much building works. We were disappointed with the overall appearancestors of the area due to many building works in progress, also the area did not meet our expectations at all,Porto is much better

Very Authentic. This place is the best district to explore the proper Lisbon. We stayed around the time of the fezzie of st Antonio and partied until dawn with the locals.Must go if you love sardines and want to see the real lisboa.

Great spot; lots of character!. A great area for walking and exploring "authentic" Lisbon. Still not too spoiled by tourism. Great restaurants, historical buildings, and great opportunities for some excellent photography.

Great way to spend an afternoon. The area is great way to get some nice views. If you're not in shape when you get there, you will be when you leave. Lots of areas to explore up and down steep streets.
Must do. If you are in Lisbon, Alfama is a must do. Old style and charming. You will see a real Lisbon here! There are many nice restaurants and coffee shops around

Interesting area. This part of Lisbon is well worth exploring. You need to be fairly fit as the streets are steep and I noticed that a number of people take a TukTuk tour to get around. The views from the various Miradouros in this area are amazing. I loved the narrow streets and the party feel during this last weekend when there were lots of stalls selling food and drink in many of the streets and lights and garlands festooned across the streets.

Plenty of tourists but also still a working class neighbourhood.. Have an apartment in the middle of Alfama. Perfect place for a short stay in Lisbon. You can walk almost anywhere from here. Local people were very friendly.
Authentic, charming part of Lisbon. Walk through the streets of Alfama to feel the oldest streets of the city. Utterly charming. Totally worth all the climbing!

Be prepared to walk. Did a 2-1/2 hr walking tour of Alfama and enjoyed it. There's a lot of history to this area of Lisbon. You need to be in shape and wear good walking shoes because this area is full of hills.

I love it.. Fantastic place, many things to see, restaurants, great views from top of hills. Although it is quite steep at times it is not a struggle to walk around. Also great place to visit in the night with many people having fun on Alfama's streets.

Get Lost n Alfama! . This is a must visit area of Lisbon. Churches, trolly cars, cobblestone streets that wind down the hills, fantastic city views, patio restaurants in alleyways and a castle for good measure. Put the map away and wander the streets to take it all in. Plan on spending half a day or more exploring.
Beautiful spot in Lisbon. Mediеval beautiful neighbourhood in the heart of Lisbon. Steep and narrow streets, but with trams :) Lovely tile covered facades

Awesome experience!. We ended up stumbling upon a large festival, St. Anthony's, in the streets of Alfama. Amazing time! A major plus here is its not overran with tourists. It's mostly locals, so as a tourist you can immerse yourself into their culture and society.

Wonderful district of Lisbon. This is a wonderful district of Lisbon to wander round.
Be prepared to walk and walk and discover the lovely streets , the castle and the cathedral. Great photo opportunities at every turn.
Go and enjoy !!
A little treasure . Well worth the visit, made even better when done by a local guide on a free walking tour. This is a must see and compliments all the beauty that Lisbon had to offer

Soo romantic!. Small narrow roads with laundry hanging outside like in a Disney movie. Plazas with restaurants and music makes this the most romantic city ever! Fado music in the allyes at night what more can you ask for?

So many great things to see and do. Put on good walking shoes as there are so many great tourist attractions in Alfama. You will need a really good map and help from others to find your way to and from the various sites. The sites however are very much worth the effort/cost.

Quaint, beautiful, bring your walking shoes. The best way to see authentic Old Lisbon, starting at the castle and ending at the waterfront. Bring your camera and prepare for a hike. You won't be sorry.

Old Town of Lisbon. Alfama is the old town of Lisbon with many cobbled streets and alleys leading around the back of the Castle. A visit to this area is highly recommended for those who don't mind steep climbs

Time to hear the bell singing!. I've never thought that a bell could have a singing ring to it and yes i experienced that on our stop-over at alfama viewing deck. The winding, tram-operated interior streets is quite an adventure riding on a tuktuk. Alfama is a section of the city where the older buildings and churches are (churches in Lisbon are quite aplenty). It is also a place where every winds and corners has a Fado restaurant featuring their best artist. Nice place of orange and white buildings reminiscent of the history of the place.

maze of alleys, staircases and hidden stories. The Alfama, the old quarter of Moors and Jews, keeps its atmosphere plenty of beauty and mistery, principally at the time the moon visits Lisbon…I call the Alfama a proof of faith because during the Great Earthquake, it was merely damaged (though its population wasn't exactly "good, old Christians" so, if this was a celestial punishment, why it didn't hurt the "infidels" first and most?)We didn't have an strict schedule what to visit, so we just start walking…then, we found fountains, read names of streets with old engraves that told us about who lived there and what did them do for living. Of course, a visit to the Cathedral is "a must" –this heavy, fortress-like building, has a few highlights worth to see.Two tips: (1) If Fados interest you and you're travelling around and visit also Coimbra, just leave the expensive (and very "tourist") recitals at the Alfama and go straigth to Santa Cruz café (beside the church with the same name, on 8 de Maio square)! There, you'll find local singers and exquisite guitarists (most of them, students al Coimbra's University) and a majority of Portuguese people from all over the country (that makes the evening much more interesting because they usually join the singers and you also can change a few words with locals)!! You don't have to pay any extra money, just the normal price for coffee or/and cake, and you can spend the whole night longing (if you understand the lyrics! otherwise: imagine!)(2) If you came to Lisbon by car, try to pick a spot at Bacalhoeiros street (very near Saramago's foundation). This street is one of the extremely rare streets with free parking! You can seat and drink a coffee nearby and ask some of the employees to have a look at the car now and then…we spent 3 nights in Lisbon and just left the car there from the very beginning (it's just worthless to drive in Lisbon!)

Very typical.. It is probably the most characteristic area, going back to roman and arab times, and still featuring a sort of medina in its upprt part. You can surely find a couple of jewels there: Sé, the cathedral, and Museu do Fado.

Joyfull Alfama. We were in Alfama last week and we find it full of hapiness, smells, music and crowded!!!Music and smells everywhere!If you want to eat don't do this here!the price are high and the food average!

A very charming part of the city!. The Alfama district of the city is very charming with it narrow and winding streets. In this part of the city you can visit the beautiful medieval castle, that is very impressive with its walls and towers. The gardens around the castle are very beautiful and it is a great place to relax and unwind in. In my opinion the castle grounds offers one of best views of the city!On every Tuesday and Saturday there is an excellent flea market here and you will have a lot fun looking for hidden treasures.In the quarter of the city you will find plenty of little shops selling artisan handyman gifts and souvenirs. It is perfect if like me you don't want to buy the unusual tourist rubbish. I would highly recommend visiting this part of the city.

Fabulous district. Didn't disappoint. Amazing character full of winding cobbled streets, alleys and staircases. You will get lost, but not for long and if in doubt, head for one of the church domes or follow the tram line (the famous 28). Lots of bars, restaurants and Fado. Best to just walk and explore as you go.
Beautiful atmosphere. Went there in June around Sao Antoni festival - great atmosphere and barbecues on the streets. An old times atmosphere, nice views, nice people...

Get lost in the lovely small streets. Afalma gives you some nice romantic feeling. The little streets up and down, left to the right. Enjoy some fado music and drink something in one of the cafes. From 1th June till 1th July there is a festival!

The Castle, the Bridge, the Periscope. We took tram no 28 to climb the hill and watch the view of 24th April Bridge and Sculpture of Jesus. Further we entered the Castle and after watching the city from each corner we had the magnificent experience of periscope. On the way back, you can take a tuk tuk to elevate the fun.
Brilliant to just get lost in. We were here for dinner at a tiny restaurant X simply wandered through the streets getting a bit lost. Fabulous atmosphere and quaint houses X the heart of Lisbon
