Explore the old city. Put on good walking shoes and try the small streets and steps: there is no single flat street in Alfama but the atmosphere is great and the views from the higher parts are excellent

Picturesque place.. What a picturesque place this is. It is not for everyone, as it is quite hilly with narrow streets. However it is the sheer beauty and old world charm of this great area that makes it so special. There are plenty of little, friendly cafes, restaurants, churches, little, narrow, winding streets and, provided you have the stamina, you will definitely enjoy a stroll here.

Go during June when festival on. The whole area taken over at night by pop up bars, restaurants and music acts. Atmosphere outstanding. Very good value for money if you don't mind drinking very strong cocktails out of plastic tumblers!!

Adoring Alfama. My partner and I were unsure of Lisbon as a whole when we first arrived, but the city sneaks up on you and then steals your heart. Alfama is the epitome of the country as a whole: run-down, dirty and in need of ... nothing! Because it is what it is. Charm oozes form the pores of the beautiful old "azulejos" (tiles) that cling to the sides of the buildings; the people are wonderful and the place has a romantic feel that few other places in the world can match - and that includes Paris, Rome and many other more popular cities in terms of tourism. Yes, there are steep streets; yes, it's narrow and crowded. But the beer is cold and the food is great - and cheap!! Alfama is a great place to visit if you want to understand the true nature of Lisbon. Five fat stars *****

Breathtaking views! . We had a real taste of Portugal here! Our timing fell between the weeks of Santo Antonio celebrations ( first fortnight of June) so there were lots of decorations to enjoy on the streets! Definitely worth a pit stop at the café at the top. Good photo opportunities along the way- remember go turn around to get them!

Great for a visit. From our perspective of a family with two young kids and a stroller, we were glad that we didn't stay in Alfama on our recent trip to Lisbon. There are a lot of steps, hills etc that are difficult to navigate with a stroller. Of course the old part of Lisbon is a must see when in Lisbon! We found some areas to be nicer than others. It's fun to spend a day getting lost in the narrow side streets. Those with mobility issues might want to take a tuktuk or the tram car ride instead. You won't see as much but will help with all the steps/hills.
traditional buildings kept, great atmosphere, get your Fado fix here. Great views over the city from the St Vicente Monestery. great place to take in the view with a nice cold drink
Interesting place. Lovely winding streets on a hill. Please beware of pickpockets and people who come begging in restaurants and leave with your purse!

Typical view of Lisbonne. Do not miss the way up either walking or with the tramway to the mirador allowing the view on the Afama neighbourhood and the Tagus. This is so nice to see the red roof houses. Magic city.

Hills!!!!. We walked all over Alfama and challenged the steep hills. Well worth the effort as the shops and restaurants were wonderful. If you have trouble with hills there are flat parts you can also explore. Don't miss the castle.One tip.....There's an elevator you can take for free. Google it!

Best walking experience. We went on a free walking tour of Alfama which lasted around 3 hours. The guide Nuno had a good knowledge of the city and its history. We even had small stopovers during the way where he would explain about the little things that we saw on the way.It was a good experience.
A little jewel. Romantic place, its balance in the disorder and the colors is amazing. Getting lost in the streets is the best option.

Best part of the city. Alfama is a neighborhood, and in my opinion it's the best part of the city to visit. It's one of the oldest parts of the city so the architecture is gorgeous and grungy at the same time. The food is also delcious and there are beautiful views of the water. You can get lost for hours wandering through the neighborhood taking photos, eating in local taverns, taking in the street art. A visit to Lisbon is not complete without wandering Alfama. Also - if you are in town there is a super fun outdoor flea market (Called the Thieves Market) in this area.
Bustling . An area with great history, many steep hill and uneven pavements. Keep walking up, don't stop till you get to the Castle.
Nostalgic old down town . Kept old hilly and nostalgic area . Can walk not so huge area but chill out . Small road and cute Small cafe answers restaurant

One of the best views of the city. There's an elevator which takes you to the top for 5 Euros; but there's a street with affordable slope to go up behind the place (5 minutes walk). Don't miss this place, as it gives you a good view of the city.

Fantastic visuals. Alfama is a wonderful and colourful district in Lisbon. A tuk tuk ride through the narrow streets, though very touristy, is wonderful. A stop at one of the local bars to experience Fado and good wine.

We will come back. Stayed in an apartment in the centre of the Alfama district for 2 nights. Everything that we wanted to see on this trip we managed to do so. You need to spend at least a week here to get the proper feel of this vibrant city, so we will be coming back. We drove to Lisboa and parking near where we were staying was a nightmare, next time we will park outside and get a taxi to the centre, Parking at the airport is reasonably cheap and a short, bus or taxi ride to the Alfama district.

Its the city. This old town was and is one of the must watch list of Lisbao. We went by walk in the night to this place. The restaurants and people were quite lively and got to see the actual residential and few oldest houses of the city.
Worthwhile for a day or more . A lot of shopping and especially wine shops near the Castle Sao Jorge. Start at the top via the 12E or the more crowded 28E tram.

The neighbourhood that defines Lisbon for me. Many years ago I was fortunate to have lived in this wonderful neighbourhood just above the case dos bicos. Now every return is always a pleasure and I love the fact that not much has changed since and probably for more than 100 years. It is one of the most interesting part of the city to discover by foot and also by tram with the number 28 which will go through the most narrow streets you will experience in a capital city. Of course the castelo São Jorge and its glorious Miradouro alone is a good reason to go to Alfama in the first place.

Best area of Lisbon . Wonderful for walking and exploring. It is easy to get lost in a good way. Transportation abounds and there are tons of sites, good restaurants and fado joints. No car needed. Vistas galore.
Alfama Tour with Elena . Vielen Dank, es war ein perfekter Nachmittag!Thanks Elena, we had a perfect afternoon in Alfama! We will surely recommend you to anyone visiting Lisbon.

Must must must. You cannot say you saw Lisbon properly if you have not visited this area. Not only are the streets magical with tight little alleyways and hidden gems, food here is authentic and non touristy!
Only caution: avoid it in the dead of night. It can get a bit scary.
Quaint alfama. Alfama is an interesting district with many old building. The trams and tuk tuks are a great way to get about. Easy to get into the main part of the city

Broken houses, some unclean alleys but friendly people. Many houses were broken with some building sites and some alleys are unclean but there is a special old charm of Alfama and the people are very friendly here.

Great place to walk. This is a great place to take a slow walk and experience the real Lisbon and it's side streets. There is also an amazing park that overlooks Lisbon and on it's own just worth a visit using the old tram 28.
Delightful district. Loved strolling around these tiny streets, so full of character and charm. It reminded me of Morocco although much more hilly and loads of steps involved.
Sandeman Tour of Alfama with Yuri. Yuri was fun, energetic, and passionate, as well as knowledgeable. I highly recommend him and would take another tour with him.
Great walking area. The Alfama district was a walkers dream though some of the streets were steep. But the area is full of history and a must see on any trip to Lisbon.

Fascinating area with some great views. We wandered around this locality on several occasions during our three day stay and enjoyed the panorama out over the city and the river from its lofty setting. It has plenty of interesting sites, shops, squares and cafes to relax in, sit back and watch the world go by. We ate lunch in a nice backstreet restaurant on our last day and loved the barbecued fish freshly prepared on the smokey griddle. The ancient tram cars trundling through the area and navigating its many slopes were an added scenic attraction and a must for photographers. Day or night, this seemed like a delightful area to explore and merits more than one journey in our view.

Fado district. To my mind the most beautiful district of Lisbon. Small alleyways alive with the sounds of Fado and the wafting smell of delicious food being served. We experienced such warm hospitality and sipping a glass of wine in one of the open courtyards is heavenly
Beautiful Vista. The Alfama area affords beautiful views over Lisbon and over the water. It is a lively and lovely neighborhood. Recommended!

Up and down!. Put on your comfortable walking shoes and get in and around the maze of narrow streets and lane ways. This is called the 'old town' and is full of history. You will find numerous churches and many, many interesting 'photo' opportunities. Be sure to look up as well as down! Even the laundry hanging outside the windows and people barbecuing outside their doors, add to the local flavour of the area. Just be prepared with good walking shoes. This is not an activity for anyone with mobility issues.

Best part of the city. If you are able to, this is the area to stay in when visiting Lisbon. Beautiful winding narrow streets with tons of character. This is the old part of Lisbon and will make you feel you are really experiencing this city.
lovely. take a day to walk through the small streets, see the Miradouros, enter the small churchs around the neighbohood. It's lovely, cozy, amazing.

Wander down and take your time. This is a very interesting part of the city, with a labyrinth of steps and alleyways. Different styles of buildings compete for space. Kids play in the squares and if you take time to sit and just enjoy the atmosphere.

Great to walk around. Get off the beaten track and walk through all the colourful narrow streets high up overlooking the city. Trams and put put cars are everywhere. Church after church in this district and the cathedral. Don't miss Santa Engracia church with its huge dome.
its up hill. beautiful part of town, old architecture, lovely castle, cool cafes and nice little gift shops. I loved the views of the harbour but if you tire easily get the tram

Walking Tour. Had a tour guide that took us through this district. Walked from the top down to the bottom so an easy walk. Not sure I would recommend doing on your own. Some good restaurants in the area. Shopping was geared towards residents.

Nice neighbourhood to visit, especially at night for the Fadoooo. You will find a Fado restaurant almost every corner you turn into if you explore this charming neighbourhood at night. Tram 28 travels through the Alfama area, take it up the steep slopes, view the sunset at Santa Luzia, and then hop into a Fado restaurant for dinner :)

Lovely old part of town. It is probably the oldest part of Lisbon, and worth visiting in any type of weather. it has an indefinable charm. Lovely place to stroll through, without a particular aim. Surprises are just around the corner. Some very good fado places and nice small restaurants.

The best neighbourhood in Lisbon . A nice and charming district. Me and my boyfriend staying in a flat here. We loved the area. Close to the centre (30 min walk). The evening walk through the "becos" it is another pleasant experience. Listen to the Fado music coming from the restaurants is pure beauty and romantic. You can't miss this area and have nice dinner in this area. Loved it.

Charmy, narrow and steep :). We have left Alfama for the last day of our visit to Lissabon and it turned to be our favourite place in the city! The narrow, twisted streets are fascinating. Climbing them (sometimes by stairs - so steep) is a great experience, yet having a kid on your shoulders :)) The atmosphere is like in a fairy-tale from a past time... Birds singing, colourful houses, pegged out washing - simply amazing!
Tight squeeze on old trolley. So fun we did the circle tour twice. Streets steep and so narrow you could almost touch buildings on one side.
Charming narrow street neighborhood. Walking down from Castelo de Sao Jorge thru the Alfama is an exclent way to see Lisbon's typical neighborhoods as they were in the past

Wijk Alfama. Very nice neighbourhood in the old part of Lisboa. A lot of little streets and vieuws. Nice restaurants every where. Also restaurants where they perform Fado Music. In the evening very good to do because it is less busy with tourists. Good food at the little restaurants with the White Lights where all the Portugese people are.

Busy. We spent a couple days in the Alfama area at the beginning of our trip and the last two days of our trip. When the cruise ships are in it is extremely busy. Lots of cute little shops, cafés, restaurants. You can take the tram up there but it is extremely busy and we chose to walk. The walk from old Lisbon is about 15 minutes but definitely worth it very steep in some areas. I would definitely go back to Alfama in the future as there is lots to see

A walk in another time. This is probably the most genuine part of Lisbon with tiny streets, many impossible by car, even the tiny tuk -tuks have to stay out. But for a walk they are perfect as long as you've left your high heels in your bag or back at the hotel, cobbled stones! And even though the streets are narrow they manage to find room for small shops, cafés and restaurants. Most houses are well kept, clean streets and lots of tourists are also something you'll see. To me the most enjoyable place to take a walk in Lisbon.

Gorgeous part of town. This is essentially the old town in Lisbon. It's charming to walk around in, and it's fun to go visit the castle as the views are gorgeous. There are restaurants, stands selling fresh berries, and cute shops. Must see!

Beautiful Area to Wander. Wander with no itinerary and come upon charming tiny shops and restaurants, find yourself at the Castle overlooking the gorgeous city, and give yourself plenty of time to simply enjoy.

Best neighborhood of Lisbon. Small windy streets, beautiful houses, good fado restaurants, breath taking views, little coffee places. Alfama has stolen our heart. We did many walks through Lisbon, but this neighborhood is the best.
Get lost here.. Just wander up and down the steep streets. Meander up to the Castle. It's one of the oldest parts of Lisbon and it's lovely.

Fantastic views and bustling. Following the many stairways and hills, we were fairly tired when reaching the main square in Alfama. But it was definitely worth it. We cooled down in the shade with a cocktail, and then got to walking around. Lots going on here including museums, shops, restaurants and markets.
Alfama e linda!. Get lost in narrow streets of Alfama and find yourself on Graca - you will be amazed like a child seeing something for the first time!

Ancient and charming neighbourhood that survived the 1755 earthquake. The Alfama is a tangle of narrow streets, often too narrow for a car to pass. Be prepared to walk and walk up flights and flights of steps. Each street is filled with surprises. Shops so small that when you raise both arms out straight, you touch the shop's walls. This not a place for chain restaurants and stores. This is a vibrant neighbourhood filled with photogenic opportunities. A must see when in Lisbon.Great look out point at the Miradouro de Sao Jorge.
Amazing. Lots od stairs, lots of hiking but really worth it. Old houses, you can feel the real Lisbon there. In the evening many places, small restaurants with Fado live.

Mesmerizing. You can not say that you have been in Lisbon if you miss its heart. This suburb encapsulates all the history, the flavours, the sounds and the fashion of Lisbon. Simply get lost in this part of the city and you will not get disappointed. The only recommendation is to be careful in the night.

The Heart of Portugal. Want to feel the beat of Portugal stay in the Alfama for five nights like we did. We stayed at the Memmo Alfama just behind the Cathedral and had a wonderful time exploring the Alfama. We called it urban mountain climbing and came back in much better shape than when we first arrived.What makes the Alfama, specifically, and Portugal so interesting is that you're always seeing something old, then you see something older, then you realize how much Portugal was part of world history in the 1400, 1500 and 1600's.Yeah. it's crawling with tourists. Then you see and here what happens when their soccer team wins the championship. The locals really let it loose.The Fado is probably more original in the Alfama then you find in the rest of Lisbon for sure. And you can hear it at night, especially after 10 as you walk around.And the shops... have just about any kind of souvenir that you might want from Portugal.

St George Castle, and the Old District is one of the best views.. Take the tram up this very steep incline on one of the 7 hills of Lisbon. Terrific views, wander around have drinks or bites at local cafes, and take in this breathtaking but small district. Great view of the river also, and many artists or professional people live in this area of Lisbon. The buildings look dilapidated at times, but inside they are hidden treasures, and much art and antiques in locals apartments. beautiful. Ignore the new tuk tuk trips, and walk down or take the tram.

Just walk inside the area and enjoy. This is a area with a lot of small path. Just have a walk in the area and enjoy buildings, views and the atmosphere. We have for example discover inside a nice smal place to have lunch. Taberna Dos Clerigos

Nice but less bustle . We expected a lot of nice places over here. Some like squares with cafe's and orange trees. Instead we found small streets and abbeys up and down with some gift and souvenir shops. Nice for a small visit but not really what we expected.

Amazing moorish architecture. get ready for a serious hike as some of the streets incline as much as 40+ degrees. The neighborhood is a mixed bag from the standpoint of cleanliness but the locals are all very friendly despite some hardscrabble areas. A walk down from castelo s jorge to the center of town can take over an hour but is well worth it.

One of those beautiful places where the map is absolutely useless ;). Alfama was our favorite part of Lisbon. An old part of the city with beautiful narrow, colorful streets and nice old tiled buildings. Great views of the city and lots of local restaurants, shops, etc. Lots of steps and hills and very easy to get lost. The map didn't work good in this area. Our place located next to Fado Museum. We felt very safe walking around. It can get loud at night. Easy to walk to Rossio Station, public transportation and 20 minutes away from the airport by taxi. This place had lots of character and nice atmosphere. Good neighborhood for a base in Lisbon and experience a local life. We would definitely stay in this area again.

Authentic Lisbon and great views. We didn't have long so we were only in this part of town for an hour or two but we could have stayed much longer. Full of real Lisbon buildings, some in need of repair, narrow streets, appealing bars and eateries, it is worth exploring. At the top near the church there's a wonderful place to view the city.
Great old quarter. Walkingf through the charming streets of the old quarter is an exciting experience. You must be able to challenge the differences in height,
Nice day trip. Took 3 wheel tour car. Nice time and some nice views, but traffic is a challenge with a little buggy.

Another gorgeous view of Lisbon. We walked the city streets and after walking through lovely cobbled streets up and down, came to this location. Again you see a wonderful view of Lisbon from another angle.

Get lost and love it! . My favorite part of Alfama was walking in the narrow alleys, getting lost and enjoying every bit of it. We stopped at a small souvenir store and had a really nice conversation with the lovely owner who explained the origin of certain traditions and also offered us some wine to taste!

Lovely neighbourhood with great views . Walked through here on several occasions and loved the area. Great views of the city and quaint houses with gorgeous tiled buildings. Been told to visit June 12 in future due to the annual celebrations and they were setting up whilst we were there. Go for a wander and get enjoyably lost!

Girls weekend away. We had a fantastic weekend away in the Alfama area staying just by the cathedral. What a picturesque area and so handy to visit all the local sights and restaurants! I really recommend this area to stay as your base in Lisbon!
Go and see. A great old place with the narrow twisty turny streets and lots of character. There are great views to see from up here- we walked it back tow which is easy as it's all downhill

Authentic. Me and my friend visited Alfama two times (two days) during our stay in Lisbon. We loved it! The narrow streets are very colourful, due to the typical ceramic tiles, laundry hanging by the windows, graffiti art,... and the people are very friendly and authentic. Visit this lovely neighbourhood by foot if you really want to enjoy it. There are a lot of steps, but also enough places to take a rest. Also don't forget the castle, on top of it you have a beautiful view on the city. And certainly visit a fadobar in the evening. One disadvantage is the traffic through the narrow streets, so look out for the cars.

Cute narrow streets and shops. This is part of the original old town of Lisbon where the Moors lived. It was a surviving area after the earthquake in the 1700s. Narrow streets, cute shops, restaurants, cafes, etc. Of particular interest are the restaurants and clubs featuring Fado singers. Wonderful for just strolling and enjoying. A must see in Lisbon.
Lovely Area of Lisbon. Lots to see, great views, and some nice places to eat and drink!! You can walk easily or catch a tram

The heart of old Lisbon. Worth a couple of hours of your visit to see some of the architecture, the views, and stumble across everything from artisans' workshops to cafes and restaurants that you wouldn't otherwise find.

Beautiful. This area of Lisbon is spectacular. Tram 28 scuttles through the small and quaint streets, so it's a good way to see the area. There are also many beautiful views to stop at and have a drink. Walking around this area in the sun is what going to Lisbon is all about.

Nicest area of Lisbon. We had a little apartment in this area. As soon as you walk here you get lost. The first day we went to the castle, and found it after 1 hour instead of 30 minutes :) You can try to read a map but we thought it was impossible to find anything. Google maps war our best friend :) The little streets, the people, the houses, the architecture and the atmosphere is just amazing. Everything is really old, but really beautiful. If I ever go back to Lisbon, I definitely will stay somewhere in this area.
Get Lost!. Small streets, great adventure! It's completely worth it! Not only you'll find life as it is, but also great sightseeings
Lively and great area. A must-see in Lisbon, don't miss to have look in many tiny side streets and try one the many small restaurants (preferably one with many locals, not the touristic places).

Walking around a lively district of Lisbon. This is the ideal part of Lisbon for a walk about. Around every corner you will find interesting views, little shops, cafes or restaurants, people and lots of steps... Explore at your own pace, you will not be disappointed!
Great walk!. All uphill from our hotel, great walk and view of the sea! Beautiful spot, very romantic. Great restaurants on walk up, local area as well.

Historic area . I walked a lot this district of the city, and I enjoyed the historical buildings in every minutes. It's amazing how can go the trams, cars and tuk tuks together on the narrow streets. They let the old houses on the street and didn't make any modern think, I love it very much!
Definitely worth a visit. We loved walking through the old cobbled streets of Lisbon, the buildings were fabulous to look at & we totally got lost. Some great little cafe and food joints.

True Lisbon. Outstanding place. Wonderfull views. This is the district where you can feel the real Lisbon. Wandering the streets with short stops for a coffe or sardines is the best way to get to know Lisbon.

The best place in Lisboa. We just loved it. It's so nice, people are lovely there, old ladies, always try to help you even if they just speak Portuguese. In the evening you can listen some nice FADO music. A lot of nice restaurants and bar.On the top of the hill, you have an amazing view of the city.
Tourist nap. Just don't go there !!!!! Much better to stay in Bairro Alto - more life more bars more feeling. And definitely do not eat there !!!!

Day Trip to Alfama. The quickest way to get the Alfama is to catch the 28 Trolley that does the climbing for you. Dont walk unless you are working for a marathon. It is a great walk with beautiful churches sites. There are also great tiny restaurants that you will only find in this old historic area of Lisbon. If you really want some great fun....go during the 1st 2 weeks of June for the St. Anthony's Festival where you will great music and food.

Middle ages with a view. Alfama is the part of Lisbon where you can visit the cathedral and of course the Castelo de San Jorge. In this part of the city you can find some very nice bars and cosy little restaurants.The best way to visit is to go up by taxi or the little railway number 28. Once you visited the castle you can come down the little streets on foot or with the elevators.
Must visit. A very nice neigbourhoud to visit for culture, food and fado.had a nice time walking through the streets

The best bit of Lisbon. The medieval streets of Alfama are a joy to explore. Accept that you will get lost, and enjoy the sense of discovery as courtyards and steps reveal themselves. If all else fails, head downwards until you reach the main road with access to the buses and metro station.
Fabulous neighbourhood to explore. This was my second time to explore the Alfama area.....so much to see and do and such a great wandering experience.
Great views. We went by tram and got off on the way and had a drink under the shade of some trees on a terrace overlooking the river. Well worth a visit.

Loved this part of Lisbon!. Charming quarter of the city. DO NOT attempt walking all over Lisbon if you have weak ankles or knees. Take the buses, funicular, trains, etc. Alfama is narrow and steep and holds many sweet surprises.
Great place to spend whole day !. We have beautiful time in Alfama, great view, food, wine and a lot of gardens all the way.Peace and harmony.
For a summy day. Climb the hill to Alfama by foot, by trolley or by bus, have a lunch in one of the few restaurants within the wall and roam around the cliff and fortress overlooking Lisbonn.

Lovely Old Town and Market. we had a morning visiting the Alfama area, we got the Metro to Santa Apolonia then walked up to the Tuesday 'Feira da Ladra' Market, mainly bric-a-brac, antique and vintage, purchased some lovely old ceramic tiles, from there we walked to Castle Säo Jorge (15 mins) lovely views of the city. We then walked back down through the Alfama area. Walking was fine as its small streets and busy with local & tourist traffic.

Awesome!. So romantic and beautiful. Truly the best of Lisbon. We loved exploring the old cobble-stone streets and twisting and turning streets. Beautiful architecture and nice restaurants. Great for a romantic night out!
a walk you should not miss. I liked Lisbon a lot,and Alfama is one of the points that will remind you Lisbon when you you will be back home,The only problem was tourists like us.So many.Really.

Great Vista Point. Take the Tram hills view route or any of the "hop on hop off" bustours that go by way of the Alfama and you wll not be disappointed.Great views of Lisbon as well as the river Tagras too.

Where culture and tradition is in the air.. As a local that grew up close to this place I do know some things of it, BUT, every foraigner reacts always in the same way!''Wow'' ''how is this possible'' ''won't we get lost?'' are the most typical things I hear when I walk around there.From its small and different buildings (some of them probably medieval ) to Bright colors, to narrow-full-of-dead-end streets, to it's people....Alfama is a place you should check for sure and you will fall in love with its corners.Issues? restaurants are pretty much for tourists and it can be hard to walk around it during the night so I advise during the day.

Great with its hills and hidden restaurants, bars, places and tiny streets. We visited Alfama for the second time and always find something new, in this old neighbourhood. Although it is supposed to be very touristic, you find yourself feeling as a local wandering through the narrow streets or sitting in a small cosy restaurant.

You cannot miss it. You must not miss that one of the kind quarter.. Alfama is the gem of Lisbon. This medieval neighborhood is charming like its inhabitants. The colors, the smell, the Fado songs make Alfama unique.
Charming place. Charming place to walk around, with no specific route. Just leave the Castle and walk around as you wish...
Old school. Great neighborhood of old homes and small businesses..probably best seen at night..not many places open in the early morning.

The real Lisbon!. Weed loved our visit to Alfama. It is very lively, colourful and gives you the true Lisbon feeling. Reading some of the reviews here, we avoided boarding the tram 8 and walked everywhere instead. The place is very eventful with lots to do and see. We especially loved to walk around Alfama and explore all the views (or the miradouros). We were extra cautious about our wallet and bags but our experience in Alfama was pleasant.

Gorgeous cozy neighborhood. Our hotel was in Alfama and part of the Chill Out Lisbon tour was in this neighborhood so we spent more time in Alfama than anywhere else during our vacation in Lisbon. Alfama has a distinct feel to it, with its narrow stepped passages, cozy open courtyard areas and lovely historic buildings. And of course it is crowned by my favorite castle, Sao Jorge, then runs downhill to the river Tagus. If you can stay in Alfama during your vacation, do it!

How good is life!. Take an entire day and just get lost in the narrow streets of this old Part of town dating back to Moorish times. Unplug. Do not follow a map or a guide, just stroll around, a little to the legt, then a little to the right, then again a little to the left. Seek upwards to find the great views and cozy cafees. Most importantly: Just relax and enjoy. Really, this will make you appreciate this district the most.

Moorish splendour. Use Tram 28, we did and a full circuit gave us the lie of the land and on the return journey we jumped off at Graça where we walked up past the barracks and enjoyed great views from one of the highest viewpoints in Lisbon. From here we navigated the narrow, winding, quaint and cobbled streets of Alfalma the former Moorish area, taking in the flea (thieves) market and Panteão Nacional. The Panteão Nacional's position meant that my climb to the 4th floor not only gave me a close up of its huge dome, but impressive views over Alfalma down to the Rio Tejo. Inside the balcony at this level gives you dizzy views of the internal space that plays homage to Portugal's heroes. Our biggest blunder was to then try and pick our way to the castle, where many hilly streets and tired legs later, we realised we should have got back onto the Tram and taken it down to the Cathedral (drops you outside) and used the 737 bus from the city to drop us close to the Castle entrance.
A great sentimental walk.. Awesome place full of old character. Nice little streets with full of history around. Nice view and lots of regional restaurants.

A place to get lost. This is a lovely part of old Lisbon, well away from the main roads. We tried to follow a map,but soon got lost. We came across so many pretty views, houses with old tile decorations, steep steps to climb up or down to the different areas and a glimpse into the life of the locals. It's best to get away from the main tourist attractions like the castle and explore the quieter areas.
It was difficult to find a place without dining. We had to try several places to get in for just the music and something to drink (needed 6-7 attempts...)
Walk Theses Streets. After a visit to Cestello Santa Jorge, walk down the hill to Al Fama. Upon reaching the shoreline road there are nice views, cafes, and people enjoying the cooling sea breeze.

A Great Walk. We took a taxi to the top. Taxis in Lisbon are easy to get and reasonably priced. We continued to walk up to St. Jorge--lots of great views! If you have time, be sure to walk down- a very nice stroll downhill--great way to see Lisbon!

Mystical small streets. This is am amazing part of town to ramble around. Lots of hills but every street is captivating. Most restaurants don't open until after seven and music is after eleven so with small kids we missed the best fun. Besides that it's worth a ramble and its full of characters and quaint rustic shops.
This is the Portugal I wanted.. This is a great neighborhood reflecting the old city of Lisbon. Wear your walking shoes for comfort and just stroll to see what you find--lovely shops, food, scenery.

Fun to walk the maize like streets. This is the "real" Lisbon where people live, do their laundry, paint their houses, stand outside and chat, argue and drink beer. There are some good viewpoints of the river. The castle is in this area also with the best viewpoints.
Beautifull place. At any time of the day or the night you can enjoy Alfama, during the day you can take the kids and enjoy the views, at night...a good wine and Fado are the best.
Love the winding streets. Such character, the winding streets with little restaurants appearing around each corner. Lovely day wandering around here.
Very beautifull. Steap stairs, dark alleys, at every corner a new beautifull view! And of course nice small coffebars. This is the old part of Lisbon

magic neigbourhood. Very ttractive, interesting and enchanted neighbourhood. It reminds one of the narrow streets of Venic italy only here you have cars crawling through the maze and no water canals.Nevertheless highly recommended for those who want to spend the time and wander around aimlessly, sit at the sidewalk cafe and climb the narrow colorful streets.Do not plan anything, just start walking. You won't get lost. All narrow and winding streets get to the ocean where you can find your way to any destination. Don't miss the Alfama!!

Great views of city!. The viewing point at Alfama is amazing. There are also a number of stalls selling fresh pasteries and coffee. There is a small bar selling a variety of drinks which is nice while you soak in the view. Get your selfie sticks ready!
Wander heaven.. Loved wandering the narrow streets and finding small shops and artisans. The Tues and Sat flea markets are amazing.

Bohemian and Quiet. Probably its the best place if you want to stay in a working class neighbourhood with a bohemian touch in it. A part of old Lisbon is still there, and it does not feel that touristy, despite the hordes of tourists around the place

Very pretty . Great picture spot at the top. Reminds me of the small corridors and towns in India. Not sure how the locals like tourists snooping around their neighborhood and homes but it was cool to see. We saw it with the Lisbon Free Walking Tour.
Interesting. Had a brief walk through the Alfama on a cold rainy day in Lisbon. Loved the old buildings and the tiles.

Walkking tour of Alfama. This is something that you must experience, but do it with a lot of energy!TIP: There are two elevators that will take you up to a higher level instead of climbing up steep hills. Once you are up there, have a look at the view, but don't forget to look around you at the charming little area where fishermen and their families have lived for centuries. Theirs is a way of life unique to Lisbon where women can be found to lean out windows and gossip to their neighbors while they hang laundry on lines connected to posts that are supported by the bottom of wine bottles cemented into the walls. Look for them and you will see them everywhere. The best thing to do is to take a walking tour of the area to learn a little more about what you are seeing and stop at certain points of interest. This is a richly endowed area of Portuguese culture that can only be appreciated when experienced.This is also a terrific place to stop for a traditional Portuguese meal of codfish or octopus! Don't forget to try the unique cherry wine!Enjoy!
A maze to get lost in. Lovely historic area - a maze of streets with some lovely bars and restaurants. Worth just wandering for a couple of hours.

Nice walk. Gorgeous views of old architecture and history, keep in mind that the old part of Lisbon has many hills (streets go up), therefore you either walk a lot or take a tour in a TukTuk. We had a great time and this part of the town is very charming. We walked around the Alfama area (a lot) and also took the tuk tuk. There are two more tops in the mountain where you can overlook the entire old city of Lisbon. Those top of the mountains are called "mirador" (forget the specific name of each, they have a church and a cafe) which are the top of the mountain to view the city. Bring comfortable shoes and a bottle of water... You will be thankful you did (it's very hilly and rocky)
Stunning views. Great. Views over. The front .A nice walk up and can see the castle to the left .A few nice cafes about .Good place to relax and. Watch the world go by .
Be prepared to have your calves hurt!. Up and down go the tiny, twisted streets. Laundry hangs down from above. Churches perch on the steep hillsides as do Fado restaurants. Lots of fun.

So MUCH to See and Enjoy :-)) .... but so little time :-((. Visiting the Alfama District of Lisbon is like going to the "Georgetown" area of Washington, DC ... the "Greenwich Village" neighborhood of New York City ... or the "North End" of Boston! How can one even begin to describe "What" to see or do ... or what shouldn't be missed?! There's just SO much for the adventurous visitor willing to 'just follow one's nose"!As Lisboa is one of the oldest cities in Europe, the Alfama District reflects that fact and more! It's a great place for walking around, just taking in the sights and sounds.Fortunately for us, one of our family is native born Portuguese and his knowledge of both the city and the language allowed us to delve much deeper into the Alma than what a short, whirl-wind "formally guided" tour might have provided. Not having to adhere to any set schedule also gave us lots of flexibility.We stopped in at shops just for fun ... sampled food and wine wherever our noses led us ... and spent a wonderful and leisurely afternoon at the Castelo de São Jorge.We took a taxi UP the steep hills TO the castle ... then leisurely walked back DOWN the cobblestone streets. Strongly recommend you do some advance research before visiting for the first time so you can maximize both your time and enjoyment. Equally important, bring your camera & wear comfortable walking shoes! The cobblestone streets are 'fun' ... but can be killers for those wearing just sandals or 'flats'. An umbrella is also a good idea if you visit in late fall/winter/early spring.

Old and narrow streets with inexpensive eating. Alfama is the oldest untouched part of Lisbon, as this area was relatively unharmed by the great earthquake of 1755 due to its location on the bedrock.It provides great views over the rest of the city. The streets are small, narrow and winding providing lots of trafic jams. Lots of nice grafitti in the area. There are plenty of small restaurants in the area which are quite cheap, but they all have very similar menus: Fish, Meat and Omelette.
Lovely Lisbon life . A beautiful part of the city to watch the world go by. It's quite steep in places so take your time wondering around. I felt it was cooler up here than in the city below.

Magical part of town. But this area would be difficult for people with mobility issues. The laneways and stairs are wonderful but it can at times be quite steep, and have lots of stairs. Be sure to rest at the many Cafes/restaurants if you need a break.

Lovely winding streets. The streets are narrow, winding and filled with restaurants, bars and the like. The kind of area that does come to life after dark and also offers plenty of entertainment in the form of the infamous 'fado'-music being played life in lots of places. Do, however, take care as many of these places are rather small and are also popular amongst locals.

Overhyped. I recently visited Lisbon for the first time. I had heard a lot about Alfama, so we even booked an apartment in Alfama. I didnt find it all that special. It is just the old part of the city with old houses and narrow street but not that beautiful or having a character like Rome has. I was disappointed as if I knew I would have spent that time in Algarve instead.

More than 1000 years of history in only one neighborhood!. After a narrow street, there's some lisght. A neighbor by the window. Some childs playing. A wondering dog. Here, since more than 1000 years ago, the history don't run away from this hill and keeps shapping the narrow streets where the people has wide hearts!

A Lisbon must. Had a huge amount of fun watching six trams get caught behind a stalled taxi on the tram rails on a rather steep part of the line!Very touristy, but also quite beautiful, and lots of fun. Unfortunately, the castle grounds, free last visit 11 years ago, are now very expensive :-(((

Love at first sight . I fell in love at the very first sight of Alfama. It's absolutely beautiful. The buildings, food, scenery, culture and people. Plus the weather was fantastic! I visited with my boyfriend a few days ago and we both really enjoyed our holiday. There are many hills so I would highly recommend very comfortable walking shoes. There's not many tourists. More locals, which I prefer. The Portuguese are extremely friendly. I would highly recommend Alfama as a romantic get away. Perfect place to propose! Top marks from me :)

You can get lost here but you won't care 😊. A lovely part of Lisbon. Narrow streets, cafes, shops all set in amongst lovely old buildings.Loads of pavement cafes.The picture is of a great little cafe that looks out over the river just near the castle on tram route 28

Step back in time. Wonderful place to wander with no map or guide - just follow the pretty winding streets peppered with tiny eating and drinking spots. Caution if you see a huge tour ship anchored on the harbour as that means possibly everywhere will be saturated with people

Lovely part of town. Alfama is the "old town" of Lisbon, most of which managed to survive the great earthquake of 1755. Still looks lovely - fantastic architecture and a great view of the city once you get to the top of the main hill near Mt Moniz
Must see when in Lisbon. There is so much to see and do. There are so many places to eat & drink, There's the #28 tram. Say no more!!!

Forget the No.28 Tram - walk up!. Many visitors had recommended taking the No.28 Tram up the hill. We queued up initially but decided to walk up because the crowd was just maddening. It was the best decision I think we made. The walk up looked daunting at first but if you take your time and savour the views and buildings around you, there are surprises and wondrous picture perfect moments at every nook and corner. We enjoyed the walk up so much that we decided to walk down a different route and it did not disappoint. We can say we saw Alfama more than those on the tram. And the walk up was a darn good exercise !!

The Alfama is essential . Sights to see, vistas to admire and narrow medieval lanes to get lost in; the Alfama is a must see for any trip to Lisbon. Take the street car to the top and meander your way down. Stay off the streets with traffic and enjoy the quiet patchwork neighborhoods that give the Alfama it's charm.

Good place for a walk. Visited here on the last day of our trip, recommended by our host as a "must see" place. Very glad we went. Absolutely beautiful. Wished we'd gone earlier so we could have had more time to explore!

Gorgeous views and archetecture. The Alfama is a very old and very high part of Lisbon. Take the bus or trolley up to the top to go to the Castelo Sao Jorge, hear live fado, and see the city from amazing heights. There are lots of small cafes and antique shops as well that are worth popping into.Be careful, however: the sidewalks (and stairs) are very steep and can be slippery.

Getting lost is part of the fun!. Although it was a steep hill with cobbled streets, it was a great area to explore on foot. Discover the many Miradouros in the area with expansive view of the old town. The many colourful tiled walls from the houses are excellent backdrop for great portrait shots.

fado and fun. Alfama is the oldest district of Lisbon and is a delightful maze of narrow streets, which lead from the Tejo estuary uphill to the castle.The most enjoyable activity while in the Alfama district is a ride on the number 28 tram. The tram route connects the district of Graça with Baixa and passes through the streets and hills of Alfama.

Alfama Quarter, Lisbon. The Alfama Quarter is the oldest part of Lisbon that survived a terrible earthquake in 1755. Here you will find beautifully tiled buildings, an old Moorish Fortress, narrow streets strewn with laundry drying on lines, and quaint little restaurants. It is old and worn and not someplace I would care to spend much time, but it’s worth a look for the historical significance of the area to the city if you are coming to Lisbon.Our tour description touted it as the “gorgeous Alfama Quarter” but it really isn’t. It’s somewhat shabby and run-down in appearance. We didn’t understand why it is considered one of the highlights of Lisbon. Possibly a more discerning eye would find the beauty in this place.

Strap on your hiking boots!. Not really. It's just that this section of town is mostly uphill and has tight alleys. It's a great place to explore, take in the history, and imagine times past. For those who are beaten by the up and down walking, you can also find an elevator that leads to a nice overlook near the castle. (Santa Luzia)
Lovely. Very cultural and old! Was lovely to wander around and look at all the houses/streets. Had a coffee too um galo yum!

Lost and Found. After 10 minutes of meandering down a couple of alleys, one gives up on orientation altogether. Even Google Maps are at best minimally helpful. It's okay though. Just feast on the colorful 'tuc tucs', packed trams bumping up and down the narrow streets, laundry flying in the breeze, old ladies hanging out of upstairs windows, fado music blaring from pubs and cafes. When tired, there are bars and cafes at every nook and corner. Locals drape curtains and sheets over open doorways to have a little privacy from the passerby and their cameras. Buildings may look rundown but the outside walls can be completed covered by lovely tiles, some of them are individually handpainted.

This is a must see in Lisbon if you like history and cool neighborhoods. We wandered the streets of this very cozy neighborhood with our guide and enjoyed the uniqueness of this historic area of Lisbon. The views from the top are amazing and it is a cool experience to walk through the narrow streets.
Old part of the city centre. Old part of the city centre and one of the most atractive places for historical, adventural and party places

Highlight of alfama was a tiny restauant, homely, fab food, great owner and waiters. Lisboa tu & eu, rua da adiaca,58. Bring good walking shoes and a relaxed attitude. Sit at this tiny place and watch the passing scene.
a real 'find'. Loved the winding streets, 2nd time here we took the elevator, the steps are a killer. Loved the little bars and enjoyed amazing taps with great views
Alfama place to be. I loved this part of Portugal so much. Its a must see. I did not use the tram so I could see more of the place and really enjoyed myself. Would recommend this place.
Beautiful. Alfama is just beautiful and it underlines why Lisbon is called the "white city". You also get some fitness as you have to climb hills while strolling around.

Alfama. The Alfama District of Lisbon is the historical area that remains after the devastating earthquake of 1755. The streets are winding caverns where Trams clatter through on an irregular schedule. It is best to take a tour ( I suggest Chill-Out Free Walking Tours ) to reall appreciate what you are seeing and experiencing.

Historic. Take Tram 28. The city is located on a very steep hill. Its best to just take Tram 28 since it will take you im the heart of the Old Town Alfama. Lots of small restaurant and cafes. The Castle of St. George is the most famous attractions. Lots of other things to see, do and explore the many small cafes, restaurants. Cathedral, church, museums. Its worth spending a good day.
Nice old district.. Just walk along the narrow streets and you’ll discover some nice places and views! Be prepared to go up and down!!

A gem. We are fortunate to be staying in the Alfa,a district, full of narrow streets and alley ways full of interesting buildings shops an d eating places away from the busyness of central Lisbon but easy to get around on foot or by iconic tram.

Amazing Old Town. Beautiful streets and buildings. Amazing to visit, and also great to stay in during your visit. There're many great restaurants and fado restaurants to enjoy while walking the streets at any hour.

Lovely old part of the city!. Beautiful old part of town on a hill (bring your walking boots!) worth doing the tram ride up to the top! (it's an experience!!). Some good restaurants, great views, castle, cathederals etc worth exploring!!

Get lost in Lisbon's Alfama for the day. This is a wonderful place to spend the day, walking down narrow lanes filled with beautiful tiles, busy graffiti and brightly decorated little shops and small places to eat. We spent hours just following our noses, eyes and ears. Warm smells from emanated from every little corner restaurant and coffee shop, brightly decorated eating areas and some delicious ripe oranges hanging just out of reach. Amusing sounds of the locals navigating their cars around tight corners and steep inclines. Very quaint and more authentic than the more commercial side of Lisbon.
great day out hard walking. spent a day in the area lots to see and lot of hill walking, really interesting place with great views and historical places to visit. went up by tram which is good fun
Beautiful. Nice old party of the city surrounded by old buildings, restaurants, tram. The architecture represents the old world but it's beautiful, a must visit if you are in Lisbon.

this place has spirit and is walkable from the centre so worth seeing. Alfama comes alive more at night with fado all around and slow drinking and eating of traditional cuisine. During the day the locals are friendly and it only took 2 nights here before the tiny one woman bakery and cute grocery shop owners knew me and asked about my day and experiences in a warm and wonderful way. Community feeling seems very alive here to me which is wonderful as well as the views and fun of getting lost!

Alfama the old district. This was the old Moorish Quarter of Lisbon. Narrow streets winding and intertwining was a strategy against their enemies. This is the poor section and you need to watch out for pickpockets!. Our tour director warned us about them before we started our city walk through this area. One notable place to see is the Se Cathedral, the oldest church in the city, constructed in 1147. As you walk away from this district you will be near the banks of the Tagus River.

Fantastic area of a beautiful city. So interesting to meander through the old streets; lovely cafes, shops. Interesting building in various states, but remains a vibrant quarter. Easy to find your way around; distances not that great and although on a hill this means easy to navigate; go up to get further in and down to get out.

Alfama per tuk tuk. A wise way to visit Alfama is per tuk tuk due to the climbing. The oldest area of Lisbon is getting renovated step by step. Beautiful houses, panoramic views, archeology, Fado Museum,... Nice area with own identity

Take a walking tour of Alfama. This is a must for anyone who goes to Lisbon. You are no longer a tourist, just someone enjoying the ambiance of the area. Steeped in history, you'll be transported to another time and place, while still in the present. Like so many wonderful places in Europe with their narrow cobblestone streets and inhabited by little local shops (no malls here!), the experience is worth the time. Highly recommend it.

Great area to wander. Fantastic and atmospheric area just through away the map and keep walking about if you get lost just head downhill you'll turn up,at somewhere you know. Good wee bars and eateries dotted throughout this area. Wear your trainers as it's very uneven ground and extremely hilly

Very nice . Wonderful sights delight walkers at very turn in this culturally rich and charming part of Lisbon, Whitch trough its architecture reminds visitors of its vesighotic roots, Arabic influence and fishing port heritage.
A must see in Lisboa . Alfama is a very wonderful part of Lisboa where Portuguese life feels very authentic. By far one of the best places to eat, I highly recommend visiting this area.

Beautiful view of the old city. As per our local guide, if the 1755 earthquake had not destroyed the complete city, all areas would have looked like Alfama part. This was the only area which wasn't ruined in the earthquake. The houses are positioned randomly to avoid any animal entry in the residents living area. Some of the spots in the city, provide perfect views and should be visited. Streets are narrow and steep.

My favourite place in Lisbon. I visited Alfama as part of a walking tour and it was my favourite place in Lisbon. I loved just wandering through the windy streets and getting lost. We even bought some Ginjinha from a lady selling it out of her shop window for 1 €! Not to miss.

Cozy. I loved the narrow winding streets. My wife found it oppressive. Not for the claustrophobic I guess. There is a surprise around every corner. Be prepared for some real exertion on these steep, cobblestone walkways.

The Best part of Lisbon . It's my favourite part of Lisbon. The district of poor but happy people. There's a lot of different local cosy restaurants with good and cheap food but you won't find them in the main streets of Alfama. You have to enter all the narrow streets to find them. The narrower the better. Everything which is located in the main streets is meant for tourists - always check prices there as it may turn out you'll pay 13 euro for your beer.

So so. This was interesting but not a must see place for me. Maybe it was the rainy day that dampened my enthusiasm. It was fun to see the narrow streets and how families had to adapt to the area but meh!

The origins of Lisbon. Located on a hill by the banks of the Tagus, this area cries out loud it's history to you most unabashedly. It's steep inclines, it's Fado bars, the impact to its buildings by the earthquake of 1755 and it's absolute vibrancy every evening, are just a few features that will tug you back like a magnet into its midst. Don't leave Lisbon without experiencing Alfama to its full.

lovely neighbourhood. i could spend hours just walking around.
A tip i got from the Walking Tour guide - the street is considered part of the residents houses, so keep quiet and respect their privecy.

Heart of old Lisbon. I adored Alfama. Every small street, every authentic restaurant, laundry drying on the clotheslines, small squares, smell in the air and fado in the evenings. THis is absolutely must see when in Lisbon. Just wander around, don't think where you are just enjoy this unique part of Lisbon. Say Olá or boa tarde and the locals will be grateful and even more friendly because you payed them respect. As our guide told us, the residences of Alfama are very proud of the place they live in so be respectful and tell them Alfama é linda (Alfama is beutiful) and they just might offer you a glass of wine or some food

Wonderful area with super views!. This is a highlight of a visit to Lisbon.One of the oldest and quaintest districts of the city, just packed with character on every street.Old cobbled streets and pavements abound, so careful walking necessary, and the views are among the best in the city!
Small streets to explore. Very hilly but well worth the walk or catch the tram. Views fantastic and the small windy streets great to explore.
Charming narrow steep streets. Lovely old town houses, narrow streets, bustle and activity, trolley buses and tout tuts, loads of small nice restaurants

Must See. This is a Lisbon must-see - be sure to bring comfortable walking shoes, the streets are super hilly, cobblestoned and quite slippery. Amazing views at every turn, it is a place to wander at leisure and lose yourself. Streets packed together with washing flapping in the breeze, we took tram 28 to the top and walked back down again - definitely the way to do it if you want to save your legs. It is crammed with atmosphere and very charming. There are timeless alleys and squares, lovely old houses and pastel colours - a Lisbon must-see.
Best viewspot of Lisbon. One of the most outstanding spots to view the old town of Lisbon. Nice terrace and a pair of small restaurants to have a quick drink.

Wonderful area of Lisbon. This is a delightful area of Lisbon to wander. Start at the top near the castle and just wander down the streets until you get to the bottom. Lots of lovely shops and cafes and bars.
Must see Alfama. Take a tuk tuk and let the driver/guide take you to the narrow streets of Alfama - have a Ginjinha. Don´t miss this!

Best District. We stayed for a week in a lovely old apartment with fantastic views of Mirador das Porta do Sol and the river Tagus. We really liked Alfama and would recommend staying in the district if you visit Lisbon. There was lots of sympathetic regeneration going on while we were there rooves being repaired cobbles re-laid. The one thing that is a huge problem is the large amount of graffiti which really needs to be sorted out before it ruins the area.

Great views and evocative streets. Had a lovely ramble around the streets, walking to the top from the bottom through the old lanes - it really doesn't take long to get to the top. You could take a taxi or tuk-tuk but I think you'd miss a lot. We stopped at a little snack bar for coffee and cake then continued on. The views at the top are brilliant but the old buildings around you are fascinating. There is quite a lot of building work going on, actually this is true all over Lisbon.
exceptional view of the city...... I climbed by foot to read this miradouro and I was impressed by the wonderful view of the city.....incredible.....

Flea Market. Do not miss the Feira da Ladra---the Tuesday and Saturday open air flea market---in the Alfama. Walk uphill from the Baixa district, or take Tram 28, or get a Tuk-Tuk ride, but go see what's being offered. Lots of bargains on ceramics, CD's and artwork.

Architecture and colors. Beautiful hillside town with lots of character. Find the HUGE flea market. It's about 10 blocks long. Everything from touristy "needs" to antiques. Beautiful old tiles. Very busy though. Train station is right at base of hill. Wear your walking shoes because you'll need em. Pretty churches and great coffee.

Totally beautiful . The best place in Lisbon! Get lost walking through the tiny streets, go on Saturday for the big outdoor market. Looks like a very hilly version of Venice without the water. It's breathtakingly beautiful! Lots and lots of hills, steps and walking. No need for the gym when you go here!
Stunning view. A must see.. And the best sangria at the local restaurant.. Not a to far walk from the city centre either if the nr 28 is full..
Do It FOR the view. The tuc tuc ride takes like 15 minutek from the Centre and you Can ask to be dropped there and enjoy the walk back
Lisbon old quarter. Lovely walk around the old streets, here can find the local and more interesting local shops, steep roads up the St George castle.

Touristy but charming. You will get lost in Alfama but that's all part of the experience. The streets are narrow and somewhat crowded and it is a place bustling with locals and tourists alike. I absolutely loved it. My tip would be let yourself get lost! It doesn't matter where you walk, just try to aim in an uphill direction until you can't walk any farther- you will see a "mirodouro" or lookout for amazing views of the whole city.
You have to love Alfama. Beautiful Alfama is Lisbon's sightseeing attraction on its own. Relax in cozy cafes, wander around small alleys and soak the scenery. Love it!

Warren of old streets. Make sure you visit when in Lisboa, interesting, authentic and good fun. Take the time to explore the old, narrow streets, shops and alleys. Savour the authenticity that old Lisboa provides

A pleasant place to stroll. Tiny passageways and an interesting history make this neighborhood slightly different from the rest of Lisbon. Definitely take a stroll there. Stop in the shop Handicrsft Souveniers at 41 with the free taste of port. Friendliest owners/workers we encountered.
Lovely to just wander. This is the old area going downhill from the castle to the Tagus river. Lots of quiet, narrow streets. It is delightful, and the right way to ascend to the castle.

Getting lost here is fun!. Somehow I ended up getting lost after visiting the Castle.
Found some small alley ways down the hill and ended up in this district.
Many old buldings with interesting design and tiles. The small mom and pop bars with patios are great for resting my legs over a cold beer while watching the passing by people.

Very beautiful district with steep climbs. Walking through Alfama is no easy job, but it is worth it. A lot of beautiful old buildings with a nice Portuguese style. Especially the fort at the top of the district is very beautiful.If climbing is not your thing, you can make it a little bit easier by taking tram 28. This will do some climbing for you, but it is still a steep climb afterwards.

Best part of Lisbon. Stunning. Hundreds of narrow streets, uncomparable vibe of old Lisbon, great place to "get lost" for couple of hours. Famous tram 28, but I recommend to take a photo of it from the outside and explore on foot - standing ride on overcrowded tram with orher people disturbing the view and pocket thieves hunting for your wallet isn't a must-do experience ;-)

TOURIST CENTRAL. There are shops selling tourist tat. There are lines of tourists fresh off the boat. There are expensive restaurants, ALL with live Fado for the tourists. There is tram 28, rammed with tourists. There is the castle, the main destination for all the tourists. There are tuck-tucks ferrying tourists back to their ocean liner. There is also the Vihls street art painted on the walls of building next to the dock which all the tourists walk straight by without looking! And there is the brilliant Cortoco and Netto selling authentic tiles. Some stunning views too (check out Hotel Memo Alfama's roof top bar). TOP TIP: STOP AND LOOK AT THE VIHLS STREET ART BEFORE THEY PULL IT DOWN. Go early or go late but be prepared for the crowds and pick pockets
Nice place to wander. Culture around every corner, hidden cafes, great coffee and bakeries! Need to be fit though. Do not miss tram 28 and tram 12
Very interesting neighborhood . Very interesting neighborhood, a must see in the Lisbon area. Highly recommend go walking in the neighborhood to get a feel of what life is for locals living there.

Charming district. Our tuk tuk driver took us on a tour of Alfama, definitely worth exploring, the residents are very proud of their properties, the colours are beautiful and the narrow streets are a rare find. Some quirky restaurants which are family run are dotted around the area.
Beautiful Views. Got to see the beautiful area of Alfama during a segwaty tour in Lisbon. Lovely little cafes and restaurants, great place to listen to the traditional Fado music!

Alfama Tour. I would recommend the Free Lisbon tours which include Alfama Tour but you actually pay for this one as it is a little special! Try and get Yuri Wentink as your guide as he is brilliant!!!!
Amazing. Alfama is absolutely amazing. We were lucky enough to have a lovely guide who took us in his tuk tuk to showed us around. Alfama is spectacular and definitely worths to be seen.

Beautiful. We loved walking the streets of Alfama with its quaint narrow winding roads and lovely places to eat. There was some building work along the way but it was easy to navigate and immerse yourself in the atmosphere of this atmospheric area of Lisbon, loved it.
Charming & unique. The oldest area in Lisbon. Nice for a tour, old world charm. It's the fado central. Worth a walk through, or use the Tuk tuk tours and ask to stop at this location.

Lovely Old Town. The Alfama district of Lisbon is a lovely atmospheric older part of the city. narrow cobbled streets with very little traffic make this area ideal for exploring on foot. We enjoyed a drink at a lovely terrace bar with fantastic panoramic views over the city before walking up to the castle. we then walked down from the castle to the cathedral.
The charming heart of Lisbon. This is where all the charming pictures of Lisbon are taken. There is a surprise around every corner. I suggest starting from the castle and working your way down.
Unique. The oldest of Lisbon. The tiny streets. In the evening, you walk in the tiny streets and you can hear fado shows in many places.

It's very touristy.. I read the reviews on the alfalfa area and we stayed in that part on Lisbon. It was nice but seems very touristy compared to other parts of Lisbon... I would stay elsewhere the next time we come.

Magnificent Alfama!!. Failing to visit Alfama is to miss the best part of Lisbon. Walking through it's narrow footpaths is to walk back in time when trams and cars were nonexistent. Laundry hangs from lines outside apartment windows, small neighborhood restaurants dot the streets; artist shops, small parks, bakeries and potters offer places of respite.

The place to come. Lisbon's oldest district is so compact but with streets of both steep hills and character with the Castle sitting right at the top.It's so easy to get to and really sets the scene of what Lisbon is all about.If you come to Lisbon, you will miss out if you don't come here. The only problem is, as often the case with old districts, that wheelchair access is really difficult.
Next time, I'll spend more time here. The old twisting, curving part of the city is gorgeous. My next trip to Lisbon, I'll be spending more time exploring this unique neighborhood.

Beautiful area of Lisbon, incredible food. If you are visiting Lisbon, Alfama is a must. Around every corner there is a beautiful view of the city. It can be quite hilly but the views more than make up for this. Such a lovely place to stroll around and some incredible places to eat. Plus very very cheap sangria!

Hills, sights and good restaurants. Get your best walking shoes on and get exploring. Lots of walking or the ever full tram 28. Maybe best to take the tram to the top, near the castle and walk down from there. The castle is a good sight with a splended view over the town. Near by are some monasteries, churches and national pantheon. You might also visit the cruise harbour down the hill with some nice restaurants by the river and take metro back to the Baixa.Eat lunch or come back at night for dinner at some of the small cosy and good restaurants. Some with fado.
Everywhere is a short walk.. We explored all of the small streets and alleyways. Great for those who love to walk. Views from the viewpoints are exceptional.

Interesting neighborhood. This is a windy, hodgepodge of buildings that compromises an entire neighborhood. The area is very compact, with public showers and laundry for some of the areas. As a result, the people spend most of their day outside of their homes. It has a warm, friendly atmosphere. A typical suggestion is to walk around and get lost. There are numerous small bars and restaurants to stop and watch the world go by.

Best views in Lisbon. You can access the best views in Lisbon via the infamous tram 28 the tourist tram. Many people visit this area so always very crowded. I was staying nearby so had a lot of time to take in the views both day and night.
Alfama. Nice and historical place in Lisbon.. raining day not good idea to visit the most of Fado restorante is here

Only passing through but it had character!. We only passed through on a walking tour around Lisbon, however if you're looking for a corner of the city that offers authenticity, this would be worth a look.
A taste of old Lisbon. It's wonderful to sit on the café of the square overlooking Alfama drinking a coffee on a sunny day. The place is full of life, street artists, tourists, traffic.
Great part of town. All of Lisbon is fun to walk around in and to see the sights from, as they have several places that overlook the hills.

beautiful. best view over the city
fantastic place to take fotos
lots of relaxing places to have a drink
is a must go/do in Lisbon!

Good as part of a tour. Alfama is part of 'hidden' Lisbon and its relevance to the city may be difficult to discern unless you have someone guide you through the narrow , twisty, steep-stepped streets. If you want the best views of the city you will get some of them from here and if you want the fado nightlife this is the sultry spot to visit. Not one for people with physical disability, however!
Should not miss..... It's a lovely section of Lisbon, full of history and culture. The views from here are simply gorgeous, and it also offers varieties of good restaurants.
A beautiful old neighbourhood of Lisbon!. You would be a fool to come to Lisbon and not wander around Alfama! Beautiful old cobbled streets, trams, beautiful architecture :)
Lovely old part of Lisbon. Wish I had more time to go thru Alfama. So much to see. Make sure you have plenty of time as it's so hilly you'll need to take your time to see it all.
Old part of Lisbon. Make sure you have very comfortable shoes and be ready for multiple stair cases. You can always take tram #28.

Lovely neighborhood. No visit to Lisbon would be complete without a visit to Alfama. I recommend taking tram #15 to the top and walking from there. You will see so much more just wandering the side streets. Lots of great cafes and shops. Forget the map and just take a compass, you can't get lost.

Very interesting historical area of Lisbon. It helps to take a guided tour of Alfama as the history of the area helps to appreciate it better. (We went with Sandeman's tours which are excellent) Very steep winding alleyways with hidden gems at every corner and beautiful views of Lisbon. Get a tram 28 to the top and walk down to save nergy but also because the trip on the tram is a great experience.
Charming. This area of Lisboa is very charming with its narrow Streets and colourful houses with washing hanging outsider besiddes small squares and churches.
Portuguese Montmartre. Lovely neighborhood. Super quiet at night. Perfect location for staying. It is quite close to the city center. I recommend walking, taking tram 28 is a nightmare.

Do the free walking tour.. Take the free walking tour and explore lissabon.
Get some history and visit place's that tourist most of the time don't see.
After 3 hours of exploring the nice city, you pay what you like.

A small village in the middle of Lisbon.. Alfama is one of the best things I have experienced in Lisbon. Our Tuk guide already showed us around in a small part of this area and he advised us to go back to Alfama and get lost in the small streets. We followed his advice and had a great day. There are a lot of cosy affordable restaurants and if you walk around it doesn't feel like you're in a big city. For people who want to escape the crowded centre this is a good option!

losing my way.... This is the older and the most tipical area of Lisbon, it's so easy to lose there... but after a few times you lose yourself, you can definitely find your way, and meanwhile you're going to enjoy the amazing view of the city...

scenery view is breathtaking. when walking around in Lisbon, you must visit this area, enjoying all the different terraces on a different level, with local food and drink stands, musicians or real cafe's. Look around you and discover !
Nice to see. Nice place to stroll around and see the views over Lisbon. Quaint streets and small souvenir shops to visit.
Old neighbourhood. Old buildings, was quite in the morning , smell of food in the St was nice. Nice tiles on buildings.

Old Town. Alfama is set to the side of Lisbon city centre and is the crumbling old town. It is hilly and full of narrow streets and is a real experience. A must do in Lisbon. Even if you skip the main sights like the castle, just wandering around is experience enough!

Ahh Alfama. Stayed in this neighbourhood near the castle. A culture shock at first coming from a quiet little Welsh village to what seemed a packed, noisy, graffiti maze but by the end of the week loved it and was really sad to leave even the midnight rubbish collection we thought was an earthquake, the builders running from falling rubble (no 'elf n safety), the neighbours fado music, the old ladies in the dark little corner shop and the lively community atmosphere. All happy life is here.
House Of Fado. À wonderful neighbourhood to walk and enjoying the best fado in town...Stop sat Esperanza a wonderful Italian restaurant next to the cathedral

Old part of town!. Definitely check out Alfama. While only a stone's throw away from the rest of Lisbon, it is easy to distinguish the narrow, winding streets of pre-earthquake alfama with the rest of Lisbon.
Try hit up a hostel walking tour and go check out a few of the wine bars in alfama - don't forget to check out a flamenco show!

a place to be. Being a place of many summits and conferences Lisbon in my imagination was always the city of "officials" or "politics" until watching the movie IMAGINE where the main characters were filmed in wonderful and historical Lisboa. Since then I was eager to visit this city, to walk in the tiny streets of Alfama and to see those famous trams going here and there. Luckily I did it. As an Old Town lover (wherever I go my first choice is to walk in Old Part of the city and to feel that aura) walking and seeing things in Alfama made my travel worth for it. Mixed culture, muslim and christian ornaments on the buildings, lovely people - neighbours, fado music in the cafes, from the upper side view to the Tajo River makes Alfama unique in it's own way. Definitely must see place for Mixed Culture and Old town lovers.

Old City. We visited the Old Cities in several different cities in both Spain and Portugal. This one still needs clean up. There was graffiti on some buildings and we were warned numerous times about the professional pickpockets.

Trip to Alfama. My wife and I just spent the day in Alfama after going to St. Jorge's Castle in Lisbon. We mainly walked around the neighborhood. Alfama has a lot of character and is quite interesting. St. Jorge's castle is definitely worth seeing and has commanding views of Lisbon. If I were to go back, I would take the tram through. I think that would have been a perfect pairing with the neighborhood.
must see. If you don't mind walking, and it is quite steep, it is very interesting, Lovely little streets. If you don't think you can walk it, take a Tuc Tuc
Quaintest Place. My favourite part of city - twists and turns , narrow little streets ,restaurants etc . Beautiful. Enjoy best by aimlessly wandering
Cool area. Spent a week on business in Lisbon and was here for an afternoon. Worked everywhere. Worth the visit for sure.

So pretty!. Be prepared to walk and wear comfy shoes on this lovely walk through Alfama up to the St. George's Castle. You must experience the views from there. There are inclines, and the roads are paved, but if you are prepared for all of that, go and enjoy!

Excellent District. This is where there are many good authentic restaurants at reasonable prices and at night one can go here to listen to Fado music. Also in this area is the Fado Museum which is great for music lovers and one can buy discs here too. Also nearby for the historians is the Army museum which is a must for historians.
Great Fado and Views. Great place to hear traditional fado, super picturesque to walk, and full of food, drink,and history-a must place to visit

Gritty, but over all safe and charming. This neighborhood is on the gritty side, but I enjoyed my lost for about hour and half through the inter winding streets tour. Over all the neighborhood is safe. Everyone I asked for directions, gave me a different set of directions? Finally I reached my destination, a fado club called abiuca, only to be told it was closed for renovations. I still had a good time soaking up the atmosphere. Whole neighborhood felt like a movie set. During dinner time the whole neighborhood smells like grilled sardines, which I love.

A Great Walk. Beautiful for views and spending a day just walking around as well as checking out other close by attractions. We enjoyed a lovely lunch in the area with a pitcher of sangria to top it all off.
Worth a visit. Alfama is worth the visit when you are in Lisbon. Nice views, cosy streets. Enjoy a drink and experience the Portugese culture.

Wonderful old city sights. The origin of water in Lisboa - needs a lot of walking - do a tuk-tuk tour. There is also a beautiful tree with huge oranges. We saw the place in the daytime, but evening is when it comes alive.
Good for nightlife. Walk down the streets, dine in old-age restaurants, enjoy the sunset, shop in traditional outlets. Good Portuguese foods are available. Must for foodies.

Attention heart beat. We spent four nights in the historic centre of Alfama, discovering it's maze of small streets,wonderful restaurants ,cafes.There is a fantastic " ambiance" in this area , the sound of fado, reverberating around the ancient buildings.
