One word of advice, take some good walking shoes and be prepared to tackle some fairly steep streets!

Best sunset view in town!. Have a Vinho Verde, take your time and relax in the late afternoon with a wonderful view. You will meet people from all over the word, just chilling, playing guitar and talk to each other

Lovely old town. We stayed in Alfama for a weekend. It was so nice, very hilly, narrow little streets, lane ways and steps. Not suitable if you have mobility probs but lovely little district. We really were in the heart of things!

Interesting and typical neighbourhood. An old hilly neighbourhood of the city, characterised by narrow paved roads and alleys, fados restaurants, and small dwellings. In some aspects, it reminded me of the old parts of Italian southern cities. Some great monuments, miradouros (panoramic points), and churches can be found here or in its immediate whereabouts.Ask the locals about a good place where to eat, as the area has also touristic restaurants with inflated prices.

Very interesting place. Lots of Fado We will have to back to experience more Fado and visit the fado museum. We ran out of time as it was our last day. Recommend see Alfama first and experience local Fado
Alfama is beautiful. Alfama's beauty and pitoresc apeals to most of the tourists, but also to the portuguese foulks. I simply love it! It's my favorite part of Lisbon

Time travel!. A stunning old area of Lisbon, filled with charm, character and history! The little cobble streets, small taverns, restaurants, sites, smells and fado, will leave you blissful and begging to return! Tip, wear comfortable shoes... Alfama is based on a hillside!
Unique . Unique old town with very steep winding cobbled streets, a maze of tiny streets with surprises round every corner, residents very welcoming. Beautiful place to visit.

To be avoided. Travel Agents often include it in the programs. They do it because they want to give you the ilusion that you will be visiting a charming, typical place, but the true reason is that it is free, and other places to be visited have entrance fees. Alfama is dirty, smelly, full of pick-pockets, so just do not go there. I am myself an Official Tourism Guide, I know what I am talking about.
Full of character . Very pleasant walk with the bonus of trying some Ginjinha off the locals! Came through this area on the free walking tour.
A piece of silence. It's a old part of Lisbon where wa a port and brothels in old times. You may walk around small streets. You can see but nothing particularly attractive.
Walking tour. We did a podcast walking tour and it was quite easy to get lost! Interesting though. I would do it on a day that's not really hot.
Lovely quarter. The area has been largely preserved and rewards wandering. The views from the castle are superb. The removal of disfiguring graffiti could be pursued more vigorously

A must. Use the tram 28 to reach Sao Jorge Castle, after visit it walk down the Alfama district direction Tejo River, going through little streets, typical buildings and great tavernas as well as very good snacks or restaurant places. Good wine and tapas.
Cute area. Walk around the small streets to get a real experience of alfama. Stop and listen, in the middle of a big city you don't hear any cars.. Quite unique

Winding cobbled lanes and authentic Lisbom. We absolutely loved this area and recommend setting a day aside to walk the cobbled lanes of authentic Lisbon. Lots of pretty side street cafes and wine shops, so perfect for hanging out for the day. We came across plenty of view points during our walk too, which had amazing views across the whole of Lisbon. We stopped off at a wine/tapas cafe at the foot of Castelo Sao Jorge, which was lovely and very reasonable. Despite the hoards of tourists visiting this area, it still felt authentic and keeps its charm. We came backIn the evening and had a lovely, authentic meal at Guitaras De Lisboa Fado - a little restaurant off one of the side streets that played live Portugese music. The food was amazing and although pricier than other meals we had, it was worth the extra euros - for 3/4 starters (bread, olives, cheese and sausage) 2 mains and a bottle of wine it was just under 100 euros. There are probably lots of restaurants like it as the whole area seemed to have the theme of small and authentic, but as the only one we went to we would recommend.
Charming. Was great to walk around this area! Narrow streets with lovely houses and roof-views! A must see when you are in Lisbon.

Holday. Just a lovely timeless place. Stroll the streets, be with local people. Lots of cafes and restaurants. Go to the flea market. Loads of things to do and the magic of tram 28 rumbling through even if it wakes you early in the morning.

Don't Miss This. If you ever happen to visit Lisbon, Portugal, you must spend some time in the Alfama district. This is the oldest area in Lisbon and it offers an excellent taste of historic Portuguese culture! It's not the easiest place to get to-buses can't really get into the area, the streets are way too narrow! My best advice is to take either Tram #28 or catch a ride on one of those little scooter taxi's which I did, up to the top of the area, then work your way down of foot. If you like culture, you'll love this place! Make time to sample a little food and drink there, and hopefully stay until evening and catch a little Fado music. You won't be disappointed! The people there are very friendly and simple folk. Would've loved to spend a few more days there!

Historical Lisbon.. We stayed in Alfama and it is a place full of history and great views of the river.There are plenty of small side streets to explore and if you keep heading upwards you eventually come to the castle which is well worth a visit and has great 360 dregree views over lisbon.There are some nice cafes that overlook the river and are a great place to stop and have a coffee.

interesting history and walking. We loved wandering through the Alfama district. It is quaint, beautiful and full of history. We enjoyed a stop at an outdoor cafe and prices were great, like 2 Euros for a glass of wine!

Place full of wonders! The best place to get lost.. Tip 1: Transportation. Buy a daily ticket in Metro or Kiosk for 6 euros and travel with metro/bus/tram/elavators for free. Its especially useful in this district as walking there is literal hiking up and down the hills! You can take tram 28 or tram 15 to get on the top and then start discovering little streets and charming views from there.Tip 2: Food. Take your own lunch or at least some sweets. In this way you will be able to have your picnic on any time you want!Tip 3: Use elevator! there are two elevators, which will take you up and down to this district.

Proper Lisbon.... Just wander around the hilly streets climbing up to the castle and absorb the atmosphere. Listening for Fado music,flapping laundry,people gossiping and enjoy the colours and style of the buildings.
Great views!. Great city views. Little coffee shop on top of the hill with artists available to sell painted tiles and accessories.
lovely town to look around. You can get Tram 28 to visit but we chose to walk, very hilly but views were amazing, so many historic places to see, its well worth going
Charming. You really feel the history while walking up and down (and criss-cross) these narrow charming streets. Enjoy!

So beautiful that it is worth getting sun burnt for! . We paid for the Yellow Bus tour to get to Alfama. We were provided earphones for the radio guide which is part of the yellow bus tour service on the way to Alfama. The weather was extremely hot, quite a hilly and tiring walk to get to castillo De Sao Jorge - but with no regrets, it is one of the most breathtaking view I have seen in my life.

Slice of historic Lisbon. The Alfama neighborhood was apparently one of the few that survived the 1755 earthquake relatively unscathed, so it provides a slice of what historic Lisbon looked like centuries ago. Lots of narrow, crooked, jagged streets provide such a cool experience. Photo ops everywhere if you're into this (like I am). Beautiful tile work, homey shops nestled in rows of narrow buildings. I felt very safe the whole time, though there was a lot of walking up and down elevations. Take your time and enjoy.
Stay in Alfama. If there is anywhere in Lisbon you should stay it is in Alfama. Near to Everything and lots of good restaurants.

Charming and hilly. Charming little part of Lisbon, situated just below the castle. On our first attempt we actually walked straight through Alfama into another town and had to head back, it isn't a very large area! Lots of nice eateries and places to drink with a spectacular view too and if you can, grab a tram at the top and head back down on it to the main square.

Must see part of Lissabon. Small streets in this old part of town. Lot of Fado restaurants. Very nice panoramic views. Very beautiful historical sites. Take tram 28 to cross this part of town. Otherwise a good walk. Wear sneakers.

Great area to wander around. Charming area with narrow streets. Great area just to wonder around and enjoy the charm of an old part of the city. Great photography opportunities with hilly and narrow streets with old trams. Check out the miradouro Nossa senhora do monte at sunset for great views over the city and the castle.
Beautiful district. Completely different to the centre of Lisbon and worth exploring. It is like travelling back in time! Great local feel to the area.
My favorite part of the city. The small charming streets, great coffee shops and restaurants, fab shopping and easy access to the castle. Loved loved this place!
Very interesting. A very special place you must visit if you have the oportunity. You won't forget its typical streets. I recommend you to take a camera with you.

Beautiful view. The first time we went the weather was warm and clear skies-lots of women trying to sell beads on the street. The next time the weather was raining and no one around but we still enjoyed the view. A local shop advised us to watch out for pick pockets-fyi. They crowds were keeping us from the trolley-may we will be there again.
Old town charm. Loved the old town charm. We recommend joining a free walking tour and learn about the history of the area. Very interesting indeed.

Beautiful old section of Lisbon. We stayed in Alfama for the first half of our Lisbon trip, and ended up wishing we'd stayed there the whole trip... just walking around the narrow streets, seeing all the historic buildings and small shops and restaurants...so much culture. A must see if you travel to Lisbon!

Walk. Use the 28 Tram to Alfama, walk along rua and be lost, you will discover nice places, some Portuguese restaurants, cafés and shops Visit museum of Fado not so far away..On Tuesday go to the market behind the Pantheon.be carefull with you money bag this place is known as a pickpocket place! I don' experience that.Take time, walk and have a good time.

Don't forget your walking shoes!. Alfama was all that I read about and more. The tiled walls, the little shops, the little cafes/restaurants, the narrow picturesque streets.. An essential part of the visit to Lisbon
Walk or Tram. Walk or take tram, but whatever you do visit it to get real feel of Lisboa. Also look out for where locals eat, as area is a mix of tourist and locals.
Where the locals are. We stayed at Alfama. It's very pleasant and authentic. Lots of cobbled roads, titled buildings. The Santa Apolonia links to the rest of the town.

Get off the beaten track!. Wonder off the main streets and get lost in the back streets of this lovely area. Okay so it's very hilly and it's almost impossible to orientate yourself with a map but the small squares and cafes make up for it!

Ful lof tourists even in February school term time. I have seen many Arab places full of little streets etc etc. This area is vastly over rated and full of tourists. It felt like it had the "Barcelona" effect - in other words, spoilt be so called fame.

Alfama, is the eldest city part of Lisbon, my favourite place to live.. Visit Sao Vicente de Fora Church and the Monestary (a super museum) with lots of tiles.Go up to the Graca Church with a miradouro, a viewpoint over the city of Lisbon -and to the Castle Jorge, lots of neat and narrow streets, colored tiles and colored houses, small cafees, bakeries, restaurants, mini mercados.... a jar of house wine costs 2,50 euro, there is a fleemarked every tuesday and saturday behind the Sao Vincente de Fora Church and that area is called Ladra. The fleemarked is fun, I bought DVD's for 0,50 to 1 euro a piece, make sure it say ingles audio on the cover! The yellow tram 28 goes up through Graca and ends near Rossio Metro station, there visit Sao Domingo Church, absolutely wonderful and special. Read its history on the net first. It's a Jewish memorial star outside in the front of a Massacre in the 15th century. If you take the tram the other way, you arrive at Lisbon SE Cathedral, on the otherside of the street is St Anthony's of Paduas birthplace, on with is erected a church, visit the crypt, Pope John Paul ll visited the crypt 12/5-82, before he went on to Fatima on the 13/5-82, to place the bullet that hit him, in the Crown of the Lady of Fatima. Further down the street you find Luzia miradouro, with a stunning view to the river, then walking downwards is the St Mary Magdalena Church and continue your walk down to Rua de Augusta, have fun!

A stunning place. We saw a marvelous panorama above all the city. A unique place to visit. It looked like a photo from a postcard: the sky was blue, ancient buildings, the river... I recommend going there. Very nice atmosphere, too.

Excellent views across the city.. The castle is a bit of climb but well worth the effort, make sure you have flat shoes as the streets are cobbled. The views from the top are magnificent. You can walk around the battlements, there are lots of steps to climb and the handrails are not in the best condition, so children will need keeping a careful eye on. Good walking shoes are a must, interesting shops and cafes some with lovely terrace bars overlooking the city. The locals are very friendly and you feel quite safe walking down the tiny side streets. Take a camera, you will get some fabulous photographs.
Nice old part of town. We booked a place here with airbnb. It is a great place to stay. Quiet at night, a lot of old buildings to visit. Great place

Maze of small streets. Alfama is the heart of the old city. It's a maze of small streets, with very authentic look. Not tourist fancy, but authentic neighborhood that looks a bit out of time. Take a tram to the top, you'll be amazed how old trams navigate narrow streets, and than you'll get the best views over Alfama and Tejo.

Rooms with a view. We stayed in this area. Fantastic views from all parts. Very beautiful lots of interesting little streets that all seem to leed to the same place. You can,t get lost just keep walking. Castle has a fantastic view point. Jump on a tuk tuk but be prepared for all the bumps roads are cobbled and your teeth with rattle.
My favourite neighborhood. Start at the castle and wander down to the river. Get lost. Say Ola to locals. Eat fish. Drink wine. Experience Fado. It's magic.
Impressive. We were intrigued with the old world atmosphere of this area.Especially loved the buildings, If you find the hills too steep, take the tram.
Old Lisbon. A much older and part of Lisbon, old building and very few shops. A great place for a peaceful walk with several vantage points for great views over Lisbon
Unique Neighborhood. Just walk the streets slowly being sure to stop frequently to examine the buildings and stores. You will feel like you are in another time, let alone place. Nothing else like it.

Good panorama view point near the central. Look down most of the city including Ponte 25 de Abril and Castelo de S. Jorge. Get there by Tram 28 with a bit of walk, or entirely by walk up-hill (tram is always full). On fine day, the promised place for a picture of memory.

You simply must visit. I spent an afternoon getting lost in the streets here. There are so many amazing viewpoints and it is such a quaint part of the city. You simply cannot miss this when you come to Lisbon, it was my favourite part of my trip!

Lovely stroll. I used the DK eyewitness Lisbon guidebook 90 minute walking tour of Alfama with a side trip to the Se and Santo Clara market as well as the castle. I ate lunch at Cafe Pois near the Se rather than the coffee break recommended. It was excellent and reasonably priced. This was a lovely walk filled with great views, lovely buildings, and charming side streets. I ended the day in the large squares below and chiado and Baixa walk. Highly recommend these walks for a slice of Lisbon. My Fitbit said this amounted to 6 miles of walking and 56 flights of stairs so wear the right shoes. The key to enjoy this spot is to walk and soak in the atmosphere. I did it over a day and found it not at all tiring.
where getting lost is what u should do. a charming and quaint area of lisbon. walking there can give u a sense of what life was like way back. wish we had more time to explore.
A lovely area to visit. Lisbon is a lovely city to explore on foot, and the charming alleyways, bars and houses of the Alfama are a particularly lovely way to spend an afternoon.
Most see it!. An interestin place from Lisbon to be visit! A beautifull view, nice restaurants, nice streets and very nice houses and an unic history!

Just wander. The old quarter of Lisbon has all the features you could want - a cathedral, a parthenon, museums, a castle, tile, but most of all stunning views, lots of little streets and a feeling this is not just an empty tourist trap but a place with a soul all of its all.A little bus will take you right through the district and stop near the castle entrance if you dpn't fancy the walk. Or (but be warned they are often full) the No 28 Tram is one of the old-fashioned trams and will take you on a scenic route through the district but not as near to the castle as the bus.Great little cafes can be found down little alley ways and I had my first taste of the amazing Portuguese custard tart in one such cafe.

Good view. I was keen to visit the place based upon the photos shared by tourists during my 2 days visit at Lisbon. Of course once you reach to the point you will enjoy the scenery but be sure to get down at right place since the location or the stop is not displayed in the public bus. The lack of stadia and conspicuous sign boards of attractions at several places, in fact spoiled the pleasure of seeing all these beautiful places.

Lovely Area, Friendly People. There is an amazing view over the city which can be enjoyed as street musicians strum and the elderly trams rattle passed. There are a good range of small shops and plenty of places to city with a coffee, relax and watch people walking past.

Great place to stay or visit. We're staying in an apartment here and feel like we're in the real/old lisbon. Lots of cobbled streets, 28 tram gets you out of the area every 10 minutes or more, nice little cafes and restaurants and beautiful, traditional architecture.
Wonderful for a stroll. One of the older parts of the city. Great for walking around. Lots of steep and narrow streets. Beautiful houses with the famous Portuguese tiles.
Nice stroll . Walked over from the city centre. Lots of small restaurant and shops along the narrow streets. Felt atmosphere was better up the hill, wasn't as nice near the water front.

This is the REAL Lisbon. If you want to see the Real LIsbon, then Alfama is a must! Especially on Saint Anthony's day 10th June. That's when its street parties are second to none. Especially if you soak up the atmosphere by eating with the locals the traditional St Anthony favorite ie freshly grilled sardines, boiled potatoes and salad or you could just have the sardines on bread to soak up all the juices. Of course all washed down with plenty of wine! Perfect!

Make sure you have Ulmon.. This is the hilly,narrow, winding area of Lisbon that will give you a real authentic feel for the city. Tiny shops, hole in the wall bars and cafes, bakeries to die for. Hustle and bustle and if you don't have the ap Ulmon on your phone get it before you venture in and and then just go where ever the feeling takes you. People are so friendly but their accents are gruff, so take no notice. Wonderful people, Don't taste to much Ginja (cherry liquor served in chocolate cups) or you will never get out. I loved it and would probably stay in that area next time rather than up on the hill at the castle.

What a view. Alfama is maybe the most ancient district of Lisbon. The famous FADO is performed in many places in Alfama. There is an amasing panoramic viewpoint of the town with the River Tejo on the background (which many think it´s the sea because it´s blue). (There are another 3 or for of these viewpoints, called Miradouros). Going there on foot is a great fun because of the narrow streets where, if you do not take care, you might get lost.Saint Jeorge Castle (Castelo de São Jorge), is a fortress also deserving a visit.

Wonderful Atmosphere . I love wandering around the streets of the old Alfama district. It's steeped in history with lots of little winding streets and a wonderful atmosphere. There are many little cafe bars and restaurants to choose from.Highly recommended.

Had a great tile fantastic palce to visit!!. We had taken a guided tour of Lisbon so we were chauffered from our hotel. Our guide gave us a detailled explanation about the palce history and all. Was really nice and as it was sunny that defenately enhanced our visit. Nice tourisitc place to visit.
The soul of Lisboa . Hilly, gritty, colorful, soulful, interesting and authentic. And hilly. Lots of history but a generally enjoyable neighborhood to soak up the authentic Lisbon living

Picturesque part of Lisbon. Very picturesque jumble of narrow streets and alleyways running down to the waterside. Sited between the castle and the river. Some interesting little shops, bars and cafes. Worth a meander down.

Remote and still not so. Alfama...get lost ( I mean, walk without a map, according to your orientation system ) and 'taste' this piece of Lisa. You won't regret it.If you are a fado fan, this is the place : you can choose the restaurant according to your budget, small or big, a homey sphere or grandeur..there is for all budgets.Admire the walls of old buildings, feel the life of this different world...and then go down in Rossio...if you are like me, you just turn back, up the hill...

Amazing view. It really is an azing view there. I had a really good beer followimg the sunset. The only thing is that the waiter of the caffee we went to was really rude when I mistaken one church with castle. I really cant know everything about foreign countries. So locals, be more polite please, we are doing our best!
A maze of streets and alleys. Make Alfama a part of any visit to Lisbon. Wander the streets and just meander around. Stop at Flor dos Arcos for lunch and eat grilled sardines.

One of the few places where you get a real taste of Lisbon. One cannot say he went to Lisbon if he did not visit one place like Alfama. It is a Typical place, with a deep connection to Fado, the portuguese soul. It is nice for a little walk, to get an insight of how the last century was.You can find there some real Fado Houses (if you pick well, it is always recommended to ask the locals). And have a nice meal.There are lots of historical and beautiful places near it, like "Castelo de São Jorge" and "Igreja da Sé".
Great to wander . What a great spot to walk around and soak up the Lisbon vibe. Great little bars and restaurants around every corner and some amazing street art.

THE OLDEST PART OF LISBOA; ALFAMA. I enjoyed my walk up to hilly Alfama quarter and tere were many photo opportunities.The street plan refers to the roman and muslim period;Alfama survived the 1755 earthquake due to it,s possition on a hill.there are some museums and many churches to visit,both a working class and a touristy neighborhood.

A must visit. Go in the early evening , visit the Fado museum which is very well done . Then cross the street & stroll in the narrow streets of Alfama . Listen to Fado from several resturants & bars around . We usually go to St Antonio da Alfama , great food & a very charming typical place . Captures the soul of Alfama . Club do Fado always have great fado singers too

Colorful neighborhood back in time. A favorite place to visit, wander the narrow streets and seeing canaries perched in their cages singing their Lisbon songs, chatter throughout the day from older ladies sitting in their windows watching the world outside, great family restaurants and whitewashed buildings reminiscent of old Lisbon. A must see when visiting! !
Amazing. Portugal at its best. I highly recommend it. It's sunny even in winter.... you couldn't possibly want more.

Heart of historic Lisbon. Alfama, the heart of historic Lisbon, consists of a maze of cobblestone streets, many stairs, small bars and cafes, amazing views, picturesque buildings and friendly locals. I initially took a guided tour to get the 'feel' for the area, and then returned on my own to wander the streets and neighbourhoods watching neighbours chatting, laundry hanging out to dry, the sounds and smells of meals being prepared, amazing views, and enjoying the sense sof community that is ever present. The walk is tiring, whether going up hill or down, so stop at one of the many cafes and enjoy ginjiiha (cherry liquor) or a sweet treat. While trams pass through the neighbourhood, walking the narrow and winding streets is the best way to discover the unique atmosphere of the area. You are almost bound to get lost, so don't worry about it .... enjoyi the sights, smells and sounds of a unique area that has endured for years.

Must visit!. Alfama, the old town, is a must see! The winding streets which largely survived the 1755 earthquake and the residents mulling about really give you a feel for life in this area (it doesn't feel touristy, even though it's a top area to visit). I'd recommend going with a guide, because they can give you a flavour for life in alfama, historically and now.
Alfama. My favourite part of Lisbon - have a coffee outside in Portas do Sol and enjoy the views over the city.

just go. i had a amazing week in Alfama and around... theres so much to see to smeel...to taste... and to walk around.
in Alfama you are like in the hart of the historic lisbon city. so you always find things to see to do to try to go... explore as much as you can.

So much to see. We were given a map of the things to do in Alfama when we went to the Pantheon. Everything we saw was included on the Lisboa card or free. You can do a long walk or a shorter walk and see all the sights, lots of hills but lovely to walk down the winding lanes and streets. Great way to spend half a day.
Lost. Lose yourself in the neighborhood. Give yourself time to wander the maze like streets and every turn you will find a surprise.

Forget the map, and get lost. Lovely neighbourhood with arab origin, it is a wonderful maze of streets and steps, located between the river Tagus and the castle of Saint George, at the top of the hill.The best you can do to really get the most of the area is spend a whole morning there, wandering around, without following your guide, and getting really lost. Only doing so you will be able to find deserted streets and beautiful alleyways, where you will find yourself alone and transported to a long gone time. There are also miradores and interesting places to visit, like the Sé, Panteon, etc, but you will get eventually to them if you really spend long enough in Alfama.
Old world charm. We would always stay in Alfarma at Santiago. It is central, near many sites, close to centre and accessible cheaply by tram or taxi

A must see!. Wonderful little nooks and crannies which leave you awestruck. Cobbled ' streets,' fabulous tiled buildings and architecture from days gone by. I went on my own, without a map and found my way around. You can take tram 28 if you like but I went on foot from Martim Moniz.

Gorgeous little neighbourhood. If walking around small picturesque streets is your thins this is brilliant. There's not a huge amount to do but wandering, and it's pretty hilly so a good walkout, but it's gorgeous and the people are friendly, and the views stunning.

Explore a maze of narrow streets. We rode tram 12 to the top, explored Sao Jorge Castle then walked back into town and explored the narrow streets and alleys of Alfama. A wonderful way to spend ½ a day.

Wonderful wandering. A great, safe place to stroll and get lost in. Get ready to do a LOT of stairs! Find a quaint local restaurant, they are cheap friendly and helpful. When you are warn out find a busy street, hail a cab and be back at your hotel in 10 minutes for under €10.

typical and sorrowful. The best thing to do to go to Alfama is to take the classic tram n. 28. I suggest to visit Alfama in a sunny day: priceless! I love to get lost in the narrow street with laundry hanging to dry and food smell. The real heart of Lisbon. Beautiful.
A place out of time. A recommendation: visit it with the Lisboa Free Chill Out Tour Guide. Miguel will make you appreciate and love this place
Historic. Explore the tiny winding streets, and follow the staircases, enjoy views of the city and river at every turn, watch the world go by from little cafes, and use the 2 free lifts.

Sightseeing (viewpoints). ONe of the most beautiful viewpoints in Lisbon. Really worth to have a snack there and enjoy view. It was quite crowded even in February so its not a perfect pace for romantic walk, but I can recommend for travelers, photographers, people who like to draw. The colours are amazing,

a rare surviving quarter from middle ages. Alfama is rather special, if you are loooking for something special; it is 1 of the few surviving mediavel quarters with an islamic influence in its design, still inhabited in Europe. the extremelly narrow lanes and the characteristic inhabitants and their behaviour are unique, but that is IT.
First visit to Lisbon.. Lovely little streets and beautiful views of the river. Check out the market on a Saturday, but not everything is cheap, found some items cheaper in other places.

Timeless. You can wander around the steep, narrow streets of the Alfama district and it feels that little has ever changed. you come upon colourful little squares and tiny bars selling ginjinha (cherry liqueur. it has a lovely atmosphere as you wander around. it is true that there are a lot of shops and restaurants trying to capture the tourist trade. However we found restaurant prices reasonable and the locals were very friendly.I get the feeling that the tourist trade in the area is increasing and it could, in time, spoil the charm of the district but this has not happened yet. Be warned the streets are steep to walk so not great for infirm visitors.
Alfama is the old town.. Went in January, very quiet, peaceful & the streets are cobbled and steep. You need good walking shoes. Trams plentiful.

Breathe Lisbon. Full of alleys to walk,allow yourself to "get lost" in this magnificent neighborhood,have a coffee or a beer,buy little souvenirs,"breathe Lisbon" take pictures,enjoy the view from the roofs and terraces nearby...be amazed,put your flat shoes on and go!

For you that love Fado!. A lovely neighborhood in Lisbon where you can feel the taste of real Lisbon with its beautiful and colorful tiled houses, delicious restaurants and charming Fado places to enjoy the night in Lisbon

Great Views. This is a must to see the views and to soak up the atmosphere of Lisbon. As you can imagine there are many tourist and the trams pack up really fast to get up and down - but still who could miss it!! Atmosphere?? :)

Our favorite Lisbon neighborhood. For the last eight years we have always been on a holiday trip to Lisbon during winter break (two weeks sometime between mid-January and mid-February). On a Tuesday or Saturday we take the metro to Santa Apolonia station and climb the steep streets up to the Feira da Ladra, fortifying ourselves by a bica (espresso) or a ginjinha (cherry liquor) at each of the small bars on the road. Feira da ladra is mostly a big flea market, but there are also many stands with new textiles, shoes, books, and music. On the upper part there is a small restaurant (this time unfortunately for us closed due to reconstruction work) that sells local food at a low price and is frequented by the exhibitors (no English spoken!). We then walk upwards to the Graca neighborhood where we take the #28 streetcar. Its wagons once circulated in San Francisco, CA and take you in a breathtaking ride through narrow and devilishly steep streets down to the Baixa and up again to the Chiado square. But there begins another story ...

A pretty time window. Walking around those streets and listening to the old ladies shouting and conversing from window to window, where they could almost shake hands, was both exotic and amazing. My next stay in Lisbon I will get a Airbnb at Alfama!

Tram #28 passes through ALFAMA but make it one of your stolling stops. Our family spent a few days eploring Lisbon and we loved Alfama. This neighborhood is one of the most beautiful in the city, it has tightly packed narrow cobblestone alleyways on steep hills so it is always best to begin exploring Alfama from the top and work your way down which is what we did and wear shoes with good traction. At the top of the hill in Alfama is the castle and at the bottom the estuary. Our walk though Alfama will gave us a glimpse of the traditional way of life in Lisbon and of how most of Lisbon looked before being generally gentrified. Alfama is also the site of Sé Cathedral, the national pantheon and Saint Anthony’s Church. TRam 28 passes right through this area and right in from of the cathedral. Around the Cathedral we found many small neighborhood cafes where locals hang out, small public squares, churches, tile panels, whitewashed houses, wrought-iron balconies, colorful laundry strung from the windows and window sills dripping with bright flowers. .I learned that Alfama began as a neighborhood inhabited by the Visigoths in the 5th century and you can still find parts of the old Visigoth town wall. After the Visigoths came the Moors and Alfama became an elite residential area. The area suffered from earthquakes but thanks to the solid rock beneath the houses it was one of the few areas in the city that survived the many powerful earthquakes. We liked Alfama because of its village feel where the locals were very friendly to us. Not only does Alfama offer a peak into the historical soul of Lisbon but you can also enjoy views across the city from this elevated neighborhood. As the neighborhood s now more chic, you can now find shopping streets with boutique stores and unique specialty stores but we just loved the architecture. The best way to see Alfama is to get lost and enjoy the picturesque scenes or take the historic tram #28 through the neighborhood.

Let you self get lost in the real Lisbon . We really loved this neighborhood! With small street and many typical Portuguese restaurants and shops. We rent an amazing Appartement name spirit 1512, in a old historical building. From outside we were not able to imagine how fantastic the place is inside. The decoration was fine and authentic, we felt like in a small castle! And from our place we could find many nice fado restaurant as well.Alfama is well located, not far from the shopping area and the party area, but much more quiet in the evening. For me it is the best place to stay when visiting Lisbon! Cheers
Not to be missed. THE PLACE for all including families, trendsetters: Historical, beautiful- worth the trip up the hill to see the river. Beautiful views. Gorgeous (day an dnight).

Old town Lisbon . Fado- food & Fundação Ricardo do Espírito Santo Silva& Tuk Tuk tour - loved all great neigborhood - Pantheon terraces at the top are incredible- the views the singing in the street so so beautiful -
Great Walking Area. It was a pleasure to walk around Alafama, especially to see the tiny doors. I came here with a walking tour, and I'd recommend that you do the same.

Narrow Streets and Slopes. Enjoy walking around narrow streets and slopes with your most comfortable walking shoes. You can have a glimpse of old style of people's life which is amazing to find so close to the center of Lisbon. Abundant small shops, cafe and restaurants (Fado places as well). You can walk many different ways but can combine with S Jorge castle for even better view. Fun to go after Chiado area to feel the contrast.

The old town of Lisbon. Like most old towns there was a good atmosphere with the narrow streets, trams, castle and cathedral being the highlights of the area. Although there are hawkers on the streets they are neither as many or as pushy as those found in many capitals. Just be careful of the traffic because it is busy.

Alfama a must see in Lisbon. I was born in Lisbon, very near Alfama, My grandmother lived in Alfama for many years, so I am very familiar with the area. This is a great and safe place to walk and get lost in! Great places to eat or just sit outside and have coffee. small local shops, extremely friendly people that make you feel at home. And of course don't miss St Jorge's castle.

Alfam. Take the tram for the best views ,takes you to the olde world part of Lisbon ,you can then walk back down to the town centre taking all the little bars and restaurants on the way.if you don't fancy waking just hop back on the tram
A stroll. Take time to wander and stroll through Alfama it is like going back in time. Stop and enjoy the fews and atmosphere
Interesting old part of Lisbon.. From "mirador" there is a nice view to the city of Lisbon. Stroll down the road (follow the tram rails) and enjoy this old part of the city.
Beautiful views-all uphill. Take the time to walk all the way to the top of Lisbon but be prepare to walk all up hill to get there. The view from the top is spectacular and worth the climb.

Plenty of culture. A lovely wander around the old narrow streets, with the locals hanging their washing out and the atmosphere as the streets are narrow the neighbours can talk to each other across the street from their little balcony, some of the streets are steep but we'll worth a visit
HISTORY & VIEWS. Wonderful views, narrow streets, full of history, gorgeous restaurants, walk and get lost and comunicate wih the locals. Tehy like it

Fado, culture and more. Alfama has been completely explored and discovered by tourists, but this is not necessarily a terrible thing: it allowed historic establishments to keep running as fado becomes less popular with younger Portuguese people. Walk around, avoid the tourist traps and enjoy. Best place for a good night of fado? The commonly overcrowded Mesa de Frades, hidden inside an old church. Make a reservation!

Quirky area. A very quiet and quirky area that is built around lots of hills and narrow streets. Locals spend lots of time outdoors as the properties are so small and even cook out on the pavements. Very hilly with lots of steps but full of character and well worth a visit.

Preety cobblestone streets and spendid views.. Wonderful area for a wander. Great views, pretty streets. Tram 28 was always packed when we were there, but tram 12 will take you back down to Rossio station.

Get lost in the charming labyrinthic streets. Alfama is the oldest part of the city, and the only one to survive the big earthquake. The medieval streets with clothes drying in the windows (typical portugese) and the endless stairs give the place a unique atmosphere.
Good.. Area of steep hills, not comfortable for leisure or romantic walk, though plenty of opportunities for nice photos appearing suddenly.Tram #28 might help a little cutting through the area.

That is Lisbon Life - still some charming hidden places to discover. Alfama is a beautiful and interesting Bairro where you still can see and feel the history of old Lisbon Life. Take a walk ... go left... go right ... just walk and enjoy the small details in the streets and houses. Some areas are as crowded as in Bairro Alto but there are still some charming hidden places to discover. A must to visit.

A great area to visit or to stay in while in Lisbon. We stayed in an apartment in the Alfama for a short week and really fell in love with the area. The streets are narrow and winding, but we really felt safe and welcome in the neighborhood, and enjoyed the Fado clubs, the organic feel, and buying Ginja from streetside windows while walking around.
Beautiful beach. Friendly, beautiful, soft sand, turquoise water and cliffs and marine life. A quiet lagoon in winter. Worth checking out.

Charming old neighbourhood!. It's a great area to explore on foot. Make sure you stop for a moment at the Santa Luzia viewpoint. Be prepared to climb some stairs, the area is on a hill so no two streets on the same level. It's not easy to find your way even with a map, as streets are tiny, narrow and hidden. There are some lovely little pubs and restaurants for a drink. The trams are running in these little streets too. There are a few big churches in the area worth visiting.
Charming . My favourite part of Lisbon, beautiful old buildings, sloping, narrow roads, fascinating little cafés and bars with breathtaking views ..
Interesting Location. Alfama is quite a different locale. We had a tour guide take us through . You really get a different perspective of Portugal and how some people live. It's well worth a visit.

Beautiful old quarter. Great little neighborhood to get lost in. Windy, narrow streets, up and down the hills, with little courtyards here and there. A must-see. It does get dark quicker in this neighborhood than others, because the buildings are so close together (you can touch both walls if you spread your arms, the streets are that narrow). So, after dark, I think it's easy to get lost, although many fado bars are there.
A real must when visiting Lisbon. This is the most beautiful part of Lisbon and a real must to visit, excellent views and a good glimpse of the Lisbon time forgot.
The most beautiful part of Lisbon . I enjoyed walking around. This is the oldest part of Lisbon and the most beautiful one in my opinion.

Living the Alfama lifestyle. My wife and I booked an apartment through RBnB for a week and stayed in the heart of this district. Our host recommended numerous cafes and restaurants to eat at but the best bit of staying here was to just walk out of the front door and hit the lanes. In addition to being accessible to all major transport links and city attractions, we discovered great little local cafes where we spent many a happy hour using pigeon English and sign language to converse with the locals and drink the local tipple of Ginja (cherry liquer). Really friendly people and uniquely Lisboa!

Enjoy the very heart of Lisbon. Miradores, bars, roofs, the river on the background... This place is simply amazing! It is the very heart of Lisbon, the place where second-time tourists love to come back and enjoy over and over. Enjoy the viewing point and also an aperitivo on one of the many terraces while relaxing and people watching. Take hundreds of pics and bring home some wonderful memories!

Photo opportunities galore. Really nice to hop on the tram 28 and go up to this area, views are splendid, the rooftops from above make super photos and there are charming cafes to stop, rest your legs and people watch.

We loved it.. So much food and so much culture. It's a dirty old town kind of like New Orleans but we love it. The food is phenomenal and the locals are super friendly. Visiting Calcais and Sintra is a must at only 30 minutes away.

Great neighborhood. Perfect mix of restaurants, location, locals, visitors, and picturesque streets. We we in walking distance of most places we went to, except maybe Belem, on the opposite side of Lisbon.

A great walk through winding paths. It is better for the knees to walk down from the castle down to the river front, than walk up the steep incline. The narrow paths seem timeless, winding down with characteristic Portuguese colored stone pavements (can be slightly treacherous after a rain – wear thick souled shoes). It feels great to wonder away from paths prescribed in guidebooks, but guidebooks correctly point out terraces with fantastic views from the castle up top, over roof tops leading to the river.

Uotstanding views of Lisboa. You can not leave Lisbon without wondering around Alfama, the most picturesque district of Lisbon. Steeped in history, its narrow streets rising from the Cathedral to the Castle is a journey back in time. simply unmissable

Portugal at its best. A great way to spend nighttime in Lisbon. Be wary though you could be overcharged. My a firm offer for food and a Fado show and stick to it. Normally 20 to 30 Euro would be sufficient.
A beautiful day in January. Bright blue skies made our trip to Alfama very pleasant. But...I fail to see how this area is any more charming than other places in Lisboa. It is nice but not compelling
Must see old town district of Lisbon. Very nice old town district, small paths, nice viewpoints, old and small buildings. You visit Lisbon, you have to visit Alfama.

Wonderful area, very busy!. It was a great day in Alfama! Beautiful views and a real feel for Lisbon. Start at the Castle and work your way down to the Fado museum. If you are a music lover, it is well worth it.
Fun place to get lost. It's fascinating to wander this area, the narrow cobble stone streets and incredibly how the trams go in them! The charming cafes and of course tasty white coffee...amazing!

Stayed here would stay again. The Alfama is the oldest district of Lisbon. We stayed here and were minutes away from the Pantheon and buses, trams and train station, so it was a very convenient place to stay. There are many slopes in this area and the streets are cobbled so good walking shoes are a must. Very atmospheric, serene and an unhurried place. Lots of meandering narrow lanes. Lots to family run small shops, cafes and restaurants. A lot of construction going on, but many buildings still in their original state.Found out that the name Alfama comes from the Arabic Al-hamma, meaning "hot fountains" or "baths."

A must see area. Great historic area, get lost in the winding streets and have fun! Narrow streets with wonderful local places to eat, Fado music. A great work out too due to the hills and stairs. Walk up to the Castle, eat with the locals.
stunning place. it was so amazing to visit this place and this place offers stunning views and getting there to really know the city. it was wonderful place.
Walking through history. This is a wonderful place to wander. The narrow alleys are full of intrigue, restaurants and fado places. Take the time to investigate this area while in Lisbon.

Go there for the fado and the buildings. This place makes me feel very happy, the way ghe buildings are and how you have to climb the stairs, plus its is the area where most of the fado houses are, with amazing sangrias and a nice Portuguese meal, best time is at night.
Charming !. Little narrow streets, peaceful ppl, but again..we were there in January, which was a bad decision..ask your guide to see alfama from the top..you'd definitely enjoy it

Quaint village with great restaurants and sights. We wandered around the Alfama district for a few days and loved it. Saw the local flea market, stumbled upon great cafes and sangria. Definitely got a feel for the local culture and its peoples.

Tour de Alfama SANDEMAN. That was the most amazing walking tour! If you speak Spanish, take the tour with Fernando! The guy knows everything and everyone over there, gives you a lot of fun facts and historical data from the place and makes you understand why the things are the way they are. 100% recommended.

Alfama or Al fame...or tem muito fama! ;-) A must see!. Please avoid the too touristic downtown area and get lost in this unique arabic flair neighbourhood of lisboa! There are so many gems to discover...be it neighbourhood greasey spoons a.k.a. tascas with their down to earth customers and employees...or the miradores---squares from which you have marvelous views over downtown lisbon and/or of the Tejo river. If you really get lost there...just follow the countless downhill roads and you will meet the road parallel to the river which leads back to praça de comerçio. By the way this neighbourhood used to have or still have community shared and owned public laundry places where they used to wash clothes the old school way on stones and running water...nowadays many houses are still too small for normal sized washing machines so laundromats are commonplace...No visit of Lisbon should exclude Alfama! It really is the icing on the cake and what makes Lisbon stand out among many capitals/cities
stunning view. Amazing View of Alfama from Miradouro de Santa Luzia. Just stunning. It's so elegant and timeless makes you want to move there.
Alfama. Beautiful part of Lisbon - getting there by foot is to really get to know the city. This is where you can see the big cruise ships and people watch. Breathtaking.

A timeless neighbourhood. If you really want to experience the old Lisbon, you must visit Alfama. Get lost in the small streets, see where Fado music was born, say hello to some of the nicest people you will ever meet and have a delicious meal in a small tavern. But beware of some mobility challenges in the shape of steps and slippery cobblestone.

A magnificent day. This town is truely spectacular. We went to the palace in the middle of town, through the little winding streets and i went up to the moorish castle. Do not miss if you go to Lisbon!!!!

It is a beautiful neighbourhood. If you have time, energy and you like walking you must walk in this neighbourhood. You can acces the main streets with the tram, but i love to walk and walking you can go of every little street. The atmosphere is magic, you have "miradouro" (point of sight seeing) where you see the river or parts of Lisbon. Alfama has intersting restaurants and bars for everybody ( expensive or cheaper). You must visit this.
Charming Portugal. A definite must see when visiting Lisbon... From charming little shops, cafes, the tram and picturesque views...
Get Lost in the streets of Alfama. Great place and a must see if you are in Lisbon. Alfama also has great restaurants for everyone. Follow the tram tracks if you get lost :)

You don't know Lisbon if.... You don't know Lisbon if you haven't been to Alfama.Take a walk on small spiral like streets, climb up and down and enjoy the unique atmosphere of Alfama. Definitely visit the Fora monastery to escape the city noise. Climb up to the tower for nice view to Alfama rooftops and river. From here you will also see the Pantheon from bird perspective!For those who want to get lost a bit and forget everything else.

Great place to base a visit to the city. This is a great neighborhood to stay in during a visit to Lisbon because of the location.A five minute walk from downtown, a twenty minute walk to the tile museum and an easy metro ride from the airport. This is the Fado district with the museum of Fado and numerous restaurants all featuring Fado from about 7:30pm on. If you want the flavor of life in Lisbon it is here in the narrow alleys and tiny neighborhood grocery stores, the souvenir shops, the cafes and boutiques. If you want Brand shopping take the metro about 3 stops. The National Pantheon is hereas well as the fantastic outdoor flea market on Tuesdays and Thursdays nearby.All in all a wonderful area.

Amazing authentic Portuguese architecture. This is the place where you can find the amazing authentic Portuguese architecture with thick irregular walls, tight streets and the tram coming and going. The bars and restaurants around make you breath the real Portuguese lifestyle.

My favorite neighborhood in Lisbon. My hubby and I joined a walking tour and covered Alfama neighborhood. We really like this area. It is not a polished or developed area in Lisbon, nothing fanciful. But it's precisely this old charm of the neighborhood which we love. There was a local elderly lady who gave us a warm smile when we were touring the area in a rather large group. We did not have the time to return for a fado show and dinner, which was a great pity. We will if we return to Lisbon.
Go with a guide. Nice and cozy neighboorhood. Would definately recommend to go here with a local guide, to get the most out of the visit
Favourite part of Lisbon . This was by far my favourite part of the city. Old narrow streets and shops that don't look like they have changed in years.

The home of Fado!. I had a great time touring this section of Lisbon where the music of fate and longing, Fado, is performed in many of the small restaurants and bars. Small and quaint, there are many wonderful craft and art stores to visit, as well as several tour guides available for hire, all well versed in the rich history of the area and music that made it famous. A very enjoyable afternoon.
Beautiful area by the sea. Just let yourself wander around this stunning area, admiring beautiful architecture and colourful buildings.
colours and view. A combination of the Greek islands of corfou and Rhodes with more colours and view.Get the 28 tram and stroll around.don't miss the visit
The best. Sitting in one of the small alleyways late at night with a bottle of red and some fresh fish. What could be better?

The nicest part of Lisbon. We stayed in a very nice design hotel in the middle of Alfama, a few minutes from all attractions. The district is really nice, could be tidier, but not worse than other parts of the city. The Fado bar area is too touristic, but the general senasation about Alfama is very positive, which was strenthened by the beautiful weather. 18-20 degrees in December!

Stunning. We visited in last days of December late afternoon! The alfama was full of people , great atmosphere and stunning streets up in hills! Walking shoes is needed but its amazing and must visit area in Lisbon

romantic. a romantic place to go
go crazzy in bairro alto and fall in love in alfama
a lot of nice restaurants and cosy places
birth place of fado. lovely old city part. small Streets ans authentic houses. In many of its restaurants, you can listen to life fado music, while enjoying your food.

Love at first sight. We stayed in Alfama following a friend's suggestion. We loved getting lost in the tiny streets and being able to walk to the Castle, the Cathedral and even Commerce Square. If ever coming back will stay here again.
very sad Old Town. It has nice views of Lisbon, but generally it is quite dirty and shabby. The streets are very narrow, there is a lot of traffic, a lot of houses are neglected. i was disapointed.

Most interesting walk in Lisbon. So Lisbonne! Stunning view esp with the sun and blue sky. its a lot of walk up and down, so make sure to wear a very comfortable shoes. This is our favorite part of the city.

Great place with loads of history but. make sure to have a walking tour through it (perhaps a free walking tour?) and make certain you're great at finding your way, because you *will* get lost. This area is a maze and no cars can go inside so if you get lost, you might have a bit of trouble finding your way out. But, it's full of history and an important of Lisboa so make sure to visit it if you're there for a lot of days and you have already visited Belem!

Nicer than Alta Baixa, vieuws and hidden spots. Nice neighbourhood with narrow streets and a surprise behind every corner. A lot of stairs towards the castle but well worth the climb. Fantastic small viewpoints to the sea and city. Enough small craft shops and nice little bars.

Great for walking and to see a view of the Lisbon. There is a lot of walking. This is the part of Lisbon that was not destroyed by the earthquake. You'll notice that the streets are more narrow than the main area of Lisbon. There are a few churches to discover, street market near the church, and at Calçada Graça there's a free view of the city with a cafe there. I took the tram down. There are also tuk-tuks taking people but I don't know the cost.

Back in the middle ages. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes! And be careful with the dog sh@t...No need to get frustrated that you get lost, you just head towards to water and you will get out of the district.
Typical. This is the old Lisbonne! I loved it. This place shows how people lives in the capital city.But you better like walking.
Cute, narrow streets . The area is overwhelmingly charming. The small, narrow pedestrian only streets are quaint and have several great shops and cafes.

An attractive district for walking. The narrow streets of the Alfama district are definitely one of the highlights of a visit to Lisbon. Easily reached by foot from the downtown area (if you don't mind a bit of walking) there's plenty to see here with lots of interesting small shops and cafes. Take your time and just walk around and observe.

Interesting districy of Lisbon worth a half day visit. We stayed about a half a day and it was an interesting district of Lisbon. There is a place on the main shopping street that offers great views for Sunset but we did not stay that long.
beautiful place. Alfama is heart of Lisbon. Cost narrow streets, azulejo, fado...small cafes with tasty seafood...you definitely should try and see it.

Uphill or downhill stroll. This used to be a fisherman's village and then occupied a lot by immigrants. It's best to go straight up to the castle of San Jorge at the top of the hill and walk down but you can also look up through the very narrow streets easily getting lost looking at the different squares and then finally making it up to the top of the plaza of Santa Luzia for a lovely viewpoint. The castle is uphill from here but this is where the trams stop and you can easily get a taxi or a tuk tuk (three wheeled vehicle). There are lots of small restaurants along the way where you can eat.
Very nice view. A good place for you to view the small houses and it is very Portugal~ As beautiful as you can see in the photographs! The small district around is worth visiting as well.

Walk. Went to the flea market which is held on tuesday and saturday next to the church, looking to get an old Nikon 35mm film camera, at a place called Vintage cameras, then walked around and took these pics! It's a moorish neighborhood full of history and little intimate corners an alleys. At the bottom is train station and the new cruiseship terminal. At the top is the S. Jorge castle which overlooks Lisbon

A must when you are in Lisbon. A visit to Lisbon is not complete until you have a walk through this picturesque part of the city. The best way to visit is to take public transportation to St Charles Castle, visit the castle and then walk downhill through Alfama. We had a car and managed to find a spot close to the castle. Parking is difficult but not impossible. As part of your walk you may visit the Fado Museum and the remains of the Roman Theater. We had coffee and Belem cakes at a charming cafe. We did not eat there as all restaurants appeared a little too touristy. The Alfama comes to life late in the evening when the Fado live entertainment begins in many restaurants. We felt perfectly safe in the dark alleysof Alfama as we criss crossed the neighborhood.
Interesting architecture. Interesting architecture but grubby and a lot of graffiti. Castle de Jorge located here plus incredibly large and fascinating flea market on Tuesday and Saturday
Fun Neigborhood. Fun neighborhood in Lisbon with lots of eateries, cafes, bakeries, and shopping. Its fun to just walk around
beautiful area. we really enjoyed walking around this area and eating at a little cafe on the hillside overlooking the ocean and the beautiful rooftops in the area.

Worth going . This area is not accessible by Metro only bus but it's quant with cobble stone extremely narrow streets, almost alley like with extremely steep hills. While some areas have larger flat squares that sit near the water. Some ways it reminds me of Amsterdam. Go in comfortable shoes!!! Restaurant and shopping is on every little street so don't miss going into those streets even if it looks bleak. I don't think it's a huge tourist attraction but I liked the area because of its local and quite setting. There is a small plaza where local live entertainment is going on and I was told they performs the local dance of Portugal, Fado. I would go back here so check it out.
What a nice historic area!. We spent 5 days in the Alfama neighborhood and had a great time. Beautiful old church, cobble-stone streets and great views on the Taag river. A must see. AAA !!!

Wonderful Time in Lisbon.. We're a retired couple who like to get out of their comfort zone when we travel. In planning a two week trip to Portugal and Spain we had read that Lisbon was a little "rough" so we were a little apprehensive (but excited) before we arrived for our three day stay. Pleasant surprise - we loved Lisbon. We stayed in an apartment in the Alfama district. Very close to the Castle and a downhill walk to the center. Lots of atmosphere and steps. Down side, in the evening the locals put out their trash and take their dogs for a walk (watch your step) but in the morning everything was cleaned up.The Portugese we met were extremely friendly and fun to talk to. We were surprised how many spoke English (many spoke several languages). It was also surprising how much we found out about their families in conversation. In comparison, we found the Spanish to be reserved.The food was wonderful and inexpensive. Everything we ate while there was good, especially the seafood and the pastel de nata (a custard tart). We recommend Restaurante O Triguerinho . It's family run restaurant, serves traditional Portugese food and has a cozy neighborhood feel. We ate dinner there three nights. Not in the Alfama but downtown we found a unique store worth a visit. The store sells a variety of canned fish. We're not talking American canned tuna. This stuff is fantastic - the Portugese love their canned fish. The store has table display tables and wall shelves filled with canned fish. They offer samples. We brought some home for an adult son and his first words after taking a bite,"when can you go back for more?".We're planning on going back as soon as we can.

Very typical neighborhood . A true way of knowing the most typical people and places of Lisbon. It's a very nice neighborhood where you can see older people doing their lives, eat on wonderful restaurants typical food and have a very good walk. There is a lot of small streets that show you new details.

Nice. Went here with my wife. We walked up. A bit sketchy. A couple of locals warned us that we were being followed and to watch our stuff. We did notice a pair tailing us. We fell in with a tour group for safety. Be careful in the area. Otherwise the area is cool. The castle is great. We were there at sunset so enjoyed a great view. Then followed the crowds down for safety. Nice attraction, but be alert.
Nice surroundings. Tis nice to walkmalong narrow streets and thinking about why IT looks like this. Take a Cooltour by night with fado!

Charming!. I had read quite a bit about Alfama before actually visiting it. It was quite charming - all the narrow and up-and-down streets, the eateries, and the vibe was great. I am going to find time for a Fado show the next time I am there.
Nice place to get lost!. Wonderful streets and cozy atmosphere, excellent place to forget about any schedule and just get lost. Old buildings, with some imagination you can feel the 18th century air.
Interesting and quirky. A great place to wander. Just have some decent walking shoes on - those hills! Lots of little streets but beware of the trams.

This topic and charming. This was our favorite area of Lisbon and enjoyed especially going up to the castle with spectacular views of the city, as well as going to the Fado Museum, and going to hear afford music at a local restaurant

The place to be. If possible, I recommend to stay in Alfama! It is such a wonderful area of Lisboa and walking into the centre of town can be done easily from here. Walk around and get lost, it might just be your favorite part of your trip!

famous hillside old suburb with views to river. popular tourist destination - get there by tram or walk up the hills - it is worth the effort. Walk down from the Graca to Alfama for the best experience and easier on the feet walking downhill!

Great atmosphere. Alfama is the oldest neighbourhood of Lisboa. Finding your way to Alfama is absolutely amazing, because you have to follow narrow stairways and steep tiny streets. In the end, you get rewarded with the great atmosphere of the area, locals, deliciously smelling food and beautiful landmarks. Definitely worth a visit.

Old town. Great restaurants in the narrow, crooked lanes. The oldest part of Lisbon that for the most part was destroyed by the 1755 earthquake stroll the area to get the real feel of the city. Is the area that the cruise ships dock.
Interesting . Here you find the narrow streets where the trams nearly ever so closely nearly hit the houses that line the tram lines. The place has a beautiful feel to it, is colourful and is unique.
Excellent downtown choice to stay at. picked a hotel in this neighborhood and it is amazing to walk around it. Not so good in rainy days where it can be slippery
Jump off Tram 12 or 28 for smashing views!. A great spot to enjoy panoramic views over Lisbon Harbour and city rooftops. Expect some street sellers plying their trade.

Wander up & down the Hills. Narrow streets with many picturesque buildings covered in tiles and small interesting shops.
Plenty of places to eat and miradours but watch out for pickpockets, especially if using the 28 tram to arrive there.

Very very beautiful!. A very beautiful area, with its perfectly thin streets and small cafes. If you wanna see the entire neighborhood, follow the tram lines and simply enjoy the view :) Very clean and peaceful, I loved the area! Lots of traditional architecture and beautiful old buildings. A must see when in Lisbon! Very close to Placa de Comercio [5 minutes walk, to the left]
beautiful. is probably the most special place of lisbon, so guys in my opinion u should go snf the best thing is to get lost in this area! GO WITH THE FREE WALKING TOUR WITH PEPE
Heart of Lisbon. Every angle is a postcard. Very ancient, colourful and friendly. Sea view from almost every street, trams complement every scenery. Food is great and people too
Lovely Alfama. I stayed here in December with an apartment overlooking the harbour. I recommend taking a tram and walk around on the tiny streets.

Historic city view. This is a historic district in Lisbon. You can easily go to see many famous spots around here. My favourite is St. George Castle. The view on the top of the wall is so terrific. You can easily find the castle since it is on the top of the city.

Must go to this side of town!. We went here the second to last day in Lisbon and wish we had at least visited this area at least twice. It seemed way more authentic than the area we stayed with a lot more to do. The castle is on this side of town as well as gorgeous look-out points with artists selling their work. I would go to this area if you are looking for tourists souvenir shops, but there's also some more authentic shops where we bought cork products and looked at some historic tile for sale. Just wander around here for a while, you will not be disappointed or feel unsafe.
Go slowly, without any pre-planned route.. Go slowly to check every single corner of Alfama! The neighborhood is sooo beautiful!! Turn right, left, go straight ahead...go wherever comes to you!
Vacatin. This is a nice place to visit. There are a lot of souvenir shops and small restaurants within the area. it's quite hilly specially going to the old church.
Beautiful place in Lisboa. Very kind and pretty place. Stayed here for 1 drink at first, but..... more than 5 - i cannot go away:o

Great view. I went on the #12 trolley and got off at the top. There is a great overlook of the town below, as well as the cruise ships docked. I went at night, The churches and ships were all lit up. It was an amazing view.

Great views and many nice places for food and drink. Go there by tram or the picturesue lift visit the castle and mostery and then walk down to the square at the river. Be sure to enjoy the many viewpoints over the city and the river and enjoy a nice snack or lunch in one of the many small bars/restaurants. In the autumn there is no better way to spend an afternoon.

Truly Lisboa!. The oldest district of Lisbon is one my favourite place in Lisbon. The view of the river, white Lisbon buildings, narrow stony roads, and the none the less the famous Tram no. 28 - its simply amazing. There are passages for the painters, artists. This area is full of nice restaurants. Lisbon trip will not be completed without visiting this charming district.

A different world. Alfama is the oldest place in Lisbon, starting downward from the slope of the São Jorge Castle towards the Tejo river. The narrow alleys and the stairs make this place worth visiting. Its like a different world. Even the great 1755 Lisbon earthquake did not destroy the Alfama,Its mostly inhabited by the fishermen and the poor. Some of the best views of the city can be seen from the terraces of Alfama.
Great walk around day. Easy area of the city to visit. We mainly took the Rick Steves independent walking tour. Casual and safe area to view the city for a couple hours
A must visit. The best place to get a real feel of the early life in Portugal. Make sure to attend the fado performances.
what a view. go there it is a MUST , the people the sights the buildings , the resturants., the casle is there also the Si catedrale.you can take tram 28 to climb there or 737 from near rossio .

The castle area. This is the place to go to see over the Whole of Lisbon, Lisbon is built on 7 hills, ( Like Rome ) Think I climbed every one of them, But trams run back and forward all over the city.

Beautiful old city. I walked from Saldanha to Alfama which was a 40 minutes walk, it was fall so it's not hot at all, but before you get there you will experience alot of up hill so make sure your knees are in youthful condition. Alfama, you can just get lost in it, it is gorgeous.

Great area for walking - spend time here!!!!!. This is a really nice area you should spend time at. Talk tram number 28 or walk to Alfama area. Enjoy the view and the life in the area. You should at least spend half the day walking in the area, and have a lunch at well

Old old old. What a stunning little suburb. Would recommend visiting whilst in Lisbon. The tram up and a slow walk down was such fun... stopping on route for pastries and drinks was ideal. The view to die for

Great neighbourhood for strolling, viewpoints, less-touristic caffes and fado places. Alfama is great when walking up from the river bank, it has some similarities to south-Mediterranean villages, such as Amalfi in Italy, or certain villages in Cyprus/Greece. Streets are narrow, you can still see people grilling in the street and enjoy the view when reaching higher ground.
We did a tour to Alfama. . A beautiful hilly side of Lisbon. Had a great time viewing all the sceneries from different places in Alfama. Recommended.

Take a stroll. This is a wonderful neighborhood in which to spend several hours. Stroll around and absorb Lisbon like a native on a nice day. My wife and I did and we thoroughly enjoyed the shops, the restaurants, the street scene and the architecture of the area.

Walk through from Porto do Marinha. If you don't want to bother with the tram there is a walk along the river edge into Alfama from the huge square. The views of the cruise ships are good, and the traffic flows alongside the pavements are not too much. There are some interesting tiled frontages and a mini castle building alongside the tiled terraces. The museum of Fado is in that area. Climb up from the river through some alleys and you will reach the cathedral eventually the Castle. Some good photo shots of the trams making their way up the hills and avoiding the cars closer to the castle

Beautiful view. A beautiful view of the city, it's picturesque buildings and architecture. One of the most beautiful cities in the world, with lots of history and culture most people don't even know about. Lots of sunshine throughout the year.

Loved the old town vibe. Fortunately the Alfama section is just being "re-discovered" so much of the old character and building still exist. We loved wandering around the narrow streets seeing the old and some of the new. Great views from the top.
Very nice " authentic " neighborhood . A must visit when in Lisbon. Just take 28 tram and explore the neighborhood by walking . Charming , untouched , old Lisbon
Safe an easy to get by.. could easily find the Fado Rest. for the night shows. The fado museum is located in the Fama barrio, also the train station for Coimbra is in Fama.
Not the pretiest of its kind. I have seen nicer neighbourhoods in this style, like the one of Sevilla, but it is certainly worth to get lost in

Must visit spot in Liboa. Take a walk and get lost in the beauty of Alfama. Close your eyes, listen to the sounds and breath in the scent of oranges blended with the fresh laundry and sea breeze. And greet the locals with a smile. :)
Beautiful. It is such a nice place to visit. A lot of historical buildings and events. You must go there and get involved by the atmosphere.

Real Lisbon starts in Alfama!. Alfama is the best place to get lost in the city and discover it unique character, lots of coffee bars with locals, surrounded with great architecture, amazing atmosphere where you can feel real joy of portugeese style - in high season a bit crowded with tourists though!

Alfama is a unique place - very rare in modern european world. Winding roads; slippery slopes, narrow streets and the history, Faldo music, and unique cuisine makes Alfama a fascinating place to visit. Walk around and explore yourself all the shops and cafeterias yourself. All locals are residents - amazing characters . Lovely art and craft shops particularly one shop owner/local artist fluent English speaker who fell in love with Alfama characteristics and never left the area!You need to be fairly fit walker due to the slopes - take tuk tuk in rain .

Its inevitable you'll be wandering here while in Lisbon. By all means take a tuk-tuk around the streets and up to the vistas, but then also summon the energy and get out and walk the winding alleys/ streets/ pathways and see that there's a whole authentic way of life here that, in a sense, isnt exactly easy: some areas look startlingly like south american favelas. Abounds with great shops, restaurants, and historical attractions. Plan an afternoon.

Character historic area. Visited as part of a tour. A walk through the small streets give you a feel for the history and character of the area. And it is living/working suburb. Alive and oozing that environment. Between the point of interest spoke about, you may see washing out too dry, delivery people, and locals chatting loudly to each other. And small delivery vehicles miraculously winding their way around corners and avoiding tourists.

Real Heart of Mystery :). Open spaces and full view on the river but also - magical music in every corner and small streets with beautiful colors - you turn right you cross through a lot of clothes left there to souk up the sun and get dry, on the left very narrow stairs that lead down to some beautiful terrace with restaurant... oh it's perfect to shoot a movie there and I had an opportunity to see it's done! :)))
Brilliant area. If you get lost just keep going downhill,can't go wrong.people really friendly loads of places to eat and drink.dirt cheap

What Next?. Best way to experience the Alfama is to put on a good pair of walking shoes and just wander - you never know what to expect around the next corner. There is not really any destination (but the aim should be to get to Castelo Sao Jorge) but unusual, interesting and surprising sights (and I mean sights rather than sites) can be found around almost every corner. Even the urinal aside the old city wall is a sight to behold - I cannot believe how many pictures are taken of this, even some action shots! We walked it on two days. On the first day we took one of the old yellow trams part way up and strolled from there. On the second day we approached from the bottom on the riverside (which was probably more interesting). The vistas from the Castelo are superb as was the tour of the ramparts.

Strolling around is a must. The tram 28 left us in the middle of Alfama.Then we spent 2 hours walking in the small streets up and down.We immediately switched to sport shoes as strolling around requires being well equipped!
Beautiful . Roam sit and absorb this amazing place. Beautiful atmosphere. Lots of good restaurants to eat. Had a incredible feeling at the time of sunset.

Very beautiful. A very picturesque district in Lisboa. Almost all the houses are covered with the tipical and colorful azuelos. It is interesting to walk through the streets without a clear destination.

An all year round tourist destination. Catch the tram up as the hills are steep, and walk back down. Like most tourist areas, there are a wide variety of cafes, with varying menus and views. In the two places we ate, we were overcharged, against the price on the menu. When it was challenged the price was quickly adjusted with no debate, which makes me think it is a custom and practice to catch unsuspecting tourists.

This is the real Lisbon!. Bring your walking shoes! So quaint. We had so much fun walking the narrow cobblestone streets. You can visualize families of old Lisbon gossiping and shopping with children running and playing! Loved the shops and quaint restaurants!

must in LISBON. on your visit in Lisbon make plans for a long day in Alfama district.Choose the day with the flea market on to start from and after spending somtime there walk up to STJohn s castle through all these small streets.Check for interesting shops and art places mark a nice restaurant for your meal after your walk.Iam sure you will a very nice day

Alfama. Lisbon consists several hills and this an example how they have build houses in the past using such a hill. It is a lot of narrow short houses. You can go through it using stairs. Also it is shown clearly as a poor area in Lisbon.

A beautiful area of Lisbon. A lovely area very quaint restaurants and shops. This really is old Lisbon. Go in the evening and enjoy the restaurants and clubs with the singing but beware you will either be charged for the entertainment which is put on the bill or you will find prices considerably higher.

Day 12 of Trans-Atlantic Cruise. Off the Celebrity Eclipse & had not book a tour so walked the Alfama! The streets, so narrow - the shops, so quaint - the houses, so beautiful with their tiling - the sights at the top, so breathtaking!
