Back at the ship we did hire a man who spoke good English & took us back up the Alfama with a lot of explanation & stories & history. A great tour with so many places to see.

Where to begin a trip to Lisbon. The Alfama is the oldest section of Lisbon. Whether you climb up or come down there are surprises around every corner. As you proceed through the Alfama you get a feel for this special neighborhood. Lots of shops and restaurants to dash into. Then entertain yourself with admiring the architecture, the residences, and the pocket parks. Quiet and so fascinating. This Lisbon at its most special.

Wonderful. The Alfama is a perfect place to begin a visit to Lisbon. The ancient fort offers views of the city. The tiny streets and lanes wind their way from the top of the hill to the river. It is a lovely peek into life in Lisbon.
loved every day. enjoyed every day...rain or sun there is so much to do and places to see...wish we could have stayed longer

Very charming!. The Bairro de Alfama is part of the old town in Lisbon. Houses were built very close together and it's just amazing to walk through the very narrow alleys to explore this part of Lisbon with all the tiny shops, houses. Even the Museu do Fado is located in this area. Don't miss it! :-)

Beautiful city with lots of nice restaurants and shops. I visited Alfama with a friend just for a few days. The city was really pretty with all the terracotta roofs. Restaurants were plentiful and served the local cuisine cooked to perfection. We went to one of the restaurants just off the high street and had a really nice meal. Codfish in particular is very famous in this region and all fish fishes are really very tasty. The city itself boasts winding roads along the old town, where you can see all the ceramic tiles which make Lisbon so famous. At the highest point of the city, there are some spectacular views of the coast and all the buildings, it's really very pretty! The weather in February was perfect for when you want to be touristy, not too hot but sunny and bright. Will definitely plan to visit again, those few days were certainly not enough!
Time stood still. Such a lovely area to live in as a base to explore lisboa. Totally recommended! Also check out the new Europe tour for alfama.

get into the real atmosfere of Lisbon. we spent 12 days in an apartment in Alfama, and I reckon it is the more characteristic place to live when in Lisbon. Enjoy the view of its wavy roofs, the sounds of Fado been played often during the evenings. Get lost in its small and narrow street and discover little spots you won't find on the guide but which will make clear why Lisbon is such a charming city. Lots of walking up and down the hill. if you use the bus or tram the center it's only 10-15 minutes away. But we liked strolling down and pausing in the bar along the way to watch the people and absorm its magic. Stop in puerta do sol for your morning bica and pastel de nata. take a pessoa book with you and be nurtured by the view
The Alfarma. A totally surprising tour of a way of life for people who have lived there for generations in peace. So interesting...

Alfama ! Where Lisbon was born. Alfama is the oldest neighborhood of Lisbon. The city developed just around St George's Castle and the old Moorish style little streets which are very typical, before the sister of square streets was even invented. You MUST visit. It has a lot of history and all kinds of restaurants and bars.

The "Real" Lisbon!. Great to walk around the very narrow streets that give you a taste of the "Old Lisbon"! You have to be quite fit though because it is quite hilly but there are lots of little Bars and Restaurants(mostly open in the evening but a few open during the daytime) and quaint shops.Will also be treacherous in wet weather ,as all the pavements are made up of the local small tiles. Good footwear required!

Stop your clock!. Visit this quarter where one can still find some hidden places of genuine charm before it is assaulted by tourism business. Take your time. Choose the narrow alleys. Don't avoid speaking with residents. Some of the nicest views over the river Tagus. Be sure you've got walking shoes.

Interesting area.. This was one of my favourite barrios of Alfama, it has gorgeous small street,s lots of Fado restaurants and on tuesdays and Sundays there is a flea market near the Pantheon. Highly recommend a walk aronud here, especially if you are going to the Castle anyway.

Quaint area with windy hilly cobbled streets, restaurants and crowds. Busy and touristy area but picturesque all the same. Windy cobbled streets with trams, little interesting squares and vantage points out over the coast. Lots of places to eat and touristy shops with trams rattling by. Busy in November so wonder what its like in summer! Reminded me of Montmartre in Paris.

Fell in love.... This neighbourhood is all you need to instantly fall in love with ancient Lisbon. It defies all maps and before you know, you've rambled and meandered for hours along its sun-bleached cobbled alleyways and discovered a glimpse into what old Lisbon once looked like. Brimming with atmospheric cafes, local restaurants and the birthplace of Fado it is a MUST. Every single day we were in Lisbon, we returned.

Good shoes and a beer. Most probably the best place in Lisbon to relax and have something cold.It is a battle to get a seat but wait a wile it is worth it. To watch the ships and the washing on the lines and the pace these people move is amazing. Also a very good place to stop for night photography. The 28 also stop near by.

On a sunny day .. It would make a great selfie backround to take pictures.. Once your are on top of it, it was a very beautiful view. I do not recommend walking your way up there .. unless you enjoy the sensation walking up a hill. You can even get there by Tuk-Tuk and it will cost your around € 10,00 one way to go up or down. You can also take a tram, but i have no idea how that works so .. if you do figure it out .. it's also a nice way to get there. Just go see it while you are there ! ;)

Breathtaking . Amazing place just to walk around and see the beautiful view of Lisbon. Highly recommend to visit Alfama. Very charming area and like being in the old world again. A couple of nice look out points in the area.
Old Lisbon. Very authentic, good food and fado . Crowded in summer time. You need good shoos, it's a lot of walking. Best time to visit is June

Great quarter, enjoyed a week here. If you enjoy being in the heart of the old city this is the place to be. Our apartment was just up from the #12 trolley line. St George castle just a series of right turns to arrive. We walked all over the area and saw a lot of the things to do noted in TA using the trolleys, buses and taxis. The taxis were the last resort when you just could not climb another set of stairs back up toward the apartment. Walking, actually climbing up streets that were never meant for vehicles is just part of the daily life for these locals. We were thankful to have an online map, we never found an information center with a good map. Once you get the hang of it, finding your way around isn't bad, just the steep streets! Great food options along every street. We used the mini-mercados to buy our food and cooked all our meals. "Republica Portugal" was a great Bistro not yet noted in TA for fresh juice drinks and other drinks and food items.

Loved this older area of Lisbon!. Saw Alfama area via segway first then returned the next day to further explore all the nooks and crannies of this old historic area. Found a fun bar (Sao Miguel) sitting way up on top of a hill and enjoyed an afternoon snack while experiencing the fabulous view of the port of Lisbon and Alfama.
Spectacular. located on one of Lisbon hills. Spectacular view of the old city and the river. Nice small plazas were you can relax and enjoy thhe view and coffee.

An adventura. The neighborhood is really beautiful, super mystic but at the same time not too friendly for foreigners, the streets are complicated and the signs are few. Anyways great place to get lost around and see amazing views of the city
Great views. This area is a pain to the feet as it lies on the hilly area but is a treat to the eyes. It is full of beautiful views that easily kill the swelling of the feet. Totally worth it!

Leave a trail of crumbs!. We spent the morning wandering the old Fisherman's streets of Alfama, you could seriously walk for hours and not retrace your steps!The district is an area of very narrow streets with high storeys on each sides, some of the houses with very intricate tiling on the front.Whilst there's no particular 'attraction' to head for you can easily spend a couple of hours being impressed by the narrowness if the streets and daily community life in the area.
Where Faro is played. A place that has kept its atmosphere. Many restaurants, small streets, Faro in some of them or music. Go check it out!

Get lost and enjoy!. A wonderful and historic area to explore and get lost in! To get out just keep going downhill to the main street but dont do so without spending time here. A good introduction is to join the Lisbon Chill-Out Free tour for an historic introduction to the area and to Lisboa too.

Beautiful, just get lost! And do it often. I have done Alfama area several times and i was under the charm each time!I went during the day, at night (inside the residential area not recommended except accompanied)and sunset time.Beautiful disctrict, a lot happening from flea market, viewing points, monuments and churches to visit, coffee shops and restaurants, sunset rooftops.Lovely streets and discoveriesMust must must do!

Beautiful view of the city. We walked 6 hours around Lisbon and found ourselves at this spot in the heart of the old town. Very steep hills but well worth it - accessed by Tram 28 or by Tuk Tuk - lots of independent restaurants and bars

Maze of alleys . We stayed here 4 nights in an air BnB apartment which was great fun exploring all the alleys with cafes and wine bars. Only downfall is no supermarket close by although tons of little deli shops. Don't even think about parking a car. Some people say it's dodgy but in Lisbon there are beggars and drug dealers in most busy tourist areas and we never had any bother here. Lots of options for fado too
Nice wandering around in a active neighbourhood. Just walk till your feet hurt! You can find so many cozy alleys here and nice places to eat. Just experience it.

Old world charm. This area is made up of a maze of narrow streets which can either be experience on foot or by the famous 28 tram. There is a lot of restoration going on. Historical and sites of interest in Alfama include, St Georges castle. Lisbon cathedral, and the National Pantheon. There is a Flea market in the cathedral area on Saturday's and Tuesday's. The area is famous for its Faldo music bars of which there are a number but beware whilst some are free, some can be pricey though they do include a meal.There are plenty of places to eat and drink. Some fantastic views of the city can be had.
Beautiful part of city. It is amazing part off city. Download audio guide Lisbon and select Alfama tour and just follow the route.
intersting neighborhood to visit. the Alfama is a charming neighborhood of Lisbon which is easily walked. it reflects the Muslim influence on Lisbon and is now a pleasure to stroll through

Beautiful Alfama. We were taken to the Alfama area of Lisbon in a tour group - the day was sunny, the tour guide was knowlegeable and gave the group much information about the various areas of beautiful Lisbon. The Alfama was an interesting area, cobbled small laneways, colourful small buildings closely built together, tiled fronts and doorways, interesting and delicious smells from the many restaurants and cafes and small squares with fountains or statues to see. This was one of my favourite spots in Lisbon.

Best area to stay in Lisbon. If you are visiting Lisbon; you need to stay there. Having our hotel in the area allowed us to walk everywhere. Trains/bus/trams close. The best are all the cute narrow streets you wander in.

Alfama, the old heart of Lisbon. The oldest part of Lisbon is full of characteristic houses, alleys and Fado restaurants.The area is located on the top of one of the seven hills of Lisbon, therefore many ups and downs have to be expected but, at the end, the view pays off. There are two remarkable view points: Miradouro Santa Luzia where to enjoy Alfama from the top and Miradouro Nossa Senhora Do Monte for a breathtaking view of Lisbon and the bridge 25 do Abril lighted until 22.00.
nice walk. I was lucky to have a nice weather to walk there and to go though little streets. view was beautiful and lovely church's

Interesting old part of Lisbosn. Interesting old part of Lisbon, once apparently a prestige district. Lots of character and architectural gems here. It is hilly, so bring good shoes and a good camera. Definitely worth the visit.
Fascinating old part of Lisbon. Up and down hill gives this place a real character. The trams visit so worth using. Cathedral is quite impressive but just wandering the streets is a real treet
Sandemans Tour. The tour was good and covered most of Alfama, the guide was painful - 25 minutes on some kind of dance was over the top.
Fabulous. Walking around this area is one of the highlights of going to Lisbon. Every corner and every alley. Wonderful views from the higher street. Fun to jump on the cable car. Wonderful

Lovely walks and sights.. Lovely walking through the narrow streets of Lisbon and some of the views are really fantastic. You can get a real taste of what Lisbon is about, there is plenty of places to eat along the streets you are actually spoilt for choice. A very interesting and beautiful part of the city that is well worth visiting.

A charming walk. Take the E28 to the castle and walk the ramparts for a beautiful view. Then wander down the small, narrow streets to the Fado Museum. Have delicious fish soup at an al fresco restaurant.
Must see. Visiting and stroling along the narrow streets in the Alfama is a must in Lisbon. Lots of cafes and restaurants to enjoy the visit as well...
Beautiful walking tour. this is the heart of old Lisbon. Beautiful, quaint alley ways for strolling. Start at the fort and walk down.

took the yellow bus tour and went back to the castle and decorative arts Museum.. Interesting District. The castle is worthwhile as is the Decorative Arts Museum. The walk down from the castle was also interesting.

Tiring on foot...but what a surprise!. I decided to go at Sao Jorge Castle on foot during an afternoon and I realised late that climbing that hill would have been challenging for my heart and legs... But it was amazing going there but more beautiful was the way down I made to go to the Portuguese Pantheon and so to the harbor where cruise ships arrive. It was a whole surprise of smells, colours, music and noises of those authentic streets. If you trust on your body, do the same!
Quaint, try the little streets. The best place in the city is the viewpoint where the trams go by, but far from a miradouro. You can get a view of Alfama, which is alright despite all the cranes.

Go! A few times, and take a camera.. Alfama is definitely worth a couple of visits. No map needed - just wander around the narrow streets and feel the vibe. Some great monuments, old buildings, local life, bars, interesting wee shops, great food and a sense of liveliness ( not so much early in morning though!) For the most part its not a tourist trap though. Castle def worth a visit. There are many many good Fado bars that are not touristy. We found A Baiuca Fado bar and A Vielo da Fado both terrific.

Very unique and relaxing neighborhood.. According to our guide from the free tour, Alfama is the oldest neighborhood in Lisboa and has remained mostly unchanged since its creation. Alfama is well known for its Fado bars as well as its narrow streets and is definitely worth a visit!

Most pitoresque area of Lisbon centre. the useful 28 tram will take you to this beautiful area (several stops). You can visit it in the evening (there are lots of nice restaurants) or during the day (to visit the Cathedral - Se' - the Castle, the church Sao Vicente de Fora, and to enjoy the breathtaking views of the town and the Tejo river from the several miradouros (belvederes). Enjoy Alfama on Saturdays, during the Feira da Ladra (flea market)

Must explore area in Lisboa. It's the most fabulous area and great to walk round and get lost. If walking up is not a problem then I'd suggest walking from the river side and walk up. Getting lost is the best way to explore it. Watching the sunset from up there is amazing too. Lots of places to eat and drink. Maybe a good area to stay during your trip too. Can be accessed by tram too and do the walk down. Either wait don't miss it

Lose yourself!. This is a great neighborhood in which to lose oneself. Narrow, windy cobblestone streets. The higher you go the more beautiful the view. Wear good walking shoes. Easily worth 1/2-1 day of your time. An old neighborhood with lots of tiny shops and cafe's.

Nice views and very quiet. If you are in Lisbon, definately visit Alfama.It's a quiet neighbourhood in a big city. Narrow streets, and when you stop for a moment, you will notice there's no city sounds at all. Very recommended to get a quiet moment in a busy city.

Nice views and very quiet. If you are in Lisbon, definately visit Alfama.
It's a quiet neighbourhood in a big city. Narrow streets, and when you stop for a moment, you will notice there's no city sounds at all. Very recommended to get a quiet moment in a busy city.
Great vibrant part of the city.. Just the heart of the city. Easy to walk around, great bars and restaurants. Every kind of shop you can imagine.

Original Lisbon. Alfama is the best kept secret until you arrive in Lisbon when you realise it the most traditional area to visit. Castillo de St Jorgs is at the top and offers the best views of Lisbon . Best way to see the area is on a local Tuk Tuk as they can access narrow streets other transport can't , and all the drivers have expert local knowledge of its history and will take you to all the well known sites along with some never to be found bars.It is very hilly and you need to wear very sturdy and comfy walking shoes or trainers.
Lovely. Excellent views. A slice of old Portugal, a bit like stepping back into time. It should be a definite in your itinerary.
Charming. A beautiful, historic, and charming area of Lisbon. We walked around the narrow streets and people waved out their tiny windows at my toddler.

A perfect area to get slightly lost and enjoy this old part of Lisbon.. We spent the whole day walking around Alfama, stopping for the occasional coffee or drink and taking in the stunning views and architecture. Well worth it!

Alfama is such a nice lady! i would highly recommend a walking tour with her. Her local knowledge is amazing!. We did a walking tour of Porto with her what a great gal! I would highly recommend taking a walking tour with her she has so much local knowledge (very impressive)

Authentic at its best. We stayed in Alfama for the duration of our 5 night trip to Lisbon. Other than being in downtown Lisbon, Alfama is a very central location and being the oldest district in Lisbon offers an array of charm and character. Exploring the narrow streets, finding hidden gems at every corner and with the castle at the top of the hill, there is plenty to keep you amused. It is also the main area for Fado music which may not be everyones cup of tea but it adds to the authenticity of the area.

Fabulous historic area of Lisbon. A visit to Lisbon should include a visit to the Alfama district, one of the few historic areas not destroyed by the major earthquake which destroyed much of the city. The quirky atmosphere makes for an interesting amble amongst the curvy lanes. There are lots of cafes and restaurants dotted around this district allowing for a full day to be spent here,if needed. There are numerous fantastic viewpoints over the city from all corners of this district, so it is a must for photographers.
Nice place to visit. while you are in lisbon dont miss this place to visit. Always full of visitors. Nice restaurantes with Fado. Good bars.... enjoying

A delightful and historic area of Lisbon. We have just come back from a wonderful week in the lovely Alfama area of Lisbon.It is full of history, character and some lovely old windy (& sometimes quite steep).The number 28 Tram travels a circular route around the area.There are also some brilliant restaurants. We just didn't have time to visit them all. What a great excuse to go back!

Slightly shady and tacky. When they tell you that this is the old part of town they really mean it. The houses here are a little dilapidated and in need of repair and some parts seem to be getting more attention than others. I did not find this area particularly inspiring other than for the narrow streets reminiscent of Fez and the views from the higher points. There are other nicer places to spend you time.

The old town is probably the most romantic section of Lisbon, and has great views. We spent a week there, perusing the neighborhoods of the Chiado, Alfama and Bairro Alto. Alfama is old town, where most of the Fado clubs are located. I have to say there was a somewhat "hucksterish" tone to the most famous club there, the Clube De Fado. If you don't go there, you can still hear the Fado in the streets, and there are lots of charming shops. Make sure to bring sturdy shoes. Those with physical handicaps will have a very difficult time navigating both the hills and the cobblestone walkways and driveways
Nice neighborhood. Took the tram to the top and walked down. Nice views from there. Narrow medieval streets. Very interesting.
This is Lisbon. The streets are narrows and laundry hanging out to dry when you pass by tram you could steal it this is Alfama

Great history in a simple neighbourhood. We enjoyed venturing the alleyways of Alfama, and seeing how simply people can live and enjoy themselves. Neighbours sitting out in the thresholds of their homes chatting away, or others meeting in many of the watering holes.This is where Fado is popular, and in practically every restaurant, one can expect to hear Fado.As one walks around in the neighbourhood, one will meet Sales people from more commercialized establishments, just wanting to get bums in the seats and gouging them on food, beverages and additional charges for "musicians" that they conveniently forget to mention at the outset.Alfama was originally a Muslim area many decades ago. Other than the design of the alleys, closeness of buildings, and certain streets, there is not much in the area showing the Muslim heritage.Worth a walk around, and perhaps listen to Some Fado.

This is one of the great ares of the world.. This is a blend of wonderful historic buildings, unique Fado music and fantastic Portuguese food. Be prepared for the challenges of walking the ancient streets, most of which is uphill. Although you can use a variety of transportation systems such as trams, busses, hop on hop off buses, taxis and more, the best albeit challenging ways of sight seeing this area is walking. Don't miss a Fado performance or the many historic cathedrals and museums - they are spectacular.

Really unique for an European capital. If you want to experience the windy streets of moorish origin withour visiting Marrocco or other Arab countries this is where you get a mixture of European and Arabic influences. Nice Murals with San Cristofor, Amalia Rodriguez.Visit also the Miradouros around!

Great area to make your home base in. We rented an Airbnb in the Alfama area and we loved how it was within walking distance of the main area of Lisbon, close to teams and subway yet far away from the hustle and bustle. Ita a nice quite neighborhood but full of wonderful shops and restaurants. It's a bit hilly and most streets and side walks are cobblestone, so be aware if you have walking or mobility issues. But oh how the views are worth the climb.
Place with old soul . Alfama is hard to describe. You have to go there and feel that place. Sometimes you got lucky and discover real face of that heart of Lisbon

When is the best time to visit. We spent the afternoon, early evening walking the streets and alleyways of Alfama. Great little shops that you will miss if you move too fast. By evening everything comes alive, we unfortunately did not have time for Fado, but the Faso Museo has a great exhibit

A wonderful place to visit when in Lisbon. We've been to Alfama several times, and it never fails to surprise me. We were there a couple of days ago and enjoyed our visit as much this time as we have done on previous occasions. We were on a group tour, a first for us, and our guide, a local young woman spoke excellent English and her knowledge about the area was excellent. A great place to people watch in one of the plentiful cafes.
Beautiful authentic area. We stayed in this area and it's an experience to walk/climb around here and especially: find your way back to your apartment :-)
cool neighborhood. Thoroughly enjoyed our stroll thru the neighborhood. Had a nice lunch there on a wonderful day. Lots to see

Wonderful Alfama. The Alfama is the heart of old Lisbon; romantic, timeless, beautiful. Wandering along the narrow cobblestones streets, sitting in cafes watching the world go by, eating seafood and enjoying the atmosphere are just a few of the things to do here. We chose to stay in the Alfama (Santiago de Alfama Hotel) and loved it as a home base in Lisbon.

Do not miss this area. Up a hill and around a bunch of winding streets, this old section of the city is a one of a kind. The tile work, Moorish influences, old buildings, great views, and places to eat make this a must see if you visit Lisbon.
beautiful neighborhood. Definitely worth strolling around this ancient, historic neighborhood while in town, especially at night when the fado bands are playing.

Walk into Nooks and Crannies Everywhere. Hills galore!. It is worth walking up from the end of the blue line (Metro). If you take the trolley, you will miss out on alleys and streets not on the main route. There are great lunch spots where more locals than tourists visit. Seek them out and you will be rewarded. The walk down to the Bairro Alto from there is great, too. This is the oldest part of Lisbon that survived the 1755 earthquake.

Charming Old Neighborhood. Do not miss Alfama. It is a lovely stroll best started with a tram ride to Largo da Santa Luzia. There is the Castelo Sao Jorge and the Decorative Arts Museum, which has a great lunch at a reasonable price.

Beautiful part of Lisboa. Small streets and narrow pathways - old houses with beautifully decorated tiles. Here you find endless charm and views to marvel at. It never gets old to explore this part of town.
Good for a good walk through. We walked throught after visiting the Castle of St Jorge. It was mentioned in Rick Steve's tour book and wanted to visit

Night out with Fado. This is the old town, the origin of Fado. It is picturesque part of the city with narrow pedestrian streets and interesting outdoor restaurants.You wander in the streets and hear music from all the places.It is highly recommended to visit. We visited in the night, though and dont know how it looks in daylight! You can visit restaurants with live Fado to have a drink!

Lively days and nights of fado music. The Alfama offers an opportunity to explore many winding streets in one of Lisboa's historic areas. Take time and stroll through the streets, sit and enjoy a drink and take a walk by the shore.
Alfama. there are so many things to see around the area. the scenery is very different between day and night.

Another world. Walking the streets of the Alfama would be treat enough, especially for anyone who appreciates wall art. Talking with students who were just starting their fall term and then dining in a great restaurant made it one of the best nights in Lisbon.

historical and magical. you can arrive there via tram 28E, visit the castle and cathedral. walk into narrow and cute street. dont forget to listen to Fado at nigth. (reservation is neccessary for weekend )

A must!. Great neighbouhood. Traditional shops, nice houses, intresting allies and lanes and many spots of view points. Tuk tuk may take you in a tour around for 15 mins as a minimum. It will be easier than walking cause of many hills and inclind roads.

The real Lisbon-but watch your step both literally and metaphorically.. The old quarter and least affected by the eighteenth century earthquake apparently. A maze of old streets ans steps leading up to the cathedral. Atmospheric in parts, with feel that real Lisbon life is still going on here, but there is tourist catchpenny amidst the apparent veracity. I would not, for example, vouch for the authenticity of all the fado offerings in clubs and restaurants here. Also for the less firm of foot there are a large number of steps and steep inclines with inconsistent handholds, making negotiation in wet weather especially tricky.Worth seeing wh a healthy care and scepticism
Old, picturesque town. Narrow, cobblestone streets. Great little shops with 'made in portugal' artistic wares, pastries and little coffee shops. Nice area to wander around on a sunny day.

You must meander through this area of town.. A great place to walk around, or get a tram or Taxi up front the lower town. Narrow streets, small cafes and restaurants, churches, museums and of course the Castelo - so picturesque. Apart from the Castelo which is a must visit in its own right, the whole area is worth a wander through to enjoy the atmosphere and quaint streets etc.

Nice area for walking, with lots of views and steps!. We downloaded a walking tour of Alfama district off the web and decided to do this from our base in Rossio. Started near the Castelo de Sao Jorge, which meant lots of steps just to get to the starting point but the views from there were worth it! Once we had (eventually!) found the start, we followed the guide and were rewarded with lots of quaint back alleys, passages, nice views and plenty more steps! Well worth a half day out if you are near that area to start with.

Great place but a bit touristy. We stayed in Alfama for a couple nights. It's a beautiful place. However, you must search to find non-touristy restaurants. Dinner on our first night was at a fado restaurant that was terrible. You must go down toward the water to find good fado.

taste the scent and sounds of Lisbon. Alfama ...Fado , coração e Alma Alfacinhaescadinhas, miradouros... Tejo a abraçar o MarA Must See famous neighbourhood district in a very romantic city . I Love Lisbon
Lovely mood. Romantic place to walk along, take pictures and enjoy . Many people, but still cosy. Full with street musicians, cafes restaurants.Very much alive.

Overrated part of Lisboa. This is the old part of Lisboa just under the Castle and ending up by the river Tagus. It was destroyed with the earthquake and now is inhabited by people that have remodelated the houses as best they could. Complicated, twisted and with grave ups and downs is full of cafes and clubs of Fado at night.

A MUST VISIT WHEN IN LISBON. We discovered the beautiful ALFAMA district of Lisbon whilst on a discovery walkA beautiful area of Lisbon and certainly well worth discoveringPlenty to see and loads of great restaurants and cafes Everyone seemed so friendly and welcomingLooking forward to returning soon

Wear Flat Shoes!. Having visited Castle Jorge with it's steep climb up we took a delightful walk through the Cobbled back streets of Alfama, stopped and had a coffee in a small street café and enjoyed a great view whilst letting the world go by, loads of small back streets/alleys with bars/cafes/RestaurantsWEAR FLAT SHOES!

Hippest Old District in Europe. Love the Alfama District. One can not say they have been to Lisbon without going there. Great Fado Restaurants there especially O Faia. Night Life is something to be experienced and savored. The only district of Lisbon to be saved from the big earthquake that nearly leveled Lisbon.
So glad I found this!. Found Alfama on a walking tour, it is by far my favorite part of Lisbon. It is like stepping into a different world. And the people are so friendly!

Mesmerizing, haphazard maze.. What an enchanting neighborhood! Once a notorious red district quarter, it survived the terrible earthquake which destroyed everything else in Lisbon...how ironic that a sinners' nest was miraculously protected! Charming cobblestone streets, meandering alleys and very old, tiny apartment buildings, plus many bars and restaurants, many of which feature heartfelt fado music. I cannot wait to return to this beautiful place with its charming atmosphere.

Romantic and beautiful.. Alfama is very romantic, atmospheric old town. You can easly get lost here in the labyrinth of narrow, beautiful cobblestone streets. If you haven't visited Alfama, you haven't seen the real Lisbon at all.

Labyrinthine Coolness. Easy to get turned around or out-right lost in this part of town, but the old buildings, narrow cobblestone streets, shops, and restaurants makes this place surrounding the old Castelo extremely interesting. You have to pay attention or you will miss many beautiful details dotting the area.

Atmospheric old town. We stayed in this area which had a great atmosphere. Restaurants and bars were all within walking distance. On the downside uneven cobbled streets and being hilly does mean it would be difficult with pushchairs etc. It was bad enough dragging suitcases from the station. It is a little run down but there does seem to be some regeneration going on.

Flea market lunch. Flea market - a rainy day but inside a market was lunch very reasonable hot buffet choices and a glass of wine or a craft (artesen) beer. Bought some bread too which we ate next day as toast.
Beautiful Views. Take a TukTuk who knows this area ( John 914022275 who grew up there) and see all the back roads and areas. Our best visit of the trip-- absolutely fantastic !!!!

Highly recommended. A typical Lisbon area, very old and genuine. Picturesque houses, churches, little taverns and lively gift shops. Go there if you can in june, because of the St Anthony feasts, but it's lovely anytime
Good way to get the local flavour !!. Alfama Quarter.Narrow winding roads up the hill. Steep climb to the viewing point at the top. Wonderful view of Lisbon from the top.

The oldest part of Lisbon. During the great earthquake of 1755 this was the only area which was not destroyed. Therefore Alfama is now the most ancient area of Lisbon. Best way to see it is on foot. Go up and down the little streets. Find the pleasure to get lost. Look at the old houses, some very charming. Observe people living. Now and then discover beautiful views over the river.

An Amazing Maze. The Alfama is one of the oldest districts of Lisbon dating back to Moorish times and is a maze of narrow alleys and steps, all higgledy-piggledy, leading down from below the Castelo down to the river. If you do not get lost in the Alfama, then you haven't really experienced it. In the lower reaches are a myriad of restaurants and bars, the home of "Fado" that peculiarly Portuguese music form, and genuine local cuisine. Evening is a great time to wander through these streets taking in the smells of grilled fish and listening to the plaintive song of the Fado singers. A must-do experience.
Walkable neighborhood with great food!. Just walk down any street and pick a restaurant! If you want authentic food then this is the place to try it out for a great low price.

The most lively part of the city. This is our favorite part of Lisbon. Therefore it is - according to our opinion - a MUST.
Go there during daytime and enjoy tourist and locals mixing in the small shops and coffee bars. Go there at night, stroll through the small streets with an incredible amount of restaurants and music, listen to Fado...
Interesting....... We went here as part of a walking tour. Fascinating area and especially when you learn about it from the guide!

A "must see" on the old part of Lisbon. Lisbon is a small town (compared to other european cities like Paris, London, Madrid) but with lot of history to tell and see. This part of Lisbon is one of the oldest, with very typical places, streets and houses and, also, with a beautiful view of the city.

Beautiful Alfama. Alfama is considered to be the oldest settlement of Lisbon. Located on the slope from the top of the Castelo de S. Jorge the area to the river Tagus, it has old multi-storied houses in narrow paved lanes. I lived in the area and had the opportunity to touch and feel the place. In the evening a number of restaurants-bars have live Fado music shows. Fado museum is closeby. If one climbs to the top of the hill in the evening one can listen to live music from local and touring musicians. Metro stations, tram route, tourist attractions like Place de Comercial, restaurants and bus stations are within walking distance.

Pleasant. The pleasant old town which is worth a stroll and gives you the chance to use the trams. Exactly how much strolling you will do will probably depend on how much walking you want to do on steep streets. The Cathedral (Se) and the Castle are both easily accessible (tram for the Cathedral and small bus for the Castle)
Nice walk to the castle. We strolled around Alfama on our first day in Lisbon. It is a small area surrounding the castle with plenty of nice cafes and shops to stop and look at.

great insight into the "real" lisbon. We walked up through all the old streets to get to the market in the Alfama district. Although the walk was tough at points (maybe our hangovers were to blame), it was great to see the "real" Lisbon and the market at alfama was a must-visit - really interesting and with great views over the city.

Best restaurants in Lisbon. We stumbled upon the Alfama district after a recomendation from a friend and we are glad we did. There are some phenomenal little spots tucked in the alleyways to get authentic Portuguese food. This also seems to be the best part of town to hear Fado music. I would definitely recommend a night out in Alfama if you are going to be in Lisbon for a couple of days.

The Soul of Lisbon. This large area of narrow winding streets, long flights of steps acting as streets, and surprises - restaurants, cafes, and churches - around almost every corner, is the heart and soul of the old part of Lisbon. Get is shape before visiting as the climbs and irregular pavements can tire even the most intrepid. This is an area to enjoy is small bites, a street here, a café there, and some wonderful vistas and magnificent buildings. Together with the Castelo de Sao Jorge this is a great excursion into Lisbon's charm and character.
Only with a guided tour. A special othenthic neighborhood, crowded with people even not early. Guided tour is recommended to seize the full magnitude of the place

Great Views. I always love this place to sit and have a coffee. The views are great and the little square for sitting in is just perfect. Take the tram up (or if you are feeling energetic walk up the steps). Afterwards a little stroll down the steps back to the main square gives an insight into the "real" Lisbon.
Amazing. Well worth a visit with lots of places to rest your feet! Takes about two hours to see everything and is well organised
Downtown tastefull Lisbon!. Alfama is a very interesting neighbourghood full of restaurants with tastefull portugese cuisine. Don't avoid to take the tram and ask for the "Cataplana de mariscos"!!

a nice walk uphill. a typical area that deserves to be visited.
I made it just strolling around and trying to get lost in the sneaking tiny roads.
A lot of very nice spot for taking pictures

Roman ruins. We walked up the hill to see the Se and the church which was built on the site of St Anthony's birthplace, when we stumbled across the remains of a roman theatre. My husband loves Roman history so it was good we found it. We also liked Alfama for the arguments which often sprung up between coach, car and tram drivers in the narrow streets! Some kind of traffic control is needed. There is a lookout point to take photos and lots of Fado joints offering meals, snacks or just a beer.
Must see Alfama !. Alfama is a most see for sure ! With all the small roads , you are really seeing the local life in Lisbon.

Incredible neighborhood.. Loved this historic, hilly neighborhood. We spent an evening here, eating at Restaurant Leopold, then walking around the windy, hilly streets, and finally ending up at Clube Fado for amazing music. We went back during the day and explored more, attending the humongous never-ending flea market, and then going to the castle after getting lost looking for the entrance. Post-castle, had a sangria with a view of the harbor. Lovely.
A must in Lisbon. Very beautiful.. the scenery is so amazing. Overlook the skyline of Lisbon. If thought it was raining the view was still so fantastic.

Romantic walk with partner, sunny and calm env.. As read, we tried to gey lost in beautiful Alfama after enjoying the best Bifana in a bar in front of Porta do Sol resto.A variety of talented musicians and a cheerful ambiance made the walk memorable for both of us.

Must see in Lisbon. Alfama is the old city with a lot of restaurants (some tourist traps as well) and winding streets typical of any historical old town. Best to start at Largo da Graça to get a view of the city and then take the 28E tram down to the harbor. You will certainly then get a feel for Alfama quickly. Walking back up is a challenge but totally fascinating.
Beautifull. beautifull, no words to describe. You should visit now. People, the weather, the food, drinks... everithing is goog
Beautiful. Narrow streets. Beautiful tile. Great culture and great people. We stayed a short walk away and this was one of our favorite areas.
Old portugal. Fascinating must visit. A glimpse into the past of life in lisbon before mod cons. Delightful narrow streets.
Underwhelming. I was expecting a little more from this area. Not sure what but it is certainly a must visit. The fact it was raining may not have helped.
Too many tourists. Alfama is beautiful but with the tours and tourists, it's hard to enjoy. Go very early in the morning to avoid the herds and tuk tuks!
Great for a walk around. Great place to visit, quirky shops and narrow streets, also a roof top pool below the castle, worth a look around
local feeling. we feel as we are local in the streets of alfama. it is the oldest district of lisbon and we really enjoyed the food, attractions and shopping there.
Fado district. It is nice to venture into the neighborhood but not so unique. Of course, if you are looking for fado, you found it. It is in every place you see.

Go back in time and enjoy the view. The fort is a wonderful way to get an overview of the city and walking the walls is a lot of fun. Instead of waiting for the streetcar number 28 to go up to the old town and the fort, we took a took took, which cost just a bit more . It is basically a motorcycle pulling a two seater, open air cart...a way to navigate the narrow, steap hills. There are many great caffee places to just take in the view and the atmosphere of this neighborhood.

The old charm. This is the best place to stay in Lisbon to get immersed into the old charm and character... the restaurants, shops and everything is relaxed, nice and full of life. The narrow winding roads up and down the hills with trams crossing through, tuk tuks going around is just amazing. Tram 28 ride is a must, so is the castle and all the squares... lovely to walk around aimlessly as well

Loved it here. a lovely area of the city and well worth a wander during daylight. Our tour book suggested to avoid late at night but it seemed pretty safe when we went. Pretty views and things to photograph all over.

Worth a visit but its looking 'tired'. The buildings are stunning & a legacy of days gone by. There are some great views over the City & the River Tagus. Nice place but it is looking tired, it needs some investment ! Go now before it gets worse

Best walk in Lisbone. Very nice place
Excellent views. Very nice small,local bars. A lot of atmosphere
Highly recommended walk starting from the castle
Rick Steves book is a huge help

Three days in alfama. Winding roads, but all lead to the waterfront. You think you will get lost, but it's pretty easy to find your way around. Alfama is home to the fado music and a lot of small restaurants. It's quaint and safe.
A good hike. Spend a afternoon hiking, not walking in this special neighborhood. It's one of a kind. But prepared for some uphill climbs and wear appropriate shoes.

Walkabouts in the old part of Lisbon. The area is a maze of winding streets and steep steps. Its easy to get lost so best to have your GPS handy and also set a starting and end point. People are friendly and there are lots of fado restaurants to have meals & catch performances.

Feel like a local in the old city. We rented an apartment in Alfama and stayed for a week. We felt like locals, going out in the morning to buy bread and fruits from the mini markets, or get lost from taking a stroll around the old city and discover small but lovely restaurants. Alfama has several viewpoints where its lovely to sit around sunset time and enjoy a glass of Portugese wine. Every Saturday they have a huge flea market.

Went for the flea market...got lost, walked back to hotel; fun. We went specifically for the flea market...not sure if it is everyday, so check days. Much to see and fun to bargain and find treasures. Got lost and rambled through back streets and ally ways...rather fun. Have fun in this old and historic district of beautiful Lisbon.

Fun Area.. We enjoyed the food, music, and strolling through the streets. Easy to navigate as down gets you back to the Main Street. Make sure when you eat that you DON'T get free appetizers. Send it back!
Awash in history, twisting streets. Twisting side streets, awash in history, we spent time in the neighborhood while on a walking tour. Would love to come back for dinner.

The heart of the city. Alfama might not have the trendiest restaurants, or the best shopping district, and certainly the widest streets and pavements. What Alfama does have is that spirit of the original with all the bumps and bruises to prove. that the strong do indeed survive.And the people of Alfama have this same spirit. "we are still here, life has not defeated us." Come for yourself and see the real deal, the spirit of life in Alfama.

Oozing character and history. Visited as part of a walking tour and could not resist staying longer to explore on our own - and the advice to "throw away the map" and get lost through the maze of charming streets in this old Lisbon neighborhood. Highlight was the Castelo SaoJorge at the top of the hill, and the walk back down towards the river while enjoying beautiful views. This is a Great area to visit for some authentic Fado shows in the evenings!

Take a good map. Take tram 28 to get you up into Alfarma and save the climb up the steep hill. Make sure you have a good map and a compass to find you way around this maze of narrow streets. Quite different feel than the rest of Lisbon.

A walk through Alfama. An interesting neighborhood of Lisbon filled with craft and souvenir shops. Arte da Terra was the best of the shops we saw for really fine hand crafted items Be prepared for walking up and down the hilly narrow streets

Great place to go get lost. This is a great neighborhood to just walk around and explore. We found it easier to stop up at the top of the hill (at the castle) so it was down hill walk. There are a lot of small restaurants and cafes so plan on having lunch as you go.There are a few of the "free tours" operators which are informative but it is also worth doing some free lance wondering.There are various points up towards the top with great views.We had mixed advice about walking around at night but have no first hand experience. A Taxi to the top of the hill (Castle) from the pedestrian area by the arch and river cost us $7. The 28 tram also goes up there as well but it was always full when we tried.The streets are steep in parts so you may not want to go when it is raining or wet.
Worth a day out. Alfama, great place to explore the side alleys and discover friendly places to eat - most of the staff speak English and most of them are friendly people as well

A Must See But Get Fit For Lots Of Steep Hills. The Alfama lies to the East of the Baixa District just Below the Castle of Sao Jorge on a Very Steep and Undulating set of Hills, filled with a Maze of very narrow Cobblestone Lanes. This is the Oldest part of Lisbon & it shows in this Ramshackle but Ultimately Charming Area that used to be a Fisherman's Quarter. The Best way to get here is either by Minibus 737 from Martim Monez Square ( which takes you to the Main Entrance to the Castle, or from the same place the Famous Tram 28 and Get of at The Church of St Vincent where You can then Wander Downhill to the Excellent View Point that houses a Statue of the Saint and from where you can Observe a Sweeping Panorama of the Alfama & the River Tagus. The best way to see the Alfama from here is to just Wander around ( a Map is Not necessary ) in the Knowledge that you Can't get Lost as any downhill Trek will Eventually take you to the River & the Baixa District.  The Alfama is well worth a Full Morning to Investigate but Definitely Get Yourself Fit before coming here as Walking Around this Very Hilly District will certainly take it out of You.

Beautiful but expensive for dinner. Very pretty, calm and charming quarter to visit but expensive for dinner. Enjoy a fado show but don't come back a second time to any of the restaurants for music cause singers and songs are the same anywhere.
I lost my way<<<<<1. I was running through Medina-like Alfama. One of the oldest parts of Lisbon. Beautiful views and lots of small alleys. I got lost, but it was worth it.

the old fashion and tipical Lisbon. if you want to get lost in the small view of Lisbon and listen fado and live the "saudade" feeling...walk around this neighborhood hood and fell like a Portuguese...remembering the time when Lisbon was the capital of an empire...

Best place to get lost in Lisbon. The most picturesque neighborhood in Lisbon, Alfama is a colorful and cheerful network of narrow, steep and winding streets unlike any other in the city. Flowers on every balcony, Fado in every restaurant, a smile on every face. Truly a special place.

Castle St George - must visit Stunning views. The neighborhood of Alfama features the Castelo St Jorge, and amazing views of the city of Lisbon. Tour the castle grounds on your own - need good walking shoes. The town is cute, with tons of shops, many touristy and many restuarants. We ate at the Contador Mor - very close to the castle with delicious soups

Stroll or climb. Very interesting area with lots of little doorways ad shops to look into. There is a fair amount of up and down walking in this area but well worth the effort. This area is old and interesting.

It's hilly!. Really great to see part of old Lisbon. But be warned strolling round here involves hills! We were advised to start at the top and walk downwards: good advice. A visit to Alfama can be combined with a visit the the castle. Get the 28E tram up, visit the castle area and then walk back downwards.

Lovely side streets and small restaurants everywhere . We took a walk to this part of town after visiting the castle and were not dissapointed. we found several lovely wine bars as well as restaurants. Its ideal for photo opportunities too with its lovely small side streets.
Alfama and St George's Castle. The History behind this castle is astonighing. One thousand years of History in those rocks. Don't miss it.
Real Portugal. We visited this area to get a feel of the real Portugal and we were not disappointed especially when we had a sardine lunch at one of the local restaurants.

Interesting Alfama. We loved Alfama, it had such a different feel to the centre of Lisbon, although it doesn't take long to walk there, we loved wondering amongst the winding streets and always finding something new. We ate there one evening and afterwards we were lucky enough to find a bar that was playing Fado music, it was a lovely atmosphere and very impromptu, the chap who owned the bar had a great voice ( sorry can't remember the name of the bar) I would love to return, soon I hope
Interesting, but tough hills!. Be warned, there are some really steep hills in this area. However, it allows an insight into authentic local Lisboan life and people are friendly.
all uphill. This was a very interesting part of Lisbon with narrow winding streets. But everything is uphill very steep hills

Most beautiful area of Lisbon. This area is very beautiful and cosy. Streets are small and steep,it is a good workout of you take a walk through Alfama. People are a lot more friendly here than in the other parts of Lisbon. Lots nive views and good restaurants also, but be aware of the typical tourist restaurants with so called original Portuguese food and fado
Breathtaking view. Beautiful place to visit and take pictures of the view. Nice places to eat and recommend using public transportation.

Alfama é linda (Alfama is beautiful). This part of the city reminds me of the Casbah of Algiers with it's narrow streets and children playing everywhere. People are friendly even if they do not understand your language you're always welcome there...you feel yourself like you were visiting a big family...
Best views of Lisbon. The narrow crooked and steeps streets of the Alfama offer the best views of the city. From the castle to cable cars and from Fado to food, Alfama has it all.

Has to be done!. We were told about Alfama from our young local tuk tuk driver, we had been to Barra Ailto the night previous to hear the legendary Faldo 'singers' but assumed we had gone on the wrong night as pretty quiet. So off to Alfalma we went, the best advise would be to find the restaurant of choice as, as far as we could tell, the singers are pretty much the same. Fairly mournful, terribly serious! Oh and heed the card on the table that reads 'please be quiet when artist singing' as we got a fit of the giggles and nearly thrown out!
Wonderful Alfama!. Absolutely beautiful old town in Lisbon which must be visited. So much to do and enjoy - pretty surroundings and lovely cafes and restaurants, plus superb views over the river.

7 Hill Tram Ride. Our electric tram ride of the 7 hills broke down - luckily we had our camera with us and strolled through the narrow lanes of the Alfama district where Amalia Rodrigues once used to walk.

Wonder the streets of Alfama. This area is beautiful. Just wonder the streets and discover its beauty. Planty of different azulazus, decorative tiles, all over the buildings make this place a real jewel. Tipical Portuguese restaurants and small shops with souvenirs. You can also take a tuktuk if you're tired, and continue your tour. Walk to castelo de sao jorge or take your time in mirador santa luzia. This neighborhood is a real must.
A must see area in Lisbon. Great sights, good food and the most beautiful streets in Lisbon. Visit at least the the church of Santa Engracia, monastery and walk up and down the streets to enjoy!

Wander around for an afternoon. Beautiful little area to wander around. Many twisting old streets to get lost in- we were told by a local that in earlier times (he wasn't specific when!) that rival gangs would entice the opposition up through the narrow alleys and massacre them at the dead ends! Maybe not true, but it gives you an idea about the type of surroundings. Hilly, so not good for anyone with mobility problems. Many restaurants and interesting shops. I liked it.
Pittoresque district in Lisboa. Go away the main stream. See the real areas of Alfama. There you will see the real Lisboa. But anyway I have to admit that the view from the viewpoints are amazing.
Alfama - solid!. The part of Lisbon not affected by the 1755 earthquake. It's old - you can feel it! Cobblestone roads, lots of restaurants, stores and central. See it!

steps back in time. The tiny winding streets of Alfama are a tourist treasure. This ancient district of Lisbon clusters around the feet of the Castle, embracing many churches, including the Lisbon Cathedral. It is home to many art galleries, tiny cafes and restaurants, music and traditional crafts abound.

It’s a must…. When you creating your itinerary for your visit to Lisbon, Alfama need to be part of that list, that place embrace Lisbon in perfect sense. Beautiful little place, just walk trough, you really don’t need transportation when you are there. The place is filled with shops, restaurants and coffee places. The park is very nice and the views are outstanding, you can also see the cruise ships from the top. This is one of my favorite places near Lisbon.
Alfama not to miss. Typical old part of Lisbon. If you go to LIsbon, you may not miss it. And it leads to the entrance of the old castle with number of little good restaurants along the way.
Charming area with lot to discover. Best way to discover the area is on foot. Walk through the cobbled hilly streets up to the castle to get the most stunning view of the city!

Labyrinth of Old Lisbon. This is truly a highlight of a visit to Lisbon, the tight maze of streets through the old part of the city, is an experience not to be missed.If you start at the bottom of the hill, it can be quite a steep climb, but the old buildings, the tiny shops and the views when you come to the top are worth it.The only thing that spoils the look of Alfama, is the graffiti on the pale walls.If you feel you cannot do the walk, then take the number ''28'' tram.

Unique neighbourhood. Nice to take a walk around this neighbourhood, quite unique with narrow alley way between buildings. Kids playing outside and old ladies watching the tourists from their apartment windows. Once again go early or later in the day because when the cruise ships arrive, there will be thousands of tourists on the streets.

Lovely atmospheric part of town. We were lucky enough to stay in an airbnb rental just inside the Alfama District, and it made our stay feel like a true peak into real daily Lisbon life. The narrow jumble of streets reveals washing hung out window lines, tiny bars and restaurants, local traders, and more.More of course includes everything from the cathedral to the castle. And all of this is readily at hand to the riverfront and the centre of Lisbon. Well worth a wander.

Unique Unique Quaint Quaint!. Words are few to describe the tram ride to and through Alfama! The narrow streets barely accommodating a single tram, steep and cobble stoned tell a history of Moorish influence on Lisbon, unique in itself The quaint Portas Do Sol square which springs out at you as your tram trundles on, catches your breath and leaves you gasping with the breath taking views of Lisbon roof tops stretching down to the sea. So impressed were we by this, we did this trip twice in a 4 day stay, with so much else to see in Lisbon! A MUST DO if any in sunny stunning Lisboa!!

Breathtaking . Unexpectedly beautiful, a big surprise. I think, number one in Lisbon, you can walk hours and enjoy. We were an hour only because we had only two days in Lisbon. By the way, Lisbon itself was a big surprise, beautiful capital, warmly recommended.

Spirit and fado. You can't miss Alfama - full of nostalgia, cobbled streets, old dated trams, lots of pubs and coffee places and spirit of the past! You can easily fall in love with this and surely must see
Beautiful sights. A lovely walk around the Alfama area of Lisbon, with pathways full of character. Although steep, the views at the top were breathtaking.

Hilly and Old Part of Lisboa. Although you can take a Tram 28 which crosses this part of the city,but it can be crowded at times. So if you don't get a seat on T-28, It would be best to take a tuk-tuk or take a stroll around this part of the city. Its a steep hike at some points but the views will compensate for it. You get an excellent view of the city from some points.The narrow lanes and the old houses in this part of city are very beautiful.Walk only if you can as it can get really tiring due to slope.
Grand views. Grand views, especially after the tram-ride that takes you through winding lanes in the older part of the city. Tram 28E - way to go!

A stroll back in time - enjoy the wander. as my husband repeatedly said, this place is crazy - in a good way. The winding streets really are a step back in time. Just wander and enjoy getting lost and seeing comes around the next corner. We repeatedly would walk in circles then make a turn and discover something we never say.

Lisboa 5-days stop. Alfama can easily been reached by either metro (blue line stop Baixa-Chiado,same stop for green line)or tramway NO.28 ( most famous tram).It's a pittoresq part of Lisboa and if you are following the tramway (also No.12)is going here

Memories of Alfama to keep us warm on a cold winter night back home. Just loved the old world atmosphere of Alfama. So glad I had read reviews on trip adviser. The winding streets, the views, the eating places - the sardines on bread! Whether you approach it from the Castle or from the sea it is equally beautiful and the Elevators do assist with the hills if necessary.

Walk till you drop!. By far, the best walking neighbourhood in Lisbon! You can meander through the tiny streets and even though you may think you are lost - you aren't because you know that your destination - the castle - is at the top - yes an uphill climb but so worth it! We did not pay the entrance fee to the castle, but had drinks at a patio overlooking city and water. Spectacular view!

Hidden charm. We chose to stay in Alfama on the advice of friends and have been pleasantly surprised at the great restaurants, quirky shops and wonderful views discovered. It's an old area of Lisbon and very hilly, expect to develop strong leg muscles. It has proved centrally located after you take the time to learn the team, bus and rail access systems and it has always offered great bars and restaurants nearby, a welcome relief after a full day exploring Lisbon.

A Moorish touch. A fascinating labyrinth of passages and staircases opening into small plazas, this is the most atmospheric quarter of Lisbon. Several fine old churches and excellent views of the Tagus at the top.

Don't miss Alfama!. You can't really visit Lisbon and not go to Alfama, it's an essential part of Lisbon. You could actually walk here from the centre but most people take the tram, especially the number 28 which has now become so touristy it would be best to do it very early morning or maybe in the evening. You can lose yourself in the small streets, lots of places to eat, drink, shop or just take it all in. If you want to walk up to the Castillo it's very nice there also with some great views over the ocean, lots of artists and a great walk back down to central Lisbon.

A most interesting part of Lisbon. I went there with a guide and don't think I would have given it any interest if I had not been given a most interesting talk about the area, it's people and information regarding its history - by this guide. I know it has many steps to climb if you come up from the port area but that is also part of its charm. We were encouraged to interact with the locals and take in the ambience of the area. I also had lunch in one of the local restaurants opposite where the cruise ships are docked. Very good food and most reasonable in price. Visiting this area was one of the benefits of being with a guide, who elaborated on its charm.

Dingy sketchy part of town. After reading about Lisbon and the best neighbourhoods to stay in, I ended up picking Alfama because reviewers say it is authentic and charming. I really disliked Alfama as a whole, it's dingy and rundown, not very inspiring at all. My parents hated it and did not feel safe there after dark. The restaurants we tried were terrible. After one night, my parents wanted to leave the city.It's like the bad part of town that is getting gentrified and so is now trendy with the hipsters. Bleh.

The Most Typical Neighbourhood in Lisbon. The most typical neighbourhood in Lisbon. Where you still can hear "FADO VADIO" the Portuguese typical Music. It's also where you will find the Saing George Castle.

A taste of the genuine Lisbon. Alfama is Lisbon's most typical neighborhood. Starting with the "tascas", along with the narrow streets, you can really catch the genuine atmosphere. By the time of the city's festivals the entire neighborhood turns into party.

Three day visit. This neighborhood is quite worth getting lost and having a long cold beer and listening to FadoWe spent the afternoon there met some very friendly Portuguese people and wondered along its narrow cobbled streets and enjoyed the sightsLoved it
rambling. perfect for me to walk around and not get lost. perfect stopping for a coffee in small places and feeling welcome
Walking around Lisbon. would also recommend theElevador de Santa if you have a head for heights and the Belem Tower with the walk along the river.
Tour with tuktuks!. Beautiful area to be visited. Narrow streets, old buildings, commerce and gret view of Lisbon. I would suggest to visit by TukTuk

Get lost wandering! . This is a great neighborhood of Lisbon to wander around in. It's full of little restaurants and shops and great spots with views of the city! It's shabby chic but so full of character! This is old Lisbon where you can hear Fado and watch the sunset!
Quaint and old world. Very quaint - good idea of the narrow cobblestone streets/paths. Would likely get lost if not for the guide
Lovely old town..... Lovely sight seeing area....to stroll though...many nice views and locations....also many nice cafes and restaurants....
Sightseeing. Wonderfull views do not miss this its a bit of a walk and the streets are cobble stones no good for wheel chairs but taxis will take you up their

I really love it! . We spent a whole afternoon walking through out Alfama. We stopIn each little street and spent a great time at the Fortaleza de Sao Jorge! Great view and great atmosphere !On the way back ( we went up with the tram) we walk down the hill and stop in several little places and had a nice cold beer! Great afternoon !We recommend this tour. It is very typical.., very old Lisbon
Step back in time in the old Arab quarter. Great walking area through narrow streets on the waterfront in Lisbon. Climbing uphill to old churches and restaurants. Working class "real" Lisbonians.

Old Lisbon with some stunning viewing points. The oldest part of Lisbon, full of little curvy narrow streets, some nice viewing points, some bars and cafes, famous tram, taking you all the way to the Castle ( 8.5 Euro to visit the castle - way too expensive!)

Worth a stroll. Alfama is a great town with nice views, it's lively, busy and has lots of history. Yet, some areas look dirty and shabby. Restaurants and souvenir shops are pricey. For me it was just another old town in Europe
Lovely neighborg. Alfama is full of life. You will find shops, coffeshops, miradores, crafts, the Lisbon Catedral, The San Jorge castle, an many other things to enjoy.

Interesting little streets and buildings , a surprise round each corner. Having visited most of the big sites in Lisbon on previous holidays, we decided to walk around this area when our ship was in port. We were not disappointed with lots of little streets and churches and good view points.

Fell in love. Wonder around here after getting Tram 12, it's better at dusk as it becomes magical. However do try and visit any time. The streets are narrow and un steady people be careful. This is a most if in Lisbon

Alfama Gourmet - the best of Portugal . My husband and I stumbled across this great deli / wine shop after we'd unsuccessfully tried to get onto a 28 tram! We loved the 1€ giginja in chocolate cups and the free tastings of the best wines Portugal has to offer. An excellent independent business, away from the annoying tourist hordes! Highly recommend! It's on Rua das Escolas Gerais 120.

Loved it. Very cool to wander through the narrow streets and alleys. Walk trough Alfama in the early morning, during the day and at night to see how this neighbourhood undergoes a wonderful transformation multiple times a day.
smell the history of Lisbon. Used to be the neighborhood of the Moorish people today it has a historical flare and charm. walking through the tiny streets and stairs is quite an experience.

Interesting but shabby. Interesting part of Lisbon, though looking a bit shabby and poor. So don´t expect luxury here.Just strolling along the streets is a good experience and you may bring a lot of weird snaps.

Passing through but was lovely . Passed through on the way to the castle. Lots to see. Lots to do. Loads of places to eat and a lot of good views. It can get very busy and queues for trams are almost not worth the wait

Best area of Lisbon. I love this area of Lisbon. But also visit the small alleys were you will find the nicest restaurants, bars and cafes. Stay in a hotel or room here in this neighborhood to experience the true vibe of the city. From here it is an easy walk to everywhere. Big +; it is a quiet neighborhood compared to the barrio Alto.

Beautiful Area of Lisbon. You can get to this area on tram no 28 or bus number 737 or by foot. The area feels a little different from the more busy areas of Baixa, whilst busy it's not over crowded and has a charm about it. To go into the castle you would gave to pay however you can walk around the area, there are places yo eat / drink and take some good photos of Lisbon. I personally found the place quite clean, certainly clean enough and very pleasant to be in.

Charming and warm. A very beautiful and warm place for walks. Cobblestone streets - better wear flat shoes, nice restaurants with very good food and excellent music (Fado). One of my favourite neighborhoods!

Quirky Old Town. Alfama is the quirky old town of Lisbon. It is not flashy, or necessarily the cleanest of neighborhoods in Lisbon, however, it is the most authentic and warm neighborhood I have come across. We really enjoyed wandering around and getting lost in the hilly streets, taking in the street art and narrow corridors between the homes. Makes for some very good photography, keeps your eyes open and your heads up!We were lucky enough to wander around on a Tuesday, coinciding with the weekly flea market which is also the largest in Lisbon. You can find some hilarious things being sold as well as some very special antiques. Again, keep your eyes open and allow yourself a good hour or two to browse properly. This area of Lisbon needs to be on your must do list. I have only wandered around on my second visit to Lisbon and regret not finding it before!!
Very interesting to walk around. Narrow, hilly, cobblestone streets with tiny shops and restaurants is a must-see area of Lisbon. You could ride a tuk-tuk if you aren't a good walker.

Charming. The oldest part of Lisbon. Lovely winding streets and lots of restaurants. Wear flat shoes - cobblestones are worn to a polished gloss by centuries of use and there isn't a level bit of pavement anywhere - all up hill and down hill.

Get lost (on purpose)!. This was my favorite part of our entire trip to Portugal. You could spend hours here getting lost (on purpose, of course). Friendly little shops and cafes surround the tourist sites of the castle and churches.

Best neighbourhood in Lisbon. Alfama is wonderful and the best place to go to just wander around and explore authentic Lisbon at its best. Full of winding, quiet streets, there are loads of little restaurants and shops to explore. Make sure you spend a few hours walking around and just getting lost.
nice Alfama. such a nice place to visit, be careful with the buggy. to really recommendable with the buggy. but rally nice area.

Hop off your hop-on-hop-off bus here!. Beautiful viewpoint over the historic center of Lisbon. We arrived here late in the afternoon and the sunlight was beautiful and warm over the red/white houses. Great place for photo's and for a sangria and a bite to eat on a terrace with a view. We didn't go to the castle though, we didn't see it from the viewpoint, so probably to much build-in between houses/streets for a good photo of it. After dinner we were to late for hop-on bus service, so we took the tramride down. I can recommend doing that!
Great area, must check out. Love this area, i would definitely recommend checking out the shops and restaurants. They have a trolley tour you can check the area out by too.
Very dirty place.. Dirty and smelly. You can walk in dirty roads, everything is full of smell. Be prepared to this evenience and be patient.
Loved the Alfama. Another area of Lisbon that we loved walking through. A lot of great sights and cute shops. Our daughter loved it here.

Obviously it must be done but, just a word of warning.. Atmospheric and full of a wonderful, colourful history but, just be aware that prices in restaurants may be a little misleading. The buildings in this area as with the majority of downtown Lisbon are steeped in history. There is however, a lot of dirty streets, messy pavements (dogs) and uneven surfaces for those who are none too steady on there feet. But, it has to be done if you are fit enough.

Buetifull part of the town. Nice day out touring around like a typical tourist haha, definitely a much in Lisbon... all the culture, markets and castles are amazing for anyone wanting some really old school culture.
Beautiful area full of culture and history.. Beautiful area full of culture and history. People are friendly, views are fantastic. A new adventure around every corner..

Super cool. The oldest part of Lisbon, is also the most popular tourist attraction. It totally lives up the hype. We took a free walking tour starting at Roccio through Baxia and then into Alfama. Glad we took a tour as got to know the history of the place. Easy to get lost in these tiny lanes,but eventually can find your way out. Lots of cool places to grab a bite and of course the ginjhi. Keep your camera ready!
Enjoy Lisbon!. Fantastic place to visit. Spend some time around buildings in the streets. You can easily find exiting buildings, streets and picturesque points. Enjoy!
Alfama. very interesting and quaint. It must be challenging trying to navigate those steep steps on daily basis. a bit of a maze so easy to get lost.

The nicer side of Lisbon. After the drug dealers, boring grid pattern and tourist traps of the Baixa its a breath of fresh air to escape into the maze of doglegged streets and alleys that make up the most historic area of the city.Built around the area that was developed during the Moorish occupation and retaining a lot more of it's history than downtown its a perfect place to get lost at night. Plenty of resturants, Fado clubs and little bars interspersed with Miradouros that pop out of nowhere.To crown it all; right at the top is the fabulous Moorish castle which is 100% worth a visit if only for the views. This Chiado and Bairro Alto are the go to places in Lisbon.

Alfama, a Great Lisbon neighborhood for dining and river views. This neighborhood of Lisbon has some of the best views, especially of the river, watching ships navigating and turning to dock, the ferries. Also, lots of nice outdoor restaurants and bars. Be sure to wear your hat and sunscreen, You will need it.

Lovely place to get lost. Whether you're looking to experience the traditional Fado singing, tracking down a delicious pastry, shopping at unique boutique shops or the wonderful open flea market near the Panteo Nacional, sipping verde wine in a cafe, or exploring the cobbled alleys and charming architecture, you can't do better than Alfama. Bring your walking shoes and sunblock!

A fascinating maze with a real taste of history.. A fascinating area to wander through. It's a maze of tiny streets, which at night comes alive with the strains of the Fado singers and musicians coming from the restaurants. There's a brand new street elevator which takes you to a super viewing point over Alfama and the river. It's actually worth taking the stairs up the elevator if you're feeling energetic. It's only two or three floors and the elegantly simple construction, with small windows giving stunning views make it feel like being in a lighthouse. At the top there's a great terrace cafe from where you can rest and really take in the view, also a point at which you can catch the famous no. 28 yellow tram.
must visit. One of the best bairro of Lisbon needs to be visited for the typcal narrow streets, restaurants and street fado

Very Interesting and Fun..Mostly from a History Point of View. I thoroughly enjoyed touring through Alfama...it is charming and interesting since a lot of Lisbon was destroyed in an earthquake. Its best feature is some history...Portugal is rich in history and culture and Alfama is charming and historical. Some may be bored by all of this...

Ancient and twisting street plan. Just lovely to wander about the old town, but very run down compared to the equivalent streets in say Barcelona.
Some interesting architecture.

Nice local sense. A really nice area to take a walk in .Its preferable to go with a tour guide , because alone you would probably get lost and there is these warnings regarding getting pick pocket .There are several places to listen to Fado in at night which is a great experience.There is a lot of going up and down , so prepare your legs for it

vibrant neighborhood. I had heard so many negative comments about drugs and dope pushers regarding this neighborhood. I was on guard. Let me tell you all, that I was not approached by a single soul, trying to sell me drugs. This is one of the most charming and vibrant neighborhoods in Lisbon. We were there during the sardine festival, and were able to sample street food, and hang out with locals. We came back again to shop the stores, filled with crafts from local artists. Very charming neighborhood.
Nice area!. The oldest neighbourhood of Lisboa is nice to walk around in. It has an authentic feel to it and you will get lost, but that's okay!
Nice neighborhood. We strolled around here and visited the castle. Its a nice place, small streets, nice houses, miradouros everywhere
Old Town!. It was great walking in the narrow streets of the old town.You hear fado playing in the shops and restaurants.It was a special and awesome experience.
Take a stroll. Really awesome. Take a stroll through the narrow streets and enjoy great views of Lisbon. Old Lisbon at its best.
Old Lisboa. Just great - ecsactly what we wanted! Small alleys, many good restaurants, some of them with fado - the live music. A must.

a visit to alfama lisbon. for fado music lovers it is a must!took a free guided tour learnt the background of fado music and enjoy a singer and two guitarists singing fado in three plazas in alfama the locals jointed in and it was very special!

Bring walking shoes. Beautiful district in Lisbon. Small roads, small doors, small stairs and a lots of hills. You definitely get a good exercise.
