Alternatively you can take the tram if you can't walk the distance. Once you're inside Alfama, it's like a labyrinth so don't forget a map or better, get some mobile data and use Google Maps!
Lisbon MUST. Just take a walk! get a cab to the castle and just your self go on walking down Alfana althrough the river. MUST!!

Moorish Lisbon. Yes, the first visit might be best with a walking tour as you won't get lost. Plus, you can return with more confidence on your own. Despite the fact you are in a large city, once you enter this ancient neighbourhood it feels like you have gone back in time to when neighbours were friendly and sincere. Over the centuries it has been home to groups that didn't fit into the regular Lisbon societies. These people are welcoming in a unique way. The streets are narrow and you will get lost. Look out for the dog poop everywhere. Stop and have conversations with the residents. Experience a place that is unlike any other.

The Portas do Sol has several terraces overlooking the Tagus and is one of the best places to relax after a day of sig. This is one of the best views of the Tagus and parts of old Lisbon. Alfama is very interesting to visit with its small steep, twisting streets and lots of small restaurants and cafes. The cathedral is worth a visit, especially the cloisters where excavation work is in progress.
A gaze in the old city. Magic atmosphere in one of the oldest and most typical areas of the city: worth spending some time walking around, also by the ancient electric (very crowded) trams.
Soul Feeding Alfama. You really feel lime time has stopped 100 years ago, perfect view, nice and small Tabernas around, a Lot of landmarks walking distance

Great neighbourhood to visit in Lisbon. Traditional Lisbon neighbourhood. Steep narrow streets, houses a few centuries old. Lots of history in the area. Popular with artists and students for it's upbeat and trendy vibe.

Very typical and unique. We visited this part of Lisbon several times, the last one being last October when spending a romantic weekend. We took a tuktuk from Rossio and off we went! With its impossibly narrow streets, interconnected in a labyrinth-like fashion, this area of Lisbon immediately transported us to a different time and we imagined how the old Lisbon would have been like many centuries ago. A must visit if you are in Lisbon!

My favourite part of a city. you can't leave the city not to see Alfama part. It's full of beautiful small streets, hills with good spots to get a good picture of a city and river, small local restaurants where you can get really good prepaerd fish, shops, there is also a good flee market and of course tram 28. Take a yellow one, red and green are for tourists, they are more expensive.

Dive into the history with Alfama. When walking in Alfama, once smell the history in its narrow colorful streets. It is a hill which overlook Tagus river. It is the most beautiful part of Lisboa. One should not miss it.

Well worth visiting this area as most picturesque.. Fascinating area with a labyrinth of steep crooked streets, alleys and stairways which is the layout left by the Moorish occupants in the Middle Ages.You are most certain to get lost but by day it is safe and easy going. Go to one of the many look out points with their expansive views. Visit the small café on the Largo das Portas do Sol.
FADO DINNER!. VISIT CASTLE SAO JORGE AND GO LISTEN TO FADO. The old town is great and could take a whole day and night!
Cutest streets, be ready to hike. Pretty streets, quintessentially Portuguese (in my mind at least). A must go in Lisbon where you can easily get lost for hours.

Local cultures ambience. Many local cuisines are served in here. The food is delicious, especially everything about fish. Be polite with the natives and don't use tuktuk to go there. They like to remain peaceful.

Loved it!. The most beautiful part of Lisbon with lots of shops, restaurants and bars! Especially great for the 'Fado' singers in most of the restaurants! It really gives you the sense of the real Portugal! I especially loved the 'Portas do Sol' to watch the sunset!
Good walkabout. Narrow winding streets are a delight. Good place to catch a fado. I recommend catching the 28 tram up and then walk back through Alafama.
Perfection in Lisbon!. Spent the better part of the day exploring this beautiful area of Lisbon. The hills, colours and views are not to be missed.

A magnificent ride to the past!!!. Don't miss this magic tour to the tiny uphill lanes that makes you feel you are in another century.Take the famous No.28 tram to Alfama ,wear comfortable shoes and walk around the area,look up to the marvelous old colorful houses many of them decorated with the famous ajouleos tiles,beautiful cafes and enjoy the view of the city.

Music and scene something to see. Great to walk around, hear the Fado music at the restaurants and experience Lisbon. Nothing to dislike, just a great experience to walk around and find somewhere to eat and enjoy the city.
The nicest district of Lisbon. Very nice old district so typical for Portugal. A little bit to much devastated - but it is a problem of whole Portugal.

Full of Character!. When in Lisbon, this is a must! Get lost in the streets! You will come across some great little cafés and Ice cream shops.
@instabuilt
Wonderful . Wonderful place, lots of secret places to visit and explore, just be aware,not an very safety place worth the effort

The heart of Lisbon . This is the real heart of Lisbon where you can breathe the history and the culture of this country. There is an amazing view of the city. Definitely my favourite place of Lisbon. You don't see Lisbon if you dont walk into Alfama.

We went to this neighbourhood because we went to a place unbelievable bad: a restaurant called Sal Grosso.. Location old and narow and dark and not so clean as de Baixa or Madragoa for instance. Alfama district is a old part of Lisbon but without the charm of Chiado or Avenida Liberdade. Typical but boring and all the places that Tripadvisor indicates are totally tourists trap! Be awear : Barrio Alto and Alfama are touristic imam to take money out of your pockets! Lisbon as much more to offer besides what is in the travel sites and Routers. . walk a little further to the right side facing the beautiful ricer. . .try Madragoa or other surrounding areas Take the boat to Cecilhas . . .be fearless and find your own way. .

The place to 'get lost'.... The books and even our tour guide really like to use the 'place to get lost' call. Make your way there, don't use a map, just wonder around. If you get lost, head down towards the river amd start again. We found some fantastic little cafes and enjoyed some custard tarts that the region is famous for. Lots of stairs and cobblestone alleys and stop to enjoy the views that can spring up at any moment.

The Best Bit of Lisbon. We spent a week in Lisbon, staying at an apartment in Alfama. And, although we did our best to see as much of the city as possible we did keep coming back to Alfama as our preferred spot for the evenings. There are loads of little restaurants and bars here, it's less tourist-y than places like the Baixa and Altro and a little quieter. If you like to spend time over dinner and drinking in quirky bars then this is the place for you.
A must see!. Alfama has an spectacular view of Lisbon. The people are very friendly and love for you to take lots of pictures.

Beautiful but overcrowded. Sad but true, it's a great part of town with wonderful views, but the tourists have now totally overwhelmed it. Thousands a day crowd the small sidewalks. The tourist pressure also brings other bad consequences--overpriced and bad restaurants, touristy souvenir shops, etc.

Most authentic neighborhood in Lisbon. Old town's most picturesque neighborhood. For me it was the best part of Lisbon with the hills and small streets going up and down. There are hundreds of corners to enjoy and any tram stop around here, you should take the tram 28, just don't take it at the beginning of the line.

Old charme, new vibes.. We bought a house in Alfama in 2009 and loved living there ever since. It is Fado, old ladies who shout our names as soon as we get there (so the whole barrio knows...), kids playing in the street and the overwhelmingly beautiful views of River Tagus. Old charme, new vibes.

Dark Side of Lisbon.... A beautiful part of Lisbon, this area tends to scare a lot of tourists from everywhere. Lots of small allies and shady streets (specially at night), but the place its great and pretty safe. Lots of artist and bars around, all within the set up of their houses and taking care of the old facade. Love the small souvenir shops, specially the ones selling tiles, and lots of cafes to see where you can enjoy the local food and some nice shows....
Magical. Pretty neighborhood to wander around and get lost in the small allies. It has lots of magic and we really enjoyed our time there!
Cool neighborhood nearby the castle.. Cool shops and little family restaurants. After your visit to the Castle, walk down and check out this neighborhood as well. Touristy though.

The most Portuguese place in Lisbon. This is THE place to visit in Lisbon if you ever want to experience the traditional relaxed atmosphere of Portugal. It's a little neighborhood with local restaurants and shops and portuguese buildings where you can see the elderly settle at the balconies. On the Eve of Saint Anthony (June 12th) one of the craziest festivals in Lisbon takes place in Alfama. The streets are filled with people from almost the entire city. The crowd is packed like sardines while, all you can see is people selling sardines and sangria and caipirinhas and stuff. There are little concerts and people chanting. Great vibes.

Fun at night AND during the day. It was fun to walk around here, both at night and during the day. We happened upon a tour being given when they were stopped in front of some great murals/graffiti art of Fado singers and learned a lot about the area vicariously.
Must See. A trendy part of Lisbon with amazing views of the city. One of the places you must visit when you are in the beautiful capital.

Interesting Neighbourhood. We came into this neighbourhood with the walls and houses all very close together. Old ladies just hanging out their windows or doors. People barbecuing in the streets laundry hanging to dry. Just a very unique and interesting area. Our guide told us how there is a street party where people are so packed in they can barely move, they eat sardines and drink wine. Not sure what the date was.

One of Lisbon's most charming neighbourhood. If you don't want to feel the true essence of Lisbon, walk through narrow streets, eat a meal of sardines in those many cozy restaurants and discover what it's like to live in the old part of the city than you better go somewhere else. But if you're one of my kind you propably will :-)Definitely a must in Lisbon!

Traditional neighbourhood . Every time I'm in Lisbon I have to walk around this place. There one can feel the real sense of what Lisboa is about. Stop in one of the traditional restaurants for a meal under 15€ including bread+butter+olives+main+drink+coffee
On our walk. Lovely area of the city really enjoyed it the market is mostly tat but that's how it goes sometimes. Enjoyed the walk and seeing the older part of the city.

Flea market. I did some shopping at great prices on Tuesday and Saturday. It's a good idea to buy gifts (eg made of cork). I also bought used, trendy clothes at a great price (could bargain) and in a good condition. There was a wide selection of cheap, leather shoes. You can also find some unique souvenirs.It is a good place for collectors.
Alfama is the BEST!. Best neighborhood to stay in Lisbon. Safe, closed to everything, beautiful views everywhere you walk, clean and above all full of character. I loved it.

The best experience in Lisbon. We rented a small flat in Alfama and stayed there for nine nights. And we had no idea what we're about to experience. This is one of the oldest arias of Lisbon, with lots of stairs, small restaurants with fado singers (starting to work around 6 pm), locals resting in front of their houses, unexpected views etc. But the most amazing thing were - we got to listen to fado (live!) almost every night from our window; local children playing on the stairs; view of the river Tagus and nearby churches, moonlight on the water... You can visit Fado museum and listen to their selection of various well known Portuguese artists in the audio room (I recommend Maria Theresa de Noronha). This was unreal! I never would've imagined our stay in Alfama would be like this - magical! It's the heart of Lisbon!

Alfama again and again!. Ok, a lot of people will tell you about Bairo Alto, but if you want to see the real thing try Alfama. Genuine neighborhoods, nice little restaurants - non touristics - and real people.The best view from the top of Alfama, "Largo das portas do sol" in the sunset! Also, here you'll find a lot of Fado corners.Really loved it!

Great Views, Lovely People!. The Alfama district is a great place to stay, with interesting architecture, great history and lot's of hidden away places to eat.The locals are also the friendliest you'll meet anywhere!

Quaint, hilly, so full of character. We stayed in alfama for our 4 nights in Lisbon. Its like walking a maze, what comes at the end of the street is always a surprise. A graffiti here, clothes drying there, faded and muffled sounds of Fado and conversations, loads of tiny bars and restaurants, a sudden tram from a narrow street and you have to hold on to the walls and let it pass...loads of wanderers, old locals sipping coffee, walking a cat... Its chaotic, charming, lots of uphill and downhill walk and the fun is in getting lost, catching your breath, grabbing a drink, listening to Fado and just living the moment!!!
Beautiful part of the old city. Stunning part of the old city with loads of interesting shops, restaurants etc. The Fado restaurants are particularly good
Beautiful Views. Beautiful views; worth the walk. Nice, historical place to walk around, see some ramparts, etc. Loved the tile mosaics, and learning about the history of Lisbon.
Charming . Well worthwhile, really nice full of charming places to have food, drinks and little shops. Great just ti walk through its smalls streets.
Smells. Old neighborhood where you can go if you want to feel the smell of old fado restaurants where people sing bad fado. The food is mostly reasonable where everything is to attract tourists.

Historic part of Lisbon well worth exploring. We caught the iconic Lisbon tram, the No.28 to Alfama and explored the narrow alleyways of this historic neighbourhood and took in the views down to the waterfront. It is also easy to visit the Sao Jorge Castle from here for more breath taking views across the whole of Lisbon.A great place to explore and make sure you take a while at one of the bars with views across the Tegus and just the world go by.
Visit is a must. The atmosphere of this Little quarter of Lisboa is great. Small cafes, narrow streets, pretty places. A surprise is waiting behind each corner!

Medieval Alfama. The Alfama district is the oldest district of Lisbon. This is the city’s medieval Moorish district which is a maze of narrow cobbled streets, churches and white-washed houses decorated with lovely tile work and wrought iron balconies. The churches in this area are the lovely Lisbon Cathedral and the tiny Santa Luzia. The views from the Alfama are quite stunning. Overlooking the Alfama is the Castle of St. George.
Favourite part of Lisboa. Alfama is my favourite part of the city. Charming, genuine, beautiful views, cosy restaurants, and a huge fleamarket (close to Santa Clara) on saturdays.

Wandered and enjoyed. Narrow lanes, full of atmosphere, we just walked and walked! No tuctuc required unless you are informed. Some lanes are very steep! Wonderful at lunch time to see workman in the area setting up a make do bbq at the side of the street to cook their lunch. It all added to the charm if the area. Superb old buildings, washing blowing high up from balconies and some sort of tiled mosaics on some buildings. We even saw a lovely green parrot hanging out in his cage. Just meander and enjoy. We did......lovely and atmospheric.
Enjoy Portugal. Excellent Site, when you are in LISBON Portugal, WORTH a very Special VISIT, to visit you have to walk through the city old part, this gives an excellent opportunity to enjoy the walk

Packed with must see sites. This neighborhood is packed with must see sites. The streets are the original medieval and confusing design as opposed to a more modern grid pattern. It's my understanding a lot of this area survived the earthquake, fire and tsunami of 1755.

Traditional Portuguese neighborhood. We walked a couple hours in this neighborhood and we could enjoy the atmosphere and the beautiful architecture.Many restaurants playing Fado (Portuguese music) so we could taste a portuguese meal and listen to this charming and full of emotion music.
Lisbpon Girlie Weekend. Stayed in this area, very pleasant and friendly. Loved the Fado bars and quaint back streets. Shopping in main area was very good. Enjoyed bus tour of tourist sights.

Great day out, cobbled streets and interesting art trail. Me and my friend started up at the Prato do sol view point where you can have great views of the whole city; the monastry churches, the sea and the main shopping district. I believe this area turns into a lively bar at night time too (we were there in the morning) . Despite being constantly warned by every guide book that we would get lost, we managed to navigate the cobbled streets, the winding alleys and the lack of sign posts! A tip would be to walk down the street named 'Helena' from Prato do sol and just work your way down. Walk down Sao Miguel and Sao Padro for the real Alfama atmosphere and you may even bump into the infamous Coco the parrot who will say 'ola' to you if you are lucky! As we walked along the streets we noticed several interesting religious murals on the brick work. Near the top of the district we stopped over at a vegan cage called Sao Tome. They served fresh, home made lemonade, vegan pizzas, cakes and other smoothies too. It was a lovely place to stop, with lovely, friendly staff and delicious food. We ended our self-directed tour at the fado museum and then walked along the water front to Rue Augusta again.

Nice area. Both touristy streets and non touristy streets, but mostly touristy. Nice and cosy, but watch out for the tuk-tuks that drive all around in every narrow street you can find. Definitely the nicest area in Lisboa.

oldest part of portugal. We walked around here today and if you just take streets away from the tram lines you will find yourself in wonderland full of winding streets lovely little resturants. We felt very safe and it was fascinating. Some of the views from the top were spectacular. We did not do the tourist cars or trams and so glad we didn't as we got to see the real alfama a good map is all you need.
The heart of the city. If you are looking for an authentic feel of Lisbon, find a quaint little place in this district and enjoy the Fado and food of the Tasca's.
Exelent. Great view. Great location to see the ocean, and all Lisboa. We came with tram. Superb to see all trip to Alfama and route old tram.

Most beautiful part of Lisbon!. This part of Lisbon is very typical, with its narrow streets and paths, climbing passages, old houses, lovely tea rooms, confectioneries and breathtaking views on the city. One MUST visit this part when staying in Lisbon.We visited this part with a guide, and I really recommend doing it this way, otherwise you can get lost and pass through the same street all the time and won't see the most interesting and its time saving.
a quaint charming area of the castle. I loved the old tiny Moorish streets and shops. Lots of views and character up here my friends. Take a tuk tuk for the best experience!

most beautiful part of Lisbon. the most beautiful area of Lisbon go sunrise or sunset for the most amazing light! wonder the tny maze like cobble streets, drink sangria and beers for 1euro in the old-timer spots, take photos at Porta do Sol and the beautiful Jardim Julio de 'something'... Chapito is a funky spot for drinks and views of the river and have Fados and other funky live music each night and cultural events! Hotel Memma for a fancier rooftop drink.
Nice typical neighbourhood in Lisbon. One of my favourite places to "get lost", take pictures and spend a nice time! Original shops and unusual cafés.

Highly recommended. I enjoyed wandering up, down and around the small alleyways. Took the advice of other reviewers and was careful with my belongings and made sure I was around others--at one point I went down a small street and found myself alone and made sure to turn back around to a busier area--but I didn't experience anything sketchy. I felt a little strange to be wandering around practically in people's backyards! I was turned off by the fado places trying to get me to come in but highly enjoyed the sweet but strong home-made ginja!
Nice neighbourhood. Nice neighbourhood worth visiting and don't miss the live fado music on the square in front of the Fado Museum!
Worth a walk. Interesting and cool place to walk around after visiting the castle. Its old and funky and has lots of cool unexpected shops and bars

Beautiful Alfama. Alfama is beautiful,tradional Portuguese architecture with narrow streets.St George's castle is one of the wonderful buildings to see at the top if the hill.Do wear good walking shoes.The prices are aimed at tourists in the cafes so, if you're on a budget bring your own refreshments.

A ride to the top of old Lisbon Portugal. We went up to the top by TukTruck which is a neat way to go as the streets are very narrow and bumpy . It is a scooter with a covered setting in the back . It sounds like it may not make it up the steep hills but it does. Also the drivers are also great tour guides in their own rights . We really should have tried them earlier as it would have been much easier on me .
Visiting Alfama should be # 1 to do in Lisbon.. Go here after 5 pm, or after visiting the castle and just walk around (trafic is almost impossible in the streets) and enjoy the athmosphere.
charming part of Lisbon. not so posh but still very stylish quarter of Lisbonthe second step to visit the city after visiting the centre

The oldest and decadent part of Lisbon. A walk through Alfama is on the must do list in Lisbon. It is the oldest part of town of great Arab influence with narrow and winding streets and it covers one of the hill of Lisbon. It is decadent and benignly neglected but it has a great charm and it is the soul and the spirit of Lisbon. There are shops, restaurants, bars, fado, Cathedral, churches and views but the best part is just wandering around without a destination

Worth spending an evening exploring the area. The narrow criss cross streets and the old architect building will take you to an another world. The small restaurant with authentic food and traditional music will a treat to your stomach and ears. A must visit place and one should spend an entire evening by just taking a stroll in these streets.

You can breathe a relaxed local atmosphere. Exceptionally beautiful part of Lisbon. I felt very relaxed and was especially impressed by the hospitality of the local people. Particularly impressive was the tram ride that led me to this part.

True lisbon. We loved getting lost in the little alleys and side streets offered in Alfama. You get a true picture of what Lisbon was like a few 100 years ago. Little houses which their owners have turned into shops from traditional food, Ginjinha and souvenirs.

Picturesque and very nice. It's a worth seeing area because of its very picturesque corners and small streets full of local people doing their business. You can see women cooking sardinas on the street, children playing football and old people sitting in front of their house.
Great views of the bay. This is a lovely suburb on the hill, with great views across the bay. The winding roads through the suburbs is great ot walk down.

Small windy streets. Its a cool place to walk around in the day & night. I learnt how they do the crazy pavements, when I saw street repairs being done. That was cool.
At night the vibe is also cool, hunting out the small place to go down a street you could easily miss!
A truly beautiful part of Lisbon. Lovely quarter. Beautiful side streets, lots of interesting shops and good restaurants. Worth spending an entire day there.

Must see Old Lisbon. I just love this old section with winding alleys, little shops and restaurants with fado streaming out the doors and windows. Research the best, or just wander in. I went three times to explore more and see how it connects with other parts and sights you want to see, such as the Castelo, the Cathedral, and the water itself. While it is hilly, there are lots of little places to stop and rest. Traveling alone, a middle aged woman, I was welcomed in to a fado performance already in session, and seated right in the front. Was not asked to pay any cover. Just had one glass of wine and then when the show was over, the owner arranged for a staff member who happily walked me down to the main road and found a cab for me.

Fun flea market. Walked around and stopped at the flea market (Tues and Sat, I think). Lots of stalls with interesting things for sale. Our family enjoyed it and then we went for a nice lunch down one of the little lanes.

You need to go at least twice.. So this is old town of Lisbon. I was there at night 9-11pm and then with a tour by Doron (from Sandeman). It was a blast. Both times. Walking in those small streets and listening to music from the streets. Highly recomended !

A good place for a walk, lunch or dinner. The Alfama section of Lisbon makes for a great walking tour. Be sure to read the tour guide before your visit to get the full benefit. It's a good place to go for lunch or dinner. Good authentic Portuguese food. Order fish and port wine.

OLD LISBON. Can't miss this, look at the houses and you're in the pre great earthquake era, windy hills and very old shops and quaint nooks.Was saved by the post earthquake tsunami due to its height and by its population (non Catholic). The gigantic earthquake tore down the city at 9 am on a religious feast day when churches were full. So interesting social connotation
Great area!. Great area of Lisbon to travel and see. Much cheaper than a lot of other parts. Small bars and live music.
Classic narrow streets of a European city. Great little area to get lost, and stumble across new bars and restaurants. Well, that is what we did!

Beautiful place. Alfama is a really beautiful district with its restaurants and the great viewpoint over the city. We visited it while doing a Tuktuk tour, I really recommend it as it adds to the overall experience.

Beautiful alfama. We took the No28 tram up the hill,to take in the fabulous views,and the wander down through the cobbled streets,stopping off at a couple of bars for some local snacks and cheeses,
Tip:-wear stout shoes as the uneven steep paths will make your feet ache

Quaint and charming. The Alfama is one of Lisboa's more historic and character-filled local neighbourhoods. Its narrow streets are great for exploring, though it is located on the side of a steep hill, so wear your walking shoes. Lots of cafes and arty shops selling handicrafts, curios and antiques. I thought there is much less tourist tat on offer here than in the downtown area. If you're here in the evening it is an excellent place to catch some fado as well as to eat. If you are not staying in the area it would make sense to incorporate your visit with a trip to Castelo San Jorge. Even if you don't make it as far uphill as the castle, there are still plenty of fine views to be had from (free) Miradouros within the Alfama.
this is Lisbon. a wonderful part of Lisbon....you have to go there and enjoy the small streets nice restaurants and the people....this part of lisbon has a very nice and special flair...

Built for strolling around. Well maybe not, I suspect it was built for living in, but it's perfect for an aimless holiday wander! The colours of the buildings, the sea and the wider city interact to produce an ever changing viewscape that always reveals new sites, squares and views. You could spend anything from 30 minutes passing through to several hours wandering, stopping for a drink, photographing. It is steep and paths are narrow, but well worth it.

great to visit. We visited this area from Barro alto, it is well worth a visit with little windy streets, restaurants round each corner and a tranquil atmosphere. For us it was a place to visit and not to stay as it isn't very central. A lovely historic place of interest, you will need flat walking shoes, no high heels here.

One old city centre is just like another. Nice but Lisbon feels a bit run down, and not in a shabby chic way I feel. Best have your walking boots on (as the Misses is in a walking challenge at the moment for us not a problem)

great to walk around with no purpose. a warren of steep, narrow streets with; local life that goes on in all its prosaic ways with laundry hanging and people congregating at small cafes - despite increasing numbers of tourists; many little tavernas, some with live Fado, and a few with very good Fado performers
Happenings at Alfama. The evenings are full of happenings at Alfama. A great place for food and fado at every corner down the narrow lanes with the aroma of fish

Alfama mon amour. The best part of Lisboa. Here you can feel the spirit of the city, with all the small shops, bars, squares. Avoid the turistic places, and try to find hidden restaurants, its the best way to enjoy at its best this area!

Authentic side of Lisbon. Once in Lisbon don't miss a visit to this old borough that represent an authentic side of the city. Great local shops, narrow streets, simple life with great spots for urban photo lovers.
. Best way to see this area is to lose yourself in the narrow alleys and staircases- beautiful tiled buildings lots of street art. Eclectic shops full of finds.

A great place to stay. Steeped in history and character with wonderful views. Some good restaurants as well as some interesting antique and crafts shops. Very hilly so you will either get plenty of exercise or resort to the trams

Breathtaking. I'm not a history expert and could of probably looked of the information before continuing this review, but I believe that is one of the oldest areas in Lisbon. Alfama is filled with panoramic views overlooking Lisbon at every corner. It was such a beautiful sight to intake and I walked up hill and sown hills riding on trams embracing the structures of the buildings and the kindness of the locals. You have to visit this area. Not only are the views spectacular, but the shopping, the food and the old art museums and churches on the hill are worth taking a look at.

fort has a great view. half daytake a cheap taxi to the fort, fort has a great vieweasy walk downhill to Catedral de Se, then Praca de commercio on the waterfront and back up Rua Aigusta to several more Pracas and the train station, then west along Rua Garrett of the Chiado shopping district -
nice place to walk. This area is nice. The old ladies in front of their window are looking for the tourists. Narrow charming streets.
beutiful , Masmerizing. Beautiful area . It's lovely to arrive by tram 28 or by feet then just spend time wandering around the streets and cafes specialy the singer in top cafe with nice spirit.

Dont miss Alfama on your next trip to Lisbon !. Just a great part of the City with wonderful atmosphere, great food offering, good local wines on offer and lots of locals who seemed to want to dance the night away ! A must for any visit to Lisbon !

Good atmosphere in Alfama.. Old neighbourhood with all the charming, little streets and croocked houses. A LOT of fado restaurants in this area, could have a better variety of establishments, but it is nice enough. I'd rather have accomodation in Alfama than in Chiado.

My favorite neighborhood in Lisbon. First day in Lisbon we were in Alfama and it was love at first sight. During evenings the streets are emptier and local people goes outside eating and talking each others in front of their buildings. I loved small local restaurants where police men and older men were waiting for a free table in front of the building. I recommend one of those tiny little restaurants, where you will sit on the same table with other guests - it is called O Eurico Casa de Pasto, own by two old people - husband and wife (great food, very good prices)
Beautiful Alfama. Beautiful area of the capital. It's lovely to arrive by tram 28 then just spend some time wandering around the streets and cafes. Lovely miradouro (view point).

Wonderfully quaint neighbourhood. The wife and I loved this area. Definitely has a charm to it that other parts of Lisbon don't. This, mostly due to the old buildings, and winding streets. We managed to find a nice, small family run bar-restaurants that did a great sangria for only 1 Euro a glass.

Old city portugal. We walked the path of the tram and found many little original boutiques we would otherwise have missed. It was interesting to see the real way the locals live and places they eat. We especially enjoyed the little port shops and all the tastings!
Interesting Old Lisbon. We loved wandering around Alfama, meandering throughout the streets and into small family run cafes and gift shops.

old portugal. Really interesting place. Very old streets, small stores, ... a place that the tourists wil enjoy a lot.
It´s Tipical from old portugal.

In Lisbon do not forget Alfama. Nice neighborhood during the day, warm restaurantes and party places at night. A must go place anytime you visit Lisbon, easy to arrive (there is even a tram that carries you from Metro stations).

Nothing special . Walked to Alfama because high ranking in TripAdvisor. Just old houses and nothing else. Caféterias and restaurants like anywhere else in Lisbon. Don't see what is so good about this. At least saw it to tell others that nothing to see here.
Backstreet history, Fado and food. Pedro gave a great tour with off the beat secrets of Alfama. The Fado and food was great! Walking tours are the best!

One of the best historic neighborhoods in Lisbon. Historic neighborhood in Lisbon. A place not to be missed if it is your first time in Lisbon. Advise: rent a tuk-tuk and go the historical route. You will see how beautiful Lisbon is!
Fleamarket Finds. Found the flea market which is open on Sunday and Tuesdays. and then hired a Tuk Tuk back to the central shopping district and our hotel. Great local flavor moments.

The real Lisbon (?). No visit to Lisbon is complete without visiting Alfama.
The place that gave the world Fado is worth visiting any number of times. At night or during the day.
This is where the working class lived and continue to live.
It also has some nice little restaurants.

Lovely neighbourhood.. Lovely neighbourhood. Lisbon began in this area. Romantic and authentic atmosphere. Beautiful view of Lisbon. One finds some interesting and quintessential Portuguese places to eat or drink a "imperial".

Not worth the visit. The main area of Lisbon are the downtown shopping district, Belem and Alfama. We took a free walking tour of Alfama and other than beautiful views of the river, there was little to see or do. We wound our way down from St. George's Castle down towards the river making a few stops along the way. We heard the same historical stories as we did on the other tours. There was nothing worthwhile about the tour. Skip it and go to Belem or Sintra.

Fado, Alleys and Sardines!. Who can resist the smell of sardines being grilled on the chalk outdoors? Visit this quarter at night for a wonderful fado night! Don't miss the grilled "chouriço" on the clay griller!
Old lisbon. This is the Lisbon you see when it is shown on TV. Lots of old restaurants and stores to browse. Nice to just walk around and soak in the surroundings.

chill out area. The beautiful view from the castle give a fresh breath of city, lot of tasty , cozy restaurants and shops for tourists, the Tram 28 is must taking transport, Tuk-tuk also funny way to explore the Alfama.
Must visit at night!. Walk the streets here at night, eat good food, drink cheap drinks and listen to live fado music. Beautiful, festive, lively, and very safe even late at night!
Old quarters of Lisbon. The picture post card place depicted in the brochures of lisbon is typical. Red tiled buildings basked in sunlight was so good to watch.

Classic Lisbon. If you're coming to Lisbon, you probably have a clear idea in your mind as to what it will be like, and it's probably Alfama you're thinking of. This is the historic area down from the Castle, and is well worth spending at least a half day exploring here on foot. Lots of twisting limestone paved streets in what is the oldest part of the city. The Cathedral is also situated here, so set aside a day in your diary to visit the Castle, the Cathedral and take a day wandering these streets.

unguided tour of the Alfama neighborhoods.. Myself and my sister in law were able to wind our way through the twisty streets of this ancient neighbor hood. I don't think I'll ever forget this place. We had written directions to get us through the tour of these streets and we never were lost. Fascinating area to see. I won't forget it. After the walking tour, we saw more churches in the area, all amazing and grand!!!

The soul of Lisbon. This district is quite touristy of course because it is so typical with its stairs, small squares, lanes and dead ends everywhere. Alfama is not only for grilled sardins and a fado recital at night, it's more than that. One should lose himself in the labyrinthic lanes and stop for a cup of coffee at a terrace, just to Watch the locals passing by, it's a real show. The view from Miradouro de Santa Lucia is a must, as well as the museum of fine arts, on the same square.

Overated!!. We went here after visiting the castle and were very disappointed. Not sure if it was due to the fact that we visited in the middle of the day and the heat, but the neighborhood was nothing to write home about. Just another old neighborhood in Europe.
Fado. Very popular with the Fado music which is expensive to attend... but you can have a walk and dinner... and with the monye you can buy a fado CD :)

Up and down. The hills are everywhere, but the are quite nice. You can walk arond here or take the tram, which finds its way throught the narrow streets. Alfala is well woth spending at least half a day on.

Narrow, lovely alleys and fado music. A great neighbourghood were people live close to each other and chat on the street. Children play around, laundry hangs everywere, old ladies watch out of the windows commenting and gossiping. You can feel that people still care abut each other here. The best way to get there are the 25 and 12 trains, and the descent on foot is very easy and picturesque. Stop on your way for a shot of ginjinha, cherry liquor and some fado music.

Authentic neighbourhood. Loved the real neighbourhood feel here....charming little up and down streets and the friendliness of the locals.Tiny little rooms and terraces that turn into nighttime eateries or bars...lovely.
Beautiful. This area of Lisbon offers great views, and provides a charming setting. We loved strolling through the streets of Alfama.
Great place to visit. Located beneath the castle and above the River Tagus’ estuary, Alfama is one of the oldest and most typical neighborhoods of Lisbon.Must visit, and eating in there.

Alfama. The Alfama area of Lisbon is its oldest area. It is located on a hill with the castle of St George at the top. This is a lovely area filled with winding streets, colourful houses, tiled houses, cafes, churches, lookout points with great views. A wonderful area to explore either on foot or on the number 28 tram.This area is home to the Castelo San Jorge and Se cathedral. It is also an absolute joy to lose yourself and just wander for a few hours.

Lovely, medieval part of Lisbon. Very hilly!. We stayed in Lisbon for 3 nights and on our first day we decided to do a Medieval tour of Lisbon (including Alfama) on Segways!! This is the best thing you could do while being in Lisbon as it's a great way to see various parts of the city, and it's so much fun!!Alfama is very hilly so you wouldn't really want to walk it all. Riding around on segways is so much easier and quicker. There are tons of restaurants, cafes, live music in Alfama and some lovely buildings too. Worth checking out for sure
Lovely spot. Lovely viewing spot. definitely worth going to see! You get a good view of the city and it's actually not too busy with tourists.
Old Lisbon. Very nice old neighborhood, with small streets and old buildings. Amazing. You can see the FADO museum, the typical portuguese music.

Alfama breathless views . Alfama quarter is one of the most magical districts of Lisbon with its breathless views and his dominant São Jorge castle. Visitors can reach the top of the towers of the castle and walk along the bastions. Near the castle, you can find the cathedral Sé built by Alfonso Henriques for the first archbishop of Lisbon.Around the district you find the Miradouro de Santa Luzia from where you can have a wonderful view of the city.

Highly recommended when in lisbon.. The alfama district of Portugal with all of its narrow alleys and sickle ways is a must see visit.the tram stops here and you can hop on and off. Great views accross the river. Some lovely typical Portugal shops as well as gift shops all around the village.

Historical athmosphere. We started our walk from Santa Apollonia station and headed towards Sé, and tried to visit as many churches as possible during the trip. Fantastic maze! Hundreds of stairs, narrow allies and steep hillsides and many fado places. Lots of original people and laundry drying outside... Teens were a bit exhausted after 1,5 hours walk in the heat...
Great place to stroll in Lisbon. Great place to stroll in Lisbon, just make sure you get lost in the tiny streets of Alfama. Amazing Street food

Historic Lisbon. Visited restaurant with Fado music as part of a guided walking tour of historic Lisbon. Food was fantastic and fado music beautiful. Old cobblestone streets with beautifully aged buildings - a walk back in time !

Lovely architecture. Historical area with lots to see. Old and modern buildings with a sense of history. The area can be busy, but more relaxing compared to the hustle and bustle of the shopping areas.

Highlight of our trip!. This is one of the best places in Lisbon. Absolutely packed and filled with delicious food and antics during festival time in June. We came here as much as we could. Be prepared for a lack of public bathrooms haha, but apart from that it's an incredible cultural experience.

My favorite hangout in Lisboa!. I spent an entire afternoon having a drink and gazing at the beautiful view of the river and surrounding area. The view from this part of Lisboa was so relaxing. From here, it was a short hike...but very steep...trek to Castelo Sao Jorge. My only regret is I didn't stay until much later to experience a fado. Well, the more reason to come back!
Great place to visit. When to visit in Alfama, you are feeling the authentic Portuguese life... WOW... don't miss the Fado museum

Most atmospheric part of Lisbon. Alfama is best seen walking around, getting lost in its streets, bumping across view points where to enjoy magnificent views of Lisbon.That's exactly what I did and why I loved it.Se Cathedral, the Castle, miradores, and various other churches worth visiting are all here, so heading to Alfama is for sure the most important thing to do of any trip in Lisbon.The area is virtually deserted at night, so come here early and move to Barrio Alto in the afternoon/ evening.
Nice view!. Excellent area for photography. The 28 tram stops near by, and you can also walk to Castello Sao Jorge from this point.
Morning walk. Went for a walk around in the morning, had a lovely coffee and pastel de nasa at a popup cafe by the view point. Great view.

Lovely!. Great part of Lisbon, a must visit. Such beautiful views of Lisbon and the sea from the top. The houses and streets on the hill are lovely: so colorful, the narrow streets, the old buildings... Loved it!

A segway tour and hours of enjoyable walking!. Too the Segway tour up into Alfama, one of the oldest parts of the City. The streets are often winding and narrow and full of interest - the architecture, street noises and activities and little tucked away bars and restaurants.This was a great place to explore for hours with spectacular views over the River and City - you can lose yourself happily as you climb higher and higher where the views get better and better - loved it!
Fine place to walk. nice neighborhood where the condition is growing and will sweat , a few reasonable restaurants and good views of the river

Typical, Lisboa at its very best. The neighbourhood you want to walk and wander in, small places, corners, churches, laundries out the windows, that is a collection of places worth the tour. We spent a half day with a guide living there that took us through the History and lives of that lovely place that is between the Castle Sao Jorge and the Taje river. No way to go to Lisboa and skip that area, it's a must see.

Don't miss Alfama. Very cool area of town - tons of narrow alley ways the wind and turn (it's easy to get lost), and the views of the river are excellent. I believe it's the oldest neighborhood in Lisbon - very cool.
Hills. So much character. Loved the area but the hills can be challenging. I do not recommend walking in this area

Hills make cities much nicer . And here it works 100%. From many viewpoints you can overlook the other parts of Lisbon and get oriented easier.
Good exercise to walk it on your own with stopping where you want.
Tram 28 was always awfully crowded, so we were lucky to be outside, walking in fresh air.

Cultural Experience. WOW! Never would have come here if it had not been for Lisbon Chill Out tours. Our guide took us through, and my friend and I had to return. We went around dinner time and the streets were incredibly lively. There was music everyone and people were dancing outside of all of the restaurants. It felt a little more authentic than other areas of Lisbon. The people were very very nice and accommodating. They were willing to talk to you and patient for those who do not speak Portuguese. Great experience.
charming. Really authentic and nice place. I reccomend to go there if you're planning a trip in Lisbon. One of my favourite town in Europe. Love it!
A great place to wander. Take some time to get lost in Alfama. Visit the Castelho and Se, shop at Santos Oficios Artesnatos, eat at Chapito.

Good for Wandering; fabulous tile buildings. I spent time in the Alfama district just wandering the streets. There are churches and fabulous buildings with tile facades. Lots of cute gift shops. The district starts at the waterfront and goes up the hill. Really gives you a feeling for the old Lisbon. A must see.
This is the part of Lisbon that the 28 tram was made for.. Apartments are available at realistic prices. Good food and entertainment. IHO this is the best bit of a stunning city.

Wow -- lucked out to see a joyous Portuguese city!. After sleeping off our jet lag, we took a taxi to Alfama. We were immediately happy to see churros and other delicious street food for sale in a bustling historic section of the city. Walked around for hours, enjoyed it all, and were amazed to see that beer and sangria often cost less than coca cola (or even water!). But the big surprise was that June 12 happens to be a special holiday, and at night the place was just a joyous noisy mardi gras type party -- lots of people wearing green wigs and hats shaped like sardines (a very popular food in Lisbon!). It was just great fun to see and be part of -- totally different from most cities I've ever visited. So if you're planning a visit for next June, I suggest you time it for June 12!
A must go for the views and life. From here you can see Lisbon from the top. Take the 28 tram and do not miss Lisbon from this spot. A must do.

Old Lisbon. Old Lisbon. Very steep uneven streets. Not for anyone with a problem walking. Wheelchairs - impossible!But for those lucky enough- you will be greeted with cosy little cafes, bars and quirky shops that line the cobbled streets.Nice to take a tram to the districtVery good views of the sea when the streets open up.

Historical Moorish centre of Lisbon. This neighborhood of Lisbon used to be the focal point of the Moorish administration of Portugal. IT is one of teh oldest portions of the town and houses a concentration of Fado Clubs and the Fort Castle of St George and the Sé Cathedral

not as charming as described but worth FADO Museum. Probably some photos would do just as well as the difficult climb of stairs and steep hills for folks who have trouble walking….the place seemed more filled with tourists than residents, and we did not feel comfortable returning to the area to enjoy the nightlife, after dark. However, the Museum of FADO is not to be missed!

The best, oldest neighborhood in Lisbon.. This is the most interesting, and the oldest neighborhood in Lisbon. Be prepared for walking up really steep hills. There are tons of terrific restaurants and sites.

Great. Enchanting and mysterious a great place to visit a fado place,
the streets are narrow and hilly but you really enjoy a walk around there you can visit the Cathedral
Beautiful . A lot of cultures co existing beautifully and a lot of history behind the city. Definitely recommend a personalised tour so you don't get lost in the winding streets.

A litle feeling about one of the best places of the city of Lisbon. It is one of the best places to walk through and feel the pulse of the old city....very tipycal places where one's can ear the national song, the FADO

Love it!. We stayed in Alfama-the oldiest part of Lisbon and I would do it again. Its lively area, with many steps and narrow streets to explore, nightlife goes on full swing in Alfama and famous tram 28 goes there too.

Beautiful neighbourhood. We first arrived in Lisbon tired. As we walked around the neighbourhood, your exhaustion leaves you when you start climbing the beautiful cobblestone narrow roads. We didn't know where we were going and a lady hanging out of her window directed us. We climbed to Sao Jorge castle, where Around the corner was a stunning view. We walked all around this neighbourhood, in and out of the little streets, getting the flavour of the area. Tram 28 is a great way to see the sights going down the hill. A tip, if the first one is full, wait for the next one and so on. There are many to choose from. No point in being sardined together when there are empty ones. There is a little vegan place, which serves delicious pizza. A beautiful area, lots of tourist, but still quiet.

Take tram 28 to visit Alfama. Wonderful historical place. Don't forget to wear comfortable shoes to be able to walk along the narrow, winding streets. The views are breathtaking. History and romance...

Romantic and beautiful. Alfama is such a nice place to walk around. We took the 28 tram all the way to the top and walked back down. Luckily the tram wasn't packed with people so we got to sit together and enjoy a scenic route comfortably by the window with a cool breeze. It was a very nice and romantic way to see parts of Alfama. We were worried Alfama would be swamped with tourists, but we got to walk by ourselves and experience the streets as the authentic, residential area it is. The views are also extremely nice.
Excellent Place. Should be visited from all people who visit Lisbon. Simply walk on the street, loos yourself by crossing the small one and take time appriciate the atmospher.

The best of all neighborhoods of Lisbon!. With Chiado, we believe that is the most lively, beautiful and awesome places of the center of Lisbon. There are a lots of streets with magic and different things to see. It is not a long walk but the streets are really inclined. My recommendation is to take tram 28 and askew al the neighborhoods with the card.

Get inspired by Portuguese's soul at romantic Alfama .... Alfama means tradition, passion and history! Let Alfama inspire all your senses! Narrow streets, old buildings, small chapels and "fado" singers ... Meet the real Portuguese's soul at famous Alfama historical quarter. Visit the mythical "Castelo de São Jorge" (with the most beautiful view of Lisbon and its awesome Tejo River), the magnicent "Sé de Lisboa" (Lisbon's Cathedral, also known as "Igreja de Santa Maria Maior", with romanesque, gothic and baroque caractheristics), and many other attractive constructions. But, be aware of pickpockets! Bring your camera and stroll lazily along the tramway ... Lovely memories to take home. Enjoy!
Really nice and colorful area. I recommend the austrian cafe in lower Alfama, very homely and great service. The winding roads of Alfama are quite picturesque and fun.
Very nice old town. Lovely old town, take tram 28 up to the town, there is a good atmosphere with some beautiful viewing points of the city.

Lovely area. I loved the whole area of Alfama Its quirky and although up along a steep hill its a lovely walk. Pretty houses and bars and cafes but its also run down in many places It has character and music at night everywhere.
Fantastic walking sightseeing !. Fantastic district. Steep narrow streets with a lot of charm. Look close at all the houses with nice ceramics decorated all over the houses!

Bring your walking shoes and camera with lots of spare SD cards.. You could spend a series of holidays wandering round the intricacies of this visual delight. It has everything from quiet corners to busy restaurants. In every weather it is perfect for photographers

inspiring. If you're a painter, a photographer, a city gazer, a wine taster, an absent minded artist, a posh recreationalist, or whatever else, Alfama district has bits of everything. Take a "blind-folded" path to nowhere and reach a restaurant, or a pub that suits your needs. And then repeat in the evening, especially Friday and Saturday evenings.

Lovely, but be aware!. Beautiful part of old LIsbon. A real working class neighborhood, very authentic. People are friendly and welcoming and charming. However be aware. I was walking around during my second visit to LIsbon and ventured a little bit a different way from the average tourist. I had my iPad in my hand as there are so many fantastic opportunities to take pictures, each street is more picturesque. One of the local "homeboys" thought I was a target and sneaked u behind me and tried to snatch my iPad. as I had been to Lisbon before I was aware of this type of thing a created a wristband connected to my iPad so the "homeboy" went away with nothing. That was the only unpleasant experience I had in Lisbon, but that can happen anywhere.

Walk it, don't wimp out and take the tram. Best seen during the late afternoon. Clamber up the steep streets by following the route the tram takes. Pop into the many chapels and churches you'll see along the way. Be sure to look for the signs marking the old Jewish quarter. Round it off with a stop at the lookout, sit outside, drink something, and watch the city laid out before you.

Ah Alfama!. Loved loved loved the Alfama. Was lucky enough to visit during the Santos Populares festival, so there was music and dance and sardines and beer and caipirinhas and ginjinhas everywhere. Such joy.
Even without the festival on, the Alfama is just a wonderful place to wander and explore life in Lisbon away from the tourist overload of places like Baixa.

Quintesential Old Lisbon, that pre-dates the Planned City. An incredible warren of narrow cobbled streets with even narrower cobbled sidewalks, with charm that Disney could neve recreate. This is one of the older parts of the city, largely spared by the 19th century earthquake, where one only walks, takes the 1920's era trams, or the distinctive Tut-Tuts, a variety of tiny motorized open air vehicles, seating two to four passengers, inspired by the motorized rickshaws of East Asia. Some highlights are the city's 12th Century cathedral, some of the best restaurants in the city, and magnificent vistas of the harbor.

The Arab memories alive. Want to fell when walking about narrow streets' and passages,the true experience of the Arab culture and is presence's in Portuguese culture,you must visit. And have only to experiment your walkabouts'... Everything will be handed to you

nice walk. Old part of Lisbon with narrow streets. Spirit of Lisbon is truly there. Beautiful houses, covered by azulejos make this place unique. Additional attraction are yellow trams. Take one to see how narrow the streets are and take your time to admire. You can easily spent there whole afternoon admiring views, taking pictures, climbing on stairs and visiting churches. If you are tired with stairs ask people for elevators as easily and quickly you can move around in that way.

Full party during Festival Lisbon. The place was packed during Festas De Lisboa. Didn't locate Fado music but did see some lovely churches and join into an amazing street party till 2 AM. Felt very safe.
Overcrowded. Went up by expensive tram first to avoid the jam packed local tram. Whole area very crowded but some very good views and buildings to look at.

Alfama!. Alfama was my favorite part of Lisbon. Its full of windy streets and hills. Wear good shoes though because its all up hill. There's tons great sites to sea and authentic food and traditional music.

Worth the walk!. Definitely recommend walking the hill, as you get some spectacular views doing so. The Alfama district itself is magical in a way. Very busy yet beautifully managed. I loved walking along the castle walls and looking out over the city. Take a water bottle as it is thirsty work!
Amazing experience!. The Alfama area of Lisbon is so interesting. In June it is decorated for the annualFestival of St Anthony. The Fado show we saw was wonderful - Casa Linhares.

Cool area of town.... Alfama is authentic Portuguese experience with narrow cobbled streets, lots of steps, washing hanging from windows, people grilling sardines on the street, lots of fado bars - every corner presents a new surprise.If you are in Lisbon, you simply have to visit this area!
a maze to discover. wandering around this neighborhood provides a surprise around every corner,quiet white washed alley ways to noisy local meeting places. all charming in their own ways
Best area in Lisbon. Make sure you catch the 28 tram and get off here, close to the castle and great views of the coast line

The place to be. This district of Lisbon is really the plcae where every small corner, street or placa, can offer you stg totally new and unexected, From old archtecture, to churches, locals on the streets, restaurants, attractions and som much more...feel the puls of Alfama by wondering on its streets.

Great Place To Explore & Get Lost. Great place to explore on foot. Lisbon's old town with lots small tiny streets with something new around every corner. We found a nice little bar and sat down for some Sangria. Located down the other side from the castle.
Cool neighborhood !. Lots to see here, some cool shops and interesting places. Take your time in this area. We walk a lot here.
Average. Went there after seing the castle and found the general area average at best. Nothing special to see. Spent 15 mins and called it quits
Very traditional. Narrow streets, traditional Portuguese houses. Azulejos ceramics on the outer surfaces are very impressive.
Alfama an interesting walk and place to wander.. Old walled city area with no cars. Tiny alley ways leading to surprises.We tried teh Cheery liquor in chocolate cups Gin.....

A must see when visiting Lisbon.. This is a lovely area of Lisbon. It has the port area where the cruise ships stay when in the city and I spent an interesting few hours with my camera in this very area. It's a real working area of Lisbon which always feels busy and is well worth visiting.

Careful of pick pockets around castle, tram 28, crowded buses. In two days, I was targeted four times! Lucky I was faster than them. These are gypsies, now they dress well, they speak English. Don't be fooled!

An amazing view combined with the old Lisbon. This district is exceptional beautiful. If you are looking for the original Lisbon I'm sure you can find it here. I wandered through the small streets and enjoyed being by myself. I avoided going into the castle but everyone who's interested will surely be satisfied. But the park around the S. Jorge is amazing. I spent several hours just sitting and writing.I would highly suggest not to stay at the tourist spots but go up the streets and get lost in the streets. I really enjoyed it and eventually got lost a little but it was definitely worth it.

Old part of the city. This is a very interesting part of the city. When we have been first time in Lisbon some 35 years ago, it was a sleepy, not too clean district, with some restaurants. Today it is full with life. If you take the Tram 28 to the top, you can walk down - churches squares, people - it si something you should do.

Get lost in the maze. Fabulous densley packed colourful streets, bars and restaurants. Fadou restaurants, churches, muesums or just kick back at a bar and watch the passing parade with a Vinho Verde and Bifana. Catch the Thursday Flea Market in the grounds and streets around the cathedral for extra colour and fun. Just Great.

Splendid neighborhood!. We rented an apartment in Alfama for two weeks, just a stone's throw from the Se Cathedral. We found hospitable restaurants with excellent food, places of historic interest, and very interesting shops, not to mention Tram 28, which brings folks up and down the historic hills.
Not for Seniors. Unless you are in very good shape and don't mind walking up and down hills you should experience this area using Tram 28 or Bus 37. Interesting, but not too terribly exciting.

A Good Place for People Watching - Go All the Way to the Top. The area is lined with make shift restaurants and as you walk through the winding streets you can get a nice feel for the culture. At the top there are nice views of Lisbon and the coast as well as their is a nice area that has concerts and a variety of food vendors. While the food smelled great, I was not a fan of the grilled sardines or verde soup.
Old City Feel. We stayed three nights in Alfama and loved the old city feel and the beautiful views. We found some great places to eat and enjoyed walking through the narrow streets.
We stayed in this neighborhood. It is very well situated, near the Bus 1 that goes to the airport, the plaza Rossio, and the water. There were many good restaurants nearby.

I almost don't want to tell people about it!. I feel like I found a gem and I don't want more people to know because in a few years it will become a very tourist-y place :) It is an amazing part of Lisbon - very scenic and picturesque, with old buildings and steep cobblestone streets. My husband and I stayed in Alfama last week and it was the greatest week in the whole year - preparations for the Santo Antonio day. It was so colourful and beautiful I cannot describe. People were very friendly and the food was simply AMAZING!!!I would buy a house there if I could...

Super area. A walk around this part of Lisbon is amazing. We were there the week before festival and the preparations we well under way. Loads of places to eat and drink. Lots of steps and narrow streets. A cool day is preferable. It was 32 degrees plus when we were there!!!A miss area to visit

Great place to stroll. It's my favorite place in Lisbon because it's very cozy to stroll along the streets up to the hill where you will have a fantastic and stunning view of Lisbon. What a nice place with narrow alleys everywhere nice little bars and restaurants artists and singer. This neighborhood is really lovely and traditional. Wear comfortable shoes the streets are really demanding. Would go back over and over.

Beautiful area, feels like the real Lisbon. We went over to the flea market on a Tuesday and spent a lovely afternoon wandering around this wonderful, authentic neighbourhood.Our favourite memories from Lisbon are from sitting in a park in Alfama watching life go by - the old men playing cards and bantering, the kids running about and the greenery full of birds and sunshine.We'll be back when we're next in town. A highly recommended place to while away an afternoon/evening in Lisbon.

Such atmosphere!. Alfama is so colorful! Narrow streets, endless stairs, mysterious passes... decorations everywhere honoring the patron Saint...barbecues to grill sardines mainly, but not just...smoky evenings, lots of laughter and songs...such resilience...I simply fell in love with this neighborhood and a few others (Mouraria, Chiado, Barrio Alto..)

Beautiful Alfama!. Alfama is the oldest district of Lisbon that has not been destroyed by the 1755 earthquake . The view from the top is great. It has many historical buildings that are older than the rest of the city. If you have time and are able to walk it is well worthwhile to explore it on foot. Some of the walk ways are quite steep. It does not take long till you reach the castle at the top. (less than an hour if you take it leisurely) A trolley is going up to the castle if you decide not to walk.
Must spend time in Alfama-Fado. This is a quaint section of Lisbon ready to go in the day or night. Hilly, lots of eateries and Fado as a special treat.
Birthplace of Lisbon. Great view, wonderful small restaurant recommended by hotel staff where locals go, be careful with pick pocketing, great during the day and night for people watching.
Get Lost!. Absolutely amazing, authentic neighborhood. It's a perfect place for a stroll without a destination. Great place for traditional Portuguese dinner
Great Place. Great restaurants and night life. Very up lifting area with bars, seafood restaurants and happy people both tourists and locals.

Alfama - the must see in June. This is for sure one of the most charming parts, Lisbon has to offer, small winding roads, through ancient houses, which whisper history at every corner. Places definitely to visit:Castelo de São ,Decorative Arts Museum, the Miradouro de Santa Luzia and azulejo greja da Graça, a religious site of majestic proportions. You enjoy eating ... dare to have a look at those restaurants: For lunches Pois Café does the trick with its light, healthy menu. For coffee and cake try Cruzes Credo. At Faz Figura, you can enjoy everything with a fantastic view, though at a higher price level. In case you're really in love with a panorama the Via Graça is your place.Otherwise - just stroll around, make a stop where it smells good - normally you want be disappointed.So why particularly June then ? It's party month in Alfama, the folks donors their holy personalities - everything is decorated and beautiful, music in all corners, sardines, beer and wine, when thinking of St. Antonio - more or less, at least. Otherwise the place as dedicated bars for great music. So Onda Jazz ,Clube de Fado and for local stuff A Baîuca should be high up on your agenda.If you stay there a couple of days, have also fun in the flea market and visiting the national Pantheon - you earn yourself a memory for lifetime, I promise !
Nice neighborhood. Nice place to go for a walk and look at how the locals live. There is steep streets, lots of stairs, so wear sensible shoes!

The throbbing heart of Lisbon!. We ate staying in Alfama for a few days. What a vibrant area of Lisbon. Last night was a festival of San Antonio. The festivities lasted until 5am. Exciting and so interesting to be amongst the many streets and walkways of the district. It was decorated and lit and there was music and good stslls everywhere. I am not a young person but I found it do enjoyable. Just the sheer joy of living was pulsating throughout the district. Instead of staying in a posh hotel, try living amongst the people of Lisbon. Stay in Alfama!!

Get lotst amongst all the little walkways. We walked the little streets and climbed the stairs and in the end we were very hungry and our noses followed the smell of some great food being cooked. We landed up in a restaurant where the locals have fish and we had a fantastic meal with the house wine. What a pleasant area with history and lovely tiles.

The place to see in Lisbon. From my point of view, this is the nicest place in Lisbon. Of course you can and should go up to the castle to have a nice view over Lisbon, but going up the hill from the riverside appears to be a-maze-ing. Small streets with, from time to time, really beautifully decorated tiny houses, with flowers and plants are simply rewarding you from the steep slopes you just walked. But the whole point of this walk is to get lost: the design of the street is oike a maze and this design dates back to the Maurs (who wanted plenty of small and complex streets so that their enemy is always in small number and not sure where to go). Well, this atmosphere is still living in this part of the city. So just get lost here: you'll find plenty of rewards on the way :)After all this walks, have a stop on your way back at Cruzes Credo (close to Se de Lisboa) to have a delicious chocolate cake.In the evening, te place is also very animated since you can find a lot of bars to have a drink, or also bars to listen to fado music.
Nice neighbourhood to stroll around!. Lovely small streets, beautiful houses...this is the old part of Lisbon that you should not miss! The streets are very streep, so bring your walking shoes.

Sweet and romantic . This area is very quaint, with lots of hills and it's an old part of Lisbon. It's highlighted by the castle of Sao Jorge. Very touristy but a sweet place. Lived amongst the locals
So romantic.... One of the most beautyful old town I have seen. Great atmosphere , little romantic streets amazing for evening walk . Great place to eat and to listen best Fado in town.

A look out point to targus river. You must stop at this breath taking location to look at building built on the hill that overlooking the targus river. There are lot tram going up this area. Dont worry if you are lucky you will get a seat Pleasr becareful of pickpicket in this area. They move in a goup of 4 peoples. Normally will hold scaft in their hand and cover your back. Dont carry valueable item to this area. You will enjoy you sight seing.

Gret tram ride, castle and wow those views. . .. High above the bustle of the central commercial old town is the Alfama - it's just great with an amazing tram ride up to the top (28 I think) and a slow nosey stroll back down the maze of alleys with shops and apartments so close you can smile at the people who live and work in them. Superb castle at the very top and for serious clubbers there is a place underneath the castle in the old Moorish dungeons (after 11pm if you can find it. . . . )

Much like any section of any old european city. Hilly, yes, a bit raw and gritty, but that's why Lisbon is different than other cities. The Alfama has so far escaped Disneyfication, people live in this neighborhood. The restaurants are little family run places that serve great food.

beautiful, historic area of Lisbon. Alfama is a very beautiful neighborhood in Lisbon. Very old, gorgeous buildings with original tiles, cobblestone streets, very hilly, beautiful views. Not to be missed, but wear comfortable shoes!
Get away from main Lisbon and wander. Full of small streets, easy to get lost but worthwhile, we dropped of the Miradour view point near to St Anthonys and down into area, search out

You can't miss out on this. The streets, old buildings and charm make this a spot to see while in Lisbon. Its wonderful to walk around and see what makes this truly unique. Alfama is so full of history. The winding streets, outdoor cafés and clothes hanging from the buildings Enjoy the view from the castle hill at sunset, for a truly memorable experience and amazing photos.

A fabulous experience in a beautiful area of Lisbon. What a place to visit. An absolutely beautiful part of lisbon. I highly recommend the Asquinha de baco bar.The hosts Sarah and Natasha are beautiful people with big hearts, they made our stay so pleasurable. The bar is excellent and the people were wonderful. We had two unbelievable nights there, the guitarists and singers were brilliant, but a special thanks to two wonderful sisters. Please visit this amazing bar and experience the hospitality it is heartwarming to say the least. Well done Sarah and Natasha. Babs and Wayne England xx

Start at the top and stroll down. The winding streets and old buildings from Moorish times transport you back in time. Can also take a tram through this area to the other side of Lisbon. It is very hilly! the cafes have limited hours and very few shops.

Must see in Lisbon. The old mauric part, aflame is a must see. Small roads, nice houses interesting people. If you are not good by foot the historic Tram 28E is a good option. Just sit in and enjoy your Lisbon tour. If you are planning to use 28E I would recommend to start in the morning (9:00 or 9:30) to ensure you get a window seat.

A different way of life. Emersion into Alfama for three days in a B&B under the Pantheon. Good food, long walks, a jitney tour and fado at night. We enjoyed ourselves and even hung our wash out on the balcony.
Interesting Area. Enjoyed eating and drinking with the locals and experiencing fado music. Probably best to be with a guide as could be a little intimidating.
interesting place to wonder around. Alfama is a nice and interesting place to wonder around, see how the locals live, browse the flea market, nice relaxing atmosphere.

Enjoy the History. The whole section of the city is so full of history. The winding streets, outdoor cafe and clothes hanging from the buildings - it is like walking back in time. Enjoy the view from the castle hill at sunset - beautiful photos.
interesting. Alfama appeals to all age groups. But I think the narrow, stone hilly streets may be a little rough for older folks, I suggests wear good comfortable shoes.

A fun walk thru narrow streets and alleys. Alfama has to be walked, I mean you can't drive down most of the alleys and streets. They are narrow and steeply pitched. They are also picturesque and a major reason to visit Lisbon. Take your time, enjoy the local shops and multitudes of cafes and restaurants along the way. Also; its great exercise climbing up and down the hills of Lisbon.

Old Lisbon - very authentic. One of the oldest parts of the city... not sanitized or touristy. There are a lot of tourists here, as it's on the way to the Castelo Sao Jorge, but this is a working class Lisbon neighborhood. It gives one a glimpse of how real people live, apart from the more touristy nightlife of the Baixo-Chiado

Fun place to wander around. We took the advice of our lonely planet guide book and decided to ditch the maps and just wander. We had so much fun just getting lost in the narrow lanesways and staircases just simply choosing one direction over the other because it looked interesting. Not to worry if you do this, there is always a good cafe, restaurant or trolley/bus around the next corner if you get tired or actually feel lost. Go find the cute Port shop just outside the entrance to the Castelo do Joao, they offer free samples, lots of knowledge and options for good Port.
The traditional fado area. This is the traditional fado area and where the quaint small alleyways intertwine up the hill. This is the place where the real lisbon people live.

Wonderful walk in Lisbons old quarter. I visited the Castelo S Jorges and spent nearly 2 delightful hours before I decided to wander back and forth down thru the wonderful very old Alfama neighborhood. I loved looking out over the colorful roofs towards the waterfront. This was an area that mostly survived the great Lisbon earthquake of 1755. There are the sounds of Fado off and on as you wander the maze like streets. You can really get a feel of old Lisbon here. I then found a small sidewalk cafe and had cold sangria in the sun. I eventually ended up at Lisbons huge Se Cathedral before continuing on down to the waterfront on a sunny, pleasant day. You owe it to yourself to visit here.

A Real Treat. This is the oldest district of Lisbon. There are many bars, cafes, restaurants and shops along the streets. Is is so pleasant to walk through the medieval streets and alleys and avoid the long lines for the attractions in this city. The houses are centuries old. The architecture is Moorish.

A charming view of "old" Lisbon. Narrow, winding, charming streets that survived the 1755 earthquake take you back to a different era and provide a wonderful look into the Portuguese people and culture

Get lost in Lisbon. This neighbourhood to me is the essence of Lisbon. Avoid the area around the Castle as it is busy with tourist and looses some of the Alfama characted.Forget your maps, to truly explore this area just walk. This is how you will discover the real 'soul' of one of Lisbon's oldest 'bairros'.

Endless rooftops of Alfama . The endless rooftops of Alfama are particularly amazing from the Miradouro de Santa Luzia. A great idea is to take the famous tram 28 downtown from there. Or visit the nearby Sé cathedral.
Awesome old town. One of the most aesthetically pleasing old towns I've come across. With the narrow winding roads and the natural foliage, it brings real character to the city.

Nice place. Me and my colleagues had dinner in this area in Lisbon. Nice to see that complicated architeture, with very small streets and old houses. I recommend Praca de Alfama, a traditional restaurante with Fado shows

Lovely part of Lisbon. Narrow streets with yellow trams and cosy restaurants and cafees. Pink, white and orange houses. Take your time to enjoy the view of the river and a Sangria on one of the cafees. The lines for the trams are long and crowdy - so we actually rather recommend taking one of the tuk-tuks instead :)
Small streets restaurants & cafes. A very charming neighborhood to walk in and explore, lots of lively cafes and restaurants and Fado places. Stay open late

Fabulous maze of an old town!. It's a wonderful place to explore and get lost in the daytime! So much history, view, architecture, photography, shopping and restaurants. The streetcars come through this area.
A Typical lisbon cachet. Alfama & O Bar are a must if you want to see the real old lisbon. Nice pubs & restaurants are there to enjoy the day or even the night. Cheers

Old City. Roaming round the streets of this old city felt like I was wandering in yesteryear. I loved the small touches that made it so authentic. Do yourself a favour and get lost within this magical little city so that you can discover some hidden treasures!
