Characteristic. We can't visit Lisbon without visiting ten birth place of Fado, one of the most characteristic song of Portugal. Even if you don't understand the lyrics, which are invariable about love, or the lack of it, you will enjoy the sound of ten guitar and viola.

Stunning!!!. Must visits and if climbing is an issue, try the three wheel cabbie or the classic tramp around. breath taking view of the port. Not easy if walking in large group. Architecture lover will appreciate the building around
The way I envisioned Lisbon. This is where the "real" OLD Lisbon lives. Lots of "fado" and character, not over priced. Great food and atmosphere !

Alfama; is it worth the visit?. I believe fado is an art form. However, not for the whole evening. Besides, if one does not speak Portugese half the interest is gone. I prefer watching it on YouTube with subtitles and leave whenever I want. Public transit with the antique trams is definitely charming. Well done Lisboa, keep it up. The neighbourhood itself feels like a small village on a hill. I was not overwhelmed but that is personal.

Historic But Dirty. This warren of alleys, stairways, maze like passages oozes history and ambiance but on a warm to hot day can be rank with the odor of urine and trash that sits throughout uncollected for days. By all means visit but perhaps choose accommodations elsewhere in captivating Lisbon. *HIGH LEVEL OF PICKPOCKET ACTIVITY AROUND MIRADOURO PORTAS DO SOL*

Charming little neighborhood. Charming little neighborhood, better taken care of than Bairro Alto for instance, not as loud or as full of tourists or those annoying drug dealers as the center or Bairro Alto, a lot of charming little cafes and restaurants which have live music (Fado being the specialty of the place)

Hilly, but great atmosphere. I stayed in Alfama while I was in Lisbon, and loved the place. It's quite hilly, and you will most definitely get lost even with a map, but by just wandering around this place, you will feel a particular ambience. It's got lots of restaurants, and famous tourist sights too. You might regret if you spend your days in Lisbon without visiting this area. But this place is not ideal for strollers, so if you aim to visit this place with a baby in a stroller, you will most definitely have some difficulties...

My favourite part of Lisbon. Love the area! Full of character and it's a must-do to spend a late afternoon getting lost in the area, but don't forget to head to one of its viewpoints at the 'magic hour' to see the stunning views of the Alfama rooftops.

Great place to wander. This in an area worth spending time wandering the narrow cobblestoned lanes, admiring the old buildings, enjoying a coffee, seeing the views from the upper streets and parks, stopping into old churches, doing a bit of shopping, eating a local meal. A great place to enjoy a leisurely day in Lisboa. Wear comfortable shoes for walking the uneven streets and bring water on a hot day.
So cozy streets!. This district is just amazing! It's streets and houses create unforgetable place that everyone should visit while being at Lisbon!

Characteristic, do not miss it. Walking around in Alfama's little streets is one thing to absolutely do in Lisbon. You can come here for dinner as well: you'll find a bunch of typical 'fado restaurant' where you will be able to assist to a fado performance. By walking around you'll be able to find lot of churches and spot with amazing sight over baixa and plaça do commerco.
Would totally live here!. Loved this neighbourhood. Lots of steep streets, but the houses, churches and shops are worth the exercise! The view from the top is worth the walking around. Loved it!

Favourite area of Lisbon!. Alfama is magical with its narrow lanes and different colour buildings. Every street has something new to offer. Get lost in its streets and look around you. There is unexpected art on the walls and in the streets including hanging balm trees, colourful tiles, all sorts of graffiti and much more. Take your camera and spend few hours just wondering around.

Alfama=Lisbon. You can't NOT love Alfama. Its colours, the mixture of new and old, local and european, modesty and tourist-friendliness. You can easily get lost in Alfama, only to find yourself again in an even more beautiful avenue.

What an amazing place. We did the walking tour of the Alfama from the Fado Musuem to the Castelo de Sao Jorge. The narrow streets winding through this neighborhood take one back several centuries. Additionally, the views toward the River Tejo as you walk up the hill are breathtaking. Once you arrive at the Castelo, you are awestruck by the massive structure as well as the realization ofmhow intensive the labor was for that period of time. It was definitely worth the climb.

A must go!. The oldest district of Lisbon (from the Arabic Al-hamma, meaning "hot fountains") is a great place to go around, enjoying the atmosphere, the white houses, taking pictures, tasting the liquor called "ginginha" or a shot of "vinho do Porto" (Oporto wine). Take the opportunity to visit the S.Jorge castle, close by!
Must see!. You have to reach it with the "Electrico" tram n. 28, Alfama is one of most characteristic place of Lisboa, with its Tascas (cheap meals) and Fado singers... for dinner is the best
Charming place!. It's very nice to walk around and enjoy the feeling in alfama.If you're in shape my recommend is to walk up the hill, if not- go up by tram and walk down after.

Beautiful old town, don't get lost! . We had the pleasure to have our apartment in this wonderful side of the city. Alfama looks like a maze, so it's easy to get lost. However the polite residents will show you the way back. In this area there are alot of restaurants and bars with the typical Fado-singers, this is something you should experience. I would def recommend this side of town!

Best part of Lisbon. We came part of the way through the old town with a guide.we did not get lost in the twisting alleyways. People cooking in the street, children playing, washing hanging everywhere. Climbing to the viewpoint outside the church. Descend via the tramlines. Best part of Lisbon, the real life.
Great View！. Go all the way up to the hill then you can see the entire old town~ there are three points of interests. The highest point is the castle.

A perfect place to be based. The cobbled streets, winding passages,churches, tram 28, cafes & restaurants - Graca, Rossio, Baixa & Barrio Alta within walking distances. It's a bit hilly so wear sensible shoes. Just loved it there, and we stayed for a full week.

Authentic and beautiful. Walk around and discover the beauty of Lisboa. Get to the flea market and enjoy the Lisboa pace. The only way to discover the part of Lisboa is to get lost and discover every conner of this neigborghood. Walk during the day, but also discover this part by night.

A surprise around each corner. A place that is so typical of Portugal,especially Lisbon.you have so many narrow streets,turns and twists you might get lost.There is always a little cafe,restaurant or tabernacle nearby to stop and take stock.Duck your head under hanging washing and greet the people leaning on the windowsills.
Dilapidated, honest. You could get lost for hours in the narrow alleys and stairways of Alfama. Do just that. Tremendous atmosphere. Don't choose the first restaurant you run across.

Alfama a magic place !!. Alfama is one of the most interesting neighborhoods in Lisbon. It maintains its old age atmosphere with a mixture of history and tradition.
One can get easily lost in the maze that constitute its streets, but the friendliness of its inhabitants will make you feel at ease.
The Fado. It was an beautifull evening filled with a lot of music, fado, when you walk around in this part of Lisboa, it seems that every restaurant has its own Fado musicians, Fantastic!!

Nice neihborhood. The old neighborhood of Lisbon. Very narrow streets and very steep hills...bring good shoes....or take a cab to the Castello San Jorge and walk downhill from there! Touristy restaurants and shops, but overall a nice historic neighborhood.

Try the tuk-tuk tours. We took a tuk-tuk tour around the area starting at the cathedral. It was a great way to get around this hilly area after a big Easter lunch and with a tired 10-year-old in tow. The driver was very knowledgeable and took us through some great narrow streets.
Great neighborhood to wander!. Lots of hills and little restaurants! The place is really cute and has lovely architecture. We took a taxi to the castle and then walked down ...easier on the thighs!

Gorgeous, but a tiring.. This is the beautiful old part of Lisbon, lots of alleyways and quaint hidden spaces. Lots of delightful places to eat and really soak up the history of the area. You need sensible shoes for all the walking, forget style and go for comfort.

Worth the time to explore. We stayed in the heart of Alfama and what a wonderful place it is. I do recommend taking the number 28 team around; just to see the town.
The people are very friendly and the food is all reasonably priced.
Will definitely visit again!

Stunning.. Wonderful province of Lisbon. Become lost and indulge in the historical content that Alfama has to offer. Aesthetically pleasing on the eye, friendly locals, spacious and great local cuisines. Enjoy.

Take the tram and meander. The old district. Interesting to wander around and see what appears round the corner. Take the 28 tram and hop and off as you please. Tram just fits down one street! Dont forget to buy Viva Viagem (50 cents) plus 6 euros per day unlimited travel on trams, buses, elevators and metro.

To get into. This is the best place to see local people and feel the real Portugal. If you go deeper to district, you can see everyday life,you can try to talk to local and let them made you buy a shot of cherry liquor:) It's nice to go to one of cafes where they have Fado music and just enjoy it without lots of tourists around

I don't get it.... Apparently at the end of tram 28, if you survive the pickpockets, there is something worth seeing. Down where the faro singers are it is just scary. But I will go anywhere with coffee and pastel De nata, so here I am. Love the place we are staying but that will be a different review. I'm so off put by the homeless people directing you to free parking then asking for money. They don't make sure you aren't towed or anything. ****public parking seems to be right on the water and costs 8€ per day max. Saw tow trucks pulling tourist cars out 3 at a time this morning. Just because a boat jumper from Libya points you to a spot and asks for 2 € doesn't mean your car will be there later. Made me super uncomfortable and I hate it here now. Reminds me of Vancouver, overrun with people that make me uncomfortable.

Gives you a sense of old Lisbon. With it's narrow cobbled streets and tall houses this area gives a good impression about Lisbon before the big earthquake. Just make your way through the streets, admire the laundry and songbirds in cages hanging from the windowsills.Of course you can take thefamous tram up the hill first and walk down...

THE place to stay. We had been recommended Alfama as a wonderful area and so booked an apartment there. It was fabulous. No map really helps you get around, but it doesn't matter as you always manage to navigate the maze eventually. You definitely need to be quite fit to manage all the ups and downs and we felt sure it would need weeks to get to grasps with all the various steps and little alleys. A really delightful area to stay in and explore.

Love These Narrow Streets!. If you are able to walk a great deal, stolling this area, up and down hill, is a great way to get the flavor of Lisbon. We had a guide for part of the visit, but you can do this on your own and at your own speed. Not to be missed if you are in Lisbon.
great walk. walk and discover medieval streets and cool little cafes...also see the Castelo S. Jorge and Se Cathedral

Great atmosphere. I was glad to see developers did not tear down this neighborhood for new condos or business offices. I last visited in 1990 and it still looks similar. Yes, there is a fresh coat of paint and more tourist shops and restaurants, but it still has a magical atmosphere. The steep, narrow winding streets, whitewash buildings, hidden squares and old World churches. Spend half a day getting lost and you will discover something special.

The most attractive view of the city. You must get lost in alfama area , this is the best way to actually see the best view of the city center. the buildings look amazing, and there are too many beautifull shops and small restaurants which they're hiding among the narrow roads.

Best Area in Lisbon. We stayed here for our 5 nights in Lisbon and loved it! Totally authentic taste of Portugese life! Loved the small winding streets and the opportunity to get lost easily. Beautiful!

Walked it for Wow images . We walked up through the area absorbing the images of the passing trams, the churches, the people plus little shops and cafes. Little detours to the sides give you opportunities to look down into the city and see the cruise liners. If you've walked up though you'll have absorbed more of this area than those on a whistle stop tour from one of those ships. Were our achey feet worth it. Definitely

Vibrant and Interesting!. We ventured into Alfama on a Sandemans walking tour as our time in Lisbon was short and we had a pretty good experience with their guide (Cuco) on their free tour.Must say Alfama was a delight, the street, people and little nooks make the place! We were given the opportunity to try the Alfama variety of Portugese tarts and also some Ginjinha from a lady who sells it from her living room.I personally wouldn't bother paying the money for the castle itself, you can get just a good a views from multiple vantage points around Alfama for free.
Great supper. Lots of lovely authentic restaurants with superb food. The owner gave us a menu but said "what do you fancy" and seemed prepared to cooke us anything we wanted.

Purest Lisbon. This is one of the best areas of Lisbon! Here you can breath with the lungs of this city, between all the small streets, stairs and the arquitectural configuration of the the houses around the castle. You find people that was born and lived all their lifes around that area. Wait for the month of June because this month is the one that brings more life to Alfama with all the traditional religious festivities, music, food and drink in the heart of Lisbon!

A lovely place to wander. I spent the afternoon wandering around Amalfa and loved it. Quaint narrow little streets at every turn and lovely little shops and bars. Great views out across Lisbon and beyond.Fabulous.

Bustling and fun neighborhood. We did the walking tour of Alfama outlined in Rick Steve's book on Portugal. It was fun and interesting with many gorgeous views of the city and the ocean. Lots of interesting little shops, good restaurants, winding and hilly streets that lead up to the Sao Jorge Castle. We took a cab up to the castle and meandered down through the neighborhood taking photos and appreciating the views. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes.

Neighborhood with character . We took a walking tour with Yuri and saw all the sights. Yuri is very proud and passionate about Portugal and showed us A Baiuca which was a great place to hear real Fado. We spent an amazing evening there. Yuri works for new Lisbon which has a free morning tour and an afternoon tour of Alfama. Make sure to do this tour
Fun enjoyable. Worth a visit. Interesting. Narrow alleys. Watch out for the trolleys as the street could be very narrow.

Enjoyable place to stroll. We enjoyed strolling the small streets and looking at the small shops and their clients. It is convenient to reach by foot from the center of town and not far from the Rossio train station. We also strolled on the other side of the station and found that neighborhood equally pleasant. Be aware that Lisbon is a hilly city so take that into account should you decide to stroll.
Just get lost. Tiny windy and hilly streets, cute shops, laundry hanging outside, and cats roaming around. Just delightful.

Plenty of miradouros. A good way to spend your day or afternoon without a real plan is to take the Electrico 28 to the top of Alfama and then just walk around from Miradouro to Miradouro and slowly go down to lower Alfama, taking a drink here and there, eat some fresh fish in one of the hidden corners, ... Really enjoyed that!
Wonderful area to stroll. `older neighborhood with lots of character, restaurants, bars and people watching. We went on a Sunday afternoon and it was full of people having a good time

Great atmosphere. It goes without saying that a walk around this area, past the churches to the castle and back down again to the cheap restaurants along the streets from the train station is highly recommended.
The street market at the weekend is still atmospheric but not as cheap and edgy as it used to be.

Lovely old area. We toured Alfama the lazy way, in the back of a Lisbon tuk-tuk for 60 minutes.Our driver was informative and an excellent guide - good English, friendly and eager to please. He took us through the area explaining features and ensured we got to see the major viewpoints and attractions in Alfama.The cost for 60 minutes in the tuk-tuk was Euro 45, which was reasonable value we thought.

Surprise - village in a city. I visited Alfama with our guide and this city part was a really pleasant surprise for me. I didn't know it was possible to have a village in the heart of a big city. People really still live there on the streets, there were orange trees with oranges fallen on the ground - and no one cleaned them. There were wandering dogs and no one cared, because they probably belong to someone everyone knows. I do recommend visiting, just go for a walk there without a goal to see a church or some house. Just breathe in the atmosphere.
Nice to walk through. Good view of the city,romantic walk or by the tram to the Fort,where you can have medieval dinner..You feel like set back some hundred years.

A lovely spot in the city. Super cute little neighborhood that is totally worth a visit! There are a ton of streets to get lost in, and cute stores and everything as well. A bit off the beaten path, but it's a nice refreshing place to see, and it's not a touristy too. You can really get a feel of what it is like to live in Lisbon here, where you can see people out talking and hanging laundry and it's very nice.

A trip to Lisbon is incomplete without visiting Alfama. Simply walk around and explore the narrow, winding cobblestone streets and walkways or take a tram to the top of the hill and work your way downward. Enjoy the cool breezes and the scent of the orange tree blossoms and take your time walking around, then stop by a cafe and gelateria for some refreshments. Many vistas to stop and take in the view or take some photos. Many cafes and neighborhood restaurants.
Very touristy. Not surprising really, but in contrast to Chiado and the Bairro Alta districts we found Alfama to be rather run down, touristy and tacky ... and too crowded even in April.

Must visit!. Narrow cobblestone streets and pathways, quaint old houses and shops, calf-torturing slopes and stairs, amazing views, fado......that's Alfama for you. If possible, stay within Alfama and it will be a delightful experience.

Mandatory to go!. Alfama is a very pure/original neighborhood in Lisbon that represents the best representation of what the city looked like before the earthquake of 1755. The narrow streets and the local inhabitants traditions are impossible to skip if you visit Lisbon! Have fun!

Gorgeous old town and views. You can get the tram up to Alfama or it is a nice stroll and not too strenuous. When you arrive at the top the views are beautiful. There are plenty of cafes and bars. The castle is there and church. It is a very nice part of town and lovely to visit for an afternoon.

Glad I Went. This is the cutest and coolest part of town: winding streets, hidden alleyways, castles, cheap eateries, and awesome trollies. Take trolley 12E from Rossio for a 30 minute round trip, then take it again and get off where you are so inclined. Make sure that you buy a 24 hour transport pass for 6 E 'cause the trollies cost 3.75 E. The very crowded 28 trolly also goes through Alfama-best to catch it in Alfama itself rather than down in the "flatlands." The best view (maybe second best after trolley 2 ride) in the city is at the top of the hill on trolley 12. Great experience.

Beautiful area of Lisbon. We stayed in this area and had a wonderful time. It is not far from the centre and makes most things in walking distance! This area is hilly and as you walk up you can get some beautiful views, its just stunning! There are lots of old cobbled streets and quaint shops that can keep you occupied just wandering around, or just sit in the sun with a wine or coffee (from one of the little kiosks) and appreciate your surroundings! :-)

The older district of Lisbon. This area is steeped in history which appears to have missed the 1755 Lisbon Earthquake with a labyrinth of narrow cobbled streets ( wear flat shoes!). Very easy to get lost among them so take a map or look out for little landmarks. It's a very quaint area with a lot of regeneration going on of older buildings. On the plus side; lots of atmosphere and history. Go down the little side streets and give the small family owned bars and restaurants your business. The only place we felt ripped off was in the main touristy areaDownside; quite dirty with rubbish left out and lots of graffiti. Also beware of the tut tuts flying about with tourists hanging on for dear life!
Beautiful. Would definitely recommend visiting Alfama. Lots to see and do! Make sure you pack your walking shoes as you will need them.

This is the best part of Lisbon. We stayed in Memmo Alfama hotel in the midst of Alfama. Truly a good part of Lisbon. All kinds of little shops, restaurants and old architectures. You can walk, but it is often up and down. Good for working a appetite though...;-)
Definitely should be visited. A very nice district of the city with many nice city view points. Traditional trams are crossing its streets making even more nicer.

What a relaxed and relaxing neighbourhood. A maze of little streets with dozens of restaurants, pastillerias and artistic shops! Away from the commercial shops and very centrally located is the neighbourhood Alfama. We stayed in an apartment here and could hear till late night locals being carried away by fado music:-)

Bit of a Hit or Miss. It's a place to get lost in and wander around, just find places you like by bumping into them. There is a lot of up and a lot of climbing, we worked out that as long as we kept going up we would end up at the castle. If you're not fit at the start you will be by the end of your visit.I feel a bit guilty by giving it an average review but I think a very good would be inaccurate. it's above average but not very good. You can wander around and just find steps and narrow lanes and if you hit the right flight of steps you might find exactly what you're looking for.We stayed near the Se for 5 nights and found some great wee restaurants within a couple of minutes of our apartment, by no way gourmet but they did exactly what we wanted, good honest food with wine for €13 each.
Great View. Spend some time here...from the top its a great view...nice old town area....although lot of walking but worth it....sit enjoy a cup of coffee...relax...
Great Hike. Lovely area of Lisbon - very steep hike bit worth it. A labyrinth of cafes, restaurants & churches. Very busy with tourists - avoid tram 28, tends to pack em in.
traditional neighbourhood. Beautiful neighbourhood on the hill, be prepared for many steps! there are plenty of restaurants and it's THE place for FADO concerts!

Amusing journey . I went to visit with my friend on April 23. When we reached the area we had the chance either to take the funicular or choose a personal guide with his tuck-tuck taking us for a tour around the area. The funiculars were very busy so we chose the tuck-tuck. It is an ancient city with a great charm, clean lovely to walk in and holds a great history. Small pedestrian corners, charming restaurants and wonderful sceneries. The tuck-tuck was the perfect choice since we had a very nice guide who took extra time to explain to us all the stories to cover all the places around. Lucky us the weather was perfect and sunny..

Best way to discover Alafama take tram #28. Went 2 days in a row, best way is by tram #28 going up & downhill, enjoy these rides in the narrow streets. Great sea view too by sunset and on time for a dinner nearby

Great area of town to walk around. I took the Sandemans walking tour of the are lead by Francisco and it was real nice. It is a really nice area to just walk around and see the culture and life. Take time to look up and down and around and enjoy it all around. If possible also peak into the windows, overall a really charming area of town.

Cute old part of the city. The place way to see this part of the city will be through a walking tour. They have a flea market on few days. I would recommend visiting it on those days. Its much more lively. We roamed around after the tour and had some local lunch. This area is famous for fado bars and you can come back in the evening for those.We rode back the legendary tram 24 back to the center. The ride goes through the narrow alleyways. This area has pickpocketing incidents, so travelers should just careful about that. There's no mugging as far as I know, just be careful of your wallet.
Lovely. Lovely neighbourhood...winding streets with gorgeous architecture everywhere...fabulous viewing area views of the harbour...great little restaurants and some very nice specialist shops

Picturesque but safe. The historic district seems to be divided into three neighborhoods, and Alfama is one of them. I had a lot of fun wandering around in its narrow, geometrically-challenged alleyways for all of one morning and part of an afternoon, getting lost but without ever feeling in a panic. Lisbon is not so overrun by tourists as some other major European cities (yet!), so the occasional foreigner walking around in a daze is still invites benign tolerance and even generous assistance.

Fado evening. Yup, attended a dinner with Fado music. It was an interesting and well worth it. The music is beautiful even if I didn't understand a word. The food at our restaurant was amazing. Really a lovely late evening out.
Amazing views. This neighborhood is so fun to walk around -- very quaint, small streets, colorful houses...and the views were spectacular!

Take a tram up to this hilltop neighbourhood. Run down but atmospheric district with washing hanging out on balconies and houses painted pastel shades on cobbled narrow streets. This is the fado area, where music lovers come to listen to the national music in bars and clubs, but there are also great views of the water from up here and many old churches.

Alfema stret. Cool and ancient street, there is not much to do there but go in the narrow streets ... The shops are expensive and offer souvenir... Good place to see the history of lisbon... 2 hours will be more than you need

Old Lisbon, quaint little shops and nostalgic atmosphere. This is a great place to shop for souvenirs, especially one-off handmade ceramics from individual artisans. The area stretches from Santa Apolonia train station to the Sao Jorge castle at the top. It is a very steep climb and everytime we visit, we opted for the minibus (575) or one of the trams to get to the castle, and then take a slow walk down. There is a viewing point at the bottom end of Alfama, where one can take time to appreciate the lovely view. There are plenty of coffee shops for drinks and ice-cream and the facilities. A must visit area in Lisbon.

Piece of real Portugal. I can't find words describing beauty and charm of this place. Safe and quiet by night and by day. Unforgettable walls colour, dramatic fado's melody everywhere. The best place for romantic trip in Europe!
Great place to walk arround. Great place to wander around the narrow streets and have a drink or a meal in the many cafes. Often you will see Tuk tuks full of people if you have trouble walking

Charming and historic. Colorful, narrow little streets. It gives you a real feel for the old historic center of Lisbon. Take a walk through these narrow winding streets enjoy the sights, sounds and smells. It feels like it could be 500 years ago.

Old Lisbon. The Alfama district is on the East side of the city and best approached from the riverside, it's the only neighbourhood that survived the earth quake. It's full of steep narrow, winding streets with kids playing outside and mothers talking. You can get a tram through the Alfama but your better walking to get some great photographs.
exotic. For those only who do not suffer from claustrophobia cause of the narrow streets. A romantic location with uncountable little restaurants where Fado shows can be visited every night.
Very nice place. Alfama is a very nice place, we got lost in the streets and saw alot of amazing houses collection shops and the local life in there, I loved every minute of my time in Lisbon.

perfection. i got to live in Alfama for a month in Nov/Dec of 2014. My husband and I rented an Airbnb here, right smack in the middle, and literally loved every second. The Fado wafting down the alleys at night, the food and drink, just wandering and getting lost, have to actually need to take a tram home (not just for the experience but because it actually brought us home!), the views from the top and the short walk into the city. Just to name a few. Such a great part of lisbon, would move here forever if we could.

Perfect contrast to Baix and Chiado. We wandered through Biaxa, Chiado, Rossio this afternoon, and ended up in Alfama. What a contrast. We saw kids walking the narrow steep streets after school, people hangiing laundry, men playing cards... It felt like normal life going on around us...a stark contrast to the Starbucks and high end shops we'd just seen. We choose a fado restaurant for dinner, and left early (about 8:30) to prepare for departure tomorrow...and had another stark contrast. Now the streets were full of tourists looking for dinner and fado singing. We noted that the entire restaurant where we ate was full of tourists...the first time that happened to us this week.This district is definitely worth a visit... Go when you have time to enjoy getting lost. (And leave your flip flops at home!)

A taste of old Lisbon. A must see attraction - an area with charm, personality and life of days gone by. Heaps of Gingha stores, taverns, Fado performances. Take your camera to capture street life happening in tine steep alley ways, apartments with washing hanging out, cobbled streets, gloriously graffiti walls. A tram ride through Alfama is not to be missed - you'll marvel at the way the drivers can navigate through the tiniest spaces and up and down steep hills and steep bends. A real highlight of Lisbon
have a cup of tea. Tiles are amazing, tea houses splendiforous, beware trams as streets so narrow, lovely views in land time forgot
very nice neighborhood. this neighborhood is the only one that survive the earthquake, so is full of history and old buildings. If you go there dont miss taking the tram 28

Good neighborhood to see. It is essential to be in Alfama, when in Lisbon. It clearly shows how they use to be centuries ago, and how they evolved in the coming years. Having said that, it is also worth the visit both in day time as well as at night, (weekends) the place is full of bars and Fado clubs visited by locals as well as tourists, the view during day time is fascinating.
Magical place. The Alfama is Lisbon. It is the hearyt and soul of this vibrant city. Take a tram up the hill and wander around the narrow streets, grab a drink or snack and admire the views.
Lovely Stroll. Got the Tram up to the Castle then walked down through the streets of Alfama browsing in shops and stopping for drinks. A pleasant morning.

Great area to explore and marvel. It is one neighbourhood that survived the major earthquake.Bulit on a hill below the Castle, it includes old houses, business and churches. We attended Easter Service at the Se Cathedral in Alfama. The streets are winding and narrow and the traffic and crowds on that Sunday were plentiful. Wonderful views from various spots. Would have liked to spent more time poking around the various streets

Fascinating labyrinth of narrow streets, small shops and bars. Great for strolling and finding seemingly hidden specialist shops and small bars and eateries in a matrix of narrow, winding streets that run up to the Miradour da Graca.

Fabulous. go get lost.. If you know where you are going, you can get to Alfama in minutes from the Commercial square. First take the walking tour from Chill-Out, ask for Raphael. Then you will know all the tricks about Alfama! Marvelous!
Nothing special. Old, specific part of town, but nothing special... Worth seeing, but only if you have plenty of time

Heart of the old town of Lisbon. Amazing walk through the old Lisbon. Narrow windy cobbled-stone streets, old houses where people looking out of windows can literally be touched, old shops and cafés! You should do a tram ride through this part of town on Tram 28!

a lovely slice of Lisbon. We stayed in Alfama, mainly to be near Fado singers, and weren't disappointed. The winding streets were full of small bars and restaurants with local fado singers. Not just the tourist places, but small family bars and cafes...it was great. The neighborhood felt safe, as we were walking late at night many nights, and the hustle and bustle of early mornings with shopkeepers, grocers, etc was so nice to see. We went to all the other neighborhoods, but Alfama is by far our favorite. You can't beat the views, and there were many many small pocket parks with seating all along the streets. Breathtaking scenery, lovely people....we're going back next year!

Loved the Alfama. We stayed here for a week n March. We found it to be a great place to explore on it's own with many little squares full of markets, cafes and restaurants. It also has many sights like the castle, Fado Museum and Beautiful Churches. Staying here also made it easy to get to the downtown area of Lisbon easily. I would definitely stay here again!

Luxury liners stop here. We took the famous yellow 28 tram which stopped there and were very impressed by what we saw. There was an ocean liner 'parked' nearby and we met two Brits who were off the ship passing the time in a nice little restaurant but can't remember the name! We also saw a local painter with a large display of oil paintings to sell, each one only costing EU8 or less. They were lovely so I bought two. If you walk further up the hill there are a few more painters at work. It's a very picturesque area and we noticed a nice restaurant situated down to the left of us near the river. We went back twice on the 28 tram as it was so pleasant.

Spectacular views in a lovely place. Alfama is a beautiful, relaxing place to wander around and take in the lovely view of the Tagus River from several different vantage points. There are restaurants, pastry shops, souvenir shops, and convenience stores everywhere here. The streets are narrow and the pavement is very uneven, and the hills are a bit steep in places, so this is not the best destination for anyone who has difficulty with mobility. Those who are able to walk without difficulty should wear comfortable, sturdy shoes. I work out every day, but still get winded walking up some of these steeper hills, and there are many times I've lost my balance on an uneven pavement. (I do have mild asthma.) That being said, it is well worth the effort, especially if you take your time and stop in several places to browse around. The sense of history here is inspiring.

Living history book!. Visiting Alfama is to visit the small streets alone there are houses of blue, red, green, yellow, all with wrought iron balconies, rooftops, church towers, viewpoints, the sounds and the smells of old Lisbon.

Charming. I took a walking tour of this charming neighborhood (Lisbon Walkers), which really helped me understand what I was seeing (and find my way through the mosaic of houses). Its winding (and climbing!) cobblestone streets can be challenging for us older adults, so give yourself enough time to wander leisurely. Highly recommended for any visitor to Lisbon.

Traditional Lisbon. Alfama is the home of the Fado music and you can find it live in many bars and restaurants throughout the Alfama area. You'll walk through lots of very narrow windy streets and walk ways and end up discovering things you wouldn't realise are there, which is why this area is so charming.Alfama is really beautiful and traditional with a lovely local feel to it.

Scenic and picturesque views, but a word of caution for families with young children... too hilly!. We walked down to Alfama from the Thieves Market on Saturday morning, and while the views and setting were picturesque, it was a little bit difficult with young children, as there are lots of stairs. I have given Alfama five stars, as we really enjoyed it, but those with young children (eg. prams), need to be prepared for the hills and stairs....

Real Lisbon. Very interesting, just wander, savour the atmosphere and enjoy. It is hilly so don't wear heels. Listen to the birds signing, look up at the tall buildings with washing hanging down, look out for the communial baths , enjoy seeing how real Lisbon

Old Lisbon. This is one of my favourite places in Lisbon, dining is guaranteed good food for very little money. Fado is all around and well recommended. The parties in Alfama are in June and it is an amazing place to be. Sardines, plenty of wine and dancing.Alfama has streets so narrow two people would struggle to pass, but it does give the true essence of Lisbon.

An afternoon in Alfama. We arrived by tram for a late lunch on a terrace with a beautiful view over the river. The area is full of narrow hilly streets lined with houses and small bars and shops. It's a good place to go to see the real Portugal.

A home of the Fado.... Alfama is the oldest district in Lisbon, located on the slope of Sao Jorge Castle and Tejo river. The great Lisbon earthquake did not destroyed Alfama which is still a labyrinth of narrow streets and small squares. In the last century most of the old houses have been renovated to became small apartments for rent to visitors. Alfama is well known for many restaurants and bars featuring "Fado" the Portuguese melancholy music performed nightly.

Quaint streets. Walked around alfama after visiting the castle and cathedral. Lovely little streets and great places to stop for coffee or beer. The fado museum is here and lots of the restaurants' offer live fado in the evenings.Would have liked to have gone back on a night if we had had time. Will do next time.
Great traditional nighborhood!. Lovely area of town, very traditional and full of interesting places to eat and drink!Do wear comfortable shoes, and be ready to explore.

One of the oldest barrios of Lisbonne. This is one of the oldest barrios of the city.Plenty of authentic fado restaurants here, but it is also the site of the National Pantheon, the Sé Cathedral, the San Jorge Castle and many more attractive places.Be in shape though, because on foot there are lots of hills to climb.If not, hop on and off of the many trams crossing the area.
Authentic. Fairly pleasant walk noy yet taintes by tourist aggressiveness. The restaurants and cafes are not particularly attractive
True old town. very quaint with many nice hidden places. A true resemblance of what the old town of Lisbon was like. Friendly locals with few hidden gems of bars and restaurants

We love the Alfama!. We rented an apartment for a week in the Alfama, and it was wonderful to wander up and down the stairways, and along the winding hilly roads and discover new places and new flavors! We felt we were just getting to know "our neighborhood" when we had to leave for home. We will be back!

Beautiful place, people, lots to enjoy.. Alfama is a beautiful neighbourhood with lots of small shops, cafe, restaurants to visit. Endless small cobblestone streets give you the authentic Lisboa post card experience. Spend time wandering and stopping in wherever you can. People are always accommodating.

Love this area. This is the part of Lisboa that you need to visit. The charming little streets are incredible. Wear good walking shoes and be prepared to get lost in the past! Area is very hilly and lot's of uneven/narrow walk ways (cobblestone).TIP: if you get disorientated, look for the water as a reference point or look on the ground for the tram tracks to lead you to the next stop!
Beautiful neighborhood.. The architecture, the people, the atmosphere - you can feel the arabic influence in Alfama. Next time I stop by, I'll get my accomodation here.

The real Lisbon. Small winding streets, real life taking place within them, lovely shops, a beautiful cathedral, very safe, crazy hot in the summer and annoyingly full of tourists in Tuk-Tuks. Certainly worth a walk in this area to get the feel of old Lisbon. Been several times, once on a segway, always a pleasure. Make the effort to visit and take advantage of one of the many bars and restaurants serving great local food.
Do Go. In Lisbon and most of Portugal you need shoes with thick non-slip soles. The streets are uneven and slippery. Wear the right shoes and walk the area entire. Gorgeous.

beautiful views and great restaurants. we lived this area and really enjoyed the tram rides around it. We ate in lovely restaurants and enjoyed the views from the bars. We visited the flea market on Saturday, which was really interesting. Great location that needs to be explored. Highly recommend.

For me the most beautiful part of Lisboa. The oldest part of Lisboa with the Cathedral Sé de Lisboa, Tram 28, the views at Miradouro de Santa Luzia and the Castle de São Jorge. I just love it to stroll a day in this area, visit some noce shops, enjoy Fado music that has its roots here and enjoy one or two of the many restaurants.

Lisbon before the earthquake!. the winding streets of this relic of old Lisbon are a stark contrast with the 'new' city and give a feel for the past. the home of fado we had trouble picking a restaurant to hear some of the local singers. prices vary widely, but check what you are paying for - some look less expensive but the extras can add up.
good area. plenty to do with castle st george and monastery loads shops viewing platform looking over city amazing views shots here ,plenty restaurents and shops to get a juice or snack

Charming bohemian streets. Beautiful narrow little streets, ending up on small squares with benches for rest and lots of flowers everywhere around. Old buildings, remarkable architecture. You can see some really old Portuguese houses with amazing wooden doors in blue and green colors, cats sitting on windows. Scenes from old black and white movies. Absolutely charming! When you get tired, sit in a local cafe or restaurant garden and enjoy - food and drinks, the view.
A bohemian treat. It has quaint, but steep narrow street leading up to the castle and is lined with quirky buildings and history. If you don't mind climbing, GO!

Wonderful Historic district. Alfama is a very old section of Lisbon on it's highest hill. Its full of narrow cobble stone streets and lovely little restaurants with beautiful tiles decorating so many park walls. It has many churches and quaint little parks. You do have to be in shape and prepared to walk up and down hills and steps. We had a delightful tour with Eco Tours in something of a motorized golf cart but our tour guide was delightful and our hotel had arranged it. This is such a fun part of the city I would definitely recommend anyone interested in the history and culture and its people to not miss. We fell in love with Lisbon in Alfama.
Excellent Views. Great historic part of town with beautiful views overlooking the Tagus. Definitely worth the climb to see. There are also some great places to eat up here as well.

Great place to hang out. This is a really interesting area of Lisbon. This is where most of the real fado shows take place so you'll probably come over there for that. There are also lots of great little restaurants/bars as well. It feels much older and authentic than other areas of the city

A must do in Lisbon!. Visiting Alfama should be very high up on your to do list when visiting Lisbon. The picturesque views, charisma and all the colourful beautiful buildings are a must see! I visited Alfama on a tour run by a New Sandemans Lisbon tour guide, it lasts 3 hours and is £12 - it is definitely worth the money, very relaxed and enjoyable!

Startling. Alfama is the oldest district of Lisbon and it's genuinely amazing. The streets are really narrow filled with beautiful old buildings which are perfectly habitable. You can hear the pleasant sounds of Fado following you around the corners. On the top there is a yet another amazing view waiting to astonish you!

Amazing evening. We venture though the streets of Alfama both during the day and at night. It has a great vibe, and every corner you turn there is fado playing. just wander in any place, dance and have a good night.

From the rooftops Alfama small streets. Alfama is a lovely area, if your expecting pristine environment then this is not the place for you however, the 'worn out' feel of the area has its own charm and quaintness about it and you can easily loose yourself around the small cobbled streets and come across some gems.We rented a small studio and loved it as it was so close to the City without paying hotel prices! the are is quiet and safe.

The Alfama Stroll - a must to see, but watch pickpockets. Alfama is beautiful and colorful Lisbon quarter. It was fishermen and sailors home since Moorish period. You can get there by foot (takes 20-30 minutes from Baixa) or by #12 tram from Praça da Figueira. Visit Sao Jorge Castle for extensive view of Lisbon.To get more or portuguese experience - make Fado night reservation. We had Sr.Fado (book prior to your trip! they are always booked). If you're planning to have lunch in Alfama - try Restaurante o Patrono (near Fado Museum); the serve grilled octopus for 11 euros with good house wine.Be aware of pickpocketing!!! We had a few moments when there were 2-3 young girls pretending to be tourists. They had maps in their hands. At some point they were behind us and we completely lost focus on them (even we had nothing in backpacks). Then one of the locals started yelling at them. Another local guy we asked direction for church said that local know them, but not much can be done.
Amazing. This is an absolute must for visitors to Lisbon. We went there twice. It can easily be reached by trams no 12 and 28.
nice district. it is good to visit with tram...there is Castel and cathedral...also a view of river Tejo and the bridge

A place to fall in love with. The Alfma in Lisboa (Lisbon) is a very unique neighbourhood, in all our travels and they are many, this one will always be one of our favourites. The old houses and streets , more like alleys. The wonderful tile work on the houses, the colours which can't be changed. The sounds and smells, this is the Alfama. An absolute must when visiting this fascinating city.You too will fall in love with it. Stop and enjoy, have a strong cup of coffee, not for the faint of heart. This is not your typical USA coffee. Have a Sangria and/or some Tapas or listen to the sounds of Fado in the evening. But go there by all means, take a local guide if small narrow streets, a foreign language and crowds are not your thing. Enjoyable any time.

Okay to spend an hour in. We walked up and back to St George's Castle (Castelo de Sao Jorge) following different streets and going into nooks and lookouts. I didn't find it that interesting actually. The streets are pretty enough as they are cobbled and there are different buildings - but I actually preferred Bairro Alto to this neighbourhood. The streets in Bairro Alto were beautiful with the balconies and decorations.Also I didn't find it that big, we walked up lots of streets but I don't think you could spend more than an hour exploring the streets unless you stopped to eat/drink or you are a slow walker - or unless you were shopping at the market.There were plenty of Fado restaurants around, but as a vegan I looked at over 20 menus and unfortunately couldn't find anything to eat. Everything was pretty much meat and fish, with an odd vegetarian pasta or pizza.

Wander through, enjoy the views, watch Fado. Had an amazing time wandering through the Alfama neighborhood. It truly is as fun to get lost in the Alfama neighborhood as everyone says. Pop into some of the artisan stores and learn about the history of Portugese tile art. Grab a drink at Portas De Sol at sunset and enjoy the views. Have dinner then watch a Fado performance
Great place. I rented a small studio in Alfama and loved it! There are so many places to shop and the flea market on Saturday and Tuesday is a "must" if you like flea markets.

Really interesting.. A must-see in Lisbon. Although it is only locals that live there, it is a huge tourist attraction because it is so authentic. Really narrow streets, tiny houses and friendly people. Really interesting history as well.
Old part of town. It's a nice part and very lively part whit a flee market and ole churches. If you have knee problem you might stay on the lover grounds. It's very steep and narrow on some places.

dirty crooked streets, garbage on every corner, walls are covered with graffitti.. You need to come here once and see for yourself as a sample of dirty old town. GPS can hardly help you in this maze of little streets.
Lovely area to dissapear in. go there with the tram - or walk - and eat lunch at one of the many smaller local restaurants in Alfamas "backyard"
Oldtown. Lisbon's oldtown - very beautiful and picturesque. Try walking through Alfama up to the Castelo de Sao Jorge, where one of the most beautiful scenic points is, especially at sunset!

What a find!. Alfama is like no other part of the city. A walk through the narrow winding cobbled streets takes you back in time. Very pretty vantage points, many opportunities to stop, take a break and relax with a cold drink. This area is a must see in Lisbon. After you've explored on foot, take the Yellow Bus' Hills Tram Tour or the 28 tram, both of which wind their way through the narrow roads. Take it slowly and soak up the atmosphere....you'll love it.
The best district in Lisbon. We stayed in an apartment in Alfalma and were near so many historic sites like St Jorges Castle Lisbon Cathedral. It is a beautiful area .
Old and traditional. Old area of Lisbon where you can find nice restaurants playing Fado. Nice to explore on a tram or walking

Lovely area of Lisbon. This is a really lovely area of Lisbon to walk around. The best part is when you wander the narrow little lanes, are lost, and discover a bunch of old women sitting together and gossiping. Makes one feel like one has stepped back in time.

The spirit of the old city. We really like the Alfama and it's very old buildings and markets and the narrow streets. We especially enjoyes eating in the restaurants around the Escolas Gerais and the Fado near Graca.
Just wander!. Throw away the map and just wander the narrow streets! Lots of interesting nooks and crannies to get lost in and plenty of bars and restaurants to stop for a drink or something to eat.
Great place to get lost in. Amazing old part of Lisbon. Catch the tram up and then wander your way down, getting lost as you go. Amazing narrow streets and friendly locals. Must do.
Best place to stay. Alfama is a vibrant place to stay, with great places to eat and drink, Tabuas Porto Wine Tavern for a start. With surprises around each corner, history and fun.
Do it by foot. The best way to do the area is by foot. If you are unable to walk well then hire a tuc tuc such as 'I tuk you' they do Fado tour for 60e and lasts nearly 2 hours.

Interesting and intriquing. Enjoyed wandering around the narrow streets. Great sense of history and habitation by working people. Restaurants and cafes, although some difficult to find. Don't hesitate in nipping down the very narrow alleys it could open up into a square or cul de sac.

Quaint old district. Wandering the cobbled narrow streets of the Alfama district is delightful. There are lots of shops selling unusual souvenirs and 'nick-knacks' and some really good bars and cafes where you can sit and have refreshments whist watching the world go by. Don't stick to the main routes taken by the tourists; go 'off-piste' and you can find some gems.

so interesting................ This area sums up Lisbon for me where you find quaint buildings and with a smattering of historic landmarks,coupled with the locals who live and work in this bustling hub hub of daily Portuguese life!

Do a walking tour to get the most out of it!. Rustic, pretty Alfama. We had a guide so we learned about the history of the place, the church, the Fado bars... also the beautiful views over the stunning architecture and over to the sea.

Old and interesting. We took the hop-on-off tram tour to here and it saved us a lot of climbing up steep road. The old buildings are interesting with beautiful tiles on the exterior of the buildings. The view from up the hill was stunning. It was a nice experience walking around Alfama and see the daily lives of the locals.
Steep climb to the castle but worth it.. Lovely oldy worldy part of Lisbon and a beautiful castle to experience once you get there. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes. The entrance is €8.50.

Worth a visit. A lovely area that is worth a visit, it has winding narrow streets that leads you to squares that have small shops,bakeries, restaurants and bars.
There seems to be lots of restoration work going on in the area but don't let this spoil your visit.
Too touristy. Maybe I just heard way too much hype about this neighborhood. It was fun to browse, but I like the other historic neighborhoods of Lisbon more
Quieter than Chiado. Alfama was more of a residential area. But the streets were great to walk, and there were some amazing restaurants.

Great views and lovely narrow streets. The Alfalfa district should definitely be on anyone's visit list while in Lisbon. The narrow hilly streets are lined with quirky shops, cafes and restaurants, and every once in a while you come across a great view of Lisbon.
You could easily waste an afternoon looking around the Alfama, but make sure you have a good pair of walking shoes.
The "Bairro". Alfama is one of the traditional "Bairros" that you must visit, as soon as you arrive in Lisbon. Just walk around, and feel the atmosphere...you will adore!
typical. a good neighborhood with friendly people and nice places to visit ... very old also like chiado, streets very small. You can find groceries, old shops...and places to stay.

Lost in Alfama. The best way to enjoy Alfama is to get lost there!!!Don't try to find the best way to visit it, but keep your time to take a look to its life, to chat with people and the 'flowing' of its flow.

Oh Alfama. Alfama is a beautiful, charming, old city in Lisbon. It is a salvaged treasure and I'd highly recommend to anyone visiting Lisbon. While in Alfama you won't miss the architecturally sound structures but be sure to also check out Castelo de Jorge and the Lisbon Cathedral. You'll be in walking distance of the Tajo River, which makes for an amazing view, as well as a few museums.

An authentic area of Lisbon. The very old part of Lisbon, perfect for just wandering around and discovering hidden things. There are some amazing view points, and very cute streets.We went there twice and on the second time, we stopped at the most random, small restaurant. And it was awesome.There were only locals- old ladies, friends, an elderly couple, and they were all super nice, despite the fact that we don't speak a word of Portuguese. They went out of their way to make sure we had a good experience, and we even left with a hand-drawn map of the best view point in the area.Good vibes!
Amazing -- do not miss. The views alone are worth the trip -- but the narrow roads, the history -- make it one you can't miss.

Charming with amazing views. The Alfama neighborhood has a lot of charm, walking around the narrow streets is really nice. Lots of things to see, specially the amazing view at the top. I was staying at a great boutique hotel The Alfama, so was very easy to walk around and then we took the tram! beautiful Lisbon!

A place to wander. Behind the Se Cathedral is the district of Alfama, once the home of the displaced Moors. Narrow streets and steps lead you to the Praca San Miguel, past tiny shops, bars and restaurants, many of them advertising Fado performances, before arriving at the Museo do Fado. Well worth a wander.

Nice neighborhood.... One of the lovely neighborhood of the beautiful Lisbon... You can get lost within the lil streets and alleys to discover the hood and you won't regret your choice... nice selection of bars for the nightlife...

Simply amazing. I loved this part of the city with small streets, climbing up, view to the river over the old houses; here and there a small restaurant with a fado singer outside, yellow trams. One of the best to feel the old Lisbon.
Beautiful and well preserved. A great part of the city with some lovely old buildings, heaps of street art and beautiful churches. Wonder in random bras for local wine. Also very nice at night.

Fado and More. Take the time to wander through this part of the city. Full of choices to hear Fado, restaurants/cafes with fantastic menus of the day (less than 10 euros) wonderful little shops and most of all, winding streets with wonderful old architecture....

Lovely District. If you are in Lisbon it's well worth a visit to walk round the narrow streets and find the little bars, shops and bakeries. There is quite a bit of restoration work going on but doesn't spoil the experience

Step back in time. Get your walking shoes on and start exploring. Getting lost is part of the fun and every turn brings something special if you keep your eyes open. Easy to lose track of time as you wander the narrow streets.

The old city of Lisbon. You couldn't come to Lisbon without visiting Alfama ... simply Alfama is Lisbon with its narrow streets and old buildings ... tourists every where climbing the streets to the highest point of the city to have a panoramic view of Lisbon .. The place is historical and very beautiful and I advice everyone who will visit Lisbon to put in mind visiting Alfama
cracking place to visit times gone by. I loved this place really old lots to see in the narrow streets, little shops with just a doorway and the tram ride is a must if you go here.

interesting place. It is known as the district of the poor but it is very charming place. Do visit this part of the town but be very careful. Don’t wear anything valuable with you if you decide to walk around.

An engaging area with lots of variety. What I liked about Alfama was the contrast between the big sites, also the varied colours and textures of the buildings. I had lunch at one bar/shop and some wine at a second, both very friendly and welcoming places. The trip on the old (yellow) tram I did here another day was exciting!

not for the infirm. What a lovely area to stroll taking in the sounds and smells in the very narrow streets. Paths are very narrow also and the surface is very uneven. Great care in some areas as cars buses and trams travel at fast speed. Very possible to get lost but locals are very helpful. Bring good walking shoes .
Great for walking and exploring. Many small side streets to explore this old area. They now charge for the fort that overlooks the town. It is well worth it if you have the time.

neighborhood to get lost. Neighborhood to get aroun and feel it's smells, noises and silences. Small like snake streets, charming corners. and lots of places to taste local specialities at good price. Not to be missed

Boho. What can I say. Some streets are more suites to tourists. I feel like the streets were more NYC Soho in the 70s-boho, dumpy. If that's you're thing then this is it! The thieves market??? Yeah.....the goods are pretty much that--someone ransacking a home and selling off old shoes, clothes, hair dryers etc.

Fantastic. Great place to wander about in early evening. Soak up the athmosphere and music. Great selection of restaurants.Go for outdoor one if weather is good. Look for menu of day as a la carte can be a rip off and not as fresh as others.Dont bother with taxis as nearby streets get very congested and traffic including trams and buses.

simply beautifull. maybe my favourite part of Lisboa:arriving with tram 28 or walking in the streets in the evening lookig for Fado-or getting lost in the flea market on saturday morning-its a must!amazing

Just what I thought Lisbon would be like.... This was a quiet calm area and right on Tram route 28 which is really good for exploring and getting about. Excellent location for exploring the castle and very central for the rest of Lisbon.

Immersion into Lisbon. This to me, is the soul of old Lisbon. The streets are often crooked and quirky and many buildings are faced with ancient or centuries old tile often in pictorials. Vibrant smells and music filter in from doorways left open to night rains and the best hotel on the planet is in the Alfama neighborhood. Here also, you can find many monuments and churches and the water is just a short stroll away.
Higgledy piggledy. Lovely lanes of beautiful houses. Tiny cafes and cobbles and little oases of calm. Take good walking shoes!

Flea in this direction on a saturday. Went to the Flea market in Alfama, huge, and fascinating even the kitchen sink. It is close to the Pantheon which you can also visit. We were short on time, a whole morning is neede. You can get a taste though

Lovely suburb. Lots of natives and countless lovely side alleys. It's very central and everything can be reached within minutes either by foot or by bus/tram. We lived in an Airbnb flat located directly next to an old watch tower with an orange tree and loved every minute of it. :)
Alfama. the narrow streets, te link between the city and the tagus river. living the real Lisbon and the history.
Gorgeous suburb. Worth it to have a wander through the quaint streets of Alfama. Gorgeous houses with great views over the water. Also enjoyed the castle at the top.

Get lost. just great to walk through some history, ignore any map and get lost in a myriad of street and alleyways. Interesting glimpses of Alfama life and how the houses are being sensitively refurbished in places.

Alfama is wonderful. We stayed in a flat in Alfama and found the area to be absolutely charming. If you go that route do ask about stairs, as our flat had several flights of steep ones. In any case the old streets that survived the 1755 earthquake are charming and people are friendly whether they speak English or not. You will find a variety of cute little shops and restaurants as well as churches to explore. I agree it is a must see and there are many areas that afford a spectacular view of the waterfront. If visiting Lisbon allow yourself a day or at least a few hours in this lovely area.

Must See!!. Alfama is absolutely gorgeous. It is a definite must see. I would advise to take Tram 28 (as there is a serious hill) up to the Thieves market on a Saturday and then walk back down. It is really lovely.

Great view. Me and my girlfriend took the tourist tram up to Alfama from downtown. this is a beautiful part of Lisbon. The sights are many and the view is beautiful. Have a beer or a coffee and sit down and relax a while. recomended.

Interesting - but beware. The narrow streets with the trams looked fascinating and the views from the Largo des Portas de Sol were escellent.But beware - passport stolen boarding No.28 tram - apparently notorious for this.

Lovely experience. I would recommend to explore this area walking up or down the steps rather than taking trams,only then you can see all the exterior of the old houses.Be careful at the beginning of Alfama as we saw good few dodgy people around,didn't have any trouble but didn't feel comfortable.Other than that,very beautiful charming area,the oldest part of Lisbon.

We stayed here and loved every momoent. Narrow winding streets and tiny shops and restaurants everywhere. We stayed here on top of the city and soon felt like home. The 28 tram runs straight through so you can easily hop on and off to take in the spectacular views of the city.
Loved it. The part of the city that remains the same as in it's beginnings! Really nice place to wander, walk around and get lost on its streets, I loved it :)

Ancient in all Respects. The Alfama district of Lisbon is perhaps one of the most amazing parts of this great city. It is topped by the medieval Castelo of Sao Jorge which sits on the highest point in the area. As other reviewers have noted, the many roads can sometimes be steep, but exploring on foot is by far the best way to immerse yourself in this ancient part of the city. I would definitely recommend good hiking shoes or even boots. The cobblestone streets can get pretty slippery when wet.My wife and I stayed here on a recent business trip to the area. Our rental apartment was literally next door to the castle. A few hundreds yards from the castle entrance there are ancient Roman ruins that have been excavated. There are dozens of excellent restaurants as well. One of our favorite events was the Thieves Market that is held on Saturday and Tuesday. Flea markets around the world are all very similar. This one is not exception. We found many great bargains and really enjoyed seeing the variety of items for sale, all set in a district filled with ancient churches and buildings. Well worth taking the time to visit.

My favourite part of Lisbon. A very hilly, very quaint district with old houses and narrow streets. I recommend taking Tram 28 up to Miradouro Santa Luzia and then walk around from there. Lots of good restaurants offering local dishes for decent prices.

Took A Walking Tour. Worth seeing, but if your time is limited skip. Home of the infamous plaza where the old men of the neighborhood gather, with an official street sign referring to it in the vernacular which you'll have to translate your self. The castle can be skipped as well.

must visit. Alfama is best explored on foot, you can get there by using tram 28 or the various tour vans. it is very steep sometimes, something to consider if walking with very small kids.
Combine this with visit to castle ( bus 37),the most beautiful part of City !
Nice atmosphere. Nice area with good food. I recommend taking a tour through here rather than just wandering on your own.

A beautiful place to explore. Although many people recommended using the to see this lovely corner of the city I would personally say if you can (and it is quite hilly) then walk it. It's brilliant to just stroll around taking whichever street you like and finding something beautiful around every corner. Look at the tiles, the trams, narrow streets, unexpected sea views. So enjoyable especially on a cool day where walking will warm you up.

Such an enjoyable walk. It was very relaxing wandering around this area. Very steep sometimes, but the ground is unpredictable, you never know whether it's going up or down every turn. If you get tired just hop on the tram 28 or bus. (Make sure you have the one day €6 unlimited ticket.)

Explore Alfama. Great place to wander and get a feel for the city. Did this our first day/evening in Lisbon and loved the experience. Winding, narrow streets. Interesting restaurants and shops along the way.
Get lost in Alfama. Put away the maps. Wander the streets and little alley ways. Such a beautiful part of the city with so much history.

Very wander-able.... I love areas where you can wander up and down the streets and the Alfama area is definitely "wander-able". Lots of small, hilly side streets but you can catch the trams if you get tired or if the weather's not that great -- great places to grab a bite to eat with locals and small artisan run stores with products made in Portugal.

Interesting to Walk Through. We took a guided tour of the Alfama Quarter, very interesting to see the old buildings and to see how their people live. Some streets are so narrow you can only walk through them. The buildings are very old, some are lovely and well kept and others very old and in need of maintenance. People very friendly. If you have the time you can spend a lot of time walking and exploring.

one oidest areas. stayed night here in an old hotel very basic but we were only there 1 night only problem we found was couldn't find bar open late for drink on way back hotel but I think that was because we didn't know area
very tipical. Old buildings in very narow streets. Not the most prety view of Lisbon. We prefer barrio alto and chiado.

Interesting area of town, hilly and with narrow streets.. Enjoyed the hill, the trip by tram car, and the narrow streets. Good for exploring. Many restaurants, museums, and artisan shops with local artist's work.
Beautiful location... Good Crowd... Full of life. Nice neighborhood. Full of life... great vibe. Liked the restaurants. Beautiful view of the sea and the city.

Awesome PLace and great atmosphere. Loved the place. Keep going back everytime I get back to Lisbon.
totally worth a visit! Great staff also what makes the experience even more interesting
Alfama left me speachless. One of the most charming districts of Lisbon. Full of fado! Being in Lisbon even for a few hrs, Almama it is just a must!
The old town. Take some time to walk (and get lost) around labyrinthic streets, breathe the fado atmosphere and just wait for the tramways to pass close to you. Charming, charming and charming.
Nice area. Nice area where you can find good restaurants and nightclubs, and some attractions like Castelo de São Jorge, National Pantheon and Sé Cathedral.

wonderful wondering. Lots of cool places to explore- hills are tricky wear flat comfortable shoes. loved the views over the harbor - the flea market sunday AM behind the church and easy access to food and snacks and Fado.

Put on your walking shoes!. Alfama is a very quaint neighborhood tucked into winding streets within the beautiful city of Lisbon. If you want to take a guided walking tour, check at the hostel in the main train station in downtown Lisbon (they are SO helpful) for times. The tours are free (although you would be a giant loser if you didn't give your guide a tip, and run daily. Or you can tour on your own. In either event, be prepared; you will be walking up and down some very steep hills! The beauty of the Alfama is how narrow the cobblestone streets are, and the beauty of the buildings. While much of Lisbon was rebuilt in the 1700's after the earthquake of 1755, the Alfama was spared the mass destruction, so you can see much of the original architecture. The only downside, which I suppose is true in most large cities, is the amount of trash to be seen on he streets. If you can't handle the walking, look into finding a tuk-tuk tour, which is a tour in what can only be described as a motorized rickshaw.

Nice stroll in Old Lisbon. Walk! Catch the wonderful ancient atmosphere in the narrow streets, stairs and alleys of the oldest part of Lisbon.And find on your walking tour some of the best places to lunch and dine (check Tripadvisor).
Wander the narrow streets. This is the old Moorish quarter. Lots of narrow streets gift shops and cafes. Good for a walk and to see some churches

Old town, it is. We stayed in a rented apartment in Alfama and became really at home in its minutely narrow streets, steep slopes and - watch where you tread - evidence of the number of dogs walked by thoughtless owners!Definitely a 'must see' area, even if you don't stay there. We felt it was part soul of old Lisbon and part tourist trap, so just be careful where you eat (and tread!) See my views on a couple of restaurants

Historical and Beautiful - do not miss. This is the old Lisbon - built by the Moors who left in the 12th Cen @ the Christian reconquest. The most important places to see include 'Castelo Sao Jorge', Miradouro do Santa Luzia and the Cathedral Se of Lisbon. There are others too but you should walk around and find your own gems. Practical info - Trams no 12 & 28 go to Alfama. Bus no 737 (from Plaza Figuera) goes all the way to Castle St George - so you don't have to walk. But I have seen Tuk-Tuks which take people up to the castle now.
One of Europe's most charming neighborhoods. Tight, winding, steep and very loverly streets in a very old neighborhood. Great Fado music. Not as touristified as the afso,lovely Bairo Alto has become.

The heart of Lisbon. This is what Lisbon is about. The houses on sloped terrain with the red roofs, the cathedrals, Sao Jorge Castle. If you have limited time in Lisbon, you can miss all except Alfama. See it at all times of the day, when the sun rises till the sun sets, it looks different each time. Dine in one of the restaurants on top of the hill, the experience will be sublime.
Just awesome.. Here where the clock stopped 200 years ago. A MUST see !The nicest area in Lisboa. And real. This is how it was and is....

Alluring Alfama. This is an older part of town, more traditional and full of character. Small alley ways, narrow winding streets, laundry lines hanging outside houses with clothes and of course adorable lil cafes and shops tucked in the by lanes. It's the only area that didn't get destroyed by the earthquake several centuries ago and its a great space to stay in.

Self guided walk in poor but REAL neighborhood (and not getting pick pocketed). Check out a DAY WALK and NIGHT STUMBLE in this neighborhood. Don't expect a groomed tourist attraction, you have to understand Alfama is POOR (many old folks in low cost small apartment in small dilapidated buildings) and old, but slooooowly upcoming at snail's pace. The average Lisbon salary at time of writing is 500 euro (a little over a third the average receptionist salary in Hongkong) and locals say unemployment is at 30%.Got to know the Alfama neighborhood by staying in small apartment on Rua dos Remedios, a week, on my own, and walked the infamously steep, rough and dirty cobblestone roads so much that broke 3 pairs of shoes and wrecked my luggage wheels! Its streets are downtrodden, run down maze, not for the casual tourist (and literally the well-heeled) but for people who want to see how locals REALLY live. Complete with overflowing garbage cans, dog poop, old ladies calling for their older sisters or husbands to let them into the apartment, laundry draped overhead and raw graffiti. Cute dogs wagging their tails to be petted and aloof cats draped from overhead balconies, unexpectedly sweet smiles from old ladies if you try to speak their lingo, amazing food at hole in the wall restaurants, soulful, live guitar playing pouring out from open windows. At night - Fado singing and guitar resonating through the maze streets at night and dirt cheap wine (paid 2.5 euro for what i thought was a glass and got a bottle! shared it and made friends very quickly). I avoided tourist traps like tram 28, and was safe, never a hint of pickpocket, even going out on my own as older woman all hours of day and night. The place is an overwhelming maze got happily lost in, but finally decided to make sense of it with a free online tour which if you dont wander off course and dive into restaurants and pasteis shops should take 1.5 to 2 hours.DAY SELF-TOURSo, iPhone set on on maps, check out http://www.lisbonlux.com/lisbon/alfama-walking-tour.html (my humble opinion against the advice of this site, DONT take tram 28 - not worth it) and start walking from St George Castle/Castelo do Sao Jorge or any easy-to-find vantage point along the tour such as Portas do Sol viewpoint, as you will get definitely get lost along the way. But that's part of the fun….You are basically heading down to the shore, southeastward.Lots of steep steps and streets, slippery cobblestones (fun fact - cobblestoning is a specialized job and there's even a union for it) so shoe accordingly. You'll pass a few un-notable and closed churches (Sao Miguel and Estavao), scenic outlooks, Manueline doorways, crumbling graffiti-ed fountains and a poignantly sad, beaten down Jewish quarter and tons of rundown,narrow winding streets -- this is a gritty behind the scenes tour. Your reward? Cool photos (checkout my lazy iPhone ones), glimpse into real life, some great pastry (pasteis), coffee and amazing hole in the wall restaurants. Stray off path now and then like I did and you'll pass some interesting old shops selling military gear (real and faux) and quaint but impractical clothing.If your starting point's the St George, turn left at the first intersection at the street leading down from castle exit and head downhill to Portas do Sol viewpoint about 8 minutes walk away. (Treasure hunt - keep your eyes peeled for a small Banksy-like graffiti along the way!!! Hint - its low on an unremarkable wall to the left of street) In case you cant find website, here is summary from the Portas do Sol. 2. Next to the terrace is a flight of steps which is Rua Norberto de Araújo, taking you down the hill into the maze of streets. 3. Turn right at Calçadinha da Figueira, where you'll see one of the towers of the church of São Miguel. 4. Go all the way down the stairs (Beco da Corvinha) to Largo de São Miguel(a). You'll see the side of the church and then a large palm tree(b) in front. I wandered off at this point into Santa Antonio Restaurant, Beco de Sao Miguel, crazy delicious fresh sea bass simply stuffed with lemon and coriander, grilled. And cheap wine! Great coffee! 5. Turn left towards Calçadinha de São Miguel and you'll soon see the tower of the church of Santo Estêvão in the distance, but you'll turn left on the first alley, Beco da Cardosa. 6. At the very top of the stairs(a) you'll reach Rua Castelo Picão where you turn right and then right again to Beco das Cruzes(b), going down the steps and turning left, where you'll see the façade of the church of Santo Estêvão(c). 7. At the end of the steps, turn left towards Largo do Peneireiro(a) where you'll turn right and go up the steps. At the top(b), turn right towards the church of Santo Estêvão.8. Next to the church is a terrace with river views. (Took photos of red roofs dotted with ugly soaring cranes - this is where u see changing face of Alfama) Go around the church, down the steps, where you'll see tiled houses. 9. Continue down, taking the steps Escadinhas/Calçadinha de Santo Estêvão. At the bottom you'll see a tile panel indicating the old public baths, and turn left. At number 2 of Calçadinha de Santo Estêvão you'll see a surviving Manueline doorway (16th century). NOTE!!!
