Somewhere between 9. and 11. is a crazy amazing pasteis shop with the most delicious Pastel de Nata egg tarts that's as good as the famed ones in Café Pastéis in Belém - sorry keep your eyes peeled I cant remember name or address. 10. You'll have reached Rua dos Remédios, turn right and go down the street where you'll see another Manueline doorway(a) on a small church before reaching Largo do Chafariz de Dentro(b). You may choose to visit the Fado Museum there, or continue heading northwest of the square, where you'll see tables outside a couple of restaurants(c). 11. Continue into Rua de São Pedro, go all the way down, passing through Fado restaurants and tourist shops before reaching Largo de São Rafael to the left. 12. Go down the hill at Largo de São Rafael and you'll see Rua da Judiaria, the center of the old Jewish quarter. You'll notice some surviving architectural details(a) and will see a fountain with an archway next to it(b). Go under the archway and you're suddenly out of the maze, close to the riverfront.13. Turn right towards the street and you'll eventually see a monumental 19th-century fountain which no longer provides water. Continue down the street and a few feet away is Campo das Cebolas with the archway Arco de Jesus to the right. 14. Go under the arch, up the steps by a tiled building, and at the top is Rua de São João da Praça, where you turn left. At number 95 is the popular Pois Café for a refreshing drink or meal (there are more options ahead). 15. At the end of the street you'll see a tiled building(a) and the back of the medieval cathedral by orange trees(b). Going around the cathedral, up the hill again (Rua Augusto Rosa), you'll see souvenir and antique shops (between numbers 40 and 42 is also the entrance to the free Roman Theater Museum for the story of Roman Lisbon), and eventually you reach your starting point, the Portas do Sol viewpoint. At this point you may choose to relax and enjoy the view, or take tram 28 or walk following its tracks to the monastery of São Vicente de Fora or all the way to the Graça viewpoint.For other touristy sights in Alfama - visit Casa dos Bicos, the Church of St. Engrácia, Fado Museum, Clube de Fado, Miradouro de Santa Luzia,Cathedral of Lisbon, Praça do Comércio (commercial plaza for shopping). NIGHT STUMBLE OF RANDOM FADO HOUSES (after all that wine its a bit of a blurrr) Note - some Fado places only have 3-night/week performances so check before heading out. I found there wasn't much to do out at night in winter except restaurants, bars and Fado. Walk from the dilapidated plaza opposite the Fado Museum on Rua Jardim do Tabaco. Facing away the plaza, take the street at back right leading north (not rue dos remedies which heads east). Take the first left, first right and right again.to Parrreirinha De Alfama (Beco Espirito Santo 1, 1100-222 SANTO ESTÊVÃO). For more Fado options along Rua do Sao Pedro, head back toward the plaza, but head westward and within 3-10 minutes' walk you'll find several Fado bars which had much cheaper for food and wine and more local crowds, sorry cant remember their names. MORE about the Jewish history in Lisbon I found on a tour operator's site -- http://www.lisbonexplorer.com/jewish_lisbon.htmlThe Jews wielded great influence and power with Portuguese royalty and traders, and were a buffer between Muslims and Christians but were also victims of inquisitions, forced baptisms and massacres. Thousands of Jewish refugees escaped Nazis through Lisbon, including artist Marc Chagall.
Put on your walking shoes. Yes make sure your shoes are up to some good walking. This area needs a few hours to wander aimlessly around the streets. Lots to take in.

Snapshot of another time. Any visitor to Lisbon should spend at least an hour walking around the Alfama district -- in broad daylight and preferably with friends. Take time to notice the architecture and the many accommodations that have been made to modern life (such as the massive spider webs of electric wires hanging over the streets and clinging to the walls of the houses). The souvenir shops full of really tacky merchandise can spoil the mood, but I also got a peek into a public wash house where women still gather to do laundry.

Stunnings panoramic views of the city. Very romantic place with many miradouro places it means- with panormanic views.
very close to st Jorge castle
u can get the views for free!

the oldest part of the city. Alfama is the oldest part of the city, with lots of narrow streets with old houses that are covered with ceramic tiles azulejo in typical Moorish style, so a little reminiscent of Tunisia and Morocco. There is also the Cathedral, the famous tram 28 passes through this quarter. Can be toured on foot or by public transport.

Most picturesque Bohemian neighbourhood of Lisbon!. The most beautiful old town with the typical narrow cobblestoned streets where people have to blend in to the wall to make way for Trams! You can view the whole village from Miradouro de Santa Luzia where there is a stop for Tram 28. Walking down Alfama will seem like time was held for centuries and preserved well to show the blend of Arabic and Portugese cultures in Lisbon! Full of hilly streets and Fado cafes - a ride on tram 28 across Alfama is unmissable and a great experience!

Don't take Tram 28. We waited for a long time after visiting the Castelo de Sao Jorge for the tram 28, it got very crowded and the pick pocket gang just butt the queue, one person would not have the exact change while other would push you to create a chaos, my tablet in the back pack got stolen. If you don't get a seat on the tram there is no street scenes to see whereas you are constantly worrying because you are surrounded by suspicious people. Leave the trip to the locals, it is not worth it.

Touristy for sightseeing, but full of local life. We stayed on Rua de San Miguel and it was very much full of local life with great local restuarants nearby (but also some touristy spots) and places for listening to Fado.Great to get the tram 28 (hopefully without your things being stolen so take care) up to the Castle, check out the Graca Church and its viewpointWalk down to the Vincent de Fora church and Monastery, which I would rate as good as the one in Belem, Then continue to the Pantheon for some more marvelous views by ascending to the top TerrenceWander through Rua de San Miguel for a bite or in one of the nearby streets, then continue to the Se' (the main Cathedral)

The point of wonderful views. From the lower part of Lisbon just head the upper part and you'll reach there to Alfama, the oldest district of Lisbon founded by arabs (moorish). You can do it easily using the tram (Yellow #28), by the green tourist bus or just walking. The streets will impress you for sure. On the way you'll discover multiple choices for dinner having Fado music the enchant your ears.Here you'll stop for a visit to Museo des Artes Decorativas, hosted in an old contruction dating from 17th century. Silvery items, furniture (fantastic), carpets, tapestry all presented like in an aristocratic way.A visit to the monastery Sao Vincente de Fora (16th century), then Campo de St.Clara - right behind St.Vincente Monastery - where you can find many antiques (every Thursday & Saturday). The place is known as The Thieves Square. Very close is to be found the Pantheon.An if you choose to walk towards Casa do Fado it means that your tour will be completed. Do not forget to visit the Castello de Sao Jorge.If I've caught your attention it means that you need to go by yourselves and feel the old Alfama.
awesome place. Best place to escape from everyday's world - getting lost between narrow streets, meeting friendly local people, feeling the way they are living

Lisbon soul is here. This is the neighborhood where Lisbon is 'more lisboner' (if I can say so). Narrow, medieval streets, tiny houses, traditional people living there. Also, good, cheap, typical restaurants. Two things to take notice: it's an up and down tour (with lots of steps) and keep an eye on the road because of what dogs leave behind (they walk free on these streets).

A must go. Truly enjoy every moment walking around Alfama town, people are very friendly and enjoy some moments siting at the cafe along the streets. Take tram 28 and go around the town if you don't like to walk. Its quite hilly here.
Lovely Touristy Area. Lovely touristy area to kill a few hours after dinner, but nothing cheap in this area, and you can find all these brands everywhere else.

place to stay to make your visit smooth. Alfama area is really the first place I will recommend on your first visit of Lisbon. You feel the heart of the city. Monuments such as castello san george, the cathedral, the commercial district are at walking distance. Lots of local portuguese restaurants to choose from.
Incredible!. Visiting the place is like traveling back in time, with its winding, twisting, hilly alleyways. There you can have a spectacular view of the whole of Lisbon. Simply amazing...

beautiful view. I am staying here for a few days. The view is gorgeous. I woke up to the beautiful sun-rise over the river. I see seagulls flying around my building. The streets are really steep so it will take a while to walk up with your luggage.

Another world inside this one. Yes, this is a different world inside this world called Lisbon. A medieval world, but with cafes, restaurants, sight seeing, monuments and a fantastic casthe with lovely grounds.
You have to return over and over. Beautiful!!
alfama. beaufiful ! lovely views , great castle , nice little snack bar on view point , convenient on tram & bus route , a few lovely resteraunts near castle !

This is where you go for FADO. Great atmosphere, this is as typical as Lisbon gets, great restaurants, great food and not at all expensive. If you want to listen to Fado this is where the best Fado houses are located, you should book as they get quite busy, going to Fado is also not very cheap but worth the experience.

Leave your high heels in your room. Really quaint area full of small streets and lots of lovely cafes. If you are in Lisbon you will be visiting this area anyway so all I would say is make sure you wear comfortable footwear. You will get lost at some point which is what it's all about. We've been to some hilly places but this really does take it out of your legs when walking around all day.

Quick tour of Alfama. Enjoyed the fort and the cathedral but the hills are substantial. The view from the fort is spectacular and worth the trip itself. The cathedral is a work of art in itself. Be sure to take the paid tour of the cloisters and the cathedral's treasures.
Fab Alfama. What a beautiful district with fantastic views towards the sea overlooking the red roofs.Take the Tram 28 uphill to Alfama and then stroll back to city centre.
Unassuming, but fun to walk around - great Fado music. Wished we could have seen a Fado show (I had been years before) but it's a beautiful district with a gorgeous cathedral.

It's just Alfama. Definitely the best place to visit in Lisbon. If you dare to go there... There is not so many tourists, Just people living there. May be dangerous if you exploring it on your own having expensive camera on your neck. The best place to observe daily life of one of the poorest district of Lisbon. The maze of stairs up and down make you unsure where you exactly are. Step into the one of dozens micro-restaurants for beer or meal to get rest and feel the climate of that place. Highly recommended!
Listen to fado in the streets. Great atmosphere, nice cosy alleys and a lot of small bars and restaurants were you can hear fado music. A must see (and hear).

Prettiest neighborhood in Lisbon!. I loved this area! Winding little streets and amazing views of the water and beyond. We had a delicious lunch at a little Indian restaurant, tapas, wine and a soda our bill came out to around $17 for two. Wish I spent more time here and saw the castle.

Views magnificent. Took tram 28 and explored this wonderful place including the cathedral and castle, found a lovely little Reaturaunt called pastel do fadi and some really nice decoration pieces by local artists near by, BEWARE of pick pockets a brave local man alerted a tourist who was being targeted so Respect to him, most locals take real pride but like everywhere in the world we unfortunately have some bad apples , but be sensible and you will really enjoy

Great to explore. Just walk around and enjoy this lovely area. Great individual shops and cafes.Visit the castle(a very steep walk up or get the local bus) and visit the Cathedral not so much for the building itself but more for the archeological site at the back and the Treasury ( worth a few extra euros).

Absolutely amazing!!. Absolutely amazing place in Lisbon, you simply need to go there, I was living in Lisbon for one year in Graca area, so there is very close to Alfama, I loved walking through those tight, charming streets. There is many good coffee places, restaurants and tascas (local small restaurant). it's a good idea to spend some time, I think you will not regret :)

Tram up, walk down. The Alfama was one of the high points on my visit to Lisbon. Another reviewer called the neighbourhood "Ok" and said that there were only two sites to see. He must have visited a different Alfama. I could have spent the better part of a day just exploring all the little side streets. A really charming area with great views of the rest of Lisbon. It can be a little touristy, but there are good restaurants to be found that cater to the locals. Head for those. Just enjoy a leisurely stroll through the twisting Alfama streets. Keep in mind that the Alfama district is quite high up, so I'd recommend taking the tram (ideally one of the old, historic ones) up and then walking down. Great way to spend an afternoon in Lisbon.
Historic. Alfama was everything I expected from a portuguese city. The arquitecture there is amazing. You should spend an afternoon lost there. And there are also great views to the river.
Cente. This is the area close to the river with a few squares and pedestrian streets with shops and restaurants. Nice for walks in the day or at night time.

Ok-neighborhood that can be seen in 2 hours. Alfama was an ok neighborhood that basically has 2 sites worth seeing, if at all (the Castle and Se Cathedral). If you are short on time or have 3 days or less in Lisbon, I would start with Belem where the historic sites are plentiful and close to one another. Alfama felt void of locals, somewhat desolate except for tourists.
Lovely area.. Pleasant area to walk around and sit while people watching. Pretty typical lisbon streets are all around ready to explore.
Great ambience. The area has a unique feeling, with narrow streets, small bars and Portuguese guitar music seeping out of restaurants. Highly recommended just to stroll around without any reason.
relaxed atmosphere. nice neighbourhood with narrow streets and lots of stairs. little shops and beautiful corners. but one gets lost easily...

Lisbon, Portugal, famous Alfama district. Close to the Lisbon waterfront, the old district of Alfama in Lisbon, Portugal, is famous for its narrow streets and alleys, its bars and cafes, its Moorish history but above all for its great music tradition known as Fado. Fado(fate) is sung music of great longing, sorrow and even romance accompanied by the Portugese guitarra and sung passionately by both men and women some of whom are world famous. This area was built by the Moors and still retains that crowed look of an intimate kasbah.. There is a Fado museum and this Alfama district acttually survived the destruction of the great Lisbon earthquake, tsunami and fires of 1755. The Alfama is dotted with many Fado cafes such as Sao Miguel D'Alfama (featured Fado chanteuse Fatima Mouro) and Restaurante Esquina De Alfama. Tourists should be aware that almost all of Lisbon is very hilly and walking up and down in the Alfama takes some effort. The Alfama also houses many gift and antique shops. The Alfama is always on the many offered Lisbon city tours and some tours bring you to the Alfama at night to dine and listen to Fado music. Enjoy the Alfama, the wonderful Fado music and sip some vinho verde.

Old part of Lisbon. I loved this part of Lisbon. Lots of steep roads, cobblestone roads and beautiful views. You can get the tram 28 and have a tour around the alfama. cafes, restaurants. It is best to have a wander round and get lost in the maze of side roads. Make sure you wear comfortable shoes, you will regret it if you do not.

interesting neighbourhood around the Castle. Thiss maze of old streets and staircases surrounds Castelo Sao Jorge. it was the old moorish quarter but was later christianized and has many small squares and tiny churches. we followed the walking tour from lisbonlux.com which was great. had a good lunch in a little restaurant in Beco de Sao Miguel.

Don't miss when in Lisbon. this ancient neighborhood sits perched on a hill and still looks much like it did hundreds of years ago. Walk the winding streets, smell what the restaurants are cooking for the day and listen to the music.

Good place to get 'lost'... Walking down from castle above is, I suspect far more enjoyable than up.You can eat shop drink or walk.Enjoyed aimlessly wandering around for a few hours and did eat, did drink and no shop.1920s trams that, yes do make it through the very narrow and acute corners...Great vantage points and unique architecture.Recommend.

Beautiful views to the whole city. In Alfama there are plenty of spots between the beautiful buildings to have a look of the city at the sunset! By walking through small streets you can find plenty of interesting graffiti art, historical buildings and and shops to buy the cutest souvenirs :)

Alfama. We walked through Alfama as we were walking back down from the Castle. It had some unique views and shops. Found one that was 500 years old and was an old horse stable. It was very unique how they designed it. The store used the food troughs for display areas and it had the original stone floor. Awesome!

a must. Take a walk between the walls of Alfama. You can get lost between old houses, small cafes and shops. You will feel the atmosphere of old Lisbon.
Take an old tram to Graca square. Be patient as they may be very crowded and don't circulate according to schedule.

Crazy trams. Alfama is a beautiful part of Lisbon, and been the old town it is very small with me watching in amazement and horror at times thinking how on earth do the trams fit between the buildings.....
It has some lovely family run restaurants and monuments to visit.
You could walk around it for hours happily, I did.

Weekend break in Lisbon. This particular district in Lisbon is one of the oldest, and most colourful, with different colured houses. Fantastic winding old moorish cobbled streets, not great for high heels, but what an atmosphere !!

Alluring Alfama. My friend and I had a lovely walk through Alfama on our way up to Castle Sao De George, but it can get quite hilly. It was a beautiful day and I loved gazing at the colourful blocks of flats and seeing women hanging out their washing on the balcony. I couldn't stop snapping away with the camera and was fascinated by how the roads twisted and turned as we got higher up. I also found a lovely street mural on the wall, well worth a walk through although can get a little tiring.....definitely worth it though!

pleasant trip on the tram. you can reach here by the old tramsthat travel round the small city streets no 28 for only 2,80 each waygreat views when you get there and theres a small bar where you can have a sit and listen to the buskers below nice afternoon out
En Route to Castle de St Jorge. Lovely quaint old village en route to Castle de St Jorge. need your walking shoes for this hilly trek!

BE CAREFUL OF PICKPOCKETS!!. This was a very interesting tour--one I would only recommend for daytime and go with a reputable guide. It 's a very hilly neighborhood, with some narrow streets. Because the cruise ships dock nearby, there are pickpockets ready to lighten tourists' load. We saw them in action, which was really sad. They look like tourists themselves. The couple we saw was dressed casually with sunglasses and she, of course, was carrying a large purse to hold the wallets and purses she stole. Have fun, but be very careful!
Nice, old part of the city. A nice area for a stroll day or night. Not ruined by touris traps or over development. Authentic, old style Lisbon.

Beautifull historical part of Lisboa. If you have the stamina, walk up and down the sometimes rather steep and narrow old 'streets'. You will experience the old days and if you manage some Portugese, try and speak with the old folks sitting outside in front of their small houses. Also try afew bites in the many small local restaurants, some of which can only host 4 people. The old castle on top of the hill is impressive. So are a few churches and Musea. To get there, you can take one of the old streetcars (none named Desire, however). Or a TukTuk imported from Thailand. We did that and it was quit an experience bouncing over the cobblestones. My kidneys are almost back to where they are supposed to be.... AND THE VIEWS ARE BREATHTAKING.

Historic Medieval City. Visiting Alfama takes you on a fascinating journey through 3,000 years of history back through the Moors, Visigoths, Suevi (Swabians), the Roman Empire and the Phoenicians who built a trading colony at Olisspo. The quarter has retained it's Medieval character of winding streets and irregularly-shaped squares, despite the fact that like most of Lisbon, much pre-18th century architecture was lost in the 1755 earthquake, apart from the Se or cathedral, and the Castelo de São Jorge at the top of the hill. There are superb views of the river, Graça, Baixa, Chiado and Rossio as you climb higher on the hill towards the Castelo. Visit Chapito's for a drink and a beautiful view over Baixa after a visit to the castle.

Old area of Lisbon. We took the Hop on hop off bus to the top of Alfama & walked back to Praca do Comercio....an easy walk down hill stopping off at an old Church and checking out quaint buildings. It is old & some say run down but this adds to it's beauty.
Best at night. Strolling down the narrow streets is just excellent. Than all the Fado bars give extra magic to this place.

Off the beaten track in a major city. The Alfama suffered least in the earthquake of 1755, so retains a much older atmosphere than the rest of the city. It was designed long before cars, so there are none. The quiet is amazing for being a 5 minute walk from downtown Lisbon.We loved the curvy streets with constant up and down steps and alleys to explore. People were extremely friendly.

lovely view at the top. we did the tram ride trip up to alfama the roads were very narrow and very steep you would have a hard job walking up and the trams were every few mins and you would have to lie against the wall to let them past anyway! once up at the top you are at the castle and there is a good view

What a treasure!. Great food, people and music! A must in Lisbon if you enjoy culture and the arts. The hills can be a little tricky to negotiate for older folks but the 28 Tram will get you there and back with no problem.

Quaint, scenic neighbourhood. Best way to enjoy Alfama is to take the public bus (737, I believe) up to the castle, then walk down the winding cobblestone streets. Old, charming buildings and churches. Gorgeous lookout from Portas do Sol. Cute shops and cafes along the way. When you get tired, just hop on the bus to take you back down to Pr. Fig. square and the downtown area.
oldest part of town. Historic area with narrow cobbled streets, small shops and bars and birds singing in cages. Easy reach of tourist highlights. Buses to extensive Castle at the top.

Fado in Alfama. We were walking in the Alfama district and came across some wonderful restaurants. The one I liked best had two Fado singers. They were unbelievable. The area seems filled with funky little restaurants. This area does require walking up and down stairs.
Grat little area. A maze of little alleys full of outdoor restaurants and dinky bars.full of character. Preferred this area of Lisbon to barrio alto.
Real Lisbon. Go and get lost for an hour in Alfama, very charming 'real Lisbon'. Tiny alleyways, lots of small local cafe's - wander up to the Castle for the best views in the city

Fascinating. I was taken to the alfama district on a free walking tour. I found is fascinating as it was like being transported back 100 years. There are people washing their clothes with soap and buckets in the street and communal washing lines. There are people selling homemade alcohol from their living rooms. The walls are uneven and it half seems like the buildings are going to fall down. There are children playing in the streets and there are very narrow alleyways. It might not be everyone's cup of tea but it's really interesting that people still live in this way in the capital city of Portugal.

Alfama - wonderful day and night. The Alfama sums up everything that is special about Lisbon. Unspolit, not gentrified - still much as it was with lots of quirky shops, real locals and some great restaurants and bars - just don't expect it to be very touristy. That is its scruffy, lived in charm - which we hope will never change.By day wondering through the narrow alleyways meandering from the miradoura's near the castle you get a taste of real life. By night the fado comes alive and there are some great places to eat and drink and just soak in the atmosphere.

Contact with Roots. Hello Travellers, this is a good to go place, you have nice typical food you have nice views over the river, and its na old part of town.I Think you will enjoy the narrow streets the people on the street and you can go of course to a house of Fado and listen our typical music.Eat, drink listen to music and a good walk...

Old town vibe. Liked walking from Cathedral Sé into the little streets where you have locals sitting on the street, the Fado museum and tasting the Ginginha out of a chocolate cup in a tiny shop. Its going up hill though, if you have trouble walking, go in a tour with a little tuk tuk or electric cart :D

A must-see district of Lisboa. The old-fashioned narrow streets with a number of decent restaurants and places where you can spend the evenings listening to fado music and enjoying Mediterranean food and wine.
The Alfama by streetcar. I went to the Alfama by streetcar, which was a colorful if crowded way to go. Enjoyed the sights and got off to walk a bit.
nice. Terrific area of Lisbon, stroll along the hill and have an eat or drink on the many nice places. Very relaxed atmospheric spaces.
less impressive than other parts of Lisbon. In the Mediterranean there are many old town from the same era, they are more impressive. Lisbon has a lot to offer which are more interesting
Walking Delight. Wear comfortable shoes. Quite a workout if heading toward the Castle of ST. George, but worth it. Stopped along the way to see the views from different points.

the a Oldest Neighborhood in Lisbon. The oldest neighborhood in Lisbon. You can feel the community as you walk through the neighborhood. We bought several great artisan gifts in this area. Definitely worth a visit.

If you haven't been to Alfama, you haven't visited Lisbon. Alfama is a neighborhood which was built on one of the high hills of Lisbon. It was built long before there was something like a motor car, and as such it is a series of alleys and narrow winding streets most of which cannot be navigated by today's transportation vehicles. Therefore, the first thing that the visitor must equip himself with is a pair of strong legs, because I don't believe you can properly visit Alfama any way other than by walking. However, as Alfama is built on a high hill, it would probably be worth the while of the visitor to take some kind of transportation up to the top, and from there work down (I have climbed from the bottom up, and believe me I regret it) by foot. As you can read in other reviews, Alfama is a very colorful and authentic neighborhood, filled with dwellings that must have existed for centuries. In addition to residences, there are restaurants, shops, and tourist attractions (clubs, and Fado venues). And because it is on a high hill, there are many panoramic views of the city and the river below. Of course it wouldn't be Portugal if it wasn't also filled with churches, beautiful churches, monuments to the deity and testimony to the faith of the people. I cannot imagine someone visiting Lisbon without visiting Alfama
Quaint area to strole through. Very scenic area with nice views of the Med. Interesting shops with many small cafes. Hilly part of the city.

Overrated. It is supposed to be one of the most authentic parts of Lisbon and so it is. However, this does not mean that you will love it. Narrow streets, yes indeed, but not necessarily beautiful or romantic. It gives you an "old" , even sometimes, "deserted" feeling. As it is stated in tourist guides you will lose yourself in the narrow streets of Alfama. In my opinion, it is more probable that you will lose your time...

breathtaking. This is a must go when you are in Lisbon. We took the Tram 28 going there which is also a must try and went around on a tuktuk also. The view is breathtaking and alfama district is a haven for photographers.
very typical. we used a touristic bus and the place war really....suggestive! people says that in the evening the atmosphere will be.....great!

Old worls. I loved the views and the small streets leading in all direction of this very old part of Lisboa. We walk to it the first time and then went back at night in a Tuktuk. Both times were well worth it
A must if you visit Lisbon and wish to see the real life.. Again like all of Lisbon be prepared to walk and wear appropriate footwear. I recommend a guide as without we would have missed so much.
Gorgeous streets. Just go and get lost in the streets. The cobbles, tiles and views from the narrow, winding steep streets give you a real sense of Lisbon's beauty from above.

Splendid view. Alfama offers a splendid view to the tourists because of its geographical location. It does take time to get there from centre of lisbon, you will have to plan depending on the time considering infants in mind as you will also have to take steps to go to the top to enjoy this spectacular view of the city of lisbon.
Step back in time. Loved wandering around this area, locals are so friendly and it was wonderful sitting in the sun with a glass of Sangria watching the world go by.

Beautiful & Historic. Walk all over the place! Green doors, white trim, tiled walls, and rich with history. Take a walking tour with Taylor Made Travel to learn more about the architecture and stories of the people.
tuk tuk or tram 28 ?. waited more than one hour to get the tram , but we think it is not worth it , as having a stroll in Alfama or going with the tuk tuk gives you more exposure to the ares.
An unforgettable Rick Steves stroll. Quaint cobblestone streets full of memorable, historical structures and interesting shopping at the foothills of the fortress/castle
Old Lisbon. The tiny streets, old buildings, tram 28 passing by. At the top you can contemplate the wonderful view over Taje and city while having a drink or lunch/dinner.

Bustling!. A highlight of a visit to Lisbon. Many reasonably priced restaurants and some lovely craft shops (as well as the usual touristy rubbish!). Several magnificent viewing points with stunning views over the Alfama and port.
amazing tiny streets. You don't need a tour guide - just wander around and soak up the atmosphere. You are suddenly in a different world!

A Maze. Don't expect any map you can find of the city to help you find your way through the maze of streets, steps and dead ends. This section of the city is the oldest purely based on the fact that when the city was damaged, I believe in an earthquake, it was rebuilt with the rubble that remained. The cobblestone streets and twists lead to a lot of fun and then having to ask for directions a few times. Worth some time to see this historic space.

Colorful birds, music, delightful shops. Alfama, the old city of Lisbon is made of a tangle of the stone streets that Lisbon is famous for. There are plenty of cafes, artists' shops, live music, pop art displays. Something for everyone. We took the famous number 28 tram up the winding hills, had lunch in a cafe with a spectacular view and then wondered around all afternoon. I bought a couple of pieces of local pottery at a little shop call Artes Sao Jorge. The owner was there and told us about the artist and even shared a tiny chocolate cup of local cherry wine with us. Next visit we will plan to spend a whole day in Alfama and certainly stop off at Artes Sao Jorge.
Different. Most unusual area. Good flea market on certain days. Found a nice little restaurant for lunch. It was raing so we ducked inside a small restaurant which had the locals dining there

The old town portion. I stayed in the Alfama district so I spent some time there wandering the old narrow streets. This is the oldest district that was not wiped out by the earthquake and tsunami that hit Portugal several 100 years ago. I took a taxi to the castle near the top and wandered from there and eventually made it down to the waterfront where I was staying. If you are staying in Lisbon for more than a few days you will eventually get sick of the hop on, hop off tourist bus. They make you wait for ever and eat up too much of your day. But be sure to take the trolley on the Alfama route. That was very enjoyable.

INTERESTING OLD PART OF LISBON. Very old part of LISBON with very tiny steep streets.
The cobblestone streets are not a place for anyone with knee or hip problems to walk around.
Steep, narrow streets. Loved exploring the old steep cobbled streets and finding little bars and fish restaurants. Enjoyed riding the tram around the castle area. Streets bit dirty.
Lovely old town. Loved the ambience and quaint old streets. Lots of climbing unless you can work out which bus to get to the castle.

Quaint neighborhood with great views. This old neighborhood in Lisbon is extremely charming and gives you a taste of the old neighborhoods of Lisbon. The important thing to keep in mind about this neighborhood, and Lisbon is general, is that it's built on 7 hills. That means, lots of inclines and declines, so good walking shoes are a requirement! Once you reach the top, however, the views are spectacular. Don't forget to stop in a cafe with Fado (live music) for a truly unique experience.Best part: Getting lost in the little alley ways and seeing the lovely architecture that has withstood the test of time.Warning: Weak ankles and knees beware!

Lovely views and nice food. The views here are beautiful. The fresh seafood here was a lovely experience, we had a dish that comprised of cod fish and pureed chick peas with boiled eggs, all in a lovely broth. It's a great place to have a walk, we came across lots of little side streets and landmarks that were very interesting. Would recommend this place for couples especially.

Lots of construction underway. We walked through the Alfama to tour the castello Sao Jorge, just want to warn you that there was a lot of street construction going on in October. Otherwise, typical hill town and a bit less touristy than Roussio and the Bairro Alto -- but also less to do.

Mixed experiences. Castle is in the middle, so worth doing at the same time but very long queues for tickets. Also went to flea market which was huge and lots of gifts at reasonable prices. The streets of Alfama are a must because of their historical significance but it is a tourist attraction now and a lot of the streets are a bit grotty and don't have the charm of 20 years ago when everyone had plants on balconies and residents sat outside their apartments watching the world go by. The pavements have been re-done but are now in poor condition so good shoes required and be prepared for steep walking.Excellent Fado near Fado museum and the cathedral was also very interesting.

Great Day. We hopped on Tram 28 and spent a wonderful day wandering around the streets of Alfama. The highlight of our day was a visit to the castle, where we spent about 3 hours. We knew we'd enjoy the castle, but were pleasantly surprised at how enjoyable it was to wander aimlessly through the hilly streets and shops.

Wear walking shoes. Fun area to walk around in. We took a cab up but walked back to our room in Baixa-Chiado. Good place for fado but we never found a place that could seat us before 10:30pm & that is too late for dinner for us.

visit with caution. A visit to this neighbourhood is recommended for its historical significance and charm. It is worth wandering around for awhile - but beware. The streets are a maze, the cobbled sidewalks are treacherous and public restrooms are hard to find. Tourists are targeted by pickpockets, especially on the trolleys (we carried a decoy wallet that was stolen.)

Nice walking trip. Don't miss the Saturday market..just walk arn..can get lost and roam arn..good tourisme.Got small restos as well..mix of old ppls..couples..familes and addicts as well..local life going on.
Old charming neighbourhood. Very nice old, Moorish area. With lot's small restaurants that serve good food. You can here Fado music everywhere even better than in Bairo Alto

An experience!. We stayed in the area basically because it was cheap but I wouldn't do it again. Its nice to visit and have a wander but not to live in. It was very noisy at all times of the day and night and although that's all well and good when your visiting somewhere its not when your staying there and aren't getting enough sleep. Definitely a place to visit only when it is charming.
Amazing. Have a walk in this area in fact that is all you can do as it is so narrow in places the only transport available is tucktucks. Look at the buildings, this is the Lisbon of the locals
Beautiful part of Lisbon. Beautiful part of Lisbon you should definitely visit. Narrow streets, a lot of stairs, beautiful views...
Atmospheric. It has lots of character and you always find something new and unexpected around the corner or up a side street.

If there is no music, its just not the same. The only reason for this area is the traditional Fado music. The streets are cute and are really only for walking but if you don't select a place that offers the song, its just not the same.
Unique. Extraordinary. Full of tourists.. This is very special, but unfortunately packed with tourists. We were there in October, which is not the high season.

Lisboa birth place. Historic Lisbon in its more antique and true expression.Part of Lisboa soul: the city would not be the same without Alfama. Get lost on the labirintic streets, chec the 2 miradouros on the top of the Hill: Miradouro de Santa Luzia and Miradouro das Portas do Sol

Worth waiting in line for!. Yep, it's a fun thing to do! Great alternative to the more formal Yellowbus tours even though you only see a portion of old Lisbon. And without narration! But if you have a 24 hr metro card there is no cost at all! And you can jump on and off as you wish! Suggestion: definitely catch it at Martim Moniz station (the start) even though you'll have to wait in line. We waited over half an hour but it was worth it!! Many great places to stop and check out the sites! You could spend the whole day exploring just the area covered by Tram 28! And plenty of spaces to stop for a beer and look over the river at incredible views. Oh, we did just that!!We loved the ride and yes, at times you wonder how it makes it through those narrow streets! Although we had many unplanned stops where people parked their cars on the trolley tracks and we had to wait for the idiot to come back and move. What's wrong with some people?? Definitely a must do in Lisbon!

Top attraction for me.. A most enchanting Medieval urban area. Set on hilly terrain with small terrace houses linked by narrow winding cobble stone streets and steps, a walk through the area was most enjoyable with surprises around every corner.

Wonderful for Walking!. This historic section of Lisbon is a great place to walk, even without aim. You'll see red-roofed building, old facades, small cobbled-sqaures for sitting, larger squares with statues or fountains, and more. The hilltops give wonderful water views.
fascinating old world feeling. It was fun to just wander the narrow streets, soaking up the atmosphere, listening to the sounds, smelling the aroma of home cooking.
Beautiful place!. No visit to Lisbon is complete without a walk through the Alfama, be sure to have a good guide book or better yet a good guide or you will miss many of the hidden gems of this area.
Medieval Lisbon. The old part of the city, that was just high enough to survive the 1755 Tsunami. Quaint without being over run with tourists.

Fado and fado. Alfama is another very traditional and emblematic place where is located the Portuguese pantheon and the Santa Apolonia Train Station, very near the river. Alfama is a very challenging neighborhood since their street is full of uneven stones called "calçada à portuguesa" with big inclination to rise. But is as well the most iconic place to listen and see Fado.

Great viewpoint onto Lisbon. We took the #12E trolley from Praca da Figueira and get off at Miradouro de Largo das Portas do Sol where you can take a great view onto Lisbon downtown below. You can walk up the hill to check out the castle where there is another viewpoint or you can walk back down the steps to explore Alfama. There are a few churches along the way to explore. The lanes are narrow and look like the place has not changed for centuries.
Amazing place!. I liked very much the food (typical of Portugal) the attention, the ambience and desserts!I liked everything!

Moorish quarter. This section of the city is charming, with streets so narrow it would be hard to drive a car. A glimpse of how the natives live. Saw people hanging out in the street after work, greeting their neighbors and talking.
Alfama District. Great old area to wonder through, with Cafe's, shops and Restaurants. Real character of the old city.

Old Moorish charm.. Lisbon as it must have been before the big earthquake. Heart of the Fado music scène (maybe a bit too much of it), but definitely a nice walk with some excellent small restaurants to discover.
The reason one visits Lisbon. It would be a shame to visit Lisbon and miss this district. Ride the tram 28, visit the fort up top, and just walk until your lost. Unforgettable!

Historical area by all means go. During our visit to Lisbon a group of 7 of us had a guide that took us to this historical area. As no cars are allowed in this area, we climbed the steps to the top of Alfama for a beautiful view, visited a church, learned of the Jewish history here as well. I like the area especially due to no cars so it was peaceful and you can see how people live in this tight-knit community.

A great walk in the riverside. This still belongs to what I consider the walking zone of the major touristic zone. It is near Terreiro do Paço, an outstanding comercial area with the city gates in it, and sometimes a place for media shows againts the buildings, at night :D So awesome. So you can walk there from Alfama, and keep going from there to other places, like Bairro Alto, Hard Rock Café, Cais do Sodré (bar zones and hot zone during nights) ;)
steps to heavenly view. amazing, stairs upward and views along the way, great murals of fado singers, little streets with cute houses and doorways. great flea market at end on tue and sats

Extremely dangerous, even in broad daylight. My friend and I were doing a walking tour we had found online to see some of quaint streets of Alfama. However, due to the narrow streets and many corners, there may be several suspicious characters lurking ready to pounce on unsuspecting tourists. We were attacked by 2 men, fortunately we did not lose anything. One of them grabbed at my phone and pushed my friend down to the ground. Do not carry any valuables and make sure to stick to public areas if you wish to visit here.
Worth the walking. The windy streets in Alfama are lovely, really gives you an idea of old Lisbon. There are some lovely cafes tucked away too, dont go straight to the tourist ones!
great place to walk around. traditional place of lisbon city.iwe recomment that.however you have to be careful with your option there to have a dinner.
Love it. Probably one of the most interesting districts in Lisbn as well as one of the oldest. Best explored on foot, at a slow pace walking from bar to bar. Fully recommend - romantic and old.

Number 1 District in Lisbon. If you are short of time to visit Lisbon, this is the district not to be missed. Full of historical landmarks, charm, twisted little streets, nice views. The only drawback is the chance to get lost due to the scarce touristic information panels.

a wonderful place where you can enjoy the city of Lisbon. Walking thru Alfama is knowing about the story and the city of Portugal, going to the top where you can see the city, and then going into the narrow streets, you can feel why in Lisbon there are so many tourist from all over the world
Beautiful!. This is one of the best areas of Lisbon. It has a lot of the local flavor, many nice restaurants with good food and reasonable prices, and much of the Portuguese charm.

A magical view.... To date this has to be the most beautiful view I have ever seen. It was magical. We didn't plan to go up there but because of all the winding alleys and streets we ended there. We also took a "tuk tuk" which is a motorized bike around the town. It was pricey but amazing.
Fado festival. Don't miss next one....new annual event? Tons of locals in attendance for current stars. Walk....too much traffic

Every visitor to Lisbon should spend sometime strolling around Alfama.. The Alfama is a labyrinthine maze of narrow streets and alleys with many small shops, bars, cafes and restaurants. Every visitor to Lisbon should spend some time strolling this area. Sensible walking shoes essential and be prepared for steep slopes. However, the views and the atmosphere of the neighbourhood make the effort worthwhile.

Very Old and Typic. Lots of small houses,small restaurants and small. Places to go to a FADO. Night out, everything. Is very old and decadent, very very good to take pictures,in a Fellini kind of way.

The original Lisbon. Here you can feel the original city with the narrow streets and small buildings. It's very nice to walk around these streets, but they should be quite difficult on the rainy days.

Get lost! (in the streets). Alfama is a very nice neighbourhood. It's a friendly atmosphere, lot's of bars and restaurants.
Because of the small streets, just get yourself lost. Don't look at the map and wonder for a while. You will see the beauty and loveliness of Portugal in real life!
Lovely. Great place with lots of little bars and restaurants. The place was buzzing with local families during the night and the atmosphere was brilliant.

Why you should choose Alfama. The weight of HistoryAlfama is the proud survivor of Arabic and medieval Lisbon and it's arguably the city's oldest quarter. Battered by the 1755 earthquake that devastated the city, Alfama stayed out of the Marquis of Pombal's revolutionary urban plan to rebuild the capital, shaping what is now Downtown Lisbon. Alfama's buildings were rebuilt essentially following the pre-earthquake urban layout, its narrow winding streets, some of them just flights of stairs, in steep contrast with the wide, straight streets of the town's newer areas.Alfama neighbourhood sprawls up Castle Hill, between Lisbon harbour and the uptown. This proximity to the river shaped Alfama's people and activity. Traditionally populated by fishermen, fishmongers and people dedicated to most activities related to fish trade, it was Alfama that provided most of the sailors for the Portuguese ships that sailed from Lisbon to discover the World in the 14th and 15th centuries. It was also from here that came most of Lisbon harbour's workers, either as dockers or shipyard workers.Thousands of stories of women left ashore while their loved ones sailed to an uncertain destiny, of sailors dreaming of their loved ones waiting for them at home, paired with stories of betrayal and death, but also of partying, religious devotion and passion for Lisbon, have set the theme throughout the years for the lyrics of Portugal's national song, the 'Fado' (literally, Fate), UNESCO Immaterial World Heritage. Reason enough for Alfama to house the Museum of Fado.The weight of traditionAlfama is probably the only of Lisbon's quarters that has best preserved tradition and the essence of being a Lisboner: friendly, easy going, hard working people, with a fiery temperament, where the concept of "neighbours" and "family" are mixed, yet surprisingly open and unprejudiced.Alfama is at its peak in June, during the Saints Celebrations, particularly on the 12th and 13th of June, when Saint Anthony of Lisbon is celebrated (and yes, this is the right designation of the incorrectly named Saint Anthony of Padova). The neighbours organise street parties, the smell of barbecued sardines, barbecued pork and roasted chouriço fills the air, wine and beer flow freely, there's music and dancing and hoards of tourists and Lisboners invade the place to enjoy the action. And in the small hours of the morning comes the result of Lisbon's Marches competition that gathers all the 30 or so Lisbon quarters in a fierce contest for which Alfama is always the favourite to win (and it did, 8 times in the past 10 years). The chances of the party turning to a victory celebration are high.Discovery around every cornerAlfama is a maze of narrow streets, alleys, flights of stairs, where it's a pleasure to get lost, as you may accidentally discover that particular corner, or small restaurant, or amazing view, or even someone to chat that can make your day.There isn't a must see itinerary in Alfama. The two most commonly used ways to enter the quarter are from Portas do Sol, coming down from the Castle, or from Rua das Cruzes da Sé, a street going along the cathedral's left hand side (South side, I suppose).The approach through Rua das Cruzes da Sé is my favourite: as you face the cathedral's main entrance, you'll see a street on the left going up towards the Castle (this is where the popular tram 28 goes) and another on the right, which is the one you should take. It's straight ahead to Alfama (keep left when in doubt), through a cute street with orange trees on one side and nice cafés on the other side. The river is to your right and the Castle is to your left; have this in mind, as this will be your two reference points when entering Alfama.Further ahead, Cruzes da Sé changes to Rua São João da Praça. Carry on until you reach a small square; 50 meters ahead, slightly hidden on the right at Travessa do Chafariz d'El Rei, you can visit the spectacular Palacete do Chafariz d'El Rei (King's Fountain Palace), now a hotel and amazing tea room. If you prefer to skip this (don't!) Alfama is just a few meters ahead.Once you're in Alfama you'll be sort of 'on your own'. My suggestion is that you let yourself wander along the streets, avoiding going to far upwards (towards the Castle) or to far downwards (towards the river). These are your only two reference points in Alfama's maze.Things you may want to see in Alfama are:- the museum of Fado- the fish market, specially on week days, in the morning- the extremely narrow street, now a flight of stairs squeezed between two buildings that were separated by the 1755 earthquake, where only one person fits at a time (find it!)- the Palacete do Chafariz d'El Rei, which I mentioned earlier;- the Memmo Alfama Hotel bar, with a spectacular view over Alfama, the river and beyondMagicalAt night, Alfama doubles its magic. The gently lit streets get a nostalgic atmosphere and the fado that can be heard from the small restaurants almost everywhere just adds to that. Lisboners usually associate Alfama to "fado for tourists" and they are partially right. In recent years, however, Alfama has been hosting a fair share of trendy bars, which are improving the quarter's offer on what nightlife is concerned. This hasn't been enough to attract the crowds of Bairro Alto, which is good, as Alfama remains much safer, clean and magical than the Bairro.So, yes, if I was you, I wouldn't overlook Alfama and would dedicate at least half a day to it. Hope you enjoy it, at least as much as I do.

Alfama, the best location for the view in Lisbon. Alfama, the most well-known region in Lisbon, is definitely the best location to see this cute city. Unlike the downtown, not so many bars can be found, but still the small branching of the valley piling up with potuguese stylish buidlings with painted bricks, classic but silently locates here. Make me really impressive and unforgettable. I really love this kinds of atmosphere and feeling.

Narrow charming backstreets. Walked through the charming narrow streets of Alfama starting at the Portas Do Sol viewpoint. Lots of (downhill) steps and really scenic. Many restaurants around, and various touristy gift shops.
An ancient neighbourhood. A don't miss visit. Be prepared to climb the narrow streets. Unbelievable hidden beauties. The birthplace of Fado.

easy to get lost. Old, in many places untidy but with extraordinary climat and charm. Very narrow streets, up und down, you can lost yourself and it is the best way to explore this area. Between houses you can catch beautiful view on the see/river.And of course there are located the most well known fado restaurants.

Lively neighborhood with Lisbons charm. If you want to listen to fado out in the open on a warm night, experience the flair and charm of Lisbon like a local then this is the place to go. Bairro Alto may be more famous for tourists because of the bars but Alfama is definitely closer to the reality of the country and its tradition.
Traditional. Traditional part of Lisbon, lots of quaint cobbled streets. Watch out for pickpockets as apparently Alfama is bad for it.

Cool place to get lost. the street of alfama are small streets with awsome graffitis and very nice buidlings. There is the church sao vincente. Do not miss the terrase amazing vue. Alfama is a great place for photographers.
Nice walk to know old Lisbon. Small coffee shops, small shops, a lot of restaurants and a lot of tourists.Probably one of the most representative place in Lisbon.

Lisbon as it once was. Walking through Alfama is the easiest way to get the feel of how the city must have looked and feeled in the past. We stayed in the apartment in the middle of Alfama and it is perfect for exploring the area on foot. Plenty of little stores not just souvenir shops (sunday afternoon most are closed) , restaurants, local people living their lives on the street. Saturday flea market is a must if you like flea markets.Castelo S.Jorge and Cathedral are also within easy walking distance from anywhere in Alfama. Baixa is cca 10 to 15 minute walk from the centre of Alfama.The area can look run down and derelict at times, but as we understood the impact of salt and wind is such that no building covering can endure for more than a few decades before it looks like it will colapse (hence tiles on the walls although they are too expensive nowdays).The only thing you have to keep in mind if staying in Alfama is that the neighbourhood is quite loud so if you have light sleep like me you may end up not having too much sleep (which can get irritating at times), but if you have not problems with it I would recomend staying in Alfama.

Perfect place to explore, but wear your walking shoes. The Alfama is a maze of alleys and a labyrinth of narrow, and often very steep cobbled streets. We never really got lost as there are enough tall landmarks to help you find your way, and as a man, we never get "lost". There are meticulously maintained houses with wrought iron balconies and some that have been abandoned. The roads and alleys are so narrow at times that you might not even realize you are on one, and often one can almost touch both sides with outstretched arms. The flea markets which are held twice a week should not be missed. We were touch to be extra careful at night, but we never felt unsafe. I regret that we didn't visit a Fado club, but that's just another reason for a return visit.
"Old Lisbon at its best". Wander around this beautiful part of the city, take in the very ancient buildings and look towards the St Georges Castle. Please not very hilly....best to take the tram.

This is Lisbon!. Here you can fell and smell the real Lisbon! This is the hood where Fado (portuguese typical music, unesco world heritage) can be enjoyed. In June, with the Anthony of Lisbon (of Padua) celebrations Alfama is crowded if thousands of people. The best nights to have a glass of wine in one hand and eat the tasty sardines witg the other.Among the churches of the Alfama are Lisbon Cathedral (12th–14th centuries), the oldest of the city and located to the West of the neighbourhood, the Convent of the Grace (Convento da Graça, 18th century), near the Castle, the mannerist Monastery of São Vicente de Fora (late 16th–18th century), where the Kings of the House of Braganza are buried, and the baroque Church of Santa Engrácia (17th century), now converted into a National Pantheon for important Portuguese personalities.

Tangled streets and alley ways. A glimpse of Lisbon's old world charm and people. A zigzag uphill climb to the Castelo de Sao Jorge fortress. Easy to get lost, but many tourists are there to guide you along the way.
Charming district. Quaint streets and alleys (often steep) with a myriad of small restaurants and cafes, and also housing the cathedral (Se) and castle. Well worth a whole day's exploration.

A unique district!. We had a Tuk-Tuk driver take us through the Alfama. Diego was a great tour guide (found him by the church close to Alfama). We learned a lot of the history of Alfama and saw most of it very, very quickly. Walking would have taken us a full day. With the Tuk-Tuk it only took 20-30 minutes and was most enjoyable. Diego was so good we kept him for another hour and he showed us lots of Lisbon - we took him for lunch at the end of our 1.5 hours to show our appreciation. If you can find him suggest you do the same but other drivers can probably provide a similar service.

Get lost in the twisting streets. The streets are narrow and winding, take the walk towards the castle slowly. Both to appreciate the colourful houses, and to make the uphill walk easier! If your time is limited the cable cars are a great way to get around.

Very authentic. Historic and authentic. Worth seeing , staying here would not be for everyone-e.g. if 4* hotel are your comfort zone but a one night stay would be very much recommended if you want to get a real feel fro the area. Its worth it to get the full picture of Lisbon.
Lovely. Plenty of lvoely views here. Be sure to take a walk up after visiting the castle. Lots of nice little food places and beautiful spots to relax and take in the incredible views.

Excellent-prepare to walk. If you are a history buff, enjoy unique architecture, cathedrals, art boutiques, and trendy cafes - Alfama is a MUST VISIT. However follow to recommendations regarding walking-pay close attention to your valuables. Get very good walking shoes. Of all the places my Mother and I visited in Portugal, Alfama was the most physically challenging. Very steep and uneven surfaces can be difficult if you have knee or hip problems. You have to stroll through feira da Ladra - nothing like it! Everything from old TV's, classic toys, tile trinkets galore, socks, shoes, clothes- a flea market on steroids. Beautiful place to take memorable pictures and end the day at a quaint cafe and enjoy fado.

Nice old neighborhood. Our host at the guest house suggested we take some time to just get lost in the Alfama, so we did just that. It was very quiet when we were there on a Sunday morning/afternoon. Just street after street of narrow little alleys with laundry hanging on the line. A mix of nice well kept buildings and run down abandoned ones.
Wonderful neighborhood. Great, older area for people watching and wandering the streets. Plenty of restaurants and cafés. Go to the flea market and catch a Fado show while you're here.
Must see in Portugal. Old town is very pleasant and obviously a must see. If you're not a fan of walking - take a tram 28. Otherwise it's a long but a worthy walkig tour, up and down.

so lucky to be staying here. We stayed in a beautiful little apartment overlooking the harbour and just walking out into the street you are immediatey immersed in the local life.....cafes, restaurants, bars, shops......wear comfortable shoes....everything is up or down!

Real Lisbon. Fascinating streets, high and so narrow. Stairways between different levels, having a map is almost pointless as you are best to follow your instincts. Beware of the traffic and especially the trams who do not swerve to avoid you ! So many interesting little buildings and shops you could spend forever wandering around except for the heat.

Fado Experience. We did a walking tour and discovered Fado (Portuguese typical melancholy music). Our guide took us to 2 wonderful lookouts (miradouros). The narrow streets were not destroyed in the earthquake of 1755 and remains a picturesque labyrinth of narrow streets and small squares.

A vibrant old town.. I like:1. The trams going up and down the hills in narrow and curved road. 2. Many small shops for discovery.3. Go up the hills to see the gorgeous view of Lisbon city. 4. Many old houses. 5. Houses are covered with beautiful ceremic tiles. 6. People are generally very nice. 7. Many local residents are still living there. Good!

The experience of culture and history of Lisbon. Friendly and fun. If you go there during the Santa festivals its amazing! Everybody is cooking some sardine drinking wine or beer the environment its so cozy and familiar you share food give food and bevareges. Awesome!
Run down, expensive, dirty. hard to find a bathroom, let alone a clean one. Forget about soap or toilet paper, or even a lock on the door.
alfama. nice neighborhood. hysterical. here was born 'fado' music.small streets and nice outlooks on the city of lisbon.many restaurants and bars. very popular. Pay a visit!

The old Lisbon. Lisbon is the most beautiful Capitals of whole Europe. In Alfama you get to see the old Lisbon, how it was like before the Great Earthquake of 1755, that destroyed almost the whole city. There you'll find the traditional Portugal. You may find in the summer traditional singers singing "fado da rua" fado of the road.

A look into the past. I ventured into Alfama right after landing in Lisbon as I read it had a lot of character and it does! I had read to start at the top and work my way down since it is on steep hills. I started from the bottom and unless you are in amazing shape I would refrain from doing this or walking it. The stone is also uneven and quite slick even when dry.I walked so that I could take it in and also photograph it's character. There are so many alley ways with character, crumbling buildings and laundry hanging between the buildings. If you do start at the bottom and cannot walk it take a Tuk Tuk! They give cheap 30min+ tours and stop at the sights up the hill. I did this half way up and thoroughly enjoyed it. It's an informal guide and they can tell you all about the history of the attractions and also stop off at other spots if you want other photos. It was 30euros for 30min. It's also fun to scoot around in these and take it all in. You could also take the famous Tram up as well, but these seemed packed and you do not get the personal attention but it is a more economical way of seeing the sights. I went towards sundown and very glad I did as I caught views with an amazing skyline and it was much cooler out.This is part of why I started at the bottom. I recommend early AM or late afternoon to beat the heat and the crowds but it is a must see!

Great old town, plenty of good food, fado goes as a dessert - what else would you need?. As a tourist, what are you looking for? How about really old streets going up and down on a hill (they are many centuries old, some are crumbling, some are pretty, some streets are very narrow, and some are steep, so it does feel authentic), plenty of restaurants serving actually good and cheap food and drinks and if you want something uniquely Portuguese - what can be more Portuguese than fado music (frankly, i'm not going to listen it while driving in a car any time soon, but if you happen to be there, why not)?Basically, there are really no good excuses, so you pretty much gotta go and check that place out. Ok, a few practical advices.First of all, the old town itself is beautiful, so it's totally fine just to walk around. Ladies, no heels or you will be sorry - it's cobblestone on steep slopes everywhere. Second, the food. There are two popular formats - a la carte where you pick what ever you like and, for the places with fado music, they commonly ask for a fixed priced pre fixed meal. Ask upfront and make sure you like the set. I don't eat pork and beef and it pretty much ruled out most of the meals. And, finally, most of the places do not accept credit cards. So bring some cash with you. It will also help if you decide to buy a flower or a song for your lady - there are a lot of bands and vendors offering their services around the tables.Enjoy your visit!
Excellent intro to Portuguese "fado". Music excellent and food not bad either . A bit of a tourist trap but we didn't mind cos we were tourists!

alfama. despite the numbers of tourists and trams it is still possible to meander through twisting passages and clamber up steps that have not changed in more then hundreds of years. Houses are piled up the slopes of alfama with small squares that come alive in the evenings with family get togethers. The local restaurants have been invigorated by the influx of tourists and it is always entertaining to watch cars negotiating the twists and turns of mediaeval passages.
lovely place. Great pleace of Lisbon, good restaurants and fado. The views are splendid, better on the evening to enjoy the sunset

Pittoresque. Coming from the Castelo de Sao Jorge, you should loose yourself in this pittoresque labyrinth neighborhood of small streets, cafés and restaurants.Don't forget to take a ride with Tram 28

Charming and steep. Nice area of the city, centered around the Miradouro de Santa Luzia. There's lots of fun parts to explore, from the Castelo de Sao Jorge to the National Museum of Decorative Arts, to all of the restaurants serving up food along with Fado music. I would avoid it on a hot day, as it does involve a ton of walking and the streets are STEEP. We only walked around part of it because it was so hot when we were in Lisbon - I don't regret it, but would have been fun to explore more during cooler weather. The location does offer up some amazing views, though.* If you like my review, I appreciate you clicking the 'helpful' button; those of us who take the time to write reviews live for those and it motivates us to do more :) *

always lovely to walk and eat here. At every visit in Lisboa, I can walk here for hours, everytime there is a surprise (newly painted houses in bright colours, interesting bar, good restaurant, music).

Best part of the city. This is one of the must see in Lisbon, day and night you'll have always something to do and see.this is the most historical part of the city.It was the main door of the city from the boats that come from the river, and you still can see many archeological remains from that time, and also see the life of that popular neighborhood, at night you will find bars and Fado houses.
Very quaint. Definitely do the historical tram tour, very good. Sorry I didn't spend another day or two up there.

Charming, but.... Yes, it has it's charm. Lots of it. Put your map in your bag and get lost. That's the only way you're going to find it. If you follow the roads you'll soon find yourself in something of a Venetian tourist inferno with so little authencity, you might as well sit at home and enjoy it on Google Earth (with no pickpockets or beggars who behave like something out of the Bible).
Nice place. I went there with friends and family .. I got some nice pic. That view was awesome ...sea view is also soo nice ... I love it ...

Magnificent old neighborhood. Absolutely loved wandering the streets alleys and climbing the stairs in the magnificant old neighborhood. Was easily able to spend three days exploring, forget the map, just wander around on foot.Some nice bars, restaurants and small eateries to come across, really enjoyed my time.

Alluring.... Alfama is a must do when in Lisbon. All the little alleys, pubs, restaurants and houses along the way are alluring. Its a maze of alleys which you must enjoy at a leisurely pace, engage a guide or go with a local who may be able to tell you interesting facts about the place as you amble around...
Fun to wander. Throw away those maps and just wander the streets to your hearts content. Narrow windy roads that seem to lead nowhere and yet surprises around every corner. Not to be missed
Old and amazing. Such an amazing place, definitely worth a visit while you are in Lisbon! Quirky and historical, with amazing views, not to be missed :)

Alfama. Alfama, old, run down and not well kept. It was quite disappointing to see that the pretty buildings are not maintained. The walls are peeling and some of the buildings look empty (without anyone staying inside) which gave me goosebumps.

Must see. Felt beautiful here and enjoyed every second. Historical quarter in Lisabon with numerous churches and small passages and alleys, you will find peace here and enjoy Lisbon. It is well connected with tram 28 by which you can pass entire alfama but you will better experience it by walking. Beautiful experience.
Don't miss Alfama when visiting Lisbon. It feels like the heart of the city, where true fado is played and sung, where you can get lost in a maze of passageways and staircases.

Alfama. Alfama is old quarter in Lisbon. There are castle Sao Jorge, cathedral Sé, many beautiful view points as Senhora do Monte and Graca when you maybe meet beautiful fashion model with evil eye. Through this quarter you can go by old yellow tram which is so old as all quarter. And in flea market on the Campo de Santa Clara you buy same charming knapsack as I. But wherever you are going you will be satisfied. It is Lisabon. Petra Bačovská
Beautiful old city place. This beautiful old city place is a must see!! Wonderful views at the Tejo river as well the real atmosphere of fado verses in Alfama narrow streets.

Beautiful historic neighborhood with wonderful cultural highlights. At first sight, this is a delightful old neighborhood with narrow streets and alleys, providing a clue into what the city looked and felt like several hundred years ago. And when you come in the evening, this is the classical center of the Fado houses, the traditional Portuguese music that is at the same time melancholy and beautiful. An absolute must-see for any visitor to Lisbon.

Lisbon`s Oldest Living Quarters!. Alfama is Lisbon`s oldest living in quarter in which once the very rich of the Christians,Jews & Arabs lived together.Seeing the present dilapilated condition of some of the houses & streets one can`t imagine that once the elite of lisbon lived here! Now an unique old times atmosphere prevails in the streets & the whole area!As i wandered through the labyrinth of winding narrow alleys,small archways & little flight of steps; i encountered many idyllic corners & picturesque images. With different sounds & smells every where as the residents live most of their lives on the streets.From the balconies/windows of bright colored houses hang equally bright clothes,numerous flower pots & cages with canaries singing!No cars can possibly enter this area full of narrow lanes & one is thrown back to a bygone era of 19th century with sad `Fado`Portuguese songs & music being played from the small bars dishing out port wine to the customers.Many tourists love this romantic past & flock its lanes which gives the quarters financial support for the maintenance & improvement of this area.If you can take a long walk & prefer such atmosphere then do visit this place.

Must see!. The Alfama district in Lisboa is a lovley place with narrow streets: Me an d my family did use a day walking about in this streets . it was an unique place to be . If you are in Lisboa this sould be mandatory to visit.!

A great workout. The small streets, the wash hanging above you out of the windows, the historic buildings and most of all: the atmosphere. If you walk up to the Castelo de Sao Jorge you have a workout in combination with a view which makes it great.

touristic but must see. take the tram up to the highest point and stroll down the narrow roads, stunning views, interesting atmosphere. Some say it's unsafe at night, but I felt safe. Just be cautious as in alll other cities around the world.
Hills. Have a walk in the Alfama, you go up and down and have very nice streets. Look around and see the houses around you.

Preferred other places in lisbon!!. This is a warren of narrow streets with stairs, some very narrow... It isnt, however, one of a kind.. There are places similar to this in sciliy and Valletta in Malta. Once there, I wasn't sure if there was something specific to see, perhaps I missed something here.. The best bits were the view at the top (tram 28) and people barbecuing food on street corners!!!

The best of Lisbon, a REAL cultural experience. We rented an apartment in Alfama for 5 days while visiting Lisbon and are so glad this is where we stayed. After visiting the Baixa/Chiado and Bairro Alto and Belem, Alfama offers you a real cultural experience. The history, the locals, the fado cafés, the winding narrow streets, the sight seeing, the trams and mirodouro (lookout points) offer you a true sense of how Lisbon started. Loved being here.

Put on your hiking shoes!. This neighborhood qualifies as one of the best urban hikes in the world. Put on sturdy, supportive shoes and be prepared to get delightfully lost as you traverse the winding alleyways this historic quarter. There are some amazing views to be had in all directions.
Great environment. Beautiful architecture. Great restaurants including vegetarian and vegan options. Plenty of places for stunning views of the city.
fun!. we were there during the celebrations for san Antonia, which made this area full of little colorful stalls on the the street with barbecues, drinks and lots of music!!!

Walk & view. There are no signs, so clutch the map you get when you buy a ticket. Go early or late for short lines and great skies. It's on the highest of 7 hills, so I was huffing & puffing by the time I got to the gate. A herd (if that is the right term) roost right above the cafe & make a horrible racket. The tables are under canopies so you don't have to worry about droppings in your coffee

Old Lisbon. This area has lots of small streets and old houses, and a lot of little restaurants too. On small squares one can see the local people , sitting on benches and exchanging the latest gossip. Most of them are a bit older. It's amazing how these people manage to get around here as the streets are very steep. Therefore it's better to start your visit at the top (e.g. at the castle) and slowly walk down. For those interested in fado, there are quite a few restaurants where fado is sung from around 6 pm onwards, but the prices in these restaurants are higher than in the rest of the city. The Fado Museum is also located in this district.
A "must visit" in Lisbon. We walked around in this area after visiting the Sao Jorge castle. The area is very atmospheric and we found a tiny passageway where we had a simple, but very good lunch.

Must see. We spent more than a day in Alfama. Best to take your taxi to the middle or top and work your way through its winding streets. Amazing cathedrals, lovely shops, friendly people, great restaurants, fabulous tile, and great views of the city. Beware that Fado club owners are a bit like perfume shop owners in Cairo--each one is trying to lure you into his/her Fado club (at least during high tourist season).
Better to view it from above. Narrow streets climing up. No special atmosphere but good view of roofs from upper level. Quite disapponted trying to find old times atmsphere.

A great experience . It is a great place to visit. With the colors and ambience of one of the oldest if not the oldest "bairros" of Lisbon.The Tok-Tok are not original from this place but also give an amazing contribution to the scenario.

Old spirit of Lisbon. Small streets, old houses and fado that sounds anywhere.The neighborhood is famous with a lot of tourists.There are many small restaurants that night are filled with young people.

The real thing. We took a taxi to the very top of Alfama, where the castle begins. Afterwards, we simply strolled down with stores and restaurants on the side, trying to avoid incoming cars. It truly is beautiful, and is a really refreshing change from downtown Lisbon. You could easily spend the day here.

Real Lisbon!. I could walk around Alfama for days, it is a truly beautiful place and still has a lot of charm to offer, with its small winding streets and cobbled paths. I would recommend visiting Alfama in the evening time and visiting one of the many bars/restaurants, it is a lot cheaper than other areas in Lisbon. Steer clear of the Fado places that offer expensive meals and charge you to hear their live music, instead choose a bar close by such as Ginja D'Alfama or Medrosa D'Alfama.

Walk around, pick a restaurant/bar and enjoy it. Great city walk with great restaurants and bars to have a drink or food.Dont miss the castle and the cathedral though which would take a couple of hours of your day.

Beautiful place. You need to be ready to walk uphill on uneven roads, but it's a charming part of town with nice restaurants and a beautiful castello. We went for a dinner with fado at Tasca do Jaime da Graca (rua da Graca 91) and it was well worth it.

Real Lisbon. This is not a Disney theme park. These are the working people of Lisbon. Their parish had won for the St. Antony festival the evening before and were still recovering. I enjoyed meeting real peopl and see how real people lived. Interesting to see vestiges of the medieval city.

A must see (&walk). While taking the tram is charming, walking allows you to explore more of the charming streets with their shops, restaurants and people. You'll find some well priced food along with some touristy priced food. Just look for a place with a bunch of locals, you'll be fine :)

Old Lisbon... the best place to go in a summer night. Alfama is considered to be the "Old Lisbon".In June you have a lot of local parties there (at night) and during all summer you should go there to eat in an outside place.Besides, if you want to ear Fado, the best places to do it are in Alfama (it has more than 10 "Fado Houses").
