The real Lisboa.... Lisboa truly stands out among other European capitals. Alfama is the area that makes it really unique. If you can see beyond roughness around the edges, some extra garbage and dog poop (which you can see in pretty much any big city in Europe) - you will be dazzled with the quiet beauty of the area...Only here you can have a meal for two - fresh fish, veggies and 0,5L of the excellent house wine for 12Euro. If you wish to sit outside - just ask - they will take your table under the big large tree... Yes, menu is not in English but you can easily figure it out... We actually stayed in one of the Alfama's self catering apartments. It had a patio overlooking Pantheon. It was dead quiet at night under the starry skies of Lisboa...

Great experience!. Charming area, tons of small shops, fado bars, winding narrow roads, cobblestone galore, and tons of graffiti and street art. I enjoyed it thoroughly. It a lot of hard walking but truly the best way to see it if you are able. If not, there are other options, bus, guides, etc..

My favorite place in Lisbon. Lisbon is a beautiful and very interesting city, and I liked every piece of it. Walking around I often thought, - Oh, yes! This is the most beautiful! ; Oh, yes! This is the most exciting!; Oh, yes! This is the most interesting place of it-, till I went to Aflama.First we got on the tram 28 and from there we could see the Lisbon Cathedral. We found that it is definitely deserves a stop and some investigation. Unluckily the original cathedral from the 13th century was mostly destroyed by the earthquake in 1755. After it was partially rebuild and thanks to the latest renovation it is a beautiful old church again, even if we know, that mostly it isn't that old as it looks like.Our next stop was the Miradouro de Santa Luzia .From there I had the view over Alfama till the Tagus River. Now we were ready for a proper , face to face visit.When we started to walk around I felt, that I just found the part of Lisbon, I was always looking for. The spirit of this old suburb was so overwhelmingly strong and exquisite, that I just wanted to stay and stay and see more and more of it, or just sit in a little shabby coffee shop and watch the life going around me. If I’ll be lucky enough to go back to Lisbon for the third time, this will be the place I’ll revisit for sure. shabby coffee shop and watch the life going around me. If I’ll be lucky enough to go back to Lisbon for the third time, his will be the place I’ll revisit for sure.
Best part of Lisbon!. Such a beautiful part of Lisbon. Rustic and relaxed. We fell asleep to local Fado singers singing their hearts out in local restaurants. I will be back.

Best stroll in town.. Wonderful for walking/strolling. This is where the "quiet" restaurants and Fado bars are located. Enjoy in the late afternoon when its a bit cooler. The trolleys will go there but you can walk from downtown.

Beautiful district!. This district facing the ocean is a beautiful area. Small streets, old crammed buildings with colourful doors and flowers everywere. Its possible to walk thru it if you first take the tram to the top and then just walk down thru the cozy streets where locals live and work. Charming neighbourhood

Earliest part of Lisbon. Alfama is the oldest part of Lisbon that survived the 1755 earthquake and as such is made up of small cobbled streets that hug the hill near the castle. Today is has many small restaurants and cafes. You will need your walking shoes to manage the hills.

This is the real Lisbon. Small winding streets, lots of steep steps and not much overtly 'touristy' scene... my friend who usually opts for more elegant surroundings insisted that we book accommodations in this neighborhood next trip... since this was the local experience he loves... although not sure how he'll do with the steps!!!

Quaint Look into the past. Alfama was fun to visit to see what Lisbon looked like pre-fire. If you go, I'd recommend bringing a tour guide so you see the best parts. The streets are narrow and winding and are probably best seen on foot on in a smaller vehicle like the tuk-tuks. We walked and enjoyed every minute of it. Beautiful scenery and a great way to see Portugal from an 'every day' view point.
the most beautiful part of Lisbon. winding streets, small alley ways, fado, wine bars, small shops. wonderful! it is a great area to get lost in….

Where fado originated.. This is one of the oldest areas of Lisbon.. An area that barely got damaged during the massive earthquake in the 1700's.. It's now a area of lisbon where mostly older people live.. It has a village feel inside a city. Make sure to visit a restaurant with fado being performed here!
Lisbon Historic Sight. A great walk through the cobblestone alleys. A good way to see where Fado singers and seaman from years gone by.

Wonderful charm. No better place to walk without a map, wandering about tiny alleys, walking up and down steep hills. Just great! Be sure to catch tram 28, the famous Lisbon tram that rattles about Alfama, past the Castle Sao Jorge and into the Cidade Baixo
Colorful. Nice place to walk, eat or drink. It's colorful and friendly. Don't plan, just wander around and get lost in the small cobblestone streets.

Best place to stay in Lisbon. We stayed in a one bedroom apartment 2 flights up in the Alfama district for one week. It was grand and really the most authentic place to stay. The other areas are like many modern cities so why do that? This is an authentic experience. We hung our laundry up outside and were across the street from a great Fado restaurant owned by a woman and she and the waitresses sang from 8pm to midnight and had the customers join in. It was great. You can just walk around the area and it is so interesting and lovely with terraces and small shops.
Interesting. It's worth the climbing.In the evening an night its full of good and not expensive restaurants and Fado shows.We enjoyed a good dinner and a good show

The Alfama is a must-see; charming, full of history, sights, views, local color, cafes and restaurants. Allow plenty of time to wander the winding ancient streets. Wear comfortable shoes to climb the many hills. It's easy to get lost, but you'll always find your way eventually. The historic houses and churches, with gorgeous tiles are wonderful; many hilltops have spectacular views, often with a cafe nearby, so you can relax and take in the scenery. The Castle of St George is at the top of one of the hills; and the cathedral (the Se) is about halfway up. Both are great choices for sightseeing. Most importantly, just soak up the local scene.

Worth walking through, take your time. Wandered through this area a number of times; quaint, old architecture and features; a number of lovely churches (including the cathedral); lots of small bars and restaurants - covering all budgets.

Old, chill, and scenic. I actually lived for a while next to Alfama. Some of my favourite reading spots are located here, as you can easily find public balconies, or benches, that look over part of the city. The buildings are quaint, and most of the small shops are worth visiting.

Unique atmosphere. Alfama is the oldest district of Lisbon, spreading on the slope between the São Jorge Castle and the Tejo river. Its name comes from the Arabic Al-hamma, meaning hot fountains or baths ,It has a very unique atmosphere .
Walk around. The best place in Lisbon to just walk around and get lost! Chill in the tiny plazas, have some wine or pop into a small restaurant.

just wander and get lost!. We started off trying to plan a route through this maze of alleyways going up and down hills but gave up and just went with the flow. We eventually got out by following the tram line - after spending an interesting half hour watching the mechanics try to get a 28 tram back on the rails after it had crashed on a bend!

Feeling like a royal couple . We were just walking up and down the road to the citadel, the 28 tram was frequently passing besides us, a lot of pictures and beautiful people, a relaxing and enjoyable moments.

Old world living in Lisbon. Charming.. My son and I spent a week living in a condo in the heart of Alfama - the oldest section of Lisbon. I'm in my 50s and staying there took me back to the simplicity and innocence of my childhood. I'd wake in the morning to hear light strains of a solo guitarist drifting into my room. I'd walk out on the narrow, hilly, and winding streets and watch women sweeping dirt off the pavements in front of their house with straw brooms..or marvel at the colourful clothes hanging on clothes lines outside windows.Towards the evening I'd watch the old lady in the small shop across the lane sit outside and keep tabs on the comings and goings of the folks in the neighbourhood, and happily chatting with the customers coming in the shop, or regular faces from the 'hood. I'd delight in the wide grin of an elderly gentleman who seemed escatitic of the sale he made to me in his tiny closet of a shop on a side street.Later I'd walk up the steep hill - almost grazing by a passing streetcar - to a small hillside lookout overlooking the city and bay of Lisbon and the Castle of S.Jorge and watch the gorgeous sunset.Finally at night I'd pass by the small cafes and hear diners singing along with entertainers playing music fado style well into the night. Soaking up the sensations of this place and time are what sweet memories are made of.

If there's one place you can visit in Lisboa - make it Alfama. The winding steep cobblestone streets, with restaurants and small shops all around are what makes this district special.There are a few miradouro (viewpoints) to see the district, there's obviously the big castle Sao Jorge on top of the hill and many more things to visit.Just remember to wear confortable shoes in summer - not flip-flops, as you'll be walking around a lot.Also, if you come in, don't do it directly from the waterfront, as the traffic on the winding road near the water is horrendous. Start walking up following the 28 tram line (or any other route).

Old City. This is one of the oldest parts of the city that survived the earthquakes. You go through it seeing a number of Churches and on you climb to the Castle. It is a neat and charming area, if a little seedy in spots.

Nice walk through alley ways with local flavor. Take tram 28 (but watch your personal items) or better yet walk up. it's not that strenuous. Great views at top. Visit the castle. Some nice souvenir stores are located by the castle with better than usual merchandise. Spend a while meandering through the narrow streets.

View point Portas do Sol. From the viewpoint Portas do Sol, you can see the all the typical Alfama district that spans several narrow winding streets to the River Tagus. The viewpoint Portas do Sol is a balcony type area with a magnificent view of the city of Lisbon and Tagus River. There are lots of small quiosques arround where you can seat and enjoy this magnificant view. There are also small shops around with nice souveniers and also lots of historical places to visit.
Beautiful district and castle. A must see.. The Alfama district is beautiful and makes a great walk with gorgeous views over the whole of Lisbon. We walked up to the castle which is a must see.
Winding Twisting Haven. Magnificent sights and sounds as you wonder back in time through these incredible streets. Highly recommend a walk around here, it exudes culture and history.

Old World Lisbon. If you are traveling to Lisbon, seeing the Alfama district is a must. With charming twisting and turning back alleys and the No. 28 winding its way down crooked streets its not to be missed.
Must go too. You can not miss this area. Just below Santa Cruz, it's do able as an extension to a castle trip. Winding streets, loads of cafés. Very hilly so great off burning off those meals.

Very pictoresque place. Nobody ca visit Lisboa without going to Alfama. Many restaurants, bars and a wonderful view of the city. Only be attentive when you take the tram to get there. Many pickpockets!

Can't help but get lost!. Be prepared to walk and climb but it is so worth it. This is the oldest and poorest part of Lisbon. Very authentic, which so much atmosphere. Cobblestones, winding streets that dead end, little restaurants with only four or five tables. Music drifts dow the winding streets. Before or after you visit Castelo St. Jorge spend time taking in the Alfama.
So....different!. A village inside the city! It is totally different and very peaceful compared to the city centre. You have to visit on foot, so as to gain an insight of local, traditional, living!
Nightlife. Lots of small crowded cobbled streets, quiet during the day but comes alive at night! Loads of restaurants, bars and street food stalls.

First stop. For your first view of Lisbon, I would take the 28 tram to Alfama and walk around the area old city. Definitely take the time to visit St. George's Castle and have lunch over looking the city at their restaurant. This was one of the highlights of the trip.

Take your time.... Take your time, walk around, don't look for anything specific and discover all that shows up in front of you! If you like architecture, you may find soem very interesting typical urban buildings. People live in a more intimate community in this part of town and, don't forget, the Tagus is always there around each corner! ;-)

actually not so spectacular. we were there 1 full day, not so spectacular view, not so nice restaurants, interesting line Tram 28 - which is also a symbol of the city. A littl;e bit crowded, a little bit insecure because of the thieves

Piece of authentity. I was told by the guide that I will like the place, and he was damn right. In some way very similar to my home Odessa patios, here all the life of Alfama and it's inhabitants is happening just around you on the street. I'd recommend to start from the top, from Castle, and go all the way down without hurry, enjoying your time and trying to use your "Alfama e linda!" on every local you'll met. Probably, you'll end up drinking with them. And for the evening it's highly recommended to lounge around Alfama main street, where you can hear Fado from every cafe, no matter is it expensive or very cheap.

Charming. Very pleasant to stroll around this pretty and interesting area.The narrow streets are a delight to wander through.We walked down into the area after a visit to the castle.Wonderful views of the city,some nice little restaurants.Be sure to wear comfy shoes.

Charming neighborhood. We stayed in the Alfama neighborhood on our 4 day visit to Lisbon and loved it! The winding roads lead to delicious restaurants and beautiful views of the city. It has a more local feel even though there are plenty of tourists exploring. The 28 streetcar takes you all through the neighborhood and is a good way to get around from other parts of Lisbon. Highly recommend staying here or at least visiting the neighborhood!
Very pretty and traditional. Loved all the colourful houses and the little alleyways. Also visited Castelo de Sao Jorge, which provided stunning views over Lisbon.

Totally Charming. This district is calmer, traditional and very charming. There are a lot of old structures and stunning architecture to see while wandering through the narrow and winding streets.The perch to view the river and back onto the city is beautiful. This area has the vistas and backdrop for spectacular pictures. There can be streets that are not touristy at all giving this a unspoiled charm to this area.There are stunning churches with many having services while open to viewing. We were fortunate to see a religious parade of hundreds after a service honoring St. Anthony. This is definitely a stop for the entire day when in the LIsbon area.
Beautiful part of the city not to be missed. We toured Alfama on Segway, which really took the sting out of the hill's. Fantastic to see the oldest parts of Lisbon.

Beautiful neighborhood. We took a walk and let ourselves get lost in the labyrinth on beautiful small streets of this ancient part of Lisbon. It`s a trip back in time - pagan, Arabic and Christian cultures, all beautifully put together to create the most wonderful mixture of southern Europe. Try the little restaurants here, like the "O Cantinho da Rute" which can give you a great traditional Portuguese culinary experience.

the real Lisbon. Climb the Alfama quarter, enjoy Portugese music and the small streets. It's a cooling trip on a hot summer's day. The streets, cafés, restaurants, small houses... it is all there! A city within the city

You have to see it to believe it. Stunning area of Lisbon that is well worth both a stroll (a VERY steep stroll, mind!) and a tram ride (#28) through.That said, it was quite obvious that parts of Alfama are also very poor, and that not all residents love the streams of tourists wandering through and taking pictures of their homes.Definitely go and enjoy both the cute cobbled TINY streets, and the stunning views of the city and river, just be mindful of the people living there :)

This is the place to walk. Take the small streets and get lost. This is the old part of Lisbon and worth the exploration. Lots of interesting architecture here, many shops and not many tourists. Just wander and enjoy. If you are staying in the Biaxa area or close, it is not far away.
What a wiew. This place close to downtown easy to find,unic wiew to city and water full of tourist,few good restaurants,don't eat the tapas before meal you will pay for it and not cheap

Like a movie set. We only spent two hours in Alfama but would love to go back. You could easily spend half a day roaming the narrow cobblestone streets, some so narrow you they were more like a sidewalk. When we stopped for a beer at a tiny café (literally like a hole in the wall) the people were friendly and everything was cheaper than anywhere else in Lisbon. The roads are a maze but you can't get too lost because you can usually see where the ocean is at the bottom and find your way back to the central Commercial Plaza. Our experience here balanced a negative impression of the Restauradores area where they actively fleece tourists.
The place where fado was born. The place where fado was born and maybe one of the most traditional places in the all city. I recommend the visit to see the true Lisbon.

Great place to stay. We are staying in this area, next to the church. There are some fantastic bars, restaurants and shops nearby. Highly recommend staying in an apartment in the area. Lots to see and do, and safe and friendly atmosphere.

an interesting place to walk around. you can get a real feeling of the life and caracter of lisbon - each little street and corner is even more interesting when you go to the flee market on saturdays and mondays or when you go to the little corner restaurants in the evenings after 18.00pm

Picturesque, but wear good shoes. Pretty streets decked out for the feast of St. Anthony (June). Windy and hilly but the 737 bus from town or tram will get you up the hill and you can walk back down easily enough.

Worth a visit. This old area of Lisbon is quaint and authentic with old buildings in various states of (dis)repair. Walking along its charming narrow, winding alleys is like a step back in time, except for the litter and graffiti.

Quaint windy streets - easy to get lost. We were here out of season, in February, and whilst the weather was pretty poor, there was still a distinct feeling and atmosphere to this district, different to that of the rest of the city.Lovely little narrow streets, often steep and mostly cobbled, with various view points over the rest of the city. If you don't feel like walking, take tram 28 through the Alfama. A journey on the old wooden tram up the narrow, steep streets is an experience in itself! It wasn't particularly busy, being out of season, and as such it did not feel too touristy. It's also a nice walk up through the Alfama, to the Castel S.Jorge, which is equally worth a visit.
Wonderful view. The beautiful view is breathtaking and the area is charming! Arriving there with the tramway 28, a classic route.

Best area in Lisbon. An amazing place to take a stroll! Its the oldest and most well preserved part of the city. Take the tram No. 28 to Alfama and then enjoy a walk to the numerous good viewpoints. Lots of good places to eat Portuguese food. A must visit when in Lisbon!
Too touristy. Lots of hills and little shops. Too touristy for us. Worth a visit for a few hours. Beware the street hawkers.
Quaint section of town. The being oldest section of the city, there are many quaint & charming buildings along narrow & winding medieval streets. Very steep hills; not for the 'out-of-shape'

Walking. A perfect spot to walk around, near the Cruise Ships dock. You can choose from several spots to have a meal, from fish to meat and see the traditional tiles on the walls of most of the houses and buildings.

Picturesque Neighborhood. Definitely my favorite neighborhood in Lisbon. Winding streets with narrow alleys, laundry lines dangling between open shutter windows, cobblestone roads centuries old, you'll find yourself lost and roaming aimlessly. But that's the beauty of the red-roofed district of Alfama because getting lost is the best way to explore. Go off the beaten path and meander through alleys not charted on maps, and while you'll find plenty of dead ends, you won't regret stumbling upon the countless vistas overlooking the city that afford you the best panoramas in town. Pack good shoes, a map, some cold water, and go on an adventure.
Dont miss it. Is one of the oldest neighborhoods in lisbon (befor the big fire), full of little and charming streets... perfect place to go at night and listen Fado (traditional protugues music)
Alfama. We stayed in an apartment on a little back street in Alfama. Lots of very busy nightlife. Did not keep us awake. The people we met and talked to are really friendly.

Get the village feeling of Lisbon!. The Alfama is the neighborhood of the ordinary people, those with the small Budgets. It feels great to see and enjoy, almost like strolling through a village. Nice little neighbourhood restaurants with local food.

Shabby and authentic. You can spend some considerable time meandering through the narrow cobbled streets of this area. The views are fantastic and the buildings are on the whole pretty ramshackle which makes it all the more appealing - authentic rather than painted nicely for the tourists.

Picturesque and old world charming. This is one of the oldest parts of Lisbon, also where we are staying. There are many little shops, museum, many bars & resturants. There is also a lot of stairs every where, but it is well worth seeing and the climb! Very warm in June, no coats or sweaters needed, only cool clothing day and night!
old part of the city. very lovely panoramic views and narrow streets. A nice tour with tram 28! Also in the neighborhood: castelo st george.

Great Recreation Park. We went for a site seeing and had good time  walking on the long large park with places to eat and drink very relaxing place to visit walk and seat as one wishes.the scenery is pleasant as we can see the houses on the hill and the activities of the locals.We had fun on a good relaxing afternoon as we end up in middle of busy city of Lisbon.
marvelous. many small alleys, courts, bars and restaurants. Wonderful photo opportunities. Funny graffiti. Beautiful handicraft shops.

Authentically Rustic. Alfama covers a wide area and I stayed in an apartment on Rua Santa Antonia which is just up the (steep) hill from Santa Apollonia train station. This is a working class district of the city and has a number of local family restaurants, chicken shops and bars scattered around. The flea market that is held every Tuesday and Saturday is a must see when you are in this area. People are selling everything and its always bustling and a lovely way to spend a couple of hours. The market is also held around National Pantheon and São Vicente de Fora Church which are worth seeing. It's also easy to walk over to the Sao Jorge Castle from Alfama. The only problem we had in this area was with the amount of dogs dirt on the pavements. People don't clean up after their dogs which I think is disgusting and you have to be very careful where you walk and look out for your children. Apart from that I loved Alfama and Lisbon and I hope to return one day.

Very quaint and pretty. It's just off the main street, lots of small shops and restaurants. It's relatively a small area, you can see a lot of it in just a few hours. Lots of color and alleys to explore.

very beautiful neighbourhood. I really enjoyed the Aflama neighbourhood, it reflects the portuguese spirit with all the small streets, the graffiti, the market...you cannot visit lisbon without visiting Alfama! I recommend that you do it with a tour because they would explain the history and culture of the place. I recommend that you do it with wild walker free tours

the best sardins in lisboa. Iam here right now, cant belive the beauty of this town,music, food, happy people, the best, but be ready for the stairs, I have to go up 86 steps to my studio apartment, , it is worth it .

Alfama District. This area was part of our city tour with "Around Lisbon". It was great. Very old, very historic. The stories are wonderful. Our driver drove us up as far as he could and then we walked. Lots of steps and steepness but he slowed it down for us when necessary. Be sure to go.
pitoresque. Beautiful little neighbouhood with fado singing taverns, and friendly people, ginginha (a cherry liquor) seems to be mandatory around here.
Interesting area. Meander around the narrow streets for a couple of hours. It's one of the oldest and poorest areas of Lisbon and it's hard to remember you're in a capital city
Amazing view. It was our last day in Lisbon when we finally wandered over to Alfama and were amazed by the views. We stopped for a glass of wine and just soak in the view. Don't miss this!

TRADITIONAL LITTLE STREETS AND HOUSES. Beware take a map, easy to get lost. Went to the Tuesday market here, Feira day Ladra, more of a trash and treasure style with antiques and tourist items thrown in for a bit of something new. Was huge, had a good hour or so wandering around but, don't know how many 1000's of outdated mobile phones, batteries and chargers one would need. Probably more trash than treasure. Interesting atmosphere.

the living labyrinth. a otherwise lost atmosphere lingers on the streets, my favorite place in Lisbon for going up and down the streets in the dark of the night... except if you go there for the month of June, where there's no more lively place in Lisbon than Alfama, people, sangria and sardines will crowd the place

You will love it or hate it!. We stayed in this area so got to know it well. It was not affected by the earthquake so remains pretty much as it was. Look beyond the obvious and you will come to love it. Some fantastic places to eat and listen to Fado. If you are visiting in June spend an evening there - the locals decorate the street with tinsel, make make shift restaurants and cook sardines! it all looked very interesting as they were getting ready for this annual celebration.

A Must Do In Lisbon. No visit to Lisbon is complete without a walk through the Alfama, be sure to have a good guide book or better yet a good guide or you will miss many of the hidden gems of this area

Old Lisbon. We took a tuk-tuk and was shown this area,was excellent and fun.busy area but beautiful with very narrow cobbled streets ,we did a port tasting and bought some jams and portSaw many beautiful cathedrals and churches,views from the top were excellent
Get lost in another Milennia. Walk through a maze of ancient streets up to a breathtaking view of Lisbon. A great way to spend a day exploring.

Like a city within a city. This is old Lisbon, like a small charming old city within a new modern Lisbon. We took a taxi up to the top of Alfama, as 3 cruise ships were in that day, and everybody wants to take Tram 28. Walked around the uneven streets to the sound of Fado pouring out the little stores and bars. We stopped at a couple of small bars for a local beer and found the more touristica places, where everyone wants to sit and watch other tourists are three times the price. Walked down and asked a local store owner where he eats and found a local restaurant with outside seating and wonderful authentic Portuguese food. Did forget the name, but the seafood in Lisbon is second to none.
Fascinating.. Old world narrow streets full of character. Disliked steep hills in the heat! Better to go early morning.

Fado old district with Tejo sightseeing towards South. Beautiful quarters along one the Lisboa seven hills facing Tejo river towards South. Walking safe and pleasant, several small spots to eat and drink since the early morning until late night. Some very good spots in Lisboa to enjoy Fado. Don't miss discovering the several sightseeing spots at the top, the small and more traditional restaurants, and the hidden local Fado houses by night...

Best Tourist Area in Lisbon. The best way to see the Alfama is to hop on Tram 28 at the Praca de Commerio and ride the little trams up to the top near the Castle. Get off and walk to the mirador and enjoy the beautiful views of city or grab a seat at the many outdoor cafes and enjoy the scenery and people watching witha half bottle of wine.Then take a tram downhill, back to where you came.

A walk back in time. The city of Lisbon offers a wide variety of places very well preserved that conects you with history without feeling you're in a degraded place. Alfama is one of this places. Just walk around the streets to be suprised every time. Always something new to discover.

The historical heart of old Lisbon. These old parts of Lisbon are very peculiar. They show how this city is so different from european capitals. Worth while seeing. There we can see the origins. The place, the people and the fado.

Cool part of town. I thought that part of town was cool cause its the oldest and has a hip vibe to it. Sort of like Brooklyn of Lisboa. I only give it a 3 star because we simply didnt do much there. We didn't eat there, spend time there, or shop there. We went to visit the castle and decided to walk that part of town too. We were supposed to have lunch there but we couldn't find the place and it started pouring rain. So, we ran into any cafe we could find and it was outside the Alfama. Its got neat buildings and history......I just cant give any higher than 3 cause I dont have much in the way of advise. Is it worth visiting.......Sure.

Must see part of Lisbon. Oldest part of Lisbon not destroyed by the historic earthquake. I highly recommend walking through the narrow cobblestone streets on the way to Castle St George. If you want a different take, hire a segway and a tour guide and give your legs a rest.

A historical hill area. With Bairro Alto, this is the second historical area of Lisbon that is definitely worth exploring. This is the hill where the old Moorish castle stands. It has steep & narrow streets & alleys. The best is to explore this charming & picturesque area on foot. The best is to take some kind of public transport all the way up to the citadel and then start slowly to walk downhill and admire the fascinating side of this old area.
wonderful old part of town. Very small, narrow streets, which you can get lost in, but that is half the fun. Don't miss the castle.

Windy, beautiful roads. A lovely sector of Lisbon, Alfama is a great place to walk around and explore. A lot of little shops and cafes if you need something to eat, plus gorgeous architecture. You get the feeling you've stepped back in time.
If you visit the castle, walk back down through this district!

Very pretty and definitely a must visit. This place lived up to its expectation. Take Tram no 28 from near chiado and get off before the tram takes a left turn (exiting Alfama and going towards Martinez). We had a drink in a couple of places at the top and the view from the top was really great. For some great pictures, find a convenient spot in a cafe/bar and take pictures of the tram when they are crossing each other
windy small streets. The area is old and has many windy streets. The area is worth walking around - interesting area and worth a look.

Lovely place to stumble across a great local bar. it is easy to get temporarily lost in the narrow streets of Alfama but they are lovely & we stumbled across a lovely bar, never to be found again. Ladies waved at us as we made our way through the streets. It is also possible to view Alfama from the old number 28 tram
Loved it. Really enjoyed the small lanes, little shops, places to sit and drink while enjoying the views. Its just the relaxed and authentic vibe you feel when strolling along.

What an Amazing place. I loved it at Alfama, came here to visit George Castle, dinner and lunch for week of May 10th. Its a lot of walking up and down the mountain, but well worth the scenic views. It's a beautiful old town and the people are incredibly friendly.

Get lost. Get lost in Alfama, and eventually you find yourself... Walk uphill, downhill, zig zag... Every alley, escadinhas, even dead ends, they have interesting... Art is on the walls, with photographs of the locals, graffiti, paintings, decorative cobble stones, tiles.... Walk at night for a different feels...

Step into a different world.. Old fashioned shops, fado houses, local bars and restaurants give this old, Moorish district a life and character all it's own. It is a tough climb on cobbled streets but the views over Lisbon and these a are worth it.
Watch your belongings. Just different and some great little bars, cafés etc try the tram through area but don't eat at top bit in square place we tried - rip off

Delicious romp through this marvellous ethnic district. Looking around us,its difficult to swallow the idea that this 'hood was the most desirable quarter in Lisbon,many aeons ago. Sure,i can appreciate the fact that fear of earthquakes in the Middle Ages saw the rich folk desert this quarter to make way for fishermen and paupers. So let's skip to the latter part of the 20th century and explore the Kasbah-like layout which is still evident around here. Compact houses line steep streets and stairways,their windows strung with washing. Be that as it may, daily life still revolves around grocery stores and the fabulous small,cellar-like tavernas. There is an antique tram that runs through parts of this district,but its in the afternoon that the joint starts jumping,coming to life when the locals like gophers emerge out of their doorways and start filling the tavernas. Given the steepness of the streets and the steps,the trick is to start at the top and work your way down. A walk around the maze of winding alleyways will reveal picturesque corners and crumbling facades of houses,churches as well as,panoramic views from shady terraces,such as the Miradouro de Santa Luzia. I like to stop on the large Das portas do Sol,for a coffee and those divine pastries and look over the rooftops to the Tagus estuary. This converted rooftop is a pit-stop essential for your survival. Drop down a street and check out the Museu de Artes Decorativas to see the superb craftsmanship of the 17th and 18th century Portuguese furniture and decorative arts. Its also a marker of the of the styles inherent in the textiles,silver,ceramics as well as,furniture,all housed in a handsome mansion,the Palacio Espirito Santo Silva,inside of which are rich examples of gaming tables,silver collections and Chinese ceramics. In the adjoining building live artisans demonstrate their expertise in cabinet-making,book- binding,gilding and traditional crafts. Fascinating place. Keep heading downwards and you spot the stalls of the Thieves market, in a shady haven,laid-out under the canopy of trees. If you are a bargain-hunter,forget finding a gem among the bric-a brac, however your in luck if you are into wrought iron work,tiles,prints and second hand clothes. What i became aware of was how much was out of Africa....masks,statuary and jewellery . There is a good fish and veggie and herb market. Its lively and engaging. One of Lisbon's most striking landmarks,the soaring dome of Santa Engrecia punctuates the skyline,famous for taking a long time to get built....from 1681 to 1966. the interior is paved with coloured marble and has a giant cupola. Take the lift up to the dome to see a 360 degree panorama of the city. great for orienting yourself.

Get lost!. Our walking tour guide said get lost in Alfama and he meant it! You can just wander around finding side streets, courtyards, people hanging out washing or grilling fish in the street. See if you can find the lady who makes her own sour cherry liqueur - yummy! Tastes a bit like Tia Maria.

Not to be missed. If you're visiting the beautiful city of Lisbon this is an area you must visit. It's on the slopes of leading up to the castle and is a maze of tiny narrow streets. Very atmospheric and packed with little cafes and shops. A different view round every corner.

Lisbon predating the 1755 earthquake. Much of Lisbon was rebuilt after the severe earthquake, along the lines of many major European cities. The Alfama district still retains the narrow streets and alleyways and has a lot of character. The walk up to the castle is steep, but worthwhile.

A walk back in time..... Really enjoyed walking the narrow streets of Alfama. Many charming restaurants to chose from ( many of them Fado restaurants ), good people watching and a good work out! Not to be missed.

Authentic experience. This is, architecturally, the oldest quarter of Lisbon. Compared with the "old" areas of Barcelona, Girona, Prague, and Rome, we found this interesting and unique. Being set on a such a hill, the narrow and winding streets are unique and always have an interesting view around the next corner. We stayed in the area and enjoyed walking to and from and shopping for groceries and eating out. There is not the night life of Barrio Alta and a slower, less crowded feel. The neighbourhood is not for those who have difficulty with stairs or hills! There is a lot of walking. The #28 tram serves the area and is a "must do" but you need to have good mobility to enjoy the area. We always felt safe and at ease in the area. You get some views of the Tagus looking south too. Enjoy!

Really romantic walk at night. This is the oldest neighbourhood in Lisbon with very narrow streets and steps up the hill it's located on. The Castle of ST George is on the top. The Castle closes at 9pm so if you are going up there for that view then be there before that time. There are a couple of places serving wine and food coming up.

an interesting side of Lisbon that u have 2 explore. went there with a walking tour, it would have been difficult to discover all the places in alfama on my own, so tricky roads. Nice walk, wish i had more time to spend over there and enter the castle.

Did I miss something?. Maybe I missed something, but walking down Alfama was nice, but nothing spectacular. The view near the castle is very beautiful, but for the most part the shops along this street took the form of touristy ones. We saw maybe two antique shops which were interesting, but not a whole lot of boutiques or unique places that stood out.
Great history and interesting location. Some nice shops and interesting sites and history. Recommend you go on a tour to get the full experience and not get lost!
Nice place to walk around. It is a nice place to walk around the narrow streets, paved with cubic stone. In Alfama are also located the Cathedral and the Castelo de Sao Jorge, which I recommend.
Authentic. Just a wonderful area to mooch around in. LIsbon is a great city and this is one of the best places. Quaint, atmospheric, rather run down.
Great history. A must see place. The streets are so narrow even more so than Venice. There is a lot of history. Also lots of small bars and resturants.
lovely. This is by far my most favorite area in my favorite European city. The old cobolt Streets, the castle, the atmosphere...just amazing. Lisboa at it's purest

Lovely area and great view at the top. Lovely area to walk around. Would agree with other reviews that say Alfama has an authentic feel to it as the old streets are not covered with tourist shops and coffee chains. It's quite a long and uneven walk up the cobbled streets to the castle district but is well worth it if you feel up to it.
Get lost in your imagination. Allow plenty of time to wander and let your imagination wonder what it would be like to live here in the past and today.
cobbled streets and funiculars. Made this area feel very authentic - well worth an amble up from the beach near the cruise ships lots of small shops and cafes along the way for a rest stop

LOVE LOVE LOVE!. This is the historic district of Lisbon and reflects what Lisbon looked like before the 1755 earthquake. The streets are lovely as are the buildings. Take comfortable shoes because the streets are steep and the cobble stones are brutal. The best way to get here is to take a trolley. There are many things to see in Alfama so separate at least 1/2 -3/4 a day to see this wonderful part of the city.

Choose Alfama over Bario Alta. For safety, accommodations, atmosphere, history, Fado...Alfama is a wonderful area to hangout. My girlfriend and I rented an apartment in Alfama for two weeks, using it as a base while we explored the city and the countryside. Once you get used to the seemingly endless winding streets and alleys, not to mention the steep hills, you'll constantly discover new places of interest.

Wear your walking shoes!. There are no parallel or perperdicular lines on a street map of Alfama. And there are not many flat surfaces either. To call it a maze does not do it justice. We walked from the Tagus River to the Castle through Alfama. It was well worth it with narrow streets and old buildings. This walk is physically demanding so you might want to take a tram or bus. After our hike to the Castle, we took a bus to the bottom, even though it is all downhill.

the heart and soul of Portugal. The location may be confusing to get around, but enjoy it's charm, it's unique, fun, interesting and great place to take pictures. Try to see a Fado show in this area also, this is where it all started many years ago. Well worth it!

Where Fado was born!. "Get lost in Alfama" was what someone recommended to me. It's a neighbourhood with a lot of winding streets and hills. It's beautiful! A lot of history to it too. A few Fado clubs and small bars(?)- They're just little shops that serve alcohol... maybe could even call them cafes. I absolutely love Ginjinha which is a cherry liqueur - there are quite a few places to pick it up in Alfama for just 1 euro. A couple restaurants in the neighbourhood too. A quick walk to Commerce Square which is easy to find if you get lost - just walk downhill and you'll eventually reach the water.

A bit run down, but with character. We ventured into the famous Alfama district. Surprisingly, many buildings are either in disrepair or under construction. Possibly signs of crisis. Some nice art stores, a few nice cafes. Plenty of tourists. I would pick Barro Alto ahead of Alfama, much more life.

Not to be missed. Alfama is one of the areas where the city of Lisbon first was born. It's a must see, also because it has the Castelo di S. Jorge and the Sé of Lisbon.You can get lost in the tiny streets and find many interesting shops.For the "fado" restaurants, there are better areas: here they are usually expensive and non authentic.

Nice place to get lost in the narrow backstreets of Lisbon. Took the Street Tram up to Alfama and after visiting the Monastery and Pantheon started wondering the streets on the way back down to Commerce Square. Got lost a couple of times, but it was an adventure and fun. Enjoyed the narrow the alleys and outdoor cafes along the way.

Narrow streets, loads of staircases, trams.... Alfama is definitely worth the visit. You feel like you're experiencing "real" Lisbon when you're in Alfama. The streets are all narrow and pretty dark (at night) but you never feel unsafe, even though much of the area is in "disrepair" and there is a fair amount of graffiti. I don't know if it's every Sunday morning (?) but Easter Sunday was uncannily quiet, only a few quiet tourists roaming the streets. Hardly a soul around. Absolutely do not go if you have mobility issues. All streets and all sidewalks are very uneven. In fact, don't go to Lisbon if you have mobility issues...
Interesting area. There are much more than Sao Jorge castle to see in Alfama. Much narrow streets, interesting shops, local bars.

get lost in the neighbourhood. i just love this little neighbourhood with it narrow little streets and alleys, where no matter which map you've bought, you will surely get lost!!but don't worry! that's the beauty of Alfama. put away the map, listen to people talking, listen to the fado music comig from the cafeterias, feel the smell of the fresh flowers everywhere... And whenever you wish to return to your hotel you just start walking down ...any street!! :)and note, Alfama is not a dangerous place at all, but mind your personal stuff and don't go around showing off!

Beautiful, unspoilt area away from the hustle and bustle of the city centre. I stayed in a hostel in Alfama so walked around the area a lot during my stay. There are some really amazing views to take in just walking around. It feels like a real, authentic Portuguese neighborhood. It would be a real shame to not check it out while in Lisbon as it's so close to the city centre.

Worth a walk. You can reach it by foot after the last stop of the blue line metro or by tram. The atmosphere and is great and each building deserves careful observation of the architectural details and the tiles that cover the facades as is traditional Portuguese. Prices for souvenirs and foods are generally higher than the rest of Lisbon.

Very Nice Area- Try to Catch the Sun-set. Really nice historic area with lovely narrow streets, castle and cobbles. It offers some historic buildings, shops, some nice cafes and wonderful viewing points. Worth checking out when in Lisbon. However, be prepared for some steep hills. If you have mobility problems, consider taking public or private transport as the streets are cobbled and very steep.
relax and enjoy. nice Lisbon neigbourhood to just stroll around. Lots of little streets, restaurants and little cafes and nice things to see.

Charming. Beautiful photogenic area.. Like the curiosity the Alfama neighborhood brings to you. Has great cozy restaurants and bars. Incredible mirador to relax and hear music. The Se Cathedral is also in this area and not to be missed.

Don't Miss!!. This is a very charming area of Lisbon. Although you are in city centre area of Lisbon, you feel like you are in a village. There are no vehicles around (the streets are too narrow), there are orange/clementine trees around, people talking to each other through their windows.Take plenty of water and wear comfortable shoes as the area is quite hilly.

Don't Miss This Neighborhood. Great little area during the day. Old, irregular and narrow street plan make you feel like you are transported back in time. Several nice churches within a short distance from each other. Saint George's Castle is open late. Old electric/rail street cars add to the old flavor of the neighborhood. Also has nice outdoor cafes.
Nice area. It's a nice old area of Lisboa, nice houses, monuments, cafes, planty of tourists. The area wich you have to visit if you are in Lisboa

A layered trifle of alleys and history, but keep your wits about you!. This crowded alley ridden part of the city centre is an experience which must be witnessed if visiting Lisbon. I started my walk from the station and just took the path along the harbour into the heart of Alfama. It’s impressive to look into the town from the harbour because you realise how steep and hilly the town of Alfama is. A word of caution, there are plain clothes locals that will approach you selling ‘weed’ so keep your wits about you, especially if you’ve got bags etc. This town has a fair amount of poor people littered around and more prominent as you make the climb into the Alfama towards the Castle. There is the odd street ‘Del boys’ selling glasses, I’d stay clear of them or anything they have to offer. Keep a careful eye out, as when we started walking up towards the castle, the alleys become narrow and it’s easy to get lost in the maze of paths which can be ideal for a thief to target you. Follow the crowd and make sure you’re around people as you walk in and around the Alfama. This shouldn't deter you but rather instil your ‘street senses’ as you would any other part of the world. There are cafes dotted around Alfama, but the whole point of navigating your way in and around Alfama is just to freestyle. Meaning no maps, just walk wherever you want and once you’ve decided to go to the castle, the only way is up – so hardly any room to get lost. I went on a sunny Saturday and the general attitude is very lazy, which is nice to roam around without large groups of people.There’s not anything you have to see or do, I guess it’s just an experience so be sure to enjoy it. There’s a nice open area called ‘Praca do Comercio’ which has steps that lower into the sea, a nice place to chill and relax. Pictures below, enjoy and embrace the culture.

Old moorish area, full of history and character. If you visit Lisbon, you have to come to aflama. The old moor area of Lisbon, and you have to see it by walking around. Very hilly, but you can take the electric tram which is fun. Fantastic views over lisbon. With the castle at the top. Again well worth the visit. Very difficult for anyone handicapped.

Lisbon's best district. I stayed in the Alfama district for a week, and it is one of those places where you will get lost so many times, and be puffed out from climbing all the hills and stairs, but it is so worth it. The castle is right at the top, there are several viewpoints with stunning views of Lisbon and the whole district is a jumble of tiny streets, traditional azulejo-covered houses and authentic little fado places.
Wonderful historic area. Great old section of Lisbon below the castle.Small wandering charming streets. Great vistas, small bistros, lovely area.

Alfama is a must. Alfama is Lisbon's most emblematic quarter and one of the most rewarding for walkers and photographers thanks to its medieval alleys and outstanding views. Because its foundation is dense bedrock, it survived the 1755 earthquake, and a walk through this old-fashioned residential neighborhood is now a step back in time. It is a village within a city still made up of narrow streets, tiny squares, churches, and whitewashed houses with tile panels and wrought-iron balconies adorned with pots of flowers, drying laundry, and caged birds. Go early in the morning.
Very cool. Wow, what a brilliant reflection of friendly people. Walking around, Boa Tarde! And everyone replies with a smile :) Cool place to get lost in wondering around.
Awesome town!. Be prepared to walk but absolutely lovely and worth visiting. Walk up to the castle and check out the views over the city. If you go up just before sunset you will get great photos!!
Come here. This is a culturally rich area of Lisbon that begs to be visited. It is not garish, doesn't have fancy shops or boutiques, but represents the real Lisbon.

to see and smell. some arab part in Lisbon, maybe the only one total Bairro that resist in europe. Take time to walk slowly and at night don´t forget tha Fado in a small ant tipic restaurant where the food is always very good and cheap

Moorish history!. A lovely place for a stroll, full of atmospheric higgledy-piggledy back streets. A wonderful opportunity to see snatches of daily life that probably haven't changed all that much over the years

Poor. Miradours covered in broken glass, overgrown with weeds, crumbling modern concrete walls, rubbish piled up, everything covered in graffiiti (as are most things in Lisbon from what we saw), lethal paths (another Lisbon trait). Aside from some nice views out of the river and rooftops from "THAT" spot, what's all the fuss about Alfama from a tourist's point of view? Maybe it's the alleys that offer endless opportunities to take the drugs that are constantly being offered as there was plenty of evidence on the floors (admittedly a wordwide phenomenon)?! I realise that the people have had it tough in Portugal these past 6 years but if Alfama is being touted as "an authentic Lisbon community" then why doesn't this community help itself out and clean itself up a bit?  Despite most of the people we spoke to being friendly enough We were left with the impression that the local people don't have much interest in tourism as they realise that the profits being generated are not finding their way back to their own area. I write this as someone who has lived in one of the most economically deprived areas of Europe for the last 30 years and has seen how far an area can fall if its people lose heart following economic decimation. The difference being that my area never had an established tourism sector to fall back on.

Loveable!. Very cosy, with plenty of hide-aways, awesome art galleries and cosy local bars..One tiny street leads to another one, and that´s the story without end. A real jewel for city-explorers and bohemic souls.:)
Amazing.. Get lost in alfama ! Don't follow book advices, just follow the little paths, the smell of orange trees, and the sound of good fado !

A true feel of Lisbon. The Alfama district is crammed with tile-roofed apartments, most with popular restaurants and fado establishments on the street floors. The place offers a slice of Portuguese life as residents shop, hang their laundry, and generally go about their lives. You'll love this part of town. In the late afternoon, the taverns and cafes open and the sounds of fado It's wonderful to walk the tiny little backstreets, up the hills, round the Cathedrals, and through the bars and restaurants of this beautiful old quarter. Loved it !

Lovely area to explore.. Alfama is an amazing part of Lisbon which you could many hours walking around and exploring. There are many steep hills so wear good walking boots. The tram 28 will bring you up part of the way but make sure to get off and walk around. Some great views of the Tagus and the city.
Fun place to get lost in. Take the Tram 28 to orientate yourself, then get off and simply wander around. Do take the time to read some guide books that help to bring the place to life.

The Lisbon Soul. You have to love everything about Alfama, the streets, the tiles, the people, food and thee Fado! Narrow streets in a Hill between Tejo river and the Castle. If you visit Lisbon you HAVE to get lost in Alfama!

Forget the map and just enjoy. We stayed at an airbnb place in Alfama and had an amazing time. My favorite thing to do was just walk around the tiny little alley ways that somehow are streets. I suggest doing this on a windy day as the wind doesn't really penetrate the area. Some gorgeous churches and little shops dot the path unexpectedly. This is the real Lisbon. Also, the area is very safe and tourist friendly -without being overrun by tourists.

Amazing Alfama. With only a couple days in Lisbon we opted for a morning guided walking tour. It was a great way to see the city and learn a little of its history. Our guide was sensitive to the diverse "fitness levels" of the group and paced the tour accordingly. As much of Lisbon's oldest quarters are built on the slopes of the castle mound this was greatly appreciated. The Alfama is one such district. A labyrinth of narrow paved laneways and tiny cobbled courtyards hidden behind the enclosing walls of multi storeyed apartment buildings. Doorways open right onto the street, washing flaps from lines strung down from windows and balconies, and stairways that disappear under archways and wind down the steep sides the hill. A picturesque medieval streetscape through which to wander and lose track of time.
Lovely little neighbourhood. On a clear day it's really nice to stroll around and sip some coffee and pastis de belem at a small cafè.
A must see. A historical part of town. Do not miss it. Walk through the small streets with steps, without planning, just let yourself be surprised.www.HeavyTravelAddict.com
Great for walks. Walk up and down the hills, and take a break at one of the small cafés on the street. Beautiful area with a lot of charm.

Just slenter around. We went up with the little tram and jumped out in the middle of Alfama. we walked around all day and enjoyed this area a lot. You see old people with beautifull faces, small alleys, particual squares and hear Fado comming out of the houses. A must do during your stay in Lissabon !

Amazing. Stayed right in the heart of Alfama in a cute little studio. Close to bars, restaurants and sights. Plently of steps so you need to be fairly fit. Fado music is amazing and can be heard every evening.
Se cathedral. The cathedral near the castle is worth seeing. We thought it was beautiful and not run down as some other travellers suggested here.

Charming Alfama. We had the chance to visit Alfama when we were on our way to the castle of Saint George (Castelo de San Jorge), and it is really beautiful, it is also worth taking one of the old trams to get to the top!
Old Historic Center. A place in history with Saint Jorge's Castle, churches, picturesque, tiled houses. Wear good walking shoes to tackle those steep streets. Fado Clubs abound.

Loved our stay here. We stayed 4 nights here when in Lisbon. If you love old and historical come to this part of Lisbon. The streets are steep, cobbled and narrow with tiny shops and apartments. We found a couple of nice cafes and frequented these when not exploring. Out walking at any time it was neat to hear music wafting out from behind the doors and locals gathering on the street to swap stories, smoke or play cards. I went wandering on my own at night and seemed safe to me. I have been in worse places and not felt good but this was fine.

Alfama love. Alfama is a very charming place to stay. It has a more rural charm compared to Belem, Bairro Alto and even La Placa de Commercia.The cobbled streets, the hilly and steep roads and the very cosy little shops and houses, all contribute to make Alfama a heart- winner. Even when you are done visiting all the places around and in Alfama, just walking nonchalantly and losing yourself in the streets of Alfama is a treat in itself. However, as charming as it is during the day, it becomes quite gloomy in small closed streets.

Oldest and most picturesque part of town. Get on tram 28 or the bus to Sao Jorge castle to avoid climbing on the steep hill of Alfama. Once at the top, take your easy way down in the winding cobbled streets with numerous cafes, shops, art galleries,...Watch the tile facades, old houses, laundry drying on balconies,...Visit one of two extrodinary view points here. Visit the old Sao Jorge castle, the Se cathedral from 12 century.Allow 3 hours.

Long and winding road through the past. This must be my most favourite neighbourhood in Lisbon. My guide and I walked through its cobbled streets and walked past houses with unique character reminiscent of its historical Moorish past. I loved and enjoyed walking and exploring it's maze of narrow, winding, medieval streets. Take your time here - and look for and observe carefully details that will appeal to your senses and particular interest. Get lost and find yourself.
Great to get lost for a while. Nice neighborhood but the streets are not really organized so we got lost a lot there. That wasn't so unfortunate because it's good place to be lost :)

Authentic Old Lisbon. We loved this neighbourhood that keeps on going around corners, up stairs and always uphill. It was an adventure to keep turning down alleys and rounding corners without ever knowing what to expect. We found orange trees, neighbourhood cafes, great architecture and the views. The view from the top over Lisbon and the Rio Tejo was priceless. There was nothing touristy about this neighbourhood, it is hundreds of years old and still a vibrant residential area. I would have loved more time to explore but it was dark by the time we came down from the castle.

a fun stroll and beautiful views. Take a taxi to the Castle and walk down--you'll love the architecture and views of the Tagus and port below. Alfama is famed outside of Lisboa as a remnant of the medieval town; rightly sow.

Great place to wander.. This is the older part of Lisbon and is a can't miss area We wandered through the cobblestone streets and alleys during the day and then went back for a fado performance at night. Although lightly lit and somewhat confusing, we felt entirely safe wandering around. Everything winds downhill so just get lost and you will eventually find your way to one of the main streets below.
What a quaint part of town. Took a walking tour thru the area. Lisbon Walking tours was awesome and free.Highly recommend you take their tours.
Sea foooood. Lovely place with lots of good family owned sea food restaurants. Its better to go their during the night time as many of the restaurants are closed for lunch.

Fascinating. This part of Lisbon is the one I enjoyed most! Unfortunately, there was almost no one on the tiny narrow streets, I guess because it was Sunday and January. But I could still feel the spirit of this lovely town, as I walked by, I could hear the sound of a guitar from one house, I could smell the home made food from another and from time to time I could see a smiling old lady at some colorful window. It was a lovely walk and I'd go there again anytime!

If you complain about it being dirty or dodgy then this is not for you. I am from Lisbon. Alfama is the core, the heart of the city. It is one of the oldest constantly inhabited neighborhoods in the city, and its name comes from the Moorish times, before 1147. Having said this it is not touristy, which is great. You won't see immaculate streets filled with cheap memorabilia stores. This is a living neighborhood, people live here as they have for many years particularly because most inhabitants are seniors. Things have begun to change, bringing fancier stores and younger people and while progress is great some of the character of the neighborhood will change forever. If you think everything that I have said is ridiculous, don't go. You won't like it. If you want to see something old and beautiful, that was not created for tourist consumption but has an appeal like few neighborhoods in European capitals have, then come and get lost. Literally. Ditch your map and wander, keep going up the gradient and you will find the castle. The small corners, hidden stairs and small plazas are why this place is unique. Lisbon at its most special and truest self, a slightly decaying, maze-like and hilly ride that affords great views and a peak to the past of something that never was.

The oldest district of Lisbon. Old area but very nice & unique you should take loads of pictures.I liked the tiny streets and narrow alleys with old small houses with Lisbon typical rooftops. A must visit enjoy a walk in the alfama streets.
Nice but have seen better. I heard nice things about Alfama from the hotel front desk staff, however when I went to visit it was dirty. Perhaps I didn't get to see the entire place.

Charismatic "olde world" part of the City. We wandered through this district on the way to / from the castle on a bright winter day and it is certainly a very charismatic area of town - lots of small thoroughfares lined with colourful little dwellings. It's a bit hilly, dirty and as someone else has said there are some slightly dodgy charachters (But not as many as stalk some of the squares).Well worth a slow wander through.

Beautiful walk. Is part of what you expect in Lisbon. Some decadence, colors and great views. I recommend the visit during the day. During this hours you can visit the antique shops and main attractions (castelo and se cathedral)

Where time stood still. Alfama is like stepping back in time. It feels untouched and it is one of the most picturesque places I've ever been to. It's a maze of streets, stairs and narrow alleys with old small houses and those typical rooftops of Lisbon. I am renting an apartment in the heart of Alfama for the week and it really feels like I'm one of the locals. The doors are very small and the stairs narrow and steep. I meet people who've probably lived here their whole lives. Some houses are falling apart, some have been carefully renovated.This is where you will find small bars, restaurants and neighborhood squares where the locals gather in the evening. In the morning, I can hear it come to life when everyone starts to wake up and open their business. You can easily get lost here but just as easily find your way again and not be bothered by not having a map. It's a bit steep and a little dirty but I guess that's part of its charm. You get great views from a lot of areas in Alfama and car access is limited, which means it's safe and relatively quiet. I really recommend this and if you're in town and get the chance to rent a place here, don't hesitate!
History. The most charming and antique neighborhood in town. Here you'll find narrow streets, charming corners, nice people, mystic churches. If you find a spot to stay please stay here!

Either you love it or hate it. The oldest part of Lisbon has two faces - it is charming, full of charisma, nice cobbled streets are plenty of little shops and restaurants, each corner brings something interesting, sometimes this is a cat looking out of the window, sometimes colourful graffiti. The other side of Alfama - rubbish, rubbish everywhere, rubbish bags piling outside for days. Strange creatures walking around at night. For me - this is the best part of the town however I would love this rubbish to be taken care of.

Just nice to get lost in Alfama. Just an area of Lisbon, where so nice to get lost in a tiny little streets, watch people, have food or just go in to the Fado restaurant to listen to the music. Lots things to see and take pictures of. Just lovely and chilled walk. Don't need maps just get lost its sweet and great place to visit.

Ok for stroll. Had done a long walk around this place at late evening and it was like being a very historical part right from the very start. Could not find too many nice quick eat cheap places which made me slightly edgy since it was my budget trip. But nonetheless a great area to get lost in an era gone past by.

Bring your Imagination. Just walk and walk and walk. You don't need an itinerary. Just an imagination. I loved looking at everything. There is a story for every scene. The red time roofs are the show stoppers on a sunny afternoon.
Easy to get lost. But just head downhill & you will be ok. Lots of quaint shops & cafés. Also the castle and church's with fantastic views
Charming and beautiful. Stunning views, excellent restaurants, upscale shops, and the magnificent 11th century Moorish castle, Castelo de S. Jorge.

Beware - Pick Pockets. I was walking down from the castle when I noticed 3 men who looked liked tourists but were acting very suspicious. I saw one man look like he was helping a woman but was trying to get in to her backpack. I had caught their eye and now they were suspicious of me. I went in to a store and hoped they would leave. Everytime I tried to leave the store they were lingering a block away. I decided to try and get a picture of them in case something happened. The next thing I knew one of the guys was yelling at me in the street in Portuguese and he then spit in my face. No one around me did anything. I was very scared and tried to get away from them. Eventually I did but I missed several sights I would have liked to have seen and I would not go back there again.

Wonderful stroll through Alfama. As noted in earlier reviews, this is the core of the city. Your feet will get used to the uneven cobble-stone streets. Some shopping, people watching, and plenty of cafes/bars.

Loved Alfama. The guide books make it out to be the "rough" part of town- sort or undesirable, but I'm so glad I didn't skip it. It is the "old" part of town, but that is what gives it the charm. We went to the Tuesday/Saturday flea market there- not to be missed. However, if you think you'll get a bargain there, think again. Most vendors know exactly what they've got and while they will haggle with you a bit, you're not going to walk away with a steal. Even if you don't buy anything though, it's a fun experience.

Lovely narrow streets. Alfama is the very core of old Lisbon. Its lovely narrow streets take you to a completely different century, where everything moves in the slowest pace..choose one of many "tascas" (little bars) and have a glass of wine...You'll love it!

beautiful!!!. This old Fado area of Lisbon, is a must. Full of character. Absolutely charming. Just seat at one of the many small cafes, drink a Ginja (local cherry liqueur) with a few olives and cured ham and watch the world go by. You will not regret it!

Delightful part of Lisbon. We loved this area of Lisbon and walked around it on 2 occasions. We loved all the narrow and cobbled streets. We walked up both times and found that there was so much to see ( churches, views, little shops, tiled houses etc) that we hardly noticed that we were going uphill! We had thought of going up by tram but all the trams were very crowded and so we walked. We did get lost trying to find the castle as it is not very well sign posted and although we had a map there are so many little streets that it is difficult to tell exactly where you are!

Best place in Lisbon. The Aflame was by far my favourite part of Lisbon it is full of character, I found some of the other areas to be a little disappointing especially Rossio square which has nothing unique and Bairro Alto which was characterless and not what I expected.Overall I really liked Lisbon and did not feel at all unsafe despite what I read on the Trip Adviser Forum before I went.

Alfama wear good shoes. We did a walking tour with the Chill out Josef in this area.Please be warned that you must have good walking shoes and be ready for uphill climb. We had been advised already by friends hence we were prepared. It was a lovely day not very hot. Alfama is part of the old Lisbon and the narrow streets. You see how really portugese people live and the conversations they have across the windows. The retired men playing cards etc. Easy to get lost in the small streets but if you have time take it slowly and enjoy. As we were short of time we took a 3 hours guided tour. Visit bakeries and small restaurants on the way.Come back down by tram.

It speaks for itself!. Wonderful area to go watch watch fado walk the streets and just be!Don't go In high hills and be aware that there are lots of steep little streets so if you are not very good at walking take a tuk tuk!

Charming neighborhood...... This is the oldest neighborhood in Lisbon. You will find very narrows streets and alleys. Wonderful food and excellent vibe. A place to enjoy strolling along and visiting the many tiny cafes and bakeries.....
Labyrinth walk. Nice to walk in this area, up and down, with real narrow streets and no planning. A lot of miradores (beautiful wiews), cafe´s and small restaurants.

A nice walk (if you can handle the hills).. While I think this area is just a tad overrated for what it is (totally neglected and rather charmless), we did have a nice time walking down from São Jorge castle in the early evening.Most of the taverns were empty and the locals seemed to prefer to stay indoors.Make sure NOT to make the way up, as the street are very steep.

Real Lisbon?. I loved walking round the backstreets of Alfama. There are photo opportunities everywhere, lots of small bars and restaurants and it feels like this is the real Lisbon rather than the tourist version in the town centre.

Colorful old city center. Needs some maintenance. Nice typical quarter of Lisbon, full of activities during the night.
Colorful houses, many broken buildings and several beggars on the street.
a beautiful part of lisbon.. we just wish we had more time to see it, there are some fantastic views, loads of history, and now a unesco site i believe. lovely.
Most charming area in Lisbon. Kept coming back to the area for the atmosphere and the wonderful cafés. Take the tram for an overall feel.

windy streets, real Lisboa, Fardo !. it's wonderful to walk the tiny little backstreets, up the hills, round the Cathedrals, and through the bars and restaurants of this beautiful old quarter. Loved it !

My favorite. My favorite neighborhood in Lisbon, so typical and old. I get lost on those streets for more than once, and I'm glad I did a second visit. Recommended at least half a day in there to see it allall

Nice castle area. A little bit different form the UK's castles, the portuguese pairs are displayed on larger areas, with plenty of more open space and less to see indoors the views are the best part of it.

Enchantingly charming. A walk in Alfama is like an enchanted walk in a chapter of history. The area is the oldest part in Lisbon and you'll see there some houses that are older than the earthquake that hit the city in 1755. As you step into Alfama's narrow winding alleys you'll feel that you've stepped out of time to another era. I don't think it's possible to take a walk there alone unless you plan on getting lost. If you're not with a local guide or someone who knows the area, then don't attempt to enter this maze on your own unless you plan on spending the whole day there. It will be a wonderful day no doubt, but you may just find it quite a challenge to find your way back on your own - unless of course you plan to stay there, which is not a bad idea at all :)Alfama is one of the places that made me fall in love with Lisbon.

Visiting Lisbon, a definate must see. My wife and I were doing a long weekend visit to Lisbon (Lisboa) during our stay in Portugal's Algarve. We did a general coach tour around Lisbon when we first arrived and decided that we wanted to look more closely at the historical area of Alfama and glad we did. We took and ride in a 'tuk tuk' which was ideal for getting around the small historical streets. The ride was a little bumpy but got to see an awful lot of the fascinating quarter of Alfama. We were able to stop next to many historical buildings - The 18th century church of Santa Luzia - The Façade of the Se, the cities main cathedral and the labyrinth of alleyways which spill out onto open air patios. The Tuk Tuk tour takes from 1 hour to 3 hours which will take you round the whole city of Lisbon if you want - do ask to stop off for photo opportunities and cost around 35 to 55 euros. The area gives you many Historical buildings, Museums, Galleries, Markets, Restaurant's, Churches and Belvederes. Have a great time, we did.

Very hilly!. Beautiful - absolutely one of the city parts to visit, when in Lisboa! Although the streets were very steep, the Pantheon and the Sao Jorges Castle made it all worth while! :D And there were so many statues and cosy viewing points over the city and the ocean (got some of our best pictures on our trip to Alfama!)

Get lost.... Walk around in the sun... Get lost... Admire the tiles on the buildings... See the locals sitting on the street and talking and the kids playing... Go up hills, down hills then up some more hills. Find random buskers dotted around the place. Just don't try to reach the river to get back to the centre.... It won't work!

Old Town Charm - A Must to Walk Around & Explore. We explored this part of Lisbon as part of a Free Walking Tour. There is no initial cost for the tour, which lasted about 3 hours. At the end of the tour you give the guide a tip, depending on how you found the tour. We later went back to this area and had a more in depth look around. The old parts of Lisbon are the most interesting and unique. It was on this walking tour that we tried home made 'Ginja' - a liquor made from cherries, sugar & cinnamon. It was delicious!Tip: To find a free walking tour, just Google 'free walking tours in Lisbon' & there they are! Some have to be pre-booked, others you just show up at a specific time & place. Your choice!There are also many great places to enjoy the local cuisine in this area. You can explore and snack as you go! :)
Interesting. We took the trolley up the hill, ate lunch beautiful views over the water. Then we made our way down via the steep windy streets to the waterfront.
Must see. Great part off old city. Must see! Many small cafeteria with good price for good food! Recomended at all weather!
Old city. Walking without haste in winding , narrow streets,, small squars and atmosphere of nostalgy and Fado . The sunshine on white walls, and view from Largo das Portas do Sol..

Worth a detour, not worth a trip.. A daytime walk was interesting enough but maybe its charm is revealed in the evening to those seeking a musical experience. Personally i would not care to venture there after dark.Having no desire to get lost in the warren of alleys we stuck to the main streets which are more rundown than other parts of historic Lisbon.

Music in Alfama. My first encounter with the music of Fado, it was Mariza concert in London.Reading her biography I found out that the Lisbon Alfama in every tavern reads as the music. I was and visited large and small family tavern. Everyone needs to have to experience before you die

Go by if you can, but if you can't won't miss much. We found Alfama as a must in some of the guides that we reviewed, so it was weird to get there and see a lot of chinese shops. We had to walk a little more to get to the main street and appreciate this beautiful ancient neighborhood.We sat in one of the restaurants that are located in the middle of the alley and enjoyed a tasty pizza while we joined the people around who were enjoying a Champions league match.We walked through these old streets and noticed that they have a lot of pastries shops, it seems it is one of their specialties.It was a good experience, however some zones were decadent or not so safe.

Alfamous!. incredible atmosphere lurs around every corner in alfama! little cozy cafes and bars and fast local food vans are all over the place along with the laundry lines and permanent habitants of the place! music and noise ! TIP: try and get lost! talk to the locals!DEFINITELY RECOMMEND!

For something different. See how people live cheek to jowl in buildings several hundred years old. This is old style European city living - accommodation over shops, lots of small squares for social gatherings, and oodles of restaurants and bars. Compare with your current suburbia over a Sangria or cheap but tasty wine.

I am in love. We accidentally ended up for two nights in this part of Lisbon. Although I wanted visit it , being part of it is much better. Well maybe not for everybody . Can be noisy in the night, with the neighbours talking to each other, barking dogs, fado singers- but as authentic as it could be. Tiny streets, small locals snacks, tons of stairs- I just love it. Right now we are above Alfama, in the castle neighborhood, but I already miss it.
