On Sunday morning the bells playing Bethowen, the guy next door walking (and talking loud) his dogs, the Saturdays laundry out of windows, the old lady talking Portuguese very loudly 24/7, the snack bar with the coffee for 40cents, the grocery store with only one kind of wine, and much more. If you want experience Lisbon in its roots - you should walk the bacas, travessas and ruas, climb the stairs and have a balcahau or chorizo in snack bar. It is not a party, but the real life stars early and finish late, be prepare. One of the spots on the world, I would be able to live.

Exciting Quarter - Day or Night. The Alfama district is crammed with tile-roofed apartments, most with popular restaurants and fado establishments on the street floors. The place offers a slice of Portuguese life as residents shop, hang their laundry, and generally go about their lives. You'll love this part of town. In the late afternoon, the taverns and cafes open and the sounds of fado, Cape Verde music, and songs of other cultures make this part of town come alive. Take the time to walk around and savor the maze of winding alleyways that hug the hillside. You won't be sorry.

Fascinating old neighborhood to wander around and discover. The home of fado music. Twisty, turny atmospheric streets on hills. Come here on Saturday for the huge flea market. Lots of restaurants tucked away on these streets.

Fabulous Alfama. Famous Tram 28 through the narrow streets, walk to the port, walk to the city, great food, very nice people. Lisbon is clean, vibrant, colourful and great to visit and stay. Close to Sintra and its wonderful castles.
Classic. This is probably the oldest neighborhood in the city. The walk down through the Alfama is going through the real Lisbon

Warning - Pickpockets (Alfama) - please see the photos. The Alfama section is very nice, but it's important that you protect yourself from pickpockets at all times. They pose as tourists and work in groups. One person spots potential marks by observing what you have (cell phones in particular) and where you keep it. They then give the information by phone to two others who will follow you until you reach a vulnerable spot. Zip up any bag, pocket, etc. Always. My wife was robbed in September 2013. We went back a few days later to spot the criminals and photograph them so that we could warn other. The attached photos are of pickpockets that work in Alfama, near Castelo de Sao Jorge and the Miradoro de Santa Luzia. The one on the phone is the spotter. The three men walking are the pickpockets who follow you and strike when your attention is diverted. They dressed exactly the same way both the day that they robbed us and a few days later. After they steal your phone, they hide it in their back pockets -- you can even see bulges in one of the photos. I've already given these photos to the Lisbon police, but only you can protect yourself from being robbed in the first place. Please share these photos with whomever is going to this area.

A charming and lively part of Lisbon. If you want to experience a part of Lisbon that's not all about shopping opportunities, but about feeling the real Lisbon, where people live and where you'll find portugese people in the cafés, this is the place to visit. There's also a lot of beautiful scenic views especially along Largo Santa Luzia & Rua Säo Tomé. Note you can take tram 12 from Praca da Figueira in a circle trip or get of and walk part of the way (and get on Again if you like). It's easy to get there (Praca da Figueira) with the Metro.

BEAUTIFUL. The most beautiful part of Lisbon in my opinion. The streets are all cobblestone, just small sidewalks and the most amazing smells from the fresh traditional portugeese food!! a MUST VISIT.

Alfama. Had a lovely day in Alfama. Got the tram up which was an experience in itself. Great views over the city. There was a salsa band playing so sat and listened for a while, people were getting up to dance,so we joined them!! I even bought the cd!! Great memories of a lovely afternoon spent sipping vino blanco and dancing in the street. Would love to go back sometime.

Old world charm. It was fun exploring endless streets of alfama offering fair glimpses of lives of locals.The houses covered with ancient tiles is treat to watch.Clotheslines sagging with weight of colorful clothes outside every household is pretty photogenic.Plenty of local foods,snacks and fruits available at many street shops.The sight of red tiled rooftops right upto sea from the top is gorgeous.Inspite of being very old neighbourhood the steets are reasonably clean.With every few minutes trams passingby or appearing suddenly at street corner is really i enjoyed very much.One word of caution while travelling in trams in this particular part of town is beware of pickpockets. Mine was picked within three hours of arriving in Lisbon and Alfama was my first outing after checking in.

Alfama. The area of Alfama in Lisbon is a fantastic place to walk around and explore this old part of the city. The small, narrow streets are a look into a unique area of the city. There are cafe's and restaurants to sit and enjoy the ambience.

Steps, Streets and Sardines. The Alfama district of Lisbon is delightfully winding, narrow and as a reviewer put it, "do not follow any pattern." A whole afternoon here is, I think essential if you are to absorb the true atmosphere of this gorgeous capital city. There are wonderful views and if are tired (and one can tire easily as the streets are steep) there is always a handy restaurant for coffee, orange juice and cake.

This should be #1 on your 'To Do' list in Lisbon. The 'old' part of Lisbon is brimming with culture, personality, charm, and plenty to do. Shops, food, breathtaking vistas. Ride the trolley, walk the streets. You cannot come to Lisbon and leave without seeing this wonderful neighborhood.

Lisbon - an absolute must!. Few cities would boast a place like this - sunken in the glittering sun, set on rolling hiils with thousands of steps up and down. You can walk around Alfama for days and still be mesmerised by its inherent beauty, ambience, the smell of grilled baccalau or sardinas, and the sound of music of which FADO is by far the most heart breaking and uplifting at the same time. There are dozens of places from which you can see breathaking panoramas of the town. It is a place which you admire with all your senses. Wim Wenders was right about the sounds that permeate the place, and many fine photos can actually give half of the credit that Lisbon deserves. There is actually something primevally instinctive about it. You see it for the first time and before long you want to live there forever.
Up and down. Alfama is the oldest area of Lisbon streets are very narrow and do not follow any pattern. You can get lost as you go up and down the hills but alot of fun.

A walk in history. Very nice atmosphere to spend a few hours wondering around the old streets of Lisbon. Make sure you walk all the way up to the castle. Be prepared that pushing a baby chair could be a real challenge on the narrow cobbled streets.

Not so sure. Initially we walked into Alfama along the main road and were not too keen. Like many parts of Lisbon had alot of graffiti and I was a bit wary of the area. THe second visit we went by tram (lots of hills) which was much mroe enjoyable. Alfama is not a very big town but worth a visit. Lots of places to eat and a few nice shops. We spent a few hours but that was enough. Walked back down into Lisbon centre following the tram lines which felt much safer and with better views. As with other reviews I wouldn't like to wander here late at night.

An original part of Lisbon with stunning views. This is a nice part old part of Lisbon with lots of charm and the best views over the city. Apart from the castle as the main attraction, there are several restaurants and cafés where you can enjoy a meal or a cup of coffee.

A must when in Lisbon- gritty. Don't expect "Paris". Old, old old, windy cobblestone streets. hills, Narrow alleys with old houses on top of each other.Laundry hanging outside windows to dry. Old ladies in black talking to passerbys from their windows. Graffiti everywhere,I wouldnt stay here (maybe 1-2 days) but definitley fun to visit, great fado clubs and authentic food.Also, a note-- I felt very safe there (I had read about some not feeling so)
With the locals. I have seen Alfama due a tour. In Alfama you really get the authentic Portugese atmosphere. Really a recommendation to visit this part of the city!

nice neighbourhood. I went to this part of Lisbon on a free tour, given by the Fado Museum. I t starts in the square in front the museum, with a Fadista and its guitarists and continues into the heart of Alfama, with its narrow alleys, with the guide explaining the beginning of Fado.In the middle of the tour, we had 5 more songs with the local residents singing along. It was great!

A typical part of Lisbon which is a “must” to visit.. Near the Castle, Alfama is a part of the city that has the typical population) poor). However they live in a peculiar way and you can feel it when walking around. Be Careful at night – don´t go alone and avoid dark and narrow streets.In Alfama you will get a lot of attractions either small restaurants or monuments like the national Pantheon.
Wonderful Alfama. The amazing old Lisbon, here you taste the real life Lisbon and where you can enjoy the beautiful fado with the locals.

History lives. Whenever I have friends visiting for the first time, I take them to my favorite Lisbon tour: Take the #28 Tram (you catch it three streets in from Praca do Comercio. Make sure you turn left as you hit the correct street, so that you get on at an earlier stop, rather than later, since the tram fills up VERY quickly). Several years ago, the Castle started charging an entrance fee in to the grounds, which I wholly disapprove of since this is an open space that has traditionally belonged to everyone. Some tourist spots should be free, and this is one of them. However, if you don't mind paying, the line moves quicker than you might imagine. If you DO mind paying, there is a Chinese restaurant nearby with excellent views of the city, too (but it really isn't quite the same!). In any case, the Castelo is a great starting point for a leisurely walk down through Lisbon's oldest quarter, the Alfama, with its cobbled streets, cable cars, narrow alleys, and many attractions, including the 12th Century Cathedral, or "Se". Walking along these streets, the modern world dissolves in a haze of picturesque beauty, blending the 17th and 19th centuries, as gorgeous old cable cars glide up and down cobbled streets, passing cool alleyways, above which hang wrought-iron balconies, festooned with plants. Everywhere you look is a poster shot waiting for your camera, but there is no greater pleasure than to simply wander and enjoy this ancient hill of Lisbon, keeping your electronic devices in your pocket, as you capture the moments with those far more sensitive devices, your mind and heart.

A great place to get lost!. Well, it's really too small to get lost in, and the river is visible most of the time, so you stay oriented. But it's a lovely old area to wander along the narrow cobblestone streets and take pictures of ordinary life.
Incredible view of history. While its not an easy trek it's worth it. The living working neighborhood is so interesting and colorful. The incredible view from the piazza is awesome.

We could have done Alfama and Belem and been happy. We could have done Alfama and Belem and been happy with only seeing those 2 areas of Lisbon. The windy streets of Alfama are the "real" Lisbon. Plenty of places to see Fado music, eat great food, and drink sangria by the pitcher.
Traditional area. We walked down through the winding streets from the castle to the cathedral. It was very interesting.

Real feel of Lisboa. The place to be for the tourist who travells for culture. You get a sense of how life goes for the ordinary Lisboa inhabitant. I fell in love with Alfama. I love the small houses, the closeness of everything, the narrow streets and "escadrinhas". I got the feeling that Alfama is a village inside a city, everybody knows their neighbours by name and they share a community heart that lapses in the big cities. (Listen to Amalia Rodrigues song "Alfama" on youtube. It's a jewellery!)
The heart of Lisbon. Alfama is the heart of Lisbon. We liked very much the ambience of this old part of the city (the oldest, with the castle), we spoted a few "fado" singers in the street.
Alfama. If you want to see the real "bairros" from Lisbon and experience the local life, Alfama is a must see.

Really quaint area of Lisbon. Alfama is gorgeous - so quaint and full of atmosphere. It is quite 'hilly'. It was lovely to wander around the back streets and take pictures. Very colourful Lovely views. Great little bars and restaurant
Amazing typical streets. Astonishing place! the tiny streets really make you feel like you're on a movie! It's better if you go on foot to experience the wild Lisbon.
Typical historical exceptional city!. One of the key historical locations in Lisbon: Better to visit late pm especially in summer time, and have a nice dinner in one of the Fado music tavernas.

Old, well worn and frayed around the edges. but if you are in Lisbon you must take a walk around this little neighborhood. It is one of Lisbon's oldest neighborhoods as it escaped the destruction of the 1755 earthquake. It has winding up and down streets and steps designed not for tourists, but for the best defense and to catch the cool summer breezes. It is a challenge not to get lost, but that is half the fun. The area is very old and depressed economically so it is wise to be vigilant, but we never felt at all threatened. Again, wear good walking shoes and be prepared to make your own discoveries of amazing tiles, beautiful detail in wrought iron balconies, old building, cobbled streets and small cafes serving grilled sardines.

nice area. It was a nice walk although a little difficult for me with bad knees, as it is very hilly. There were some views and old buildings with lots of neat tiles and some areas which where were very run down. There were also a few nice churches to check out and be careful about pick pockets. I had not issues and did not see anyone else but it is known that there are issues in that area and on tram 28.
Loved Castle San Jorge. Very worth the trip - amazing that it's still in such great shape after several centuries. Alfama is a great walk or trolley car ride from Biaxa.

Touristy, dirty, nothing to brag about, but I guess a 'MUST SEE'. I read about this area, but was not impressed. Dirty and hot, steep climbs. Went to all the suggested places but there was not really anything to see that was all that impressive. The Miradoura da Praca at the top of the hill is nice, see separate review for that.

Beautiful,steep walks but worth it.. Walked up through this area when finding st George castle.took some beautiful pictures and it was steep but we did it about 9 ish am.couldnt have done it in the afternoon heat though.our 6 year old sun managed ok. :)
Old town. Very old town and it's nice to walk through while getting to the catle. Could easily get lst but that is all the fun.

The oldest part of Lisbon. This is a great area to stroll around in order to see the oldest part of Lisbon. The city was destroyed on 1 November 1755 by an earthquake and the following tidal wave and fires. The Alfama was the only neighborhood that was not destroyed. Most of the buildings are lovely architecture, with interesting tiles, mosaics and other typical features. Lots of interesting shops to poke around in as well. The whole area is rather hilly, with lcobblestone streets, so wear good walking shoes!

Nice little area. Took Tram 23. The Cathedral and Castle were very impressive. Overall, it was a nice first day of my trip. I took the tram from Praca de Figaroa (near Rossio Square) and it was necessary and useful.

Great view. Experience the local Lisbon, with a great view of the city and of the river. Try to get lost in the narrow streets, talk with locals, taste the food local people eat! A good way to stay away from the tourist crowd

Walking tour with Discover Walks. I tried the walking tour with Discover Walks around the area of Alfama! This tour was really the high point of my trip. The tour was really not boring at all, very informative, really cool and we even got to try the famous drink of the area! These tours are all done with locals and the guide was really great! Great fun and informative!

Labrynth of tiny streets. Great place to go wondering and so many great restaurants. Remember to look up the small side streets as you will find beautiful terraced gardens to eat in. Great place for sardines

Lovely maize of ruined and not so ruined buildings. One of the must parts of Lisbon, best enjoyed by going there in tram and going down on foot. Narrow steep street show you how it looked like many years ago - and of course now, as still people live there, even many of the houses are abandoned and ruined.

My favorite part of Lisbon. I love the old colorful houses with small doors and windows, the tiny narrow streets and stairs, people smiling from the windows inviting you to have a drink or lunch in their house and fado music coming from almost every corner.

The real heart of Lisbon. One tends to go to the Chiado and barrio Alto to see Lisbon which is great, but Alfama is as Portuguese as it gets. Narrow streets, colorful settings, small typical restaurants. Walk down from the Castelo Sao Jorge towards the Santa Apolonia train station and admire the architecture and magnificent views of the Tagus River. Very special. Don't do this by yourself at night. Best if you are with other people. During the day it is safe.

Alfama - Fado capital of Lisbon. We spent an evening in Alfama after visiting the Castelo St Jorge, which is only a short walk away from the top of the neighbourhood. The winding alleys are full of home made shrines, restaurants and bars with a lively party atmosphere. We stopped at the bottom of Alfama outside the Fado Museum for drinks were I was served the largest glass of wine I have ever seen. The square there is great for people watching and close to many Fado restaurants. One note of warning, we were approached by people trying to sell us drugs. A firm no and walking away was enough to deter them but I would not recommend having anything too valuable on show.

Just lose yourself in the streets. If you ever want or like mazes go here.Just walk the streets la up the atmosphere,stop for drinks and something to eat at any of the small bars and drink in old Lisbon.No other major European capital looks like this area as for the ones we have visited. The place is just a labyrinth of narrow windy streets with a great vibe, Cannot remember which street but one as photos of the people who live in each house on the walls,remember reading about this somewhere and purely by accident ended up in that street..

Hilly, older neighborhood of Lisbon with beautiful city views. Wear comfortable shoes to walk around this older neighborhood in Lisbon. Many beautiful views and picturesque, narrow stone streets and very hilly. Wandering around we found some great small restaurants and churches. There are two trams that will also take you around this area.

Lovely, romantic..... It's really speacial place. Just take your partner and go for a walk. Forget about the guide, and walk around, have a great sardinas from the local little bar, enjoy green wine, and listen to fado... very special and romantic zone !

Wear your walking shoes!. A beautiful part of Lisbon. Be sure to wear your walking shoes, as the hills are steep and there are many of them! If you walk around in the later hours, you'll see the locals sitting in the doorways singing Fado music-lovely!

The old Lisbon. This neighborhood has survived to the biggest earth quake Portugal had, scale 9.1 richter and is like an old town. Friendly people and the small of food is like the old villages. Unforgetable.

Narrow streets, very particular, great character. You just have to experience it. Walk around and get lost in the streets of Alfama. Kinds playing football in the streets, old ladies shopping around, the old group of friends gathering for a meal. This place is full of character and reflects the beauty and fascinating side of Lisbon.Top tip: 1. Have some food there (mind the tourist traps), tends to be cheap.

Lisbon of old. We spent an enjoyable hour or two following a walk in the DK guide (and saw others doing the same!) and loved it. The tiny roads and walkways are interesting in themselves, and occasionally open out onto great views over Lisbon.
unique neighborhood. only got to spend a little time here but it's really fun to walk around the small alleys and see and hear the various fado restaurants.

Cannot do Lisbon without seeing this!. Total contrast to Lisbon city centre and the new town, alfalma is like stepping back in time. Spend a day getting lost in the winding streets and taking photos of the architecture and locals. Buy a gingja and sit on the steps of cathedral Se watching the world go by. You can get there easily on tram 28, or via walking up any of the stairs on the left of the city! They say you cannot get lost in alfalma, and if u feel lost...just walk down! Cannot miss out Alfalma!

If you only go to one area in Lisboa, this is it.. Get yourself onto to GoLisboa website and print out their walking tour of this area. It is wonderful, medieval, white and yellow houses with wonderful pantile roofs. little terraces to sit on surrounded by bougainvillea and overlooking the Tagus Estuary Get away from the tourists on this walking tour and immerse yourself in the history.
Fascinating but tiring!!. This didtrict is a must see in any tour of Lisbon. It has an incedibly rich and diverse history representing lots of cultures.

Ramshackle charm. Had a great time making my way through this area, lots of nooks and crannies. Peacocks roaming, Monsieur Chat graffiti, great sunset views of the 25th of April bridge. We had a good dinner at Resto do Chapito.

Leave the Driving. We hired a tour guide from Lisbon Top Ten. Alex took us through the Alfama. The driving alone was a feat through this area. The Thief's Market is like navigating through the Grand Bazaar. Didn't actually stop to shop but Alex offered to drop us off. We visited so many areas of Lisbon would be hard pressed to describe all the delights of Lisbon and beyond. TopTenTours just a great way to see this lovely city, Sentra, Coimbra, Obidos and anywhere else you might want to travel. Highly recommend this company.
Gorgeous Spot. This is the area around the castle and is of the old style, which really appeals to a lot of people. Some gorgeous scenery

A must if you're visiting Lisbon. No visit to Lisbon can be deemed complete without a visit to this fantastic neighborhood. A real rabbit warren of alleyways and narrow streets, with many picturesque ancient buildings, some of which survived the 1755 earthquake as they were built on rock. This is a living, breathing community, with neighborhood shops and cafes, and its fair share of litter and graffiti.. Be prepared for steep climbs/steps as you negotiate your way around, but some of the views from the upper regions make your efforts worthwhile. Alternatively, take one of the tram tours for a whistle-stop, potted experience. Personally, I prefer to explore on foot, at my own pace.

Portuguese Fado. What a lovely evening to have a meal and listen a little bit of the portuguese fado. Really appreciate the moment, people with a huge attention to the singer. Was a really nice lady and what a voice.

Great area to wander and get lost in. Alfama is a fantastic area just to wander around and get lost in. Around every corner there is another surprise and there are lots of restaurants and cafes to stop off in to refresh yourself. Many of the building do look as if the need some TLC but that adds to the charm of the place.
The one area of Lisbon that I would return to. This area is lovely...cute little shops, great little streets, a flea market, a castle with peacocks and cats and wonderful people. Spend a day here!

MUST GO in Lisbon: just hard walks to do. A lot of stuff to see, castle and monastery, is the historical part of Lisbon, dont go at night because is not so safe, dont go just girls also in hided street!

Street parties and fado through the night. May seem rough to some but interesting to others. If you fancy a bit of local life, this is the district to go to. Feels vibrant, unpretentious and real. Lots of genuine revelry and the locals are friendly and welcoming. Dont miss out
Walk through Alfama. Took a walking tour through Alafma and enjoyed the history and the people. Very friendly. Check out Tina's homemade Ginjina at the corner of Beco Das Cruzes.

Robbed...please read crime entries on Trip Advisor re Alfama No 28 tram.. Have just returned from Lisbon following a five night stay. Was particularly interested in Lisbons Moorish history and so, as one might expect, the Alfama district was on our list of must sees. What an ugly experience we had! Headed up on the No 28 tram, full to bursting with tourists. An extremely clever robbery then took place on said tram, whereby we were 280 Euros poorer by the time we'd reached the castle! This robbery was perfectly executed by at least three men and an old woman. The old woman was standing at the side of the tram driver and as the bus was so crowded I thought she was being kind when she moved aside a little in order to make space for me. Wrong! This was done to subtly separate me from my husband who was then equally subtly surrounded by three men. Even though he had a zipped wallet attached to his front jeans pocket by a chain (this wasn't obvious to the eye), he was jostled by the men during the trams jerking movements but was unaware that they'd expertly removed the wallet from his pocket, unzipped it and removed every one last note. We were left with nothing. We had to walk for ages until we found a police station whose police officers almost yawned as they listened to our account of what had taken place. We spoke to several locals during the course of our week in Lisbon and were repeatedly told that tram 28 is a notorious pickpocket venue, the thieving gangs being known to police but that nothing was ever done to address the problem. We were informed that thieving gangs were rampant throughout Lisbon but that the Alfama area was particularly bad. Reading through Trip Advisor entries headed 'crime in Lisbon' or '28 tram Lisbon' etc one can see how serious a problem this is. My husband and I have travelled the world and realise that one finds crime against tourists everywhere. Our experience has shown us however, that crime is taken more seriously in some countries. Lisbon, including the Alfama area, really does need to get a grip on this. Locals informed us that the tram drivers, some restaurant owners and even the police were a part of the problem. Our own observations would support this view. Another thing which disappointed us immensely was that nowhere in the castle or the Amalfa area was there any public recognition or information of the centuries of Moors' rule. At best, there was an odd sentence making reference to it. Perhaps more might have been gained in this respect by being part of a tour. Who knows. One was left with the impression however that Portugals Moorish past was deliberately kept low key. The entry charge to the castle was in our opinion not worth paying unless you don't mind wandering aimlessly around the walls and admiring the view ( these same views can be enjoyed for free elsewhere). Even the cafe's inside the castle walls are nothing but overpriced tourist traps...junk food , plastic tables, pigeons pooing and eating off plates. Dreadful experience. I would strongly advise you to seek out the knowledge of a reputable local guide should you be really interested in the local history and not just meandering aimlessly around the streets. Using the services of a reputable local guide may well offer you a little protection from the local thieves too, although I wouldn't bank on it. Please, before travelling to Lisbon, do read the numerous accounts written on Trip Advisor and other sites on the serious, and rapidly increasing incidents of crime against tourists. We've been shocked by our own experience as well as by the experience of others. Lisbon really does need to address this problem seriously otherwise people, like us, will choose never to return.

Just mooch!. When the temperature is 35 degrees, you want to take it nice and slow. Alfama is the place to do this. Wander the backstreets and get lost and always manage to find yourself back at the water again. Lisbon is not so big! Feels like you are in some South American sleepy city rather than a buzzing European capital city. Lovely area of Lisbon. Recommended.

The Heart and Essence of Lisbon. After visiting the Cathedral of Lisbon wander the streets of the Alfama, stop for a a Sangria near the church in the cooling evening or consume a lunch of freshly grilled sardines in one of the typical Portuguese restaurants dotted all over this maze of charming, narrow streets.
St George's Castel. Great views, museum and history. Quite a climb...take a taxi to the top. Taxis are very reasonable, and this is one time you will want one!!
Enchanting ols section of Lisbon. Take several hours to wonder around go up to the Cathedral and Castle and have lunch. Plenty to see for most any interest.

The Hood. We stayed here in an apartment. This is all very old and authentic. The locals are so friendly. The food is not so good unless you like sardines and fatty sausage . But the atmosphere and Fado music make up for it. Go to Alfama!

Cute Neighborhood, but Beware of the Hills. I visited Alfama twice during my stay in Lisbon. The first with a walking tour when we took the trolley up and then walked down. The second was to visit the Saturday flea market. My first attempt at taking the Metro failed and I ended up at the wrong stop. I then tried to take the bus up, but got off too soon. I should have just taken the trolley again, but I wanted to try something new. I ended up walking up to Alfama and the flea market. Part of me was glad I did. I walked through some very tiny streets with mom and pop shops and restaurants throughout- great deals! I really got the feel of what a traditional Portuguese neighborhood is like. Once you get to the top the views made the hills worthwhile.

classic area of lisboa. classic area of lisboa with magnificent views of lisboa. take some time to walk around and explore to experience its charming, old european feel. duck into one of the many narrow cobblestone streets and find a quaint little inexpensive restaurant... we found one with the tastiest local cuisine; a huge meal for only 7euro.
old quarter, charming. character, good restaurants, historic area, good cafes people watching. water front area. don't miss it.

The "soul" of Lisbon. The Alfama is one of the many magical places in lisbon. Just stroll through its narrow corridors and you are transported back in time. You get to touch Lisbon's soul in this part of this wonderful city. My first trip to Lisbon...not my last though.

Good for fado. Alfama looks like a small village inside Lisbon, very traditional neighbourhood with small typical restaurants to listen fado . There you also have the fado museum witch is nice to visit. In the day time you can walk around and go up to the castle.

The Lisbon you probably imagine. Alfama echoes of a time long past. Find yourself meandering through its narrow cobblestone streets marked by men smoking in the windows and women hanging laundry on the line. We stopped at a random restaurant and had a delicious seafood dinner in a small alley - very scenic and a great memory.

Lisbon-the Old City. The Alfama is the oldest part of Lisbon. It was spared damage from the earthquake of 1755 because it was built on bedrock. The streets are narrow and are laid out in a somewhat haphazard fashion. It's a great place to view the interesting Moorish architecture and the beautiful Portugese tilework on the walls of the buildings.

A maze of original impressions. We had the pleasure to visit Alfama during the Santo Antonio Festival where the whole of Lisbon seems to be partying in this most ancient part of the city. Dancing people on the streets, colorful decorations and the smell of grilled Sardines in the air gave the place a special flair.But also outside the festival season, Alfama is well worth a visit. It is just fascinating to explore the maze of ancient alleys connecting smaller and bigger squares with restaurants, Fado bars and small shops. There's hardly a better place to get lost.

Less attractive than thought. We were told that Alfama was a must see in Lisbon but we remained a bit deluded by it. It was quite dirty and degradated, maybe nice for a nite tour to listen some fado, but to be honest there are best areas in Lisbon.

Nice Alfama. My appartment was in Alfama and it's incredible place to stay.You can hear fado all day long! But you have to walk and walk up and down and take yellow train to feel the streets and houses and people of Alfama.
Spectacular view from the hills. Very hilly and quite winding. Be prepared to walk. Once you get to the top, the view will blow you away! Simply awesome
Spectacular view from the hills. Very hilly and winding path upward the hills. Be prepared to walk but the view will blow you away! Simply spectacular!
Sheer enjoyment between steep narrow streets and strange angles. A good place to spend the day ,get lost and discover the history of the city and enjoy the stunning views

Great. out of time! must see. a bit touristy in some places but worthwhile. great to discover the history of the city and enjoy stunning views. be patient if you're waiting for the old tram where tourists and locals meet.

Distinctly tourist oriented. This is a must see in the city but you also have to keep in mind that you're doing the touristy thing if you go. No problem with that, just don't expect the real Portugal! Strange and interesting side streets, great little coffee shops, a good place to get lost. Spend a day and then go some place better.

Go with a guide. If you visit this place on your own, you won't be able to appreciate why it's very significant. The guide was able to show us places within Alfama that are significant and she was able to take us back in time. This explained how this hilly landscape of a city made Lisbon unique. Alfama reminds us visitors about the Portugal past and I enjoyed walking around.

Heart of Lisbon. The Alfama can be rather crowded with both tourists and partying locals, but that doesn't at all diminish its charm. Unlike quaint areas of say Paris or Prague the Alfama is still scruffy and cheap. And everywhere you wander there are steep narrow streets at strange angles, charcoal braziers grilling fish, little bars. Sheer enjoyment.

Great neighborhood. What a charming old neighborhood. We rented an apartment here for a few days while visiting the city and could not have been happier. The windy little streets, the trams, the little shops and restaurants, the beautiful architecture everywhere and the proximity to many attractions and sights made this an ideal neighborhood for us to stay in. It is safe and the locals are friendly but like any city it is always advisable to be careful at night and be aware of your surroundings at all times. Be aware that it is quite a hilly area of Lisbon so make sure you are wearing good, comfortable shoes when exploring the neighborhood. Certain areas tend to be more 'touristy' than others but there are many small local restaurants that we found to be quite good and which provided a great 'local' experience for us.
Lovely. Nice old streets lovely restaurants . Very enjoyable just wandering the back streets. Safe area no problems
Wonderful to explore!. Quaint, old part of Lisbon, and fun just to wander about. LOT's of hills - Be sure to wear shoes with traction!

how many little streets. we walk and walk for hours great people happy people festivities every were people selling drinks food on the streets and all the streets decorate for the june festivities little cobblestones stretts,small ally was wow just walk around get lost and restaurants, fado,people the buildings,wow you must come and see it your self

Quaint. Love how quaint this place is... somehow like it is still stuck in time. Among the narrow cobbled street you can sometimes see people cooking outside and children playing around. Definitely not to be missed! Maps are useless but enjoy getting lost!

Take the #12 or #28 trolley.... to the Largo (plaza) das Portas do Sol for nice views of the river and old town. The Decorative Arts Museum is just around the corner from there, and you will pass the cathedral on your way back via trolley.

Beautiful Place. Alfama is twisty, turny, rustic, pretty and full of surprises, the little hilly roads reveal many lovely restaurants and cafes and cute little shops. Had a lovely lunch in Alfama but can't remember the name of the cafe but it is fairly high up and it has a tram come past it that seems to squeeze a round a corner ridiculously close to a building.Some lovely architecture and a castle are to be found in Alfama - the views and vistas make great photography too

Touristy Neighborhood. This red-tiled roof neighborhood is charming, but my husband and I took all the work out of going up and down the steep, narrow streets by seeing it via a Segway tour! We went back in the early evening to listen to some Fado singing at a tiny restaurant (9 tables). The area is old and has some European charm and is being revitalized, but it has a long way to go.

Beautiful Alfama.... Alfama is magic itself... little portugueses streets full of charm...
Go for a walk, get lost and enjoy the view from a miradouro !

There is no Lisboa without Alfama.. You must see and walk (drive with tram 28) through Alfama. Even if you don`t enter any museums, stores, churches etc... go there. Go, look around, count the tiles on the buildings (kidding), absorb...
If you pay attention really well, you just might be catapulted to the beginning of 20th century ;)

Go as part of a tour so you know what your looking at.. Very unique neighborhood with it's style and narrow winding passages. I went with part of tour and it really helped as they helped guide me through and point out points of interest like the public laundry and showers, that I would have otherwise likely missed. Interesting too see, but once I saw it, I didn't seem much point in spending much time around there.
A labirynth of small streets. It is easy to get lost there! Nice atmosphere of Portugal. Probably not the best place to go when it is dark.
small narrow streets. Beautiful neighborhood, with narrow streets, and trams driving by with great views and little cafes and great music!

didn't match expectations. Made out as a must see - was pretty but not sure we saw it as we were meant to - tram decided to stop short of the full journey; castle was closed although no way of knowing it when we started the walk to it; did find a nice tourist shop at the castle which was open!! - would have been nice of them to offer us the VAT refund docs as we were obviously tourists .... other than that what we saw we saw elsewhere in pockets of Lisbon - other than some lovely views. Restaurants seem to be very tourist oriented ... so we went to Senor Vinho for a real fado evening instead
Where to spend the evening. Nice reasonable sidewalk restaurants, romantic curvy small streets, fado singing at several restaurants... Spend at least one evening in this area.

Must Visit. Get lost in the windy streets of Alfama, a charming and unique neighbourhood steep in history (as well as lots of steps and hills!). Here, you can hear the sounds of children playing, people's voices and music all coming from the homes with front doors open - there is a strong community feel that you can immeidately sense.During our wander we stumbled across a 'home kiosk' where a lady sells home-made ginjinha from her window! At 1€ each, we had a couple of them and went on about our merry way. The view from the many view points in Alfama is spectacular and there are usually kiosks/cafes serving non-alcoholic and alcoholic drinks. Perfect way to unwind after a long climb, sit back and enjoy the views.

Loose yourself in it's narrow streets.. It's the oldest part of Lisbon. Although it's poorest - it's safe. Has some great restaurants. Real, friendly people. Very nice architecture. Save whole afternoon for it.

One of the Best Old Towns. Beautiful, meandering streets and excellent photo ops. Must be fabulous in June as they were starting decorations for the community festival. Lots of steps and cobblestones.
Lots to see - a visual feast. There are so many photo opportunities. It seemed every corner we turned there was someone grilling a fish streetside, an outdoor elevator, some other great photo op

Cute stroll through old town. Great place to get lost and explore the winding streets of old Lisbon. Not a lot of commercial activity when we went (no cute boutiques or other local places, seemed mostly residential), but a really beautiful part of the city that is worth exploring on foot.
Great Views. Take the trolley/tram #28 all the way up and enjoy the views. You can easily walk down from there as it is all down hill.
A wonderful, authentic area of Lisbon. We stayed in the Alfama and wished we had more time to explore the tiny alleyways. We did find 3 very good restaurants within walking distance of our apartment.
the time has stopped. Definitely you should see it. You've got a feeling that the time over there has stopped-old buildings, atmosphere.

Must visit. Dont go with a big group. You will be annoying and likely wont truly enjoy it. But do go and take leisurely strolls through the neighborhoods. Say hello to the local residents, most of whom will speak no language other than Portuguese but will be friendly and smile. Stop for a coffee and perhaps pick out a pastry. The churches are less touristy and the area is just fantastic.

The heart of Lisbon. Some may say that the heart of the city is Bairro Alto, or some other neighborhood - but for me, I would say that it is Alfama. Jose Saramago, Portugal's Noble-prize winning novelist, called Alfama "a mythological beast" and commented regarding the tourist's quest to get to know the neighborhood, "in the secret of its houses there must be a lot of mirth at the expense of anyone who thinks he can know it after spending an evening there."Well, after staying in an apartment there for 10 days and wandering the area's streets and riding the trams up and down, I don't know if I can say that I "know" Alfama. But I loved what I saw. The atmospheric surroundings, the twisting narrow streets, the old dilapidated buildings, etc., it all captivated me, it captured my imagination. I couldn't imagine staying anywhere else in Lisbon.

A neighbourhood lost in time... Alfama is purely magical. You can lose yourself for hours walking the streets and soaking in the living history of this area. It is full of little restaurants, great views and rich with textures. Bring your camera!

Labyrinth!. This is a fun place to get lost in!! The local restaurants also offer "Free Fado"....but it isn´t really free because you pay a lot for the drinks....(12€ for a large beer, 30€ for a small bottle of wine). But the Fado is authentic and the food isn´t bad, so it´s much better to enjoy Fado here than in one of the touristy concert halls in Alto Barrio.

Cobbled streets. Very interesting stories behind Alfama and also, the cobbled streets, winding little roads and red rooftops are all typical of this old town. Go with the walking tour of Alfama and you will definitely not forget some of the stories told, the half day walk will be more than worth it!
Pretty area near the ocean. This is a very characteristic hilly neighborhood with many narrow streets, outdoor cafes and authentic Fado restaurants.
Amazing!. If you only wander through one neighborhood of Lisbon, this should be it. Narrow streets with many steps, it is historic, quirky, and charming. Don't miss it!
A place to visit. The old part of Lisboa, despite of tourists it is still authentic, go there if you wanna discover the real Lisboa

tram 28 + this is it!. When you are in Alfama you need to take 28 tram - it is almost obligatory. You will be able to see all those fantactis buildings on the way of the tram. But be sure you sit down near window! What I found nice about Alfama is that you can get lost there but you will always find your way out! The buildings are astonishing. And if you go there quite early you will not see many tourists - just people eating their breakfasts somewhere in the nice caffeterias.

Amazing district to explore. This very steep and ancient part of Lisbon is absolutely worth the walking. With little restaurants of only a few tables, a fascinating castle, the number 28 tram, tiny little winding streets and lovely buildings, you can spend ages just wandering and exploring!

Loved the mysterious, winding streets.. We walked around Alfama a couple different times during our visit, even took a bike tour through one day. It's the oldest section of Lisbon and the multiple narrow twisting streets and alleys prove mysterious as well as historical. Of course the castle is there, worth a visit, as well as the many shops sprinkled on every street. We were told not to walk around at night in Alfama, so we didn't - but during the day we never felt nervous.

My favourite part of Lisbon. We stayed in Alfama on our recent trip. Its beautiful. We stayed in an apartment with a sea view, and there was nothing better of an evening that sitting on our balcony listening to the sounds of Fado drifting up from the restaurant below... Amazing

Historic area with great charm. Take the number 28 tram and just get off somewhere near the castle. You can wander round all these lovely old streets and soak in the Portuguese charm. Beware the restaurants,as some are overly touristified! But TA recommends some so it's worth checking and booking in advance rather than just wandering into to one as we did.

Essential to explore if you want to be able to say you've been to Lisbon. Oldest part of Lisbon, survived the 1755 earthquake, occupied by the generation who've lived there their whole lives. Interesting alleyways and streets, with original building facades and activities, including washing on the lines out the windows. Shoc not be missed by anyone visiting Lisbon.

Peacocks are flying? And sleeping on a tree?. Upon early arrival we were up to scroll the oldest part of Lisboa. Taking a metro to arrive to Santa Apolonia, we just went uphill and found out a wonderful surprise - it was the last hour of Feira da Ladra flee market and it was absolutely amazing! So many things you see and the atmosphere was great! Funny stuff offered along real antiquities. Churches were mainly already closed but the famous Se cathedral was open. Orange trees, Jasmine trees...I cant describe the nice smell coming from them. We like walking uphill, coming from an alpine country so we took the famous tram 28 upon our way down to visit Castelo Sao Jorge. We came during the daylight and stayed until it was completely dark. Spectacular views are provided and you'll enjoy the company of several peacocks. They yell all the time so you hear them wherever you move. Nice. I'm not sure if there are more peacocks or cats. If you doubt if it's worth visiting - dont. An absolute must for everyone. Nearby is an original souvenirs shop called "A Arte da Terra" and it happened for the first time on our trips that we bought souvenirs the very first day :))And another thing: we stayed for 9 days, being outside all the time, driving ferries, trams, busses, metros even a helicopter. But nobody robbed us or tried to sell us drugs. Special regards to Mafalda, who escorts us to Baixa-Chiado metro station and to her friend from Uruguay, who sadly we dont remember the name.

Alfama. The best way to get there is definitively by taxi which can be hired at the bottom of the hill. The Castle of St. George was kind of dissapointing, but well worth the senior rate for tickets. In all, it is a very picturesque place to visit.

Walking tour from Eyewitness Guide. We took ourselves on the walking tour of the Alfama from the Dorling Kindersley Eyewitness Guide and it was just great. Off the beaten track, up little stone staircases, through little alleyways and courtyards. Yes, we got last a couple of times - but surely that's part of the fun! The Alfama is a charming area to wander through and explore.

Marvelous view. This area is one of the best parts of Lisbon.Marvelous view from the hill, nostalgic trams, lovely small streets...It is definitely worth to visit... particularly when it's a beautiful day!

Old and new in harmony. Fascinating old area with stunning modern additions. Try the modern cafe terrace overlooking the old town and view of the river, then climb the stairs to the castle.Just brilliant.

Up, up and away. Alfama is the oldest section of Lisbon, and famously survived the 1755 earthquake relatively intact because it is built on a bedrock of stone. Alfama is a charming neighborhood of hills and zig-zagging narrow streets past old houses with their wash hung out to dry. Main streets are plagued by the touristy shops that sell postcards and little cockerel magnets, but just keep going. There are several gorgeous churches here: we saw the Madalena, the St. Anthony and the Se, or Cathedral (we tried without success to find out which of the two bell towers was the one an angry crowd threw the Spanish bishop out of during a war with Spain). Keep going up...there is a wonderul miradouro (view) across from the Museum of Decorative Arts. Somewhere (we never found it) is the remains of a Roman theater. Then, finally, at the top, you find (no signage! keep asking people!) St. George's Castle. You can walk along the walls and check out the great views. There isn't much in the way of interior space (except a cafe and restaurant) but there are peacocks and if you are lucky one will display. Then it's back down, by foot or tram. At the bottom somewhere is the Fado Museum but we skipped that and decided to go to a fado concern instead.
April in Portugal. Took a very interesting guided tour of the Alfama neighborhood. History & scenery & entertainment combined!!

Walking tour. Alfama walking tour is a must, you will enjoy the views on the city from each and every street, as well as beautiful cathedrals and also you can visit the Castello de San Jorge which is also in Alfama neighborhood.

Just wander. So cute, so old school, so beautiful. Pick a random street, pick some random stairs, and see where you end up. Don't forget to look up. The iron balconies, the beautiful lamp posts, so picturesque. I loved this area and can't wait to come back for my next wander.

Steep narrow streets, old houses.... To get a feeling of Lisbon it's worthwhile walking around this old "bairro" not far from the city's center. As you first enter the district from downtown you can visit the old cathedral. Coninuing up, up and up you reach the Santa Luzia viewpoint, where you get a fine view of the city and Tagus (Tejo) River. There are worthwhile museums too: of Portuguese decorative arts and of the traditional music. The ruins of the Roman theater and the castle are nearby too.

Ancient part of city. A bit run down but fascinating network of streets in a working class area that has not changed much since the thirteenth century. Impressive views of the harbour as the area sloped down to it. Lower part is full of fado bars (can recommends A Baiuca, 20 rua de Sao Miguel - tel: 218852704 - if you want one that does not go on too late; it closes at midnight; reservation advised)

The castle area or better: the maze!. Alfama is the famous area around the Castelo, it's a total maze of narrow streets going up- and downhill, with nice views from higher ground over the 7 hills of Lisbon. You'd see a lot of old buildings with tiles on your trip to the castle, but I would recommend to visit the district at daylight because after sunset the area seems to change its face.
Charming. Good place for you if you enjoy narrow, old streets with surprises around every corner. Lively restaurants and interesting shops.

May Favorite Neighborhood!. I loved walking around this neighborhood. We went to the flea market that is held on Saturday and Tuesday. On the way back we just walked through the different streets in this neighborhood not knowing where we were going. It was a lot of fun to see the different buildings.

atmospheric. lots of intimate winding streets. Can look a bit scruffy with graffiti etc but that's all part of the charm. Be prepared for some steep walks! A place that seems untouched by time over the last 50 years. A really interesting way to spend an afternoon and evening.

Enjoyed getting lost in Alfama. We stayed in Graca and spent a lot of time wandering around in Alfama, trying to find our way back. I swear the streets of Alfama move around like the stairs in Hogwarts, you think the route home is very straightforward but still manage to get completely lost in the little streets! The people are very friendly though and even walk with you part of the way when you ask for directions.
Nice. And traditional...a must see in Lisbon. pleanty of restaurants with traditional food and also to listen "Fado's"...
Fado. Very nice small streets and a Fado in almost each place at the evening. Loved walking there at the day and at the night.

A WANDER-ful workout and a great slice of Lisbon's personality.. A short review: we had a great time walking up and down the twisted old streets of the Alfama, soaking up the textures and sights of the buildings decorated in glazed tiles and rustic paint jobs. It was a photographer's dream! The kind of place taht you could go back to time and time again, all through the day, and never see the same lighting or shadow twice. A wonderful place to wander.

Lots of walking uphill and down, lots of atsmosphere!. This is a fun area to explore, but be prepared with good walking shoes, as it's a lot of up and down hills. Narrow alleys, laundry hanging on high, cobblestones, and great views, and a castle on the top- what's not to like? We had three Fado experiences here- the best was in a tiny restaurant where even the kitchen staff sang!
Winding through the narrow streets is fun. If you go the Castelo do walk down through the Alfama. it is such an interesting and ancient neighbourhood.
Lovely district to visit but hilly. Definitely atmospheric but you need to be agile - Moorish history and narrow little streets.Very steep.

Great Medieval Part of Lisbon. It's a great hilly, medieval old part of Lisbon with so many places of interest, it can take a month to fully enjoy. A longer weekend is still fine if you limit yourself to short sighseing, walking down the streets (actually walking up the streets :)). You can take the tram up the cathedral and start you sightseeing from there.

Superb experience. Great walk up the hill and advice to go with sport shoes. you will find lots of small places to eat and enjoy to listen to fados along the walk up. Love the experience of feeling Portugese with the art on the building. Reaching the castle, you may find an old tree that look wierd with the gigantic root growing on the rocks. Your destination should set at the castle, with the rooftops view, the typical contour+building of Portugal scenary with fados was really the great experience. unforgatable and wish to return again loves one.

Worth a visit. Take the tram up to the Cathedral and then wander around the little streets. The Castle has magnificent views and is worth the entrance fee. The Thieves Market if a treasure trove of oddities, from church vestments to handmade jewellery - you could spend hours there. There are some interesting little cafes with good daily menus dotted about too.
Great views and history. Wonderful district near the castle. Love the rooftops seen from here. A nice stopping off point. Get up there by tram.
Scenic old town of Lisbon. Nice ambiance,lots of small places to eat or listen to fados.The cons are lots of traffic in small streets and going up and down the hill all the time.
Nice walk. Set yourself a destination, and try to get there. It underlines the intricacies in a fun way. Great fun.

Where the real Lisbon is to be found. Running down from the Castelo Sao Jorge to the banks of the Tagus, this tortuous and colourful district epitomizes what makes Lisbon such an attractive city. Steps replace vertical streets at many places, and passageways burrow between and even through the houses of the local inhabitants. In one of its larger squares, the Museum of Fado is to be found. The Cathedral doesn't enjoy such good fortune and is squeezed out by the surrounding buildings. The Museum of Decorative Art, the lovely Mirador of Santa Luiza, and several churches are embedded within its boundaries. But even without any of these highlights, the district still holds terrific charm arising from its quaint shops, bars and restuarants, a high proportion of which offer entertainment ( predominantly Fado ) with dinner. The emblematic Lisbon tramcar threads its way onwards and upwards. Multicoloured washing hangs between the sides of the narrower streets, and the smells of wine and food stimulate thirst and appetite. A poorer, down to earth area, but no slum, and with a charm and dignity all its own, Alfama deserves to be savoured by any visitor anxious to acquire and take away haunting memories of the authentic city and its kindly, honest, working people.
So exciting ,like going back in time. It's an old city within the city. Never seen anything like it before. Old restaurants and stores, homes that are hundreds of years old.

Beautiful Area with great views!. Area is gorgeous! Beautiful to walk around and even nice to sit and enjoy a coffee/wine/beer with a beautiful view on old Lisbon and the river with big cruise ships docking.Taking a ride in a small yellow tram around the area is experience on its own!
beautiful place, and great singing. we had a lovely evening meal at an alfama restaurant and they even sang happy birthday to me in their local language.

History and Heritage of Old Lisbon. You must visit Alfama while in Lisbon. You can take the Tram 28 to the end and wander down the hill. It is the old city and many little streets to explore. Just meander your way down the hill and stop at St Jorge overlook for a spectacular view.
Looking at real life. This felt like an insight into how the real Lisboetas went about their everyday lives. Busy, bustling back streets filled with quirky views.

Must visit to know the old Lisbon. Oldest part of lisbon - nice history, tiny, social neighbourhood. You get the feel of old lisbon village. You forget you are in the city though the city centre is 5 minutes walk away. You can see a community slowing fading away due to changes in attitudes and lifestyle.Graffitti every where - Lisbon municipality need to do something about it. Ruins the whole experience.

Must see!!. Very interesting and very significant part of the history of Lisbon. Take a walk with Paolo from Lisbon Explorer to really understand and get a sense of what this area is all about and why it's so important.

Take a stroll. Just give yourself some time and walk up and down some stairs/streets in this old quarter in Lisbon near the castle. The streets may become more narrow every time you change your direction, the tourists become fewer until you get a very authentic feeling with the laundry outside the windows, men talking in the streets, women talking from one window/house to another together.I felt a bit lost (in a good way) and always safe. Well worth a visit!
Great place to get lost. With many dark alleys and winding roads its the perfect place to get lost and find many hidden art shops, cafes and local business. The locals are very genuin and simple...

You'll enjoy it!. Take tran # 28 at the tram stop near hotel Mundial close to Rossio square and just go the whole route. This tran is one of Portugal's main attractions by itself, it is so cute and charming. Don't forget to validate your ticket though, fine are big in Portugal! Go all the way up and just enjoy narrow streets and beautiful views. Get off by Castle, and go down to Cathedral, you'll ennjoy the walk by itself...

Delightful!. Hilly, charming streets with quaint little restaurants (every meal a joy), homes of a warm neighborhood, laundry flapping in the breeze, brightly colored tiles, fado music in the air. Ah, Alfama! I truly loved it!

a popular down market area... this is a down market area of Lisbon which u visit to c the tourist attraction and to listen to the Fado music which is v popular here.u just go through the streets to get the feel of real old lisbon.
Aflame known for Fado. Fado is a must to do on ur visit to Portugal , the music take u back to the old days of beautiful singers and artist , sad n happy songs with lots of story and character .

Go to Lisboa Past. Small streets, Small house doors. One room width, 3-4 floors tall houses, stairs everywhere, windows with negligible balconies, color, friedly people on the streets.
It is Old Lisboa inside the castle.
Go there with your photo camera.
Fascinating neighborhood. It was very old world like wandering the narrow streets up and down the hills. Quaint bars and restaurants are all over and the Portugese music cafes are plentiful.

Lovely area. Spent a nice day rambling in this and the castle area. Walk up the hill not suitable for everyone but worth it for the views. Narrow streets and old buildings. Very picturesque, Could do with more signs to Castle entrance - we were not the only ones looking a little perplexed.

Must Visit Place.. Wandering the narrow streets in this district with the stunning views over the city and the beach is a 'must visit place' when in Lisbon. You don't need to take the tram 28 (which is expensive), but it is an uphill walk from the centre of modern Lisbon, but worth it. You find lots of little craft shops and tiny bars on the way into Alfama.It is an excelelnt location for photographers as there are beautiful views and interesting architecture at every turn in the winding roads. The decorative trams set against the old town buildings make colourful pics. Stop for a glass of wine to rest those tiring feet, at just 1 euro a glass and you can watch the world go by while writing those postcards home!

in love. That was the district that I loved the most in Lisbon thanks to its authenticity. Just steps from the main attractions, it was just amazing getting lost into those tiny little streets and getting to see lisboetas in their original setting. Plus, you can never imagine the places you can discover in that labyrinth-like district. Either restaurants, either fado houses, either nice little bars or alternative little stores, you name it, it's all here! Just adored it!

You come to Lisbon for this ........ We bought the guide books and once we saw th pictures of Alfama area, we have decided to extend our holidays to visit Lisbon. Metro Stop : Martim Moniz. Look for the Lisbon famous Tram 28. ( if you buy the 1 days pass of Metro, you could use it for tram 28 FREE )We took the Tram 28 ( beware of pickpockets) admiring all the narrow streets with wonderful buildings decorated with the tiles, cobbled alleys twisting all the way uphills. We went straight to Castelo de Sao Jorge early morning. Enjoy the absolutely money well worth scenery up at castle, then we had lunch right opposite the castle. Wonder down the areas consists of Alfama, Graca and Castelo and enjoy the scenery of moorish buildings, typical daily life Lisbon ie clothings hanging out, great pictures takings everywhere, infront of the Church SE, sloping downhill, one of the best spots to wait for the tram 28 to curve up or curve down infront of SE for a superb snapshots.Lots of souvenirs shops along the way. We walked all the way down to Baixa / praca do comercio areaa and took us almost whole day for this trip from 1st tram ride up to castle.

one of the most charming neighborhoods. We took the tram no 28, meandering through the streets, marveling at the beautiful and colorful houses. Your visit to Lisbon is incomplete without a visit to the Alfama district.
charming. Only in certain towns can buildings and neighborhoods look so old and dilapidated but at the same time be so picturesque charming and inviting. A must for all visitors to see
Original!. The oldest and original place in Lisbon.It synonym of the best pictures in this city!Fado, Castle, Sightseeing places and the old Flea Market.Everything to see and discover is in Alfama!
Old fashioned. Hilly part of city, unbelievably hilly in fact. Loved the old little trams running up and down the hills like dodgems.
Quaint and fun. Walking around the Alfama district was a highlight of our tour. The twisting streets, red roofs and sense of authenticity and real life in Portugal were delightful.

Old city centre. Alfama offers a lot. A castel, a cathedral, the Museum of Roman Theatre, narrow streets, great restaurants, beautiful views. One can get lost while walking in the narrow streets, but one still feels great. One can get to it with the tram N. 28. The tram drives all the way to Chiado. If possible get a hostel in this quarter. But don't get there with a car. The streets are narrow, there is practically impossible to get a parking space.
have fun getting lost!. This area is great for an afternoon stroll..and finding a cafe and people watching over a glass of good (and cheap) red wine
A maze. This is an old neighbor in the heart of Lisbon. Though some fantastic views, there is a lot of hills to walk up and down! Be prepared!

A tiring but nice picturesque tour.. One of Lisbon's best historical tours is the Alfama district. An old neighborhood and one of the most typical of Lisbon. It comprises the neighborhoods named Frequesias of São Miguel, Santo Estêvão e São Vicente de Fora. The word Alfama derives from the Arabic al-hamma which means baths or fountains and Alfama’s water comes from a group of mineral and medicinal springs associated with a geological failure that throughout history were piped to feed its fountains. Alfama is a tangle of narrow slopes, with clothes strung ropes hanging from the windows, adorned apartments, houses of fado and streetcars. You can walk up and down admiring the cable cars full of tourists from worldwide.Walking up and down the cobblestone streets can be very tiring if you are not a fit person. Go with a guided group to avoid pitfalls. It's easy to get lost and be fooled by someone malicious.If you are not familiar with the region avoid walking there at night.What is a must in the region:. Mr. Fado restaurant. Rua dos Remedios 176.. Santo Antonio de Alfama restaurant. St. Michael Alley 7.. Crafts shops.. The facades of old tiles.. The Fado museum.
You have to visit. Had a lot of fun walking through the very narrow streets of this area , going uphill is a little bit tough but compensated by going down on your way back.

very picturesque and so Lisbon, so non-EU. It's so unique to walk along those narrow lanes and passageways. Up and down stairs, shunning cars as they pass by taking in the sidewalk too. At times it feels like a medina in a northern African country. Other, like a southern Italian small town. But the colorful facades and the tiles make it distinctly Lisbon. No EU money seems to be flowing into that area.
Interesting. The small narrow roads and alleyways in Alfama are lovely to walk around, fairly hilly and cobblestones so wear flat shoes. The whole area is full of little shops and restaurants.

Just walk around & get lost in the back streets. There's lots of view points, amazing streets with the famous tiles on unique buildings. Lots of "mom & pop" restaurants. Photo opps are everywhere, it's on the way to the castle, you can get team 28 here is you can't be bothered to walk, but the walking is where the magic is

Amazing. I liked Alfama most of all the sights. The way it has been built is just so typical of the local culture and customs. Going for a walk through it, starting down and all the way up, towards dusk was just perfect. Being at sunset at the top and having a beer or wine at a terrace enjoying Portuguese music and those amazing views from bellow made me feel what Lisbon is all about. Felt a little bit unsafe on some of the small dark streets, tho...

Lovely area of Lisbon. Lots of hills so this area may be challenging for some who are not physically able to walk or are not in the greatest of shape. Windy alleys and surprises at every turn. Great restaurants in the area. Has the best meal here - cataplana.

Multinational neighborhood. Colorful narrow mourish style streets. Dark, narrow, fresh street with a past of nostalgic memories of FADO (portuguese national folk song/muisic). Nowadays is a popular destination for the young people searching for multicultural experiences. Expect diversity but beware of the environment. Search for advice regarding the places where not to go.

only if you have a free mind. a beautiful old neighbourhood, very small streets, steep stairs, beautiful views of the city and the river.the place isn't the fenciest one or the cleanest, but it has a lot of harm if you can see beneath old wall paintings.there are great retaurants around, having the feeling your are in someone's dining room, not in a restaurant.people are friendly and helpful, but be aware of the pickpockets.
charming old neighborhood. Bring sneakers because the neighborhood is nothing but hills. It's charming, though, and well worth a visit.

Great Music. My wife and I were in Lisbon in June 2012. We had a tour that took us into the Alfama neighborhood during the day. We loved it so much that we came back at night and had dinner and enjoyed the great Fado music. Very relaxing night, nothing crazy. One reviewer was right, make sure you go to the top and enjoy the great scenery.
How picturesque!. Do not miss the view from one of the mirador before you start exploring this very picturesque barrio. So, go up as much as you can and then visit Alfama coming down

Great Fado music. Go in the daylight first and get your bearings. It's easy to get lost in the winding streets. Go back after dark for some great music. If the fado clubs are too pricey, just stand on the streets with a beer in your hand and listen!
Tile decorated houses and fado. Places to hear fado, the spirit of Portugal, and lovely old houses decorated with multicoloured tiles. Enter a different world.

see it but other sights in Lisbon are more interesting. Interesting and pleasant enough but not the most interesting old town I've seen. But there are plenty of sights to make Lisbon well worth visiting.
avoid. avoid this part of the town, very poor, dirty, scaring. the tram 28 is not worth-overcroweded, thieves, expensive tickets.
Very good food and ambience.. A bit priced, but the staff is quite professional. The place is quite amazing and does not need decoration.

Authentic. A very charming part of Lissabon. It's fun to get lost in the little alleys, to walk up and down, watch the daily business going on etc. If you are not a lazy person, just take your time, walk around, and enjoy the atmosphere!
alfama. old lisbon at its best restaurants abound ,lane ways with 18th century buildingsS see it by tram or by foot

The Life of Portugal. The Alfama district is a must see when in Lisbon. There are multiple Fado houses, (small and really small restaurants and bars in the area that have live Fado music). A very historical place to visit, (one house dates back to 500 AD).The city is really trying to reclaim this area and the improvements are noticeable. Great restaurants and people. I felt completely safe.

Wonder or blunder?. To us, Lisbon was disappointing, especially the old town that is very dirty, with lots of abandoned like buildings that smell of urine, especially in the morning. The maps are horrible, we bought 4, and we could hear everyone complaining about the same issue. I wouldn't recommend having dinner in Alfama, the prices displayed outside have nothing to do with the real thing (we ended up paying more than double)! They try to make money out of everything, but you don't always get what you paid for! Make sure you always ask before hand what's the final rate for the product/service you want to purchase, otherwise you might have a great surprise!
Walk, walk and walk.. Take the 28th to the top of the mountain (OK, a taxi, if you are afraid of pickpockets) and go down walking slowly by the wonderful streets of the Alfama. You won't forget it.

a step back in time.. One of those places you really think you are in a film. In the evening the place comes to life with the many fado houses and the crowds, but during the day the place is also okay to cvisit and you can take nice photos from there. Although it looks unsafe, the place is very safe, I have been 3 times there and never seen or heard of any crime around there. just sit at a bar outside and see the world pass by.

The real old Lissabon. We just loved to go up and down (and up and down again) the old streets of this popular neighbourhood, where people hang their clothes to dry outside the window, with very small eateries and coffee shops, sometimes with fado, and birds chirping from the balconies.
Old Lisboa. For a step back into old Lisboa complete with steep narrow streets of Calcada and hidden restauarants with the echo of Fado music echoing, Alfame is a must see.

Where you get lost and itsna good thing. A place to be a 'flaneur' and let yourself to get lost. See the streets, the architecture, the people (ask everyone about how to get to anywhee you want and experience the most valuable atraction of the city!), the signs (read them all!), and everything that you can. It could only be more provided with touristic information, 'cause this is the older area of Lisboa. Could be more well treated on this matter.

don't be afraid of getting lost. We stayed at a rental apartment in Alfama. At first I was afraid that I'd get lost in all of the alleys, but I soon realized that most paths lead to the same place eventually, so if I kept going up (or down), I'd eventually come to some place that I recognized. The alleys are also well-lit at night. Great restaurants in the lower portions of the area and incredible views from the mid-level areas. Wandering in the area really gives you a sense of how modern people live in this ancient section of town. Tram 12 makes a loop through the area and is an efficient way to get to the mid-levels. I'm glad we had the chance to stay there!

Traveling Back In Time. This extremely scenic district in Lisbon is one of the oldest settlements within the city still intact after the devastating 1755 earthquake. Wandering the endless, narrow cobble streets, and alleys offers scenic rewards around every bend. Each street is teeming with life, local restaurants, Fado bars, bakeries, coffee bars, churches, fountains, inhabited palaces, apartments, houses strewn with hanging laundry, public bath houses, abound every where. Numerous photographic opportunities, and quaint vistas are quickly stumbled upon. Touristy, but locally lived in and vibrant. A visit to Lisbon would not be complete without seeing, this walkable gem.

historic & picturesque. These houses ,many from 16 century ,make up a framework of alleys and steps are really irregular. It's not only an area for daily life, but also for many artists and designers.It's lively and elegant.I really enjoy climbing around Alfama area and taking photos of those fantastice tiles, tin glaze porcelains in all colors.However, u have to pay attention to the public society. 4 girls ahead of me was robbed. Thanks for
Historic Lisbon. One of the must-see neighbourhoods. Walk around for hours and soak in local culture and architecture, then have a shot of Ginginha (cherry liqueur) before heading for a nice meal.

Good to just have a wander. With the right weather the Alfama is a great area to just go for a wander wherever the mood takes. Many small cafes and bars and loads of steps and steep hills too! Take the bus or tram to the top of the hill be the castle and just wander down from the castle through the Alfama!
Portuguese Folklore. Many times I have climbed up to enjoy the music of the Alfama. The true singing of the Alfama is the sad folklore that you will hear here
the walking tour. The hostel took us to the walking tour and it was perfect. This ancient part of the town is full of magic.

authentic and cozy. Nice to walk around in this cozy part of Lisbon. Narrow alleys, laundry hanging outside, neighbors talking at street corners, children play in the streets - a charming insight into everyday life.

Alfama: to find out the deep soul of the city. If you go to Lisboa, don't miss to pay a visit in this charming area! Here you can find out a great atmosphere, the real charcter of this incredible city. Don't forget your camera, as well, because a lot of wonderful sights from the top of the hill.

like meandering through the medina in Tangier. The Alfama is a maze of twisting and turning alleyways posing as streets. There are tons of small mom and pop restaurants at every turn and two of the city’s miradouros with great views out over the city and out to the river. I would recommend you start at the top by St. George’s Castle and walk downhill through this lively neighborhood. There are many things to see and do in the Alfama, none more important that Cathedral Se and the Tram 28 (Pickpocket Express).
A maze (i was glad to have a guide). I loved the walking tour around the quarter which would have been hard without the walking tour guide as this is truly a maze
smells and sounds of Lisbon.. Alfama is the old part of the city with little shops, restaurants and the typical pastelaria where you can enjoy the delicious sweets of Lisbon at a really cheap price.

Lisbon's Soul. The people are amazing, the arts and crafts you can buy as souvenirs, the restaurants to eat nice grilled fish and drink typical out of the box red wine, to ear Fado for free, and just absorb the streets beauty. Lisbon is not Chiado and its youth, it's Alfama, the great old granny!

Mwah, Beautiful but touristic and expensive. It's nice but its a little bit like disneyland. A lot of tourists and they want to get money out of everything. If you go here you will spend at least 40 euro's per person.

Worth the walk. This area is hilly but well worth walking arround. Cobble stoned litttle winding streets, tramcars and quaint Portuguese shops and restaurants, this is also one of the key areas for Fado with dinner.It's very trendy and Bohemian, but the friendly restauranteurs and locals make it very much the Portugal most people go to see.

Nice quarter. Alfama is the oldest quarter of Lisboa and has many little streets and old houses. You can take one of the Electricos to avoid climbing every street. In Alfama is a popular Cathedral and a great bookshop where you can buy books about Lisboa in many different languages.
