A typical neighbourhood in Lisbone. A very typical place where to walk around. I wouldnt recommend having dinner, its very expensive and not top at all.
Alfama, district of Lisbon, Portugal. Very dirty and crowded. Lots of graffiti everywhere. A lot of the buildings look abandoned. not impressed

Walk it, if you can. The tram is often presented as the best way to see Alfama. Not true. If you are physically able, then walking it is absolutely amazing. Let yourself get lost in the maze of tiny streets. It's OK. As long as you've got a decent map of Lisbon in general, you won't be lost for long. There are many landmarks and larger streets that make it easy to find your way back. And if you're not great with a map, then find your way to the the tram tracks and follow them back down.
Good for Fado. Windey alleyways, lots of history, the centre of the Fado.............bars and cafes etc churches, It was good I am filling up space to get to 50 characters

Wander and wonder. The mournful sounds of Fado followed us down meandering lanes that are ancient and interesting after a wonderful meal in Alfama.
San Antonio restaurant.

Colour of Lisbon. A bit exhausting, but worth of exploring. Alfama is one of the most beautiful neighborhoods of Lisbon. Spend your time around the small streets, enjoy the architecture and the feeling of being somewhere outside the city
Amazing. Not be missed if you are in Lisbon. Take tram 28 from Martim Moniz. That's the second best way to see this district. The first is by foot.

Walking the cobbles of Alfama. I loved this area of Lisbon, particularly late afternoon, early evening, when the locals are moving about and conversing with each other across the narrow streets from their doorways or windows.
Loved it!. Great place to explore and take pictures. We enjoyed the winding streets and the over looks. This was our favorite area in Lisbon and it exceeded our expectations

One of the most characteristic neighborhoods of Lisbon. This is one of the most famous neighborhoods of Lisbon, for its tradition, as well as for being one of the oldest city of Lisbon. widely known for its house of fado, but also for its typicality.

Great place to explore. I really enjoyed walking in the streets of Alfama, there is something to discover or to admire at every corner of street. Worth walking up and down the narrow street and enjoying the great atmosphere.

Winding streets with little shops. One of the areas of Lisbon more preserved in character and form as less affected by 1755 earthquake. We walked through the neighborhood down the hill after visiting the castle. Enjoyed the winding streets and little shops. Stopped at the Fado museum but it was closing soon.

worth a look. went to the Sat flea mkt-huge! easy to get to, watch for pickpockets on the trolley (mother with 3 kids!)- found a culinary center that promotes Portuguese products (food and wine-very unique)and cooking-
Area Safe and quaint. Lovely cobbled stone winding streets with frequent tram service. Great feeling of being at the heart of Lisbon life.

lovely in early evening. enjoyed a stroll and some nice bars. Including some Fado and outdoor food. Note most music does not start until after 11pm. Some parts of the area felt a little uncomfortable at night.
Great Character. Little windy streets emerging to great views over the sea. Trams packed full battling up the hills. Could not be bothered to queue for the Castle. See the picture of the pissoir!

Favorite Saturday ... This is my favorite part of town to wander around on Saturday..walk to the Flea Market and then walk down finding interesting streets and great food! Always find great food no matter where we stop!

FUN TO WALK THROUGH. This is a beautiful, quaint little area of Lisbon. It is much smaller than I expected, and newer. The original area was destroyed by a big earthquake around 1855, and the Alfama was rebuilt in the same style. We had lunch in the Praca della Luz, and loved the view. Walking around the little lanes and roads was fun, but we were warned to watch our belongings, and be careful at night. We did not venture into the Alfama at night - although we felt safe during the day, we did worry about walking around at night.
The best spot for views & culture!. This area is very charming area, you can see the beautiful views from the hill and having a coffee & local sweets.
Alfama. Great place to visit. We went on a tourist bus but the 28 tram goes up the hill too. The main attractions were the castle, the museum of Fado and the narrow streets in between.

Great Fado Night. Our first introduction to Fado was at the very intimate Mesa de Frades where we had a great night with the locals. We were the only tourists there and the music was wonderful, the food good and the wine plentiful.

Picturesque quarter. It is a very old district, with a Mauresque atmosphere, houses with colourful tiles and many small boutiques.The streets are narrow and sloping and you should take the famous yellow or red trams to see everything.Nice small local restaurants with seafood and pretty local boutiques with produce such as Porto, olives, canned fish, etc

An amazing neighborhood filled with history. Really the heart and soul of Lisbon. Lots of fun fado shows and beautfil views through the winding streets. It's what you think of when you are nostalgic about Europe.

Lived in Alfama and loved it. Alfama is a great, authentic neighbourhood. If I go to Lisbon again, I will stay in Alfama again.I have talked to other people, who had a very different experience of Lisbon, because they stayed in the tourist area around Rossio and Restauradores. There, the restaurants are big, the stores are expensive, and you are constantly offered to buy drugs, which is unnerving.But in Alfama the restaurants are small and cozy, and are often run by families. We had great experiences with places where the grandma was cooking in the kitchen and came out to make sure, the food was to our liking.We lived in a small back alley, where an old lady would greet us in the morning when we left.Alfama shows the warmth and hospitality of the Portugues people.

Colourful. Alfama has truly preserved an ancient spirit. It is very colourful, a lot of interesting shops & restaurants to peek into. At the same time, it is a bit shabby and can feel a bit stuffy (both in terms of space and in terms of temperature). Still, a must visit part of Lisbon.

ATMOSPHERIC AND PICTURESQUE. We had downloaded half a dozen self-guided walks from the Lisbon Tourist Office prior to our trip to the city, and the Alfama walk was the first one we attempted. Alfama was also the area that we were most keen to visit in Lisbon and the one I had heard so much about.We started at the Martim Moniz metro station and soon started our climb up to the pretty Mouraria district.The narrow, stepped streets and cobbled alleyways were wonderfully picturesque with washing draped across between the houses and bouganvillea tumbling over the walls.Alfama itself was much busier and teeming with tourists. We decided against visiting the castle, as neither of us could face the long queues at the ticket office. I hope we didn't miss anything, apart from a wonderful view over the city, but we came across so many lovely viewpoints during our visit it didn't really matter that we didn't see them all. There were some tempting looking little restaurants in the area that I wished we'd sampled during our stay, however we had covered so many miles on foot during the day that Alfama was too far to attempt twice in aday. I had read in some guidebooks that the area was dangerous after dark which would be a great pity if true. I always find it strange that an area so lovely on a hot and sunny day could transform itself into somewhere threatening in the evening.

Go for panoramic views. Recommend going by taxi or on the traditional tram up to the Alfama. Look around the churches, stroll in the narrow streets, have a drink at one of the places with a splendid view of this old quarter of town and the majestic River Tagus. Maybe stroll into the Castelo São Jorge (small charge). Plenty of interesting small eating and drinking places at moderate prices.

Cute old houses. Alfama is an old neighbourhood of Lisbon with old brick houses and cafes/ restaurants along the windy stairwells on the hills. It is a good place to visit but not recommend staying in this area unless you love to walk and lug your suitcase up/down many stairs! Better to stay in the flatter part of Lisbon.

Nice music and excellent dinner. Magic atmosphere! Historical feeling, as we walk along these centuries old cobblestoned streets. The hospitality of its inhabitans makes you feel welcome. A highlight of my visit was to attend a live performance of "Fado"; this extraordinarly music, typical of Portugal, at the traditional "Parreirinha da Alfama". I recommend for dinner, Portuguese cod fish, and Portuguese white wine.

Important Area of the City. The Alfama has many monuments, such as the St. George Castle, Cathedral, Church of Santo Antonio, Sao Vicente de Fora, the National Pantheon at Santa Engracia, and the Decorative Arts Museum. The hard thing is climbing the hill, which takes a lot of effort. It takes several days to see all the monuments on the hill.

Enchanted and enchanting. We lived in a rental studio apartment in Alfama for a week - and loved the neighborhood so much that started discussing how we could move there. This fact alone can probably tell you how good the place is. Warm, outgoing people with a smile always ready for you - just give them a smile, and you get such a warm one in return!Lots of cafes and restaurants. Some are close to the trodden paths and cater for tourists (which inevitably affects the price range). Others are deeper inside the maze of the narrow streets, and are much more affordable. (Keep in mind that part of the price is the Fado cover price.)Alfama is one big family. They do not lock their doors, people living there know each other, so being an Alfama inhabitant imposes a certain code of behavior that looks unusual, even inexplicable at times. But it is there, and you can notice it if you know what to look at. And you need to see how seriously the locals take themselves!Trams running through Alfama make it easy to reach other sections of the city. And once you get a good idea of the lay of the land you can actually reach any spot in Alfama within 15 minutes on foot (but you need strong legs and good non-slipping walking shoes!).Some criminology is due. we were bracing ourselves for a life full of dangers. We encountered a fairly safe environment - no-one tried to rob us, we did not get mugged (and yes, we did walk around at night a bit!), no-one broke into the apartment, and nothing got stolen. We did not even meet a real pickpocket on the #28 tram. Maybe they were all on vacation as well, as the summer was over. :)Bottom line: if your "ideal destination" is a five-star hotel, Alfama is probably not for you. If you can enjoy living in a fairly run-down, somewhat dilapidated area with a character - give it a try!

Time to wander. We stayed near the Alfama area so often walked through it on our way somewhere else. The streets are fascinating. The little fruit shops are great for a stop for a quick piece of fruit as a pick me up! Be sure to give this area a couple of visits....the first one may be downright confusing. Let yourself be and just walk around. Keep going down hill and you will be fine.
Great walking tour. Our guide was outstanding and the Alfama was the highlight of our trip to Lisbon. We just wish it was longer.

Narrow streets,nice views. You can go top to the hill by tram no 28.It is a nice trip especially for the kids but is very crowded.There are two places in front of the tram for mothers with kids-take them!THE TICKET IS EXPENSIVE-AROUND 3 EUROS but the trip is very pleasant.Top on the hill the image is great and you can stay to drink a beer or a coffe on a nice and small terrace.You can get back by foot.On your down way is the Santa Maria Basilica-worth a visit-is free of charge.

It's like Albacyn in Granada only better.. We spent only a brief time in Alfaman as part of our Original Lisbon walking tour and really enjoyed the experience. The streets are much wider and cleaner than in Granada with lots of small shops, restaurants and churches that can be visited. It is fun to get lost there for a couple of hours.
Great neighborhood for photos. Great area to walk around early morning and get some phtos of architecture. Didn't try the nightlife or cafes, but for architectural photography it is wonderful.

get lost in the beautiful narrow streets.... Actually it is ironic to find that distinct eastern texture/character at the most western country of Europe. Alfama being the oldest part of Lisbon, once was a Moorish settlement. My advice is first make sure to take your camera, then take the most famous Tram 28 at the very first station Praça Martim Moniz to find a seat next to window. Lean back on the wooden retro tram chair and enjoy the surroundings. Eventually, leave the tram somewhere above, say at the Castle or nearby. Actually, your time travel has already started as you stepped into the tram, but take it even more past by wandering downhill to the narrow streets of Alfama. For the most authentic experience get lost within the narrow alleys, smell the history and breath the nostalgic air. Make this trip during the daylight and also see Alfama during the night, the latter is absolutely more gorgeous, more alive and even more magical.

Exhausting walking tour. The short, very narrow streets and alleys make this a very interesting place. But, oh so tiring, and we were relieved it wasn't raining - the tiled sidewalks would be treacherous when wet.
Worth a visit. Beautiful view. Even better than the city centre. Take the trolley up all the way to the castle on top of the city.

Blast from the past. The best way to see Alfama is just to wander its confusing, vibrant narrow alleyways. Every alley is interesting and you really get the essence of life walking aimlessly through this working class neighbourhood.
Walking shoes. Lots of little interesting shops and cafes. Bring serious walking shoes because you will need them if you explore even the slightest bit off the main path.

Electrico 28. Electrico is a tram. An old one. We must find a stop or the end of the ligne, in Martim Moniz Place, stay for a long line and take a wodden chair on this old tram. You must have a camera with you. The trip will be great, full of suspance and full of surprises... Alfama is the oldest part of Lisbon. Crowded. Full of tourists. On the top of the hill - The Saint George Castle. Bust this is another story.After some stops, a dozen or more, just find a small restaurant for a lunch with some fish food...Fish soup and sardines... A local beer or a dry red wine.Alfama is a great place.

Superb neighborhood. It concentrates most of Lisbon's attractions. The best way to see it is in one of the old trams- 28 for example, but you should take into consideration that they are crowded almost all the time.

grilled sardines red wine and a very nice people. you must go if you can in June from 10 to 13, there is music and dancing everywhere, fish is grilled in the streets, people eat, dance, laugh all night . It is the time of the popular saints ins Portugal, It is worth it, it is a unique experience.

A maze of streets..... Throw away your tourist guide and just walk and wonder the streets of this old area of Lisbon. The area is a maze of little streets and roads, some residential, some commercial but all of them fascinating in their own way. There are some steep hills to climb or steps to navigate, but there are also views to admire and cafes and restaurants to stop at and soak up the atmosphere. Stop off at the cathedral en route to St George's Castle .
Cool people. Very nice place, very cool neighbors! very frienship people! at satrday and tuesday's you have the famous "feira da Ladra"
Great views. spent a lovely afternoon wandering around these tiny hilltop streets. Where comfortable shoes and enjoy the views

Lap up the history of Moorish Lisbon. Hard to believe, but Lisbon was once ruled by an Islamic caliphate based in far away Cordoba and then Badajoz (I'm a history geek, can you tell?). And once Lisbon was conquered, the city's Muslim and Jewish residents were herded into a ghetto - Alfama and the Mouraria with their winding streets echo with their ghostly voices (I think!). So just wander and soak up the ambience.

miradores on the city of Lisbon. Go to Alfama, visit the cathedral and its beautiful azulejos, climb further and stop on the terrace (right) where you'll have the most beautiful view on the city of Lisbon. Down Alfama you'll find the most amazing fish erstaurants and in the small streets you'll hear the real fado...
Alfama. Best place to stay in Lisbon if you really want to get to know the city and if you're into fado. Narrow, winding streets, steep steps and excellent food - the smaller the place the better :)

See the authentic and historic Lisbon. Wander the narrow streets, soak in the atmosphere, and enjoy. This is the place you enjoy Fado, that mysterious sad but evocative music, and it’s quite unique. Just listen to that guitar, superb if you choose the right place. It’s rather ‘oriented’ towards the tourist, but that’s what you would expect, so be a bit careful where you choose to eat and listen to Fado etc, but if you want to travel back a couple of hundred years into the real Lisbon, you have to start here.

The feel of a real neighbourhood. There's no single sight.. it's just a great place to walk around and feel the atmosphere of a real neighbourhood... with a history of hard times.This was one of the few areas less affected by the massive earthquake in 1755 thanks to its solid rock foundations... so lots of houses that have stood longer than any others in Lisbon. This is one areas known for fado restaurants (bit touristy but still worth it).If you're staying in the area, there aren't many food shops... nearest supermarket is down at Santa Apollonia station. Wear good walking shoes and be ready for some steep steps and cobbled streets!
Get lost in the amazing place. This is really nice. You just take a camera or your mobile and get lost walking all along the Alfama area.

Wonderful little area. I loved this little area for just wandering around the streets looking at the various shops, restaurants and the culture. I wish I had spent more time there especially after 7 pm so as to experience more of the nightlife and food but only had one afternoon.

An old neighbourhood with great character. Our best night in Lisbon was a saturday night crawl in Alfama. Fado was AWESOME! We went to Clube de Fado, which made for a perfect fado experience. Then we started walking around Alfama, which was live and full of restaurants packed with people listening to live fado ... Grilled fish in Alfama is reasonably priced and quite delicious! Try to go to Alfama on your first days in Lisbon, as there is a lot to bring you back during the rest of your stay.

a village within a city. we took a Lisbon Walks tour around Alfama and learnt so much - the narrow streets and little houses are lovely and people's lives spill out onto the streets - in June the Festival St Antonio is amazing - Alfama is packed and everyone eats sardines - one big street party, loved it and will go again

Great shopping. Alot to visit here, buskers and lots of small shops!!! Loved it spent a lot of money!!! Spent a whole day here and enjoyed ever minute. Very easy to get taxi after your day of shopping
Lovely, lots of steep streets but great views!. We actually did get 'lost' in Alfama! It is so full of history & there is so much to see, a must in Lisbon to come here! Wear good shoes & enjoy!

A survivor. Alfama means 'the quarter' in Arabic. A labirynth of narrow streets where you can easily lose your track, it was always one of the poorest and dingiest parts of town,with a very closed community except during the festivities of June 13-29th. It was kept almost untouched by the horrible earthquake of 1755, which is ironic. So it stays as it always has been.
Very interest and confortable place. One of best place in Lisbon,bucolic , interest bars and restaurants with"fado", an tradicional music...but go by train... This changes the visit ...

All Up & Down hills -- wear good walking shoes. If you are the least bit out of shape or are not used to vigorous exercise, then don't go to Alfama. It is all hills -- you'll be walking up and down and up and down over cobblestone roads -- lots of tripping hazards. But if you are fit it is lovely. We actually stayed in Alfama. Lots of restaurants. Be careful, though -- it seems a common practice in Lisbon is that they will bring things to your table, like bread, a plate of cheese, and when they brought our "main course" tapas, they also brought a plate with 3 small potatoe/cod patties. At the end of our dinner we asked for the bill and almost flipped. They charged us for every single thing that they brought -- none of which we asked for and assumed it came with the meal. In Toronto, it's common for most restaurants to bring a basket of bread --- here we were charged 2 Euros, etc. Anyhow, back to Alfama. Lots of photo opportunities. If you're not in shape or have mobility problems, just take Tram 28, it takes you through and you get the idea.

Alfama. This is the oldest area in Lisbon and a must-see when visiting! The historical area is wonderful to wander around, be ready for lots of steps!, and try out tiny bars and restaurants. You're sure to get lost, but that's half the fun. We had a tour guide take us around which I was very thankful for - some areas are a bit shady in character and being an all-girl group I was glad to have a male guide with us. We never had any problems and after we felt fine exploring on our own. Make sure to check out the Cathedral and enjoy dinner with live music anywhere near the water. Alfama was my favourite part of Lisbon!
Real Lisboa. just take your time to walk the small streets, follow the fado music through one of many bars in the area...Experience the history of this charming city..
Getting lost in Alfama is a reason to smile!. Authentic, beautiful, melancholic..please do include Alfama in your itirenary, more than once ;)
Brilliant!. Get ready to work your legs and climb up and down this old village with its narrow streets, Fado singers, friendly people and great views of the city. A must-do.
Visit Castle and Se. The historical area of Lisbon. The must is to visit Castle and Se Cathedral. Right opposite of Se is a very good and cheap restaurang "tasco da se". Try shrimps and squid kempab.
Loved this area. I walked around here alot and took Bike my side tour through the little streets.It was very cool and absolutely beautiful views
Behind the modern city. Ancient houses, cobbled streets, wonderful churches. I would not trust any of the little cafes, mind you!
Beautiful Old Town. Enjoyed exploring the narrow lanes and the fado in the evening

Interesting Area. We really enjoyed wandering the streets of the Alfama. It's a very interesting, old area. We walked down from St. George's Castle and stopped half way to have lunch at an outdoor sandwich stand. They had great toasted ham and cheese sandwiches and the view from their location was beautiful.

Get lost in Lisbon. The Alfama embodies the people and vibe of Lisbon. Wander the small streets and alleys, nod to locals, enjoy Fado clubs and street life. I've been coming here for 20 years, the place is in transition with investors buying the buildings to "fix" I hope this does not remove the well earned patina of Lisboa history.

The Castle is well worth a visit and offers fantastic views over the city. It is difficult to walk to the castle, all the way there being very steep, but the lovely old trams on this route, are infested by small gangs of pickpockets, who ply their trade with impunity.

Go for a stroll, get lost and never stop smiling. This is one of the best areas to get lost in as the old streets are winding with great things to find around every corner.
I recommend visiting on 12th June as this is when this place really does come alive with friendly people dancing until the wee small hours.
Amazing Alfama. Alfama is a must see attraction; many surprises and delights on each corner; see a different and cultural side of Lisbon; take the trams if walking is a struggle for you!

Tradition at its best!. Alfama is THE place in Lisbon where you can ear the best Fado in town. Most of those little restaurants have a Fado band playing during the night.
Beware of prices, though...some places will rip you off easily if you don't pay attention to the prices (like entrés, wine, etc.)

Nice area but not amaxing. its pretty but not as Moorish as say Seville, its ok but not AMAZXING here, better to go to Castelo area next door where its prettier and more medieval within the castle walls and in the castle area

Medieval Lisbon. Start at St George's Castle and walk down. You will find shops and restaurants galore. Enjoy the architecture and charming narrow streets. Some nice lookouts on the way. Go to the Casa dos Bicos at the bottom of the Alfama.
Most typical. Very typical every year.... but the best month to visit is on June (11-13), you can feel the real heart of Alfama
Alfama. Again a must do. Lovely views, cobbled streets and time to just sit back and soak up the atmosphere.
Walk the district to get the true Flavour of Lisbon. For great exercise walk the entire old part of the City. facinating and enjoyable this is a great way to see the real Lisbon

The Alfama section of Lisbon - a survivor. Located on one of the hills of Lisbon, the Alfama mostly survived the earthquake and sunami of the 18th century. The houses and streets have a medieval look and are steep and cobblestoned. Getting around is not easy, but the Trolleys, and experienced cab drivers can show you the sites. Some restaurants, like Resto do Chapito, sit overlooking terra cota rooftops of the Alfama, the Tagus River, and the Castle.
Magnifique. Superb views en route for the Castle over the bay... If you are tired take the tram 28E up.
Wow !. The narow streets, the houses, the bricks, the view. What a place !

Fun and scenic!. Loved walking around this neighborhood. Every corner revealed a new vision of the city as it used to be. We ate some fried sardines for lunch at an outdoor cafe and that was fun too. Wish I was still there...
Oldest part of city. This area, although hilly, is full of charm and lovely little quaint restaurants and is well worth a visit.

Great to wander around. I stayed here my first night upon arriving in Lisbon. My friends happen to live right in the middle. What a great place to just wander around and eat, listen to fado or have a coffee.
Historic location. Old lovely streets and buildings. Lovely small restaurants.
Castle. Hilly and windy but very pretty and the Castle is worth a visit if only for the peacocks and the views.
Fascinating. Such a lovely and historic quarter to roam around. Strange decorations adorn the houses and lovely taverns just around each corner. Very steep and hilly so good shoes are vital.

Great Area to walk. The Alfama and Castle St George are our favorite spots in Lisbon. Get lost in Alfama, talk to its people and eat the food. Tip to get out of Alfama always choose down hill direction. To get to Castle choose uphill directions.
old world charm. lucky theres a tram that goes to alfama ... nice place with narrow winding streets that goes up ,great fado bars which get alive in the night
Great neighbourhood. Great for a walk, enjoying the view, listening to some fado and meeting locals! All in all wear good shoes and go for it!!

The original heart of Lisbon. On the side of the hill beneath the Castelo de Sao Jorge lie the narrow winding streets of the Alfama, the oldest part of Lisbon. It's an interesting and atmospheric walk, but don't go there on your own after dark.
After Castelo de Sao Jorge. After visit Castelo de Sao Jorge , go down walking through Alfama and try to find a restaurant called Lautasco and ask for a bottle of wine and "sardinhas".

gothicy. i loved the winding streets with their olden somewhat gothic architecture. really atmospheric perhaps just a bit too much at night when it can be a little scarey, unless you know where you are.

Excellent quarter for photographers. Alfama is an excellent quarter to take pictures with the steep streets, flee markets, churches and the tram 28 winding itself through all this. Take good shoes though.

Make sure you got comfortable shoes. Typical and interesting atmosphere which you feel in Alfama. As some travellers already advised you can take the cable car,Tram 28E or the Tram 12E (similar route) and go down at different stops to have a view of the inside of Alfama or just walk up to Mirador to have a great overview of the city. lots of typical roads and of chuchers (iglejas)Make sure you hae comfortable shoes, because the road are not flat and not regular either. Pretty facade of various color and clothes hanging from the windows to dry. Some streets with graffitis, very pleasant to discover.At the entrance of Alfama from the Praça de commercio, you can see the casa dos Bicos. During the evening, We happened to pass by a bar/restaurant an dheard some Fado music.The Aerobus ticket of 3,50 euros that you purchase for the bus from Lisboa airport is valid for 24 hours on the bus/tram in the city.

Get lost in Alfama.. Take a walk in this pittoresque and the oldest neighborhood and you'll feel like traveling back in time. Start at Portas do Sol Viewpoint and go down - river direction - and you'll find some breath taking views of this Lisbon hill. In Alfama you'll be able to find some of the bests Fado houses/restaurants and a must is the Tile Museum (Museu Nacional do Azulejo).

Quaint with great views. Lovely winding cobbled streets, old houses, many with beautiful azulejos tiles, great views over the city and estuary from the various viewpoints. Be careful of pickpockets operating in the small old trams, however!
The oldest area in Lisboa. Cool trams, nice and steep walk, great views. Cathedral is not much to see, castle is OK, not great

Amazing maze of small streets. a Amazing maze of small, winding streets, small squares ("Largo") and a set of stairs. We have lived on the edge of the Alfama, We began from the beautiful "Largo das Portas do Sol", enhanced by coffee and a panoramic view over Lisbon, and then descend the stairs to the church of Santa Luzia, mostly in the direction of fado - Museum or Largo do Chafariz. On every corner there are new experiences. You can spend hours wandering through the maze of alleyways. You get tired, you could climb back to the Cafe at the Largo das Portas to get to the sound of music groups who come to recover from the Portuguese-speaking former colonies (Brazil / Africa).
Fado. Very cosy quarter with lots of Fado restaurants that in retrospect is a must-do when in Lisbon.
Worth the slow walk. Leisurely stroll through the neighbourhoods show more of the historic features of the city

my favourite part of lisbon. alfama is such an atmospheric area with narrow, winding cobbled streets and stairs leading to different places. we got a bit lost going to the castle, so was pretty cheesed off by the time we got there, but wandering the streets of alfama was such a nice surprise. there are alot of restaurants and cafes on the way down from the castle - as it's a touristy area, the prices are average. we did manage to find a nice place for lunch. near the bottom there are a few restaurants advertising fado performances in their establishments - perhaps to do with the proximity to the fado museum!! i dun think climbing upwards would be much fun, but alfama is great to explore coming downwards and loads of nice places to stop at!
Not what I was expecting. The Alfama is a very intricate series of passages and steps which all looked very run down - picturesque perhaps, but I would not like to walk there at night on my own!
interesting place to visit, but I wouldn't want to live here. I enjoyed walking around the Alfama. it was a little hard for me to imagine living here, but people do. Very interesting unique place
Hilly !!. Steep narrow streets, amazing views, fels like it has not changed in years. Worth a visit.
Old town. Area seems totally unchanged from the original. Many narrow streets a bit daunting at first but no evidence to make you avoid.Plenty of cheap restaurants & bars.

Central location to most attractions. We stayed in an apartment here. Easy access to both Tram 28 for Sao Vicente,Fiera de Ladra and St.George Castle. Tram 12 takes you to the City Center. Streets are hilly but worth strolling as they are filled with local shops and restaurants
great. Really great feel of faded elegance, charming old-world trams, lovely musical sounds coming from characterful doorways.
Fab area-make sure you visit. This area of Lisbon is well worth a visit-quaint little streets, beautiful views. St Georges castle had fantastic views. Lovely and relaxing with plenty of nice cafes.
Historical Significance. Be sure to visit Cathedral Se & Castelo San Angelo!

Fado in Ancient Neighborhood. If you want to experience old Lisbon in a neighborhood where cars are not allowed and visitors has to negotiate narrow streets and steep staircases, visit Alfama! There are lots of small restaurants that offer good food while allowing you to listen to Fado music. You will leave happy with this great treat for both body and soul!
great neighborhood. Fado (local "blues") and food, narrow streets, trolley rides.
fascinating alfama. beautiful castle quaint streets and amazing veiws and of course the photogenic peacocks at the castle who readily posed for photos
Charming Neighborhood. The most unique part of Lisbon. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes with rubber soles. Beautiful views. Soak it up, it's worth an afternoon at least!
Do It. We saw Alfama from a Segway which was perfect because the streets are narrow and steep! Great views up and down. Oldest church in the area - Se- worth a peek.

Walking tour is worthwhile. We took the two hour walking tour of the "Old Lisbon" with Lisbon Walks. Our young guide was enthusiastic and knowledgeable. The trip through Se and Alfama areas is very interesting. Recommended for the reasonably fit as there are many steps to be climbed. Great views from a number of viewpoints along the way. Good value at 15 Euro pp - apparently only 10 Euro for your second or subsequent walks.
St Jorge castle. Nice to walk around the samll streets. See shops, stop in a restaurant or a cafe place and of course see the museum
Portuguese scent. Very nice neighbourhood .... once you get to the top you will enjoy breathtaking views of the city ^_^ I wouldn't miss it!
Old town. A taste of old Portugal, quaint and interesting. Take a yellow tram number 28, but watch out for pickpockets.

Go there!. Take the tram and get out at the Santa Luzia miradouro. Start with a coffee at teh little terrace. From there you can visit the castle and walk down teh neighberhood. Pass the antique stores, the Conserveira de Lisboa and on saturday of tuesday visit the flea market near the capitolio.
Great for local flavor. Narrow winding streets, very old buildings with great details, tiled walls, local character Not for the unfit as it is very steep.

Alfama. Very tradicional and unique oldest area of Lisbon. People scream when speaking to each other in the street!! Brilliant!!
Nothing to dislike

A real taste of old Lisbon. Do not be put off by a bit of grafitti and street rubbish, this district is stunning and has some of the best places to eat at reasonable prices. Also take the trouble to wind your way through the district up to the castle, great views.

A bit disappointed.... Comprised of many restaurants and small shops. We enjoyed a leisure walk around the area, however, most of the shops were closed. We did walk by some restaurants that were featuring live fado singers, which Alfama is known for. Though Alfama does have small narrow streets and fado singers, we found it to quite regular. We don't think Alfama is a must see according to our experience. If you are in Lisbon for a short stay there are other area that we preferred over Alfama such as Biaxa, Bairo Alto and the city centre. However, do keep in mind we were in Alfama after 6pm, perhaps earlier in the day it could be a more pleasurable experience.
mirador de santa luzia. in alfama, a traditional meeting place for portuguesewalk around, up and down, stop for a sardine break. people are extremely friendly. place has great views
Rip off restaurants. Be careful and avoid the restaurants on the tram 28 line. Long wait, expensive and inedible food. Area interesting

A nice walking tour for the fit. Walking around Alfama was enjoyable with its cobblestone streets and old architecture. It is not, however, for the out of shape or physically infirm; there were lots of stairs and steep hills to climb. Walking around, the back streets were surprisingly empty for a weekend, given the number of tourists in nearby areas, and I felt rather self-conscious whenever I would pull my camera out for a picture.

Nice area to explore. Liked wandering the cobblestone streets, up and down to the Castelo, visiting the Fado museum, eating in a very good churrascaria on a street near the water. The area has an intimate, "real" Lisbon feeling, comfortable and colorful.
Great place to amble and discover old Lisboa. Wonderful atmosphere, an assault on the senses. For some respite, pop into the lovely wine bar do castelo.

Unique area of ancient Lisbon. I can't think of an area of another European city quite like the Alfama. It looks ancient, and yet people are obviously still living there. A good way to see it is to take one of the tour buses up to the stop nearest Sao Jorge Castle and then walk down through the Alfama, stopping at one of the many small, outdoor cafes for refreshment.

Wander around!. The Alfama was the highlight of our visit to Lisbon. We took the #28 tram, got off at the castle, and wandered aimlessly. We stopped for lunch at a place full of locals and had a very good cheap meal, before wandering more. The views from the many miradores are stunning. We saw a fado performance over a beer, talked to locals, and many unexpected things that we would not have seen with an explicit itinerary. We walked back to downtown. The Alfama was the highlight of our trip to Lisbon.
beautiful view of Lisbon @ Miradouro das Portas do Sol. Miradouro das Portas do Sol - Standing over Alfama's rooftops, domes, and church towers, you can find there is a good view of this city.

Not for the weak =). The best way to enjoy the place is if you're fit enough to walk some stairs.. after walking some stairs and hoping to walk a bit more stairs after it. Lots of narrow alleys, small shops, cafes, restaurants and all and on the top the castle. Don't try to get even close with a car, and don't expect the tram ride through the place to give you more than a small glimpse. Take 2 days to experience it all if you want to eat well and enjoy some fado, too. If your legs can't take all that walking up and down the stairs, take a day or two in between the visits to recover. ..then again, if you can't handle all that walking you may not want to go to Lisbon in the first place. It has it's ups and downs, very real ones for that matter - they're called hills, and they're everywhere. Think San Francisco. Just don't expect it to be the same as SF even though you have similar bridges and lots of hills. Those two are nothing alike. I love both, but one doesn't replace the other. =)

Real Lisbon. Is a good place to go if you want to know more about the real Lisbon. This is a place where the culture is preserved a lot. Walking into narrow street by foot is the best way to know everything that is possible. You can get lost sometimes but is nice to explore this in that way (and if you really get lost, don´t be shy, ask native people how to get out and they will be pleasured to help you). It´s a way to get an amazing walking-day.There you can eat the real codfish by portugueses - for me, the bests are: Codfish a Braz and Codfish a Gomes de Sá.Walking into Alfama is for people who are really interested in local culture - for the ones who aren´t, this is not a recommended place because you can get tired in a thing that you don´t like.

Lisbon's heart. Still a living community, it is really worth seeking out a local neighbourhood bar, sitting back and watching the world go by - hopefully with some traditional or modern fado in the background. But it is very up and down - not for those with walking difficulties!

Fascinating. A fascinating area to wander around and immerse yourself in local living. The narrow streets and alleyways are very easy to get lost in but we found the local people very friendly and helpful.
Nice but not that special. We paid a visit to this part of the town. It gives a fair impression of the old town, but it was not that special (as the books decribe). So nice but thats all.
Hugely overrated. Take the tram 28 and see this from there, otherwise not sure what the fuss is about. Total tourist trap. Mind your wallet on the tram, we had a narrow escape.

Old World Portugal - Small Restaurants & Washing Hanging Out the Windows. If you want to feel like you are in the "old world" then Alfama is the place in Lisbon. you can see some great views from above Alfama but wandering through the streets and up and down the hill (be prepared for some shin splints). It is just cool to walk around. Lots of small restaurants to stop in to eat or grab a beer. A few good sites to see there too, se, castle, sao vicente da fora. Also, if you are there for the Santos festival in mid june this is the district to be :) fun fun fun!!!

Stunning Vistas Around Every Corner. A precipitous neighbourhood of winding streets, stepped laneways and crumbling buildings that evokes Cuban Havanna or the Albaiyzin district in Granada. Covers the slopes below the old moorish castle (which is an absolute must-visit). Head for the plazas which provide stunning vistas out over the city and across the Rio Tejo.

A walk on those old crooked alleys, steep steps, melancholy music.... Take tram 28 (watch out your belongings!) if possible from Bairro Alto (the opposite hill) so can enjoy well the ride... Even the neighborhood a bit dirty, just take the normal precautions and look where to put your feet; narrow sidewalks so watch out the cars too... don't miss the miradouros (panoramic terraces) and stop to enjoy a drink with Fado as background...
Lovely. This old part of the city is lovely. Spectacular views from the Castle.
The heart of Lisbon.. The Alfama is the oldest part of Lisbon and yet, it is a fairly small area, filled with old houses and Fado venues, enticing visitors with its historical significance.
Get Lost. Oldest neighbourhood in Lisbon. Great place to get lost.

Lisbon itself. This is Lisbon. Walk upstairs, turn right, downstairs, turn left, stop for a drink, up, down, stop for dinnerin a Fado rest. PLEASE, make sure that you have lost in Alfama. In June all Lisbon comes to Alfama to celebrate city festivities.

The best place to see Fado. If you want to have a nice dinner and listen to some Fado, this is the place to visit. You will find several Fado houses in this ancient neighborhood.
Be aware that this is not the safest part of the city, so avoid to walk around alone at night.

Il fascino di Lisbona. Alfama is a place which is definitely worth visiting to feel the real atmosphere of Lisbon. The district is situated on one of the Lisbon hills which make it even more scenic. Tradicional yellow trams still go thought the narrow streets, making it a unique sight. The panorama of Lisbon seen from up there is really nice.

Charming area of Lisbon- must see!. We rented an apartment in the Alfama so were lucky to be able to spend more time here and soak up the atmosphere and charm. I absolutely loved this part of Lisbon and enjoyed walking through the wee streets and getting lost! It is very picturesque and I found it fascinating getting a glimpse of local life. There are really interesting shops and little bars and restaurants and of course fado places (I would recommend Sr Fado). I know there has been some discussion on the safety of this neighbourhood but I must say we never felt unsafe here and we walked everywhere, including back to the apartment at 3am. Like any city, it is important to use common sense and not wander aimlessly at night but we found this area less "edgy" than downtown late at night
The Fado was an experience to be remembered. You have to search to find the restaurant as it is in a "dodgey" part of town. The food was good and the performance was entertaining

A must to get the feel of old Lisbon. A wonderful place to wander and take in what Lisbon is really all about. The individual, arty shops and small quaint bars together with a taste of the city's Fado tradition make for an interesting day out.
Another face of Lisbon. Walking Alfama narrow streets gives a different, interesting picture of the city
A Peek Back in Time. Windy, cobblestone streets and life is there. The dancing, the wine bars and mostly beautiful people

Nice, but what is it. Alfama is so famous, so we knew we wanted to see it for outselves, but found ourselves walking aimless through tiny (a bit dirty) streets. There is some charm to the neighborhood, but not really sure what there was to actually see there, in my opinion nice for a short visit, but plenty of other parts of Lisbon to spend your time with.

Lovely area of Lisbon to visit for views and historic buildings. Loved the Alfama district and the vistas from the various viewing points.BEWARE OF PICKPOCKETS ON TRAM 28 - a group of thieves tried to steal my fathers wallet, but luckily dropped it on the floor of the tram. It was a horrible experience, but did not ruin our time in Lisbon.
narrow winding lanes of house. if you're energetic and fancy a walk around the hilly lanes, this is worth a go.. lovely and very quaint, the old part of the city not distroyed in the sunami.
Nice. We did the walking tour described in the Lonely Planet. Very nice.
Quiet narrow streets including Roman theatre. Get the number 12 Tram which goes up near the castle and then you can walk down into the city afterwards.

Fado, my soul. Understanding facilitated by a previous guided walk. Lot of small typical portuguese restaurants and Fado music clubs. Grilled cod and vegs, vino verde followed with a deep flavored Port Wine glass. Do not forget to spent time at the fado museum before leaving Alfama. You will discover famous interpreters and texts.

The place of birth of Lisbon. If you want to see how the city was 300 years ago go no further. You will find narrow alleys and a true neighborhood atmosphere that is rare inside big european capitals. Although a lot of buildings are crumbling down, there is a warmth and happiness that one can feel in the streets. Great views from the old moor castle or from several spots where you can see the river.You can also find some traditional "Fado" houses if you like traditional music. You will need to be fit to go up the hill though...
Loose yourself in Alfama. A photographer's delight to wander through the narrow winding streets mingling with the local residents. Authentic and picturesque. Let's hope it is preserved that way.

you should walk there. It is an interesting part of the city. You should walk there and do not forget to take your camera with you as you will be able to make unforgettable photos. Use comfortable shoes.
Charming area. Great restaurants and Prado - prepare go wander around and get lost! You will meet lots of locals - not too many tourists.
The real FADO!. Enjoy the environment and the best restaurants in Lisbon!

very interesting district. well, ou can spend full a day there and be wondering around a lot around all churches and miradoros where you have fantastic view on the city. old trams are fun and sweets are tasty as in belem. the castle is liitle dissapointed. but still is worth to see

This wonderful area up to the castle is not a theme park. You can travel up this area in part using Tram 28 but I heard one story of attempted robbery so be careful. Because of my disability, we took a private tour that took us all the way to the castle, the driver displaying enormous skill in narrow streets. the very attractive narrow street s are lived by people living ordinary lives and in any other city in Europe, the area would be full of tourist tea shops and hte likes. the coffee shops had locals in them, the streets were very attractive and uniquely Portuguese and you could glimpse panoramic views here and there. At the very top, you enter the castle. We felt we had been somewhere different and as it was February, there were few other touruists about.

Nothing remarkable but nice nonetheless!. Viewed from every angle, it could be any city in Europe. The huge hike and snaking laneways are physically demanding, so consider other options like the tram and bus to reach the summit and also to descend. Can be very photogenic for shutterbugs, but two hours is enough.

Quaint sites of Alfama. Go to Go Lisbon, and follow the walk down from the castle to the river. Takes you down through quaint little streets and Fado houses, as well as seeing more locals than visitors if you time it late in the day, when most visitors have left. As you walk back into town have a glass of port at the port shop on your left.
Lots of steps. Fascinating side streets but very tiring to climb up and down stairways between levels.Try the quaint no 12 yellow tram tour of the area.

Definitely do a walking tour!. This area is great for a walking tour, if it's sunny (which it is mostly in Lisbon!) take a stroll around, up and down the cobbled hilly streets, look at the lovely old buildings and statues.

Exciting and a little bit frightening. I suggest you to taste the athmosphere of Alfama if you are in Lisboa: special, vibrating, full of life and music but I was a little bit afraid there too. Better for young people.

Charming Area. The Alfama area is very charming and a short walk from "downtown" Lisbon. There are many winding, hilly streets full of interesting and colorful building. This is the area where you'll find the Castelo with its beautiful views as well as the Se cathedral. Nice little cafes scattered about as well as miradouras with wonderful views. We were there in the daytime but I was told not to walk these particular streets at night. Daytime seemed extremely safe.
The Place to Stroll. A great place to stroll through Lisbon. Take tram 28 if you can't do a lot of walking up and down hills.

must go. We spent the majority of our trip wondering the winding streets and it was well worth the effort to see a part of a capital city that has escaped vast modernisation. And also to find some of the cheapest, most wholesome homecooked food in the city!
Pretty. Pretty old streets and hills of Lisbon and where the cathedral is.

A typical old European town layout. Yes, it was a bit of a maze. But with modern gadgets, one cannot get lost. The area is interesting but I found Porto much more interesting and its layout just as befuddling.

Gorgeous. The monastery (Mosteiro dos Jeronimos) built to honour Vasco da Gama's discovery of a sea route to India is spectacular and intricate. The belem tower is not an imposing structure but the views from the top are gorgeous.

Heart of Fado!. This is the place to go if you want to see real and authentic "Fado" shows! Everywhere around you will find many restaurants that offers this performance only found in Portugal. The streets can be shaddy and a little bit frighthing but this is just part of the abiance. Safe and Beautiful.
little streets, charming neighborhood. the small mom and pop restaurants were a good find

The light on the place is beautiful!. Alfama is a very small place. The streets are very narrow and when a car comes you need to run for shelter because the side walks are, in most cases, gone. The restaurants are good, and you can smell the Portuguese food all over the place. It's very interesting to go on a sunny afternoon, it has a beautiful light and a great view to the Tejo river. If you go there in that time of the day you will certainly hear some Fado coming from someone's window... it is a very familiar place, with very beautiful light and typical Portuguse buildings... It's worth the walk.
Narrow streets!. Alfama is really atmospheric with lots of very narrow streets with lots of buildings covered in Moorish tiles. Well worth a visit
great suggestion. atmosphere is fantastic, so decadent and posh. it's an old city into the real city, tramway 28 is the king
dining out. One of the best neighbourhoods for dining out. Great narrow streets with a lot of traditional Portuguese pubs and restaurants. Nice area for walks too.

Small streets in old Lisbon. Best thing to do to get the feel of the old city. I recommend to take the #28 trolley and get off at the entrance of the Castelo. After visiting the castle you can go down the hill through the streets. There are a few miradors that will allow you to see some beautiful views of the city

the oldest part of the city. Go and explore!!!!!!!!!!! This is a home to Fado and sardines. Nowwhere else you would experience such things. Enjoy it to the fullest. Also on the way to Alfama there is a great place with azulejos and a view to the city and ocean, it is breathtaking
Old. Very historic and old place, much related to "Fado". not my kind of interest.

One of my favorite places to explore!. I love walking the streets of the Alfama area..smelling the food, seeing the people and catching views of the water. There is also a flea market on Tuesdays and Saturdays there..have a few treasures from my shopping.

I'll be back. We listened to Fado all night long - during january where there's not a lot of tourists - it was so authentic - and the Market of Thieves - cool stuff to buy at a bargain... and of course we took tram no 28 - almost everyday.... LOVE ALFAMA

Cute neighbourhood. Alfama is one of the only parts of the city that was not renovated after the big earthquake of the 18th century so it has that old (really old) charm to it! The tiles on the houses are beautiful and the restaurants are really nice as well. Warning: if you don't like hills, don't live there: we developed our leg muscles a lot while living there;p but it was worth it!There is also the nicest outdoor market every Saturday right at the pantheon. Tip: if you want to buy those classic Portuguese white and blue plates, wait to buy them there. They are way over priced in the souvenir stores (about 100E for a big plate) and you can find the same thing for about 20E at the market. It's worth it!!!
Fun neighborhood. Very hilly. Lots of students and travelers. Amazing view.

Lovely evening stroll. I was here on a warm winter evening and enjoyed strolling through the area. A romantic full moon, ancient little streetcars, but the parts I liked best were the steep areas where cars couldn't come. The area feels very Portuguese, down to earth, workmenlike. I can imagine in the summer life here is taken out on the streets. I'd love to see it then.

The heart of the old city.... We had a nice relaxing walk in the heart of the old city...made of narrow streets and old buildings and where people is still spending time outside talking with each others.

Unique Lisbon - traditional Fado district. If you're looking for tradition, Fado music on the streets and friendly local people, Alfama district if the place to explore. It seems like you're inside a small village somewhere in Portuguese countryside.
go there ..get lost ...enjoy. experience Lisbon...stop for a coffee ...or a meal...sit on the wonderful area where you can look over the river.wander the narrow streets ...get lost and enjoy
Alfama. Narrow streets, amazing for a walk, see the churches and if it's tuesday or saturday you can walk to feira da ladra (flea market).
Very neat place. We walked through Alfama with our guide from Lisbon Explorers. A very neat neighbourhood that takes you back in time.

Enjoyed the area!. Be prepared for a lot of walking, but what a fun way to see the hillside and back "streets" of Lisbon. Walking through Alfama gave us a chance to see how some people live in this hilly area. Plus we enjoyed a glass a wine at a local bar.

Delightful hours of wandering await you!. We had our maps of this memorable old area of Lisbon but after awhile it became clear to us that wandering around and exploring the narrow atmospheric cobbled lanes was best. The variety of restuarants and shops, the changing colors through the day leading into the evening, the history, the views overlooking the Alfama together all became for us a lasting memory of this great city.

special place. I think this area has a special colour. It seems to me so, perhaps because Lisboa is situated on hills, very much different from other cities of the same situation (Rome, Istanbul). It is rather because we are talking about different civilisations. It was new for me and I liked it.

Just get lost and walk around. This neighborhood really defines Lisbon for me. Poor, run down, but full of character and characters. I never felt unsafe at night, and we ran into so many wonderful scenes and people - from men in pajamas playing chess to old women hauling groceries up one step at a time, to young girls knitting in sweaters in unison, not to mention the local drunkards and lost tourists.... not to be missed.
Great Neighborhood. Lots of dining and fado options. Interesting streets and people. Worth a walk about this section of town.

Quiet alleys and lovely views. Having a map doesn't help you in Alfama. I like most to stroll in the small alleys no matter where they lead. Getting lost in this small, 1000 years old part of town can be even pleasure - you can always head downhill and end up to riverside.
No guidebook can guide, just walk it out. this is a very characteristic place with a special energy. Just be lost in Alfama! We end up walk up to the castle!
Typical Lisbon neighbourhood.. Nice but diferent area. Poor but clean and safe. Enjoyed very much! Good tradicional and small fado restaurants. Don't forget to wear a comfortable shoe, otherwise...

Only Segways will allow you to get all of possible pleasure there. We have booked guided segways tour at Red Tours (Gonza) using Golden Lisbon website.
It was just unbelievable experience exploring this old city using this stuff. Pantheon is really admiring.

a wandering afternoon in Barrio Alfama. Great just walking around area. Charming "real" neighborhood, although we did feel a little uneasy after dark in the less populated areas. Restaurant A.Baiuca (Rua de San Miguel, 20) recommended for a later night dinner with fado music. Forget shoes with much heel anywhere in Lisbon, you will be sorry. Take big expandable bag for shopping, we also enjoyed a street fair the Campo de Santa Clara, Tuesdays & Saturdays, not far from the Fado Museum. Good Sangria at Frei Papinhas, and loved dinner at Tasca do Manel. Both on Rue de Sao Tome: #13 and #20 respectively.

Alfama and Fado. Alfama is the oldest part of Lisbon, between the Castle of Saint George and the river Tagus. To visit Alfama you must walk through its narrow streets and feel the medieval character of the place. Unfortunately many old buildings are in very poor state of conservation. For lunch try the Lautasco, in a small open air patio, For dinner listen to the Fado singers at the Clube do Fado in Rua de Sao Joao da Praca:
Quaint & attractive medievel streets & crumbly buildings. Vety charming area to get lost in - lots of bars & resturants - felt safe.

Soulful Music of Fado. The Alfama district is absolutely a must!! To see the small, winding streets with the Portugeuse music of Fado is more than you can imagine. A memory that will last a lifetime!!

And we are lucky enough to be staying here!. We rented an apartment in the middle of Alfama -- what a wise thing to do. The narrow, twisty streets, small shops, bars and restaurants are a real delight. The area is noisy, past midnight in fact, and busy. But there is a vibrancy and life to this area that has to be experienced to be believed. We have learned to stay away from the tourist areas and to simply enjoy being in the midst of an amazing little community. (One negative: we are desperate to go and see a good Fado show, but almost every review on TripAdvisor portrays these as expensive rip-offs. We are nervous to even try them.) A long walk through Alfama is well-worth the time -- be warned, though, the hills can be steep and the sidewalks and roads, all made of cobblestones, can be rough. What a treat this place is.
Fado. For me this was the heart of lisbon. Eating and hearing some Fado. It's very narrow streets full of life.A must see when you visit Lisbon

A charming descent through cobbled streets.. We took advice from others and took a taxi up to the top, strolled around the Castle, which is worth the 7 euros for the view alone. It seems to me, although I am not an expert, that the castle may be a little over restored, but I am not an archaeologist and I enjoyed it's solidity and the sense of it being a public space, where old men play cards,a busker playing the most exquisite guitar music and the umbrella pines framing the old cannons and the wonderful views across the sea. There are wandering peacocks, beggars who bless you when you give them anything and people selling home made souvenirs. The walk down was equally charming , and should be down as slowly and serendipitously as possible. When we got to the bottom we turned right and after a while reached an area which felt a bit more edgy. Although I am a Londoner and fairly streetwise I do not think I would like to have been in that bit of town at night, so possibly go straight on at the bottom or turn left!
So pretty. Lovely part of the city. Very pretty and well worth a visit. Note that it can be hard to find all the cosy little bars and restaurants that are supposedly scattered around here.
Amazing views. Amazing history and views, great eateries, lots of small shops, easy to get to, a lot of walking, so wear comfortable shoes.

Walking tour in the rain. We walked the old town area up to the castle. It was pouring rain at times but that made the walk even more memorable - a few hail stones here and there! Our lunch at Pois Cafe was great.

Tram 28. Old fashioned tram which goes through the Alfama and past interesting sights. Not a tourist tram, it's used by the locals. This tram costs 2.85 Euros, a regular price as opposed to the tourist tram which costs 15 Euros.
mind your purse!. the no 28 tram is usually very packed, so beware of the many pick-pockets. Just as easy to walk.

old Lisbon atmosphere. Take tram No. 12 or 28 from Praca Figueira to get to Alfama. You can admire the view from the Miradouro das Porta do Sol or eat in one of the restaurants up on the hill. it is also worth climbing numerous steps of Alfama to feel the old town atmosphere.

VERRY SMALL STREETS.. Every saturday between 08-13 , you have a exchibition ( people came with things from home, you can buy cheap souvenirs also , it s verry nice.) Ask at your hotel about this event ( or in tourist center ). It located close to Alfama. In Alfama you can see the real life in Portugal for average people. Try to walk it , because with the car it s difficult . Verry small streets.

Old Part of Town. Quite easy to get lost in these streets, but probably half the fun of it, apparently the layout of the streets hasn't changed since they were designed hundreds of years ago, it's an area primarily linked to the sea, and is where alot of fishmongers sell the daily catch. Best to start at the top of the district and walk down, as it's quite a hilly area.

very different from the centre. interesting, narrow twisty streets. Victims Museum is not to be missed as it filled big gaps in my knowledge of Portugal's history. It is next to the Roman Theatre Museum which is also really interesting. All labels are also in English.

A must see area of Lisbon.. Charming old part of town with wonderful views of the City and water. Fun place to walk around and look at the buildings and tiles. East to get to by trolley, and then you can walk back to the center of town, which will be downhill.

A Maze. One of my favourite part of town. Get lost in the maze of streets, in the staircases, in the patios of old ladies stretching clothes, in the old churches, smell the sardines being grilled, the sounds of fado coming out of the restaurants and some old ladies still selling fish in the street.A piece of arabic and medieval soul lost in Lisbon with no traffic of cars. A small village within a city.

Great. I took a walking-tour around Alfama with Wild Walkwers. (They had tours to Alfama and to Baixa, which start every day at 10.30 am from Rossio square (Dom Pedro IV)). It was very intersting and funny! You won't hear anything, that you can read in your guidebooks. Our guide (Jose) is in love with city, so what you hear are not the academic facts, but much like his own feelings and impressions!
Lovely District. There is a great jazz club in this disctrict called, Out Jazz. The music was great and the dessert was even greater!

Fun neighborhood to visit. This is a really fun neighborhood, with a lot to see. It's nice to just wander around and take it in. You'll probably get lost, but that is part of it. There are a lot of little shops and places to eat, as well as places to hear Fado.

Bring your walking shoes. The Alfama is lovely, old, charming and pretty confusing if you weren't born there. It gives new meaning to narrow streets, but it really gives one a taste of the Lisbon of old. Yes you can get lost, but the people are so friendly they will get you steered back out. A good landmark is the "Museo de Fado."
walk and climb !. forget your map and walk, each steet or lane is worth it.
Getting lost in old Lisbon. Narrow back streets wind in all directions - turn a corner and find a Fado cafe full of character
Great historic attraction. Love the castle and the old street, but really watch out for pick pockets. Even though we were warned, the thieves managed to steal our bag!
Taste of the old city. Narrow alleys and old buildings give you the perfect feel of a historical town when you walk through them.
A nice area.. Just wander around and get lost going up and down little side streets or sitting in the tiny squares watching the world go by. Great stuff.

a must visit. this area of Lisbon is right out the 1700's, but the castle is a must visit. great restaurants in the area. not sure if I would go here at night. we took the hop on hop off bus to get here.

Almost like a Maze. We wandered through the Alfama in June while the neighborhoods were decorated with lights and crepe paper for the holidays .. St. Anthony's Day and Corpus Christi .. and for their celebrations at night. The stroll was fun, almost like a maze, and easy .. downhill toward the center of town.

Alfama - authentic Lisboa, warts and all - a must-see. When you see Lisbon captured in postcards or drawings and there are images of narrow cobbled streets with red-roofed buildings and laundry hanging from clotheslines, you are probably looking at the Alfama. This is not an affluent part of town, and although it relies on tourists, it does not have many tourist amenities: WCs, maps, well-identified streets. You will definitely get lost in the Alfama, but that is part of the charm. The whole area is quite small, but because of the labyrinth, you will spend at least 2 hours here just finding your way. Locals speak only Portuguese, and they have likely near heard of that tiny largo/square you're looking for.Take the trolley #12E from Praça da Figueira to the Castle, and make your way down the hill, towards the water. The Miradouro Sao Jorge is a great spot for photos, the cathedral is worth a stop, and I loved the Fado Museum. (It helped me decide if I would stop at a fado club that evening.) But the highlight is just walking around, checking every nook and cranny. It's tiring, though - the hill is steep here. But it's worth it for the atmosphere, and the many photos you can take of everyday life.I wouldn't want to travel here solo at night, but in the daytime, it's wonderful. It's a nice way to spend a morning, but have lunch somewhere else. And go to a fado club in the safer Bairro Alto area.

Alfama- historic and a place you must visit. We love hills, and walking through Alfama was like going back in time, the streets off the main thoroughfare were the treats...what's around the next corner? Another narrrow cobblestone path to another discovery- an old restaurant with fantastic Fado, or another church, hidden away and when you walk inside, you are again stunned at the beautiful detail and architecture, artwork, and stained glass? Or walking through the streets, and happening upon another vista showing you another view of this beautiful town? St. Jorge castle, or the Graca church, with local singers setting up for Flamenco guitas and beautiful singing echoing off the front of this grand church? Pastry? Pick a place, buy some delicious treats, and sit on some steps to indulge yourself. The pastry will never make it back to your room....Photographers will love the surprises that await them...
Alfama - one charming old district. Alfama is a distric where you can feel the soul of the old Lisbon. You can try here many restaurants and to hear the amazing portuguese musik - fado.
An interesting area. Most travel guides praise Bairro Alta which is OK. However try a walk around Alfama and you will see a working community which is happily obliviant to the rest of Lisbon.

It's OK for a walk, the miradouros are great though. Alfama is OK for a walk during the day, as this area has a lot of character and the steep pedestrian only alleys are worth walking on them. The miradouros, especially the one called Santa Luzia are great since they afford great views of Alfama and the rest of Lisbon.

Great for 1 – 2 hours exploration. Alfama is an interesting place, but I found it lacking in vibrancy, based on several reviews I had read. Nevertheless, it's a great neighborhood to walk through, especially if you're also visiting the Castle. It is steep, but if you're of average physical fitness, you'll be totally fine... I think several reviews overexagerated.

great walkis in Alfama. If there's one place in the world to get lost in this is definetly Alfama. The Alfama neigbourhood was one of the few that survived the Lisbon earthquake in the 18th century and it show us how the Medieval (or at least older) Lisbon was.I strongly recommend walking around this neighbourhood, and especially the miradouros, which can give us perfect views from the whole city.Two must-visit places in the Alfama are the Castelo and the Sé. None of them is expensive and if you travel with little kids, the'll love them!

A labyrinth of narrow lanes to get lost in - leave the map at the hotel!!. I have lived in Alfama for 6 months but the first time I came to Alfama was as a tourist. My advice now as a resident of Alfama is to just wander around the streets, don't get obsessed with a map and finding particular things as you will stumble across many interesting little shops, restaurants, lookouts - "miradouros" and cafes. Alfama comes alive at night, it is quiet after lunch when some places are shut. There are many restaurants with prices ranging from as little as 4.50 euros to as much as nearly 20 euros for a main meal. Do not be put off by the look of Alfama, it is a safe area and most people that live in the area are old or young families. I would definitely spend a late afternoon wandering the streets, stopping at a cafe at one of the miradouros and then heading to a restaurant late around 9pm to get the full feeling of nightlife in Alfama. Summer is more alive than winter when more little bars and restaurants open and you can sit outside.

Unless you really have the time, skip this place. My family and I have been to many old towns in Europe, so was quite disappointed when our guide from Cityrama brought us to this as our last location as part of Lisbon tour. We started at 9am and ended at 12.30pm, so with limited time and so many things to see, we felt our time could be better spent. Quality of the tour may also be an issue, when she had to explain in 3 different languages. Graffati is quite rampant in Lisbon, and beautiful tiles on the walls of Alfama were in various degree of neglect or vandalism.

I'd like it a bit better-preserved. I spent few hours wandering around Alfama, taking pictures, talking to people and admiring buildings.I really liked the place but I'd like it to be even more well-preserved.There are few food stores around but you'd be better of bringing something before indulging in Alfama.Also bathroom facilities are rare.

Just walk around and enjoy!. My hostel was located in the Alfama and I'm very grateful for this!Go there and you will see Lisbon as you imagine it: old, cracked, colourful, with hanging laundry at all the windows of all the house, old men and women sitting at their door step chatting with the neighbours, stray cats and dogs walking around like the streets belong to them.This is also where you'll have the opportunity to see and get on the famous tram 28E.My best advice would be: put on your most comfortable walking shoes, take a deep breath and start climbing. Just wander haphazardly in a street, then another and watch, listen and smell. You'll probably end up on one of the miradouros (points of view over Lisbon) that are worth the aching legs.If you climb high enough, you'll get to the Castelo São Jorge (the Castle Saint George) and you'll know you've reached the climax of this beautiful neighbourhood.

Really beautiful and interesting area. Can;t improve on the other reviews here, other than to say this is one of the most beautiful and interesting parts of a city I've ever been to. If you can handle the hills, getting lost in Alfama is something you need to do if you are in Lisbon. There are some really spectacular views from a couple of viewpoints.

The San Francisco of Lisbon. If you love the hills & views in San Francisco you will love Alfama. This section of Lisbon was our favorite by far. There are great miradouras (viewpoints) from many parts of this section of Lisbon. Seeing the tram navigate through the tiled housed streets is truly a wonderful sight.

Great food. Lisbon is absolutely a beautiful city. Do not miss out out Alfama, the Arabic quarter. This is the true Lisbon if you would ilke to see local life. The foodi n Alfama is local and extremely cheap. Find an open restaurant and wait for the surprise and after lunch take walk to the castle. Do not forget to get try Pasties.

Great area to explore. I recommend you walk up from the main shopping area below Castle St. George and up the route that Tram 28 takes. It isn't that hard of a walk so we didn't take the tram. Stop at the Se Cathedral which is about halfway and then continue up to the castle. There are some interesting shops on the way to explore. On the way back down, we took a different route that had more stairs and wound through the houses - great perspective on this neighborhood.

From Castelo de Sao Jorge, we walked down through to Alfama. I've read that Alfama is a must place to walk around. And they were right! It is an uphill walk so I suggest, take either a tram or a bus and walk down. We took the bus to Castelo de Sao Jorge. Finished our sightseeing there and walked down through Alfama. The views were magnificent and the alleyways are amazing.

Funky part of city. Alfama is the birthplace of Fado music that began in the 1830's. Sad love songs & the Portugese version of the blues. It also one part of the city that wasn't destroyed in the earthquake of 1755. We took Tram 28 to Alfama & enjoyed walking around and seeing the Fado clubs. We came back at night & enjoyed hereing some great Fado music at Taverna del Rey. There are many other places for Fado too.The cruise ships are docked nearby. If you're off a cruise ship, don't miss the opportunity to come here. If you're staying in Lisbon just take the blue line metro to St Apolonia and walk over.

Walk through or ride up on Tram #28. We've walked up through the wonderful narrow streets of this old part of town and then walked back down after reaching the St. George castle on top. We've ridden up on tram #28 and again back down. We've ridden up and walked back down. That was our favorite way. You can see what you'd like to look at more closely as you ride up and then check it out while walking down. Or walk down a different way. You can see there is a variety of ways to look at this old medieval part of town. It's special and should not be missed on your travel to Lisbon.

Cute little alleys and houses. I really loved walking up towards the top the more higher we got the better the veiw we had of Lisbon! the little alleys that had doors to small little homes looked so cute. The pavement was like the ones you would imagine from old English roads and alleys. Definately a good and romantic walk. Would reccomend to all.
Great area to walk. Great area to walk
